('90', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 1
('90', 0, 1, 2, 42) 1. TWO REQUESTS 1
('90', 0, 2, 3, 60) A friend suggests that I should resume writing my autobio graphy 2 from the point where I left off and, further, that I should write a treatise on the science of ahimsa.
('90', 0, 2, 4, 230) I never really wrote an autobiography.
('90', 0, 2, 5, 269) What I did write was a series of articles narrating my experiments with truth which were later published in book form.
('90', 0, 2, 6, 388) More than twenty 3 years have elapsed since then.
('90', 0, 2, 7, 438) What I have done or pondered during this interval has not been recorded in chronological order.
('90', 0, 2, 8, 534) I would love to do so but have I the leisure?
('90', 0, 2, 9, 580) I have resumed the publication of Harijan in the present trying times as a matter of duty.
('90', 0, 2, 10, 671) It is with difficulty that I can cope with this work.
('90', 0, 2, 11, 725) How can I find time to bring the remainder of my experiments with truth up to date?
('90', 0, 2, 12, 809) But if it is God’s will that I should write them, He will surely make my way clear.
('90', 0, 2, 13, 893) To write a treatise on the science of ahimsa is beyond my powers.
('90', 0, 2, 14, 959) I am not built for academic writings.
('90', 0, 2, 15, 997) Action is my domain, and what I understand, according to my lights, to be my duty, and what comes my way, I do.
('90', 0, 2, 16, 1109) All my action is actuated by the spirit of service.
('90', 0, 2, 17, 1161) Let anyone who can systematize ahimsa into a science do so, if indeed it lends itself to such treatment.
('90', 0, 2, 18, 1266) In the event of my inability, the correspondent has suggested three names in order of preference for this task: Shri Vinoba, Shri Kishorelal Mashruwala, Shri Kaka Kalelkar.
('90', 0, 2, 19, 1439) The first named could do it, but I know he will not.
('90', 0, 2, 20, 1492) Every hour of his is scheduled for his work and he would regard it as sacrilege to take a single moment therefrom for writing a Shastra.
('90', 0, 2, 21, 1629) I would agree with him.
('90', 0, 2, 22, 1653) The world does not hunger for Shastras.
('90', 0, 2, 23, 1693) What it craves, and will always crave, is sincere action.
('90', 0, 2, 24, 1751) He who can appease this hunger will not occupy his time in elaborating a Shastra.
('90', 0, 2, 25, 1833) Shri Kishorelal has already written an independent treatise.
('90', 0, 2, 26, 1894) If his health permits, I know he would like to write further.
('90', 0, 2, 27, 1956) It may not be correct to call his work a Shastra, but it may be said to be very near to one.
('90', 0, 2, 28, 2049) In his present state of health, however, I do not think he can shoulder the burden, and I would be the last person to lay it on him.
('90', 0, 3, 29, 2182) 1 Originally written in Gujarati, this appeard as “from Harijanbandhu” published simultaneously with the source.
('90', 0, 3, 30, 2295) 2 Vide “An Autobiography” 3 Harijanbandhu has “twenty five”.
('90', 1, 0, 1, 2356) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 1, 1, 2, 2396) Like Shri Vinoba he too does not allow a moment of his time to be wasted.
('90', 1, 1, 3, 2470) Much of it is given to help solve the personal problems of large circle of friends.
('90', 1, 1, 4, 2554) The end of the day leaves him utterly exhausted.
('90', 1, 1, 5, 2603) Shri Kakasaheb, like Shri Thakkar, is an incorrigible nomad.
('90', 1, 1, 6, 2664) Just now he has made the propagation and development of the national and provincial languages his special concern.
('90', 1, 1, 7, 2779) Even if he wanted to divert a moment of his time to the writing of a Shastra, I would try to prevent him from doing so.
('90', 1, 1, 8, 2899) From the above it may be concluded that there is no need at present for the treatise in question.
('90', 1, 1, 9, 2997) Any such during my lifetime would necessarily be incomplete.
('90', 1, 1, 10, 3058) If at all, it could only be written after my death.
('90', 1, 1, 11, 3110) And even so let me give the warning that is would fail to give a complete exposition of ahimsa.
('90', 1, 1, 12, 3206) No man has ever been able to describe God fully.
('90', 1, 1, 13, 3255) The same holds true of ahimsa.
('90', 1, 1, 14, 3286) I can give no guarantee that I will do or believe tomorrow what I do or hold to be true today.
('90', 1, 1, 15, 3381) God alone is omniscient.
('90', 1, 1, 16, 3406) Man in the flesh is essentially imperfect.
('90', 1, 1, 17, 3449) He may be described as being made in the image of God, but he is far from being God.
('90', 1, 1, 18, 3534) God is invisible, beyond the reach of the human eye.
('90', 1, 1, 19, 3587) All that we can do, therefore, is to try to understand the words and actions of those whom we regard as men of God.
('90', 1, 1, 20, 3703) Let them soak into our being and let us endeavour to translate them into action, but only so far as they appeal to the heart.
('90', 1, 1, 21, 3829) Could any scientific treatise do more for us?
('90', 1, 1, 22, 3875) POONA, February 25, 1946 Harijan, 3 3 1946

('90', 3, 1, 2, 4996) 5. A NOTE
('90', 3, 2, 3, 5006) February 25, 1946 I am now tired.
('90', 3, 2, 4, 5040) If the man is here tell him he may come.
('90', 3, 2, 5, 5081) The car which was to come has been detained.
('90', 3, 2, 6, 5126) Let it be sent if possible, otherwise he will manage somehow.
('90', 3, 2, 7, 5188) First of all decide about the post.
('90', 3, 2, 8, 5224) Telephone to ask whether Aga Khan has come or not.
('90', 3, 2, 9, 5275) Write that Gandhi says that he has no house at all; all are his.
('90', 3, 2, 10, 5340) He will do what both of you say, that your convenience will be his convenience.

('90', 3, 4, 14, 5551) 6. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS POONA, February 26, 1946
('90', 3, 5, 15, 5602) I congratulate Shrimati Aruna Asaf Ali on her courageous refutation 1 of my statement 2 on the happenings in Bombay.
('90', 3, 5, 16, 5719) Except for the fact that she represents not only herself but also a fairly large body of underground workers, I would not have noticed her refutation, if only because she is a daughter of mine not less so because not born to me or because she is a rebel.
('90', 3, 5, 17, 5974) I had the pleasure of meeting her on several occasions while she was underground.
('90', 3, 5, 18, 6056) I admired her bravery, resourcefulness and burning love of the country.
('90', 3, 5, 19, 6128) But my admira tion stopped there.
('90', 3, 5, 20, 6162) I did not like her being underground.
('90', 3, 5, 21, 6200) I do not appreciate any underground activity.
('90', 3, 5, 22, 6246) I know that millions cannot go underground.
('90', 3, 5, 23, 6290) Millions need not.
('90', 3, 5, 24, 6309) A select few may fancy that they will bring swaraj to the millions by secretly directing their activity.
('90', 3, 5, 25, 6414) Will this not be spoon feeding?
('90', 3, 5, 26, 6446) Only open challenge and open activity is for all to follow.
('90', 3, 5, 27, 6506) Real swaraj must be felt by all—man, woman and child.
('90', 3, 5, 28, 6560) To labour for that consummation is true revolution.
('90', 3, 5, 29, 6612) India has beco me a pattern for all exploited races of the earth, because India’s has been an open, unarmed effort which demands sacrifice from all without inflict ing injury on the usurper.
('90', 3, 5, 30, 6803) The millions in India would not have been awakened but for the open,
('90', 3, 6, 31, 6872) 1 At Press Conference in Bombay on February 24, 1946 2 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 23 2 1946
('90', 4, 0, 1, 6968) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 5
('90', 4, 1, 2, 7010) unarmed struggle.
('90', 4, 1, 3, 7028) Every deviation from the straight path has meant a temporary arrest of the evolutionary revolution.
('90', 4, 1, 4, 7128) I do not read the 1942 events as does the brave lady.
('90', 4, 1, 5, 7182) It was good that the people rose spontaneously.
('90', 4, 1, 6, 7230) It was bad that some or many resorted to violence.
('90', 4, 1, 7, 7281) It makes no difference that Shri Kishorelal Mashruwala, Kakasaheb and other workers, in their impatient zeal for the movement 1 , misinterpreted non violence.
('90', 4, 1, 8, 7440) That they did so only shows how delicate an instrument non violence is.
('90', 4, 1, 9, 7512) My analogy is not meant to cast any reflection on any person.
('90', 4, 1, 10, 7574) Everyone acted as he or she thought best.
('90', 4, 1, 11, 7616) Supineness in the face of overwhelming, organized violence would have meant cowardice.
('90', 4, 1, 12, 7703) I would be weak and wrong, if I failed to give my estimate of the doing of 1942. Aruna would “rather unite Hindus and Muslims at the barricade than on the constitution front”.
('90', 4, 1, 13, 7879) Even in terms of violence, this is a mis leading proposition.
('90', 4, 1, 14, 7941) The union at the barricade is honest, there must be union also at constitutional front.
('90', 4, 1, 15, 8029) Fighters do not always live at the bar ricade.
('90', 4, 1, 16, 8076) They are too wise to commit suicide.
('90', 4, 1, 17, 8113) The barricade life has always to be followed by the constitutional.
('90', 4, 1, 18, 8181) That front is not taboo for ever.
('90', 4, 1, 19, 8215) Emphatically it betrays want of foresight to disbelieve British declarations and precipitate a quarrel in anticipation.
('90', 4, 1, 20, 8335) Is the official deputation coming to deceive a great nation?
('90', 4, 1, 21, 8396) It is neither manly nor womanly to think so.
('90', 4, 1, 22, 8441) What would be lost by waiting?
('90', 4, 1, 23, 8472) Let the official deputation prove for the last time that British declarations are unreliable.
('90', 4, 1, 24, 8566) The nation will gain by trusting.
('90', 4, 1, 25, 8600) The deceiver loses when there is correct response for the deceived Let us force facts.
('90', 4, 1, 26, 8687) The coming mission is claimed to be a friendly mission, entertaining the hope that they will discover a constitutional method of delivery.
('90', 4, 1, 27, 8826) The problem is knotty, probably the knottiest that has ever confronted statemen It is possible that the mission will put forth an insoluble conundrum.So much the worse for them.
('90', 4, 1, 28, 9004) If they are intent upon findingan honest way out of the difficulties of their own creation, I have no doubt, there is a way.
('90', 4, 1, 29, 9129) But the nation too has to play the game.
('90', 4, 1, 30, 9170) If it does, the barricade must be left aside , at least for the time being.
('90', 4, 1, 31, 9246) I appeal to Aruna and her friends to make wise use of the power their bravery and sacrifice has given them.
('90', 4, 2, 32, 9354) 1 The source, however, has “moment”.
('90', 5, 0, 1, 9391) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 5, 1, 2, 9431) It is a matter of great relief that the ratings have listened to Sardar Patel’s advice to surrender.
('90', 5, 1, 3, 9532) They have not surrendered their honour.
('90', 5, 1, 4, 9572) So far as I can see, in resorting to mutiny they were badly advised.
('90', 5, 1, 5, 9641) If it was for grievance, fancied, or real, they should have waited for the guidance and intervention of political leaders of their choice.
('90', 5, 1, 6, 9780) If they mutinied for the freedom of India, they were doubly wrong.
('90', 5, 1, 7, 9847) They could not do so without a 'call from a prepared revolutionary party.
('90', 5, 1, 8, 9921) They were thoughtless and ignorant, if they believed that by their might they would deliver India from foreign domination.
('90', 5, 1, 9, 10044) Aruna is right when she says that the fighters this time showed grit as never before.
('90', 5, 1, 10, 10130) But grit becomes foolhardiness when it is untimely and suicidal as this was.
('90', 5, 1, 11, 10207) She is entitled to say that the people “are not interested in the ethics of violence or non violence”, but the people are very much interested in knowing the way which will bring freedom to the masses—violence or non violence.
('90', 5, 1, 12, 10434) The people have, however imper fectly, hitherto gone the way of non violence.
('90', 5, 1, 13, 10512) Aruna and her comrades have to ask themselves every time whether the non violent way has, or has not, raised India from her slumber of ages and created in them a yearning, very vague perhaps, for swaraj.
('90', 5, 1, 14, 10716) There is, in my opinion, only one answer.
('90', 5, 1, 15, 10758) There are other passages in Shrimati Aruna’s statement which, as it appears to me, betray confusion of thought.
('90', 5, 1, 16, 10870) But their treatment can wait.
('90', 5, 1, 17, 10900) Needless to say that I have dealt with the message believing it to represent her opinion.
('90', 5, 1, 18, 10990) If it does not, I apologize to her in advance.
('90', 5, 1, 19, 11037) My argument, however, is not affected even if it is found that the reporter has not correctly interpreted her.
('90', 5, 1, 20, 11148) For my argument is, after all, impersonal and directed only to the portions which are calculated to mislead the public, irrespective of their authorship.
('90', 5, 2, 21, 11302) POONA, February 26, 1946 Harijan, 3 3 1946
('90', 5, 3, 22, 11345) 1Vide also “Conflict of Ideas”
('90', 6, 0, 1, 11376) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 7

('90', 6, 14, 18, 11985) POONA, February 26, 1946
('90', 6, 15, 19, 12010) BHAI VALLABHBHAI,
('90', 6, 16, 20, 12028) I have your letter.
('90', 6, 16, 21, 12048) What are you going to do about Rajaji?
('90', 6, 16, 22, 12087) He wants to withdraw 1; let him do so.
('90', 6, 16, 23, 12126) If you are keen on taking me to Bardoli, I am ready.
('90', 6, 16, 24, 12179) I have already suggested 2 that in a difficult situation like this your place is in Bombay.
('90', 6, 16, 25, 12271) But you know best.
('90', 6, 16, 26, 12290) In making the suggestion I did not have my convenience in view, but only what the circumstances of the nation demanded of us.

('90', 7, 4, 5, 12741) 10. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS [On or before February 27, 1946] 2
('90', 7, 5, 6, 12803) I have been asked by several friends to save Gen.
('90', 7, 5, 7, 12853) Awari’s life by asking Sardar Patel to revise his decision.
('90', 7, 5, 8, 12913) 3 I have refused, for I have neither the power nor the wish to do so.
('90', 7, 5, 9, 12983) The judgment of the Congress parliamentary Board is, in my opinion, subject to review by the Working Committee as also the A. I. C. C. Gen.
('90', 7, 5, 10, 13123) Awari says, he is not fighting for himself but for the President of the local Board.
('90', 7, 5, 11, 13208) This position is altogether wrong.
('90', 7, 5, 12, 13243) It is regrettable that he should persist in committing suicide by fasting.
('90', 7, 5, 13, 13318) But his friends should dissuade him.
('90', 7, 5, 14, 13355) If he refuses to listen, I fear, he must be allowed to die without evoking the slightest sympathy.
('90', 7, 5, 15, 13454) I say this as the author of satyagraha including fasts.
('90', 7, 5, 16, 13510) Neither can be capriciously offered.
('90', 7, 5, 17, 13547) Public sympathy with capricious fasting can disrupt society.
('90', 7, 5, 18, 13608) The Hindu, 1 3 1946
('90', 7, 6, 19, 13628) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 26 2 1946 2 The statement was reported under the date line “Poona, February 27”.
('90', 7, 6, 20, 13742) 3Vide footnote 1, “Telegram to Secretary, C. P. Provincial Congress Committee”, 20 2 1946 On February 20, 1946, the General Council of Nagpur Congress in an emergency meeting passed a resolution urging the Congress High Command to reconsider its decision having regard to Awari’s which was condemned by many Congressmen.
('90', 7, 6, 21, 14063) Awari, however, in response to an appeal from Vallabhbhai Patel broke his fast on March 10, and agreed to meet him in Bombay on March 13. Vide also “Telegram to Manchershaw R. Awari”, 27 2 1946 and “Telegram to Manchereshaw R. Awari”, 28 2 1946

('90', 9, 2, 3, 15301) I, the undersigned, heir of Shah Karamchand Otamchand Gandhi, resident of Bharat Varsha hereby authorize R[ajaman] R[ajashri] Maneklal Amritlal Gandhi of Porbandar to execute and sign the sale deed on my behalf, produce it before the Registrar for registration, execute a bond relating to the said sale deed and to receive offer for our house situated in the rear side of Srinathaji’s Haveli 2 at Porbandar, the deed (which of) stands in the name of our ancestor Harjivan Raidas Gandhi, and for which house an agreement of sale of all my rights, title, share and interest in the aforesaid property along with the construction, structure and building was made in favour of Rajya Ratna Sheth Nanjibhai Kalidas Mehta of Porbandar.
('90', 9, 2, 4, 16029) I have hereby given him authority to transfer and change my right of ownership and to appear on my behalf to do all legal work which I would have myself done.
('90', 9, 2, 5, 16188) The act of my aforesaid attorney in this behalf will be considered legal and binding from all points of view.
('90', 9, 2, 6, 16298) For a proof of this I have set my signature hereunder.

('90', 15, 6, 22, 26985) 24. NOTES
('90', 15, 7, 23, 26995) A USEFUL PAMPHLET A friend sends me a copy of a leaflet published by the Department of Agriculture, Bombay Province.
('90', 15, 7, 24, 27112) It contains hints on small scale vege table cultivation in compounds of bungalows, etc.
('90', 15, 7, 25, 27200) This was published in 1942 during war time, in pursuance of a compaign for growing more food.
('90', 15, 7, 26, 27294) What was then necessary is much
('90', 15, 8, 27, 27326) 1 Addressee’s daughter, Abha Gandhi 2 Dated February 20, it was about his and his son, Sailendra Nath’s future programme.
('90', 15, 8, 28, 27448) 3 Chimanlal N. Shah, Manager, Sevagram Ashram 4 Ashadevi Aryanayakam
('90', 16, 0, 1, 27517) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 17
('90', 16, 1, 2, 27560) more so now in view of the increasing shortage of food.
('90', 16, 1, 3, 27616) It is a pity that the leaflet is printed in English.
('90', 16, 1, 4, 27669) It may be, however, that only the English pamphlet has been sent to me, and that it has been translated into the provincial languages.
('90', 16, 1, 5, 27804) Be that as it may, the leaflet is certainly instructive and useful and I would suggest to the readers who are interested, as they should be, in the matter that they send for and study it with a view to making use of the suggestions, if they have a plot of land available for the purpose.
('90', 16, 1, 6, 28092) Among the hints contained are the following chosen by me at random : (a) Plots selected should be well drained and not overshadowed by trees or buildings.
('90', 16, 1, 7, 28247) (b) Beds in which flowers have been successfully grown are usually suitable but portions of lawns may also be dug up and used for vegetable gardening.
('90', 16, 1, 8, 28398) (c) Waste water from bath rooms or kitchen can be utilized for the purpose.
('90', 16, 1, 9, 28474) (d) It stresses the the necessity of using organic manure such as cowdung, and tells the reader what vegetables can be easily grown.
('90', 16, 1, 10, 28607) (e) A table is given at the end showing the quantity of particular seeds required, the depth at which they should be sown, the size of the beds and the distance between the rows of plants.

('90', 18, 2, 10, 33047) 25. WHOSE NEED?
('90', 18, 3, 11, 33063) The institution of domestic servants is an old one.
('90', 18, 3, 12, 33115) But the attitude of master towards servant has changed from time to time.
('90', 18, 3, 13, 33189) Some regard servants as members of the family whereas others look upon them as slaves or chattels.
('90', 18, 3, 14, 33288) Between these two extreme views may be summed up the attitude of society in general towards servants.
('90', 18, 3, 15, 33390) Nowadays servants are in great demand everywhere.
('90', 18, 3, 16, 33440) They have become conscious of their value and naturally demand their own conditions of pay and service.
('90', 18, 3, 17, 33544) This would be proper, if it were invariably coupled with a proper understanding and performance of their duty.
('90', 18, 3, 18, 33655) In that event they would cease to be servants and would earn for themselves the status of members of the family.
('90', 18, 3, 19, 33768) The belief in the efficacy of violence is, however, in the air.
('90', 18, 3, 20, 33832) How then can servants properly win the status of members of their masters’ families?
('90', 18, 3, 21, 33917) That is a question that may well be asked.
('90', 18, 4, 22, 33960) I hold that a man who desires the co operation of, and wishes to co operate with, others should not be dependent on servants.
('90', 18, 4, 23, 34086) If anyone has to have one at a time of scarcity of servants, he will have to pay what is demanded and accept all other conditions with the result that he will, instead of being master, become the servant of his
('90', 18, 5, 24, 34297) 1 Orginally written in Gujarati, this appeared as “from Harijanbandhu” published simultaneously with the source.
('90', 19, 0, 1, 34410) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 19, 1, 2, 34451) employee.
('90', 19, 1, 3, 34461) This is good for neither the master nor the so called 1
('90', 19, 2, 4, 34517) servant.
('90', 19, 2, 5, 34526) It has only one thought, that of pursuing his self interest.
('90', 19, 2, 6, 34587) But if what an individual seeks is not slavery but the co operation of a fellow being, he will not only serve himself but also him whose co operation he needs.
('90', 19, 2, 7, 34747) Through the extension of this principle, a man’s family will become coterminous with the world and his attitude towards his fellow beings will also undergo a corresponding change.
('90', 19, 2, 8, 34927) There is no other way of reaching the desired consummation.
('90', 19, 3, 9, 34987) He who wants to act on this principle will be content to start with small beginning.
('90', 19, 3, 10, 35072) In spite of a man’s ability to command the co operation of thousands, he must have sufficient self restraint and self respect in him to enable him to stand alone.
('90', 19, 3, 11, 35235) Such a person will never dream of looking on any person as his menial and try to keep him under subjugation.
('90', 19, 3, 12, 35344) In fact he will forget altogether that he is master of his servants and will try his best to bring them to his level.

('90', 23, 4, 10, 40581) 33. REGRET My brethren farmers from Bardoli are unhappy because my visit to Bardoli has been cancelled.
('90', 23, 4, 11, 40685) Others too have written to me.
('90', 23, 4, 12, 40716) I can understand their disappointment.
('90', 23, 4, 13, 40755) I am also pained that I could not go to Bardoli.
('90', 23, 4, 14, 40804) Although I am short of time, I had made all preparations for going to Bardoli.
('90', 23, 4, 15, 40883) I had also written to those who wanted to see me.
('90', 23, 4, 16, 40933) But after the riot which broke out in Bombay I changed my plan.
('90', 23, 4, 17, 40997) I wrote 1 to the Sardar that he should be in Bombay for the present.
('90', 23, 4, 18, 41066) He liked the suggestion, and the programme for Bardoli was cancelled.
('90', 23, 4, 19, 41136) I hope, all will forget their disappointment when they know these facts.
('90', 23, 4, 20, 41209) I take it that I will have to go to Bardoli on some other occasion.

('90', 25, 3, 7, 43301) 37. EXTRACT FROM TALK WITH A FRIEND 1
('90', 25, 4, 8, 43339) [Before March 3, 1946]
('90', 25, 5, 9, 43362) Look at Italy.
('90', 25, 5, 10, 43377) Garibaldi 2 was a great man.
('90', 25, 5, 11, 43406) He brought deliverance to Italy.
('90', 25, 5, 12, 43439) And Mussolini 3 did make her look great.
('90', 25, 5, 13, 43480) But where is she today?
('90', 25, 5, 14, 43504) Look at Japan, look at Germany.
('90', 25, 5, 15, 43536) The very violence which brought them to the pinnacle of power has razed them to the ground.
('90', 25, 5, 16, 43628) And has not the atom bomb proved the futility of all violence?
('90', 25, 5, 17, 43691) And yet we are crazy enough to think that we can win swaraj by breaking a few skulls and destroying property which, after all is said and done, is our own.
('90', 25, 5, 18, 43847) I am sure, out of this orgy of violence, the people will learn the lesson of non violence.
('90', 25, 5, 19, 43938) Harijan, 10 3 1946

('90', 26, 3, 12, 46427) 39. CONFLICT OF IDEAS
('90', 26, 4, 13, 46449) She was unable to understand Gandhiji calling upon R. I. N. ratings to resign, if their condition was humiliating.

('90', 26, 4, 16, 46688) If they resigned now, there would be hundreds in these days of unemployment to take their places who would be subject to the same discrimination and treatment and the R. I. N. ratings would not have achieved anything.
('90', 26, 4, 17, 46906) It simply does not lie in the mouth of Congressmen who are themselves going to the legislatures to ask the ratings to give up their jobs.
('90', 26, 4, 18, 47044) It does not help the cause of the country at all.

('90', 27, 0, 1, 47502) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 27, 1, 2, 47543) to Congressmen.
('90', 27, 1, 3, 47559) Whather she really holds or does not hold, the views put into her mouth is irrelevant here.
('90', 27, 1, 4, 47651) For the moment it is enough to examine them on their merits and to show that they are wholly inconsistent with Congress resolutions.
('90', 27, 1, 5, 47784) The first principle of non violent action as propounded in the Congress resolution 1 of 1920 at its special session in Calcutta under the late Lal Lajpatrai is that of non co operation with everything humiliating.
('90', 27, 1, 6, 47998) It must be remembered that the R.I.N. was founded not for the benefit of the ruled.
('90', 27, 1, 7, 48082) The men went with their eyes open.
('90', 27, 1, 8, 48117) Discrimination stares one in the face.
('90', 27, 1, 9, 48156) It cannot be avoided, if one enters the service which is frankly organized to keep India under subjection.
('90', 27, 1, 10, 48263) One may, one ought to, try to mend the conditions.
('90', 27, 1, 11, 48314) That is possible only up to a point.
('90', 27, 1, 12, 48351) That cannot be achieved through mutiny.
('90', 27, 1, 13, 48391) Mutiny may conceivably succeed but the success can only avail the mutineers and their kin, not the whole of India.
('90', 27, 1, 14, 48506) And the lesson would be a bad inheritance.
('90', 27, 1, 15, 48549) Discipline will be at least as necessary under swaraj as it is now.
('90', 27, 1, 16, 48617) India under successful mutineers would be cut up into warring factions exhausted by internecine strife.
('90', 27, 1, 17, 48721) India of the Congress has made little headway in the appreciation of the fight for swaraj, if it is true that hundreds would take their places if the present ratings resigned in pursuance of their campaign against humiliation.
('90', 27, 1, 18, 48948) Can we have swaraj for the masses, if we are so degraded that hundreds of us are ready to swallow humiliation even to the extent of taking the place of humiliated fellowmen?
('90', 27, 1, 19, 49122) The very thought is unworthy of Congressmen and that too at the moment when swaraj is believed to be within sight.
('90', 27, 1, 20, 49237) Those who hold that enlistment in the R.I.N. is their only means of livelihood must have a very poor opinion of them.
('90', 27, 1, 21, 49355) A soldier’s is a hard life.
('90', 27, 1, 22, 49383) He is disciplined to work in co operation and trained to wrok with the pickaxe and the spade.
('90', 27, 1, 23, 49477) Such a one will disdain to think that apart from soldiering he has no means of livelihood.
('90', 27, 1, 24, 49568) We have a poor opinion of soliders, if we think that they cannot earn their bread by the sweat of the brow.
('90', 27, 1, 25, 49676) A labourer is any day worthy of his hire.
('90', 27, 1, 26, 49718) What is, however, true is that a soldier out of his calling will lack the glamour and the amenities provided for him.
('90', 27, 1, 27, 49836) We have wasted precious twenty five years, if we have not yet stripped the profession of killing and destroying the thick coat of varnish that has covered it for so long.
('90', 27, 2, 28, 50007) 1 Vide “Congress Resolution on Non Co Operation”
('90', 28, 0, 1, 50056) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 29
('90', 28, 1, 2, 50099) Aruna Asaf Ali had been reported to have said that the ratings would have gained nothing by resigning.
('90', 28, 1, 3, 50202) Well, they would have gained honour and dignity, if they had manfully given up their job, and taught the citizens of Bombay the way to save honour and dignity, and they could have spared Bombay the senseless destruction of life, property and very precious food stuffs.
('90', 28, 1, 4, 50471) Surely this would have been an achievement not quite beneath notice.
('90', 28, 1, 5, 50540) The last statement in the reported interview is surely a confusion of thought.
('90', 28, 1, 6, 50619) Congressmen going to the legislatures for conserving the honour and liberty of the country is not the same as ratings serving for their livelihood with the possibility of being used against their own countrymen and their liberty.
('90', 28, 1, 7, 50849) Congressmen who go to the legislatures are representatives elected by their voters and they go even if it is only to prevent those from going who will misrepresent the voters.
('90', 28, 1, 8, 51025) Going to the legislatures may be altogether bad, but there can be no such comparison as has been just adverted to.

('90', 28, 2, 10, 51180) 40. WHAT, AFTER FINISHING STUDIES ?
('90', 28, 3, 11, 51216) A student has seriously posed this question : What am I to do after finishing my studies ?
('90', 28, 3, 12, 51307) We are today a subject race and our educational system has been devised to serve the interest of our rulers.
('90', 28, 3, 13, 51416) But even as the most selfish person is obliged to hold out some lure to those whom he is out to exploit, so a number of temptations for studying in their institutions have been brought into being by the rulers.
('90', 28, 3, 14, 51627) Moreover all members of Gvoernment are not alike.
('90', 28, 3, 15, 51677) There are some liberal minded among them who will consider the problem of education on merits.
('90', 28, 3, 16, 51772) Therefore there is no doubt some good even in the present ;system.
('90', 28, 3, 17, 51839) But the prevailing education is willy nilly put to wrong use, i.e., it is looked upon as a means of earning money and position.
('90', 28, 3, 18, 51967) It lends charm to slavery.
('90', 28, 4, 19, 51994) The ancient aphorism, ‘Education is that which liberates’ is as true today as it was before.
('90', 28, 4, 20, 52087) Education here does not mean mere spiritual knowledge nor does liberation signify only spiritual
('90', 28, 5, 21, 52184) 1 Originally written in Gujarati, this appeared as “from Harijiabandhu” published simultaneously with the source.
('90', 28, 5, 22, 52298) 2 This sentence is translated from the Gujarati version.
('90', 29, 0, 1, 52355) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 29, 1, 2, 52396) liberation after death.
('90', 29, 1, 3, 52420) Knowledge includes all training that is useful for the service of mankind, and liberation means freedom from all manner of servitude even in the present life.
('90', 29, 1, 4, 52579) Servitude is of two kind : slavery to domination from outside and to one’s own artificial needs.
('90', 29, 1, 5, 52676) The knowledge acquired in the pursuit of this ideal alone constitutes true study.
('90', 29, 1, 6, 52758) Having had such study, one will not be confronted with the question : ‘What, after finnishing studies ?
('90', 29, 1, 7, 52862) Realizing that a form of education devised by foreign rulers could only be calculated to subserve their interests, the Congress accepted, in 1920, among other things, the principle of the boycott of all Governmental educational institutions.
('90', 29, 1, 8, 53104) But that era seems to be over.
('90', 29, 1, 9, 53135) The demand for entrance to Government institutions and those imparting education on similar line is increasing faster than the number of such schools and colleges.
('90', 29, 1, 10, 53299) The ranks of examinees are ever swelling.
('90', 29, 1, 11, 53341) In spite of this hypnotic spell, however, I hold that true education is what I have defined.
('90', 29, 1, 12, 53434) A student who is superficially attracted by the educational ideal set forth by me and leaves his studies is liable to repent of his action later.
('90', 29, 1, 13, 53580) I have, therefore, suggested a safer course.
('90', 29, 1, 14, 53625) While continuing his studies in the institution which he has joined, he should ever keep before him the ideal of service set forth by me and use his studies with a view to serve that ideal, never for making money.
('90', 29, 1, 15, 53839) Moreover he should try to make up the lack in the present education by application of his leisure hours to the ideal.
('90', 29, 1, 16, 53957) He will, therefore, avail himself to the utmost of whatever opportunity offers for taking part in the constructive programme.
('90', 29, 1, 17, 54083) POONA, March 3 2, 1946 Harijan, 10 3 1946

('90', 38, 0, 1, 66653) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 39
('90', 38, 1, 2, 66696) I have known Dr. Dinshaw Mehta for a long time.
('90', 38, 1, 3, 66744) He has dedicated his life solely to nature cure of his conception.
('90', 38, 1, 4, 66811) His one ambition is to see a full fledged nature cure university established in India.
('90', 38, 1, 5, 66898) A university worth the name must be predominantly for the prevention and cure of the diseases of the poor villagers of India.
('90', 38, 1, 6, 67024) No such university exists in the world.
('90', 38, 1, 7, 67064) The institutes in the West are designed more for the rich than for the poor.
('90', 38, 1, 8, 67141) I feel that I know the method of nature cure for the villagers of India.
('90', 38, 1, 9, 67214) Therefore I should at once have known that nature cure for the villagers could not be attempted in Poona city.
('90', 38, 1, 10, 67325) But a Trust was made.
('90', 38, 1, 11, 67347) Very sober Jehangirji Patel permitted himself to be a co trustee with Dr. Mehta and me, and I hastened to Poona to run for the poor Dr. Mehta’s erstwhile Clinic which was designed for the rich.
('90', 38, 1, 12, 67541) I suggested some drastic changes; but last Monday 1 the knowledge dawned upon me that I was a fool to think that I could ever hope to make an institute for the poor in town.
('90', 38, 1, 13, 67715) I realized that if I cared for the ailing poor, I must go to them and not expect them to come to me.
('90', 38, 1, 14, 67816) This is true of ordinary medicinal treatment.
('90', 38, 1, 15, 67862) It is much more so of nature cure.
('90', 38, 1, 16, 67897) How is a villager coming to Poona to understand and carry out my instructions to apply mud poulties, take sun cure, hip and friction sitz baths or certain foods cooked conservatively?
('90', 38, 1, 17, 68081) 2 Will it not be impudence?
('90', 38, 1, 18, 68109) The villager would go away nodding, but at the same time he would smile and think that the person who advised him to undergo nature cure was a fool.
('90', 38, 1, 19, 68258) He would expect me to give him a powder or a potion to swallow and be done with it.
('90', 38, 1, 20, 68342) Nature cure connotes a way of life which has to be learnt; it is not a drug cure as we understand it.
('90', 38, 1, 21, 68444) The treatment to be efficatious can, therefore, only take place in or near a man’s cottage or house.
('90', 38, 1, 22, 68545) It demands from its physician sympathy and patience and knowledge of human nature.
('90', 38, 1, 23, 68628) When he has successfully practised in this manner in a village, or villages, when enough men and women have understood the secret of nature cure, a nucleus for a nature cure university is founded.

('90', 41, 2, 5, 74255) 57. SATYAGRAHA IN FACE OF HOOLIGANISM 1
('90', 41, 3, 6, 74295) A friend has gently posed the question as to what a satyagrahi should do to prevent looting by goondas 2. If he had understood the secret of satyagraha, he would not have put it.
('90', 41, 3, 7, 74474) To lay down one’s life, even alone, for what one considers to be right, is the very core of satyagraha.
('90', 41, 3, 8, 74578) More no man can do.
('90', 41, 3, 9, 74598) If a man is armed with a sword, he might lop off a few heads but ultimately he must surrender to superior force or else die fighting.
('90', 41, 3, 10, 74732) The sword of the satyagrahi is love and the unshakable firmness that comes from it.
('90', 41, 3, 11, 74816) He will regard as brothers the hundreds of goondas that confront him and instead of trying to kill them he will choose to die at their hands and thereby live.
('90', 41, 3, 12, 74975) This is straight and simple.
('90', 41, 3, 13, 75004) But how can a solitary satyagrahi succeed in the midst of a huge population?
('90', 41, 3, 14, 75081) Hundreds of hooligans were let loose on the city of Bombay for arson and loot.
('90', 41, 3, 15, 75160) A solitary satyagrahi will be like a drop in the ocean.
('90', 41, 3, 16, 75216) Thus argues the corresp ondent.
('90', 41, 3, 17, 75248) My reply is that a satyagrahi may never run away from danger, irrespective of whether he is alone or in the company of many.
('90', 41, 3, 18, 75373) He will have fully performed his duty, if he dies fighting.
('90', 41, 3, 19, 75433) The same holds good in armed warfare.
('90', 41, 3, 20, 75471) It applies with greater force in satyagraha.
('90', 41, 3, 21, 75516) Moreover the sacrifice of one will evoke the sacrifice of many and may possibly produce big results.
('90', 41, 3, 22, 75617) There is always this possibility.
('90', 41, 3, 23, 75651) But one must scrupulously avoid the temptation of a desire for results.
('90', 41, 3, 24, 75723) 3 Here I am indicating only a possibility.
('90', 41, 3, 25, 75766) May no one regard results as a temptation.
('90', 41, 3, 26, 75809) I believe that every man and woman should learn the art of self defence in this age [and in all ages] 4. This is done through arms
('90', 41, 4, 27, 75940) 1 Originally written in Gujarati, this appeared as “from Harijanbandhu” published simultaneously with the source.
('90', 41, 4, 28, 76054) 2 Rowdies 3 The rest of the paragrpah is translated from the Gujarati version.
('90', 41, 4, 29, 76133) 4 From the Gujarati
('90', 42, 0, 1, 76153) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 43
('90', 42, 1, 2, 76196) in the West.
('90', 42, 1, 3, 76209) Every adult man is conscripted for army training for a definite period.
('90', 42, 1, 4, 76281) The training for satyagraha is meant for all, irrespective of age or sex.
('90', 42, 1, 5, 76355) The more important part of the train ing here is mental, not physical.
('90', 42, 1, 6, 76426) There can be no compulsion in mental training.
('90', 42, 1, 7, 76473) The surrounding atmosphere no doubt acts on the mind but that cannot justify compulsion.
('90', 42, 1, 8, 76562) It follows that shopkeepers, traders, mill hands, labourers, farmers, clerks, in short everyone ought to consider it his or her duty to get the necessary training in satyagraha.
('90', 42, 1, 9, 76740) Satyagraha is always superior to armed resistance.
('90', 42, 1, 10, 76791) This can only be effectively proved by demonstration, not by argument.
('90', 42, 1, 11, 76862) It is the weapon that adorns the strong.
('90', 42, 1, 12, 76903) It can never adorn the weak.
('90', 42, 1, 13, 76932) By weak is meant the weak in mind and spirit, not in body.
('90', 42, 1, 14, 76991) That limitation is a quality to be prized and not a defect to be deplored.
('90', 42, 1, 15, 77066) One ought also to understand one of its other limitations.
('90', 42, 1, 16, 77125) It can never be used to defend a wrong cause.
('90', 42, 1, 17, 77171) Satyagraha brigades can be organized in every village and in every block of buildings in the cities.
('90', 42, 1, 18, 77272) Each brigade should be comp osed of those persons who are well known to the organizers.
('90', 42, 1, 19, 77360) In this respect satyagraha differs from armed defence.
('90', 42, 1, 20, 77415) For the latter the State impresses the service of everybody.
('90', 42, 1, 21, 77476) For a satyagraha brigade only those are eligible who believe in ahimsa and satya.
('90', 42, 1, 22, 77558) Therefore an intimate knowledge of the persons enlisted is necessary for the organizers.

('90', 42, 2, 24, 77687) 58. PERSECUTION OF HARIJANS 1
('90', 42, 3, 25, 77717) Sir Parikshitlal Majmudar 2 writes :
('90', 42, 4, 26, 77754) There was high mortality due to some epidemic in a village in Wadhwan State, Kathiawar.
('90', 42, 4, 27, 77842) The superstition of the villagers ascribed this misfortune to Harijans and they began to intimidate the Bhangi families.
('90', 42, 4, 28, 77963) The latter fled from the village through fright.
('90', 42, 4, 29, 78012) Harijan workers .
('90', 42, 4, 30, 78030) approached the State authorities to take immediate steps to protect the Bhangis.
('90', 42, 4, 31, 78111) The State acted
('90', 42, 5, 32, 78127) 1 Originally written in Gujarati this appeared as “from Harijanbandhu” published simultaneously with the source.

('90', 43, 0, 1, 78344) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 43, 1, 2, 78385) promptly and the families returned.
('90', 43, 1, 3, 78421) The only remedy for this kind of superstition is the spread of correct knowledge.
('90', 43, 1, 4, 78503) The reason for its existence in Kathiawar seems to be that the reform movement has not yet touched the villages there.
('90', 43, 1, 5, 78622) Workers must make Herculean efforts to remedy this de fect.
('90', 43, 1, 6, 78682) But wherefrom are such workers to come?
('90', 43, 1, 7, 78722) Even those already working in Kathiawar fight shy of going to the villages.
('90', 43, 1, 8, 78798) And, even if they go, one can well imagine the immense difficulty of the task confronting them.
('90', 43, 1, 9, 78894) Man’s endeavour at its highest consists in contin uing to perform one’s duty undeterrred by difficulties.The Kathiawar incident must be taken to heart.
('90', 43, 1, 10, 79046) Both the State and the people understood their duty and took prompt and firm measures in the instance quoted and the difficulty was surmounted for the time being.
('90', 43, 1, 11, 79209) If this example were to be widely followed, it would cut at the very root of superstition.
('90', 43, 1, 12, 79300) And that would be true education.

('90', 45, 1, 2, 81099) 62. HINDU AND MUSSALMAN TEA, ETC.
('90', 45, 2, 3, 81133) Hindu and Mussalman tea is sold at railway stations.
('90', 45, 2, 4, 81186) Separate arrangements for meals for the two communities are sometimes made and none seems to be there for Harijans.
('90', 45, 2, 5, 81302) All this is a sign of our pitiable condition and constitutes a blot on British administration.
('90', 45, 2, 6, 81397) One can understand their not interfering in religious matters, but for them to allow separate arrangements for tea, water, etc., for the two communities is to set the seal of approval on separatism.
('90', 45, 2, 7, 81596) Railways and railway travelling offer a golden opportunity which could be used for social reform and for educating the public in sanitation and hygiene, good manners and communal unity.
('90', 45, 2, 8, 81782) Instead, however, an utter neglect of and indifference to these desiderata are shown.
('90', 45, 2, 9, 81868) Railway travel serves to strengthen, rather than mitigate, evil customs and bad habits.
('90', 45, 2, 10, 81956) First and second class passengers are pampered, luxurious habits encouraged.
('90', 45, 2, 11, 82033) Third class passengers on whom the railway revenues largely depend are denied even elementary amenities and exposed to all kinds of hardship.
('90', 45, 2, 12, 82175) In either case weakness is exploited.
('90', 45, 2, 13, 82213) And when, in addition to this, separatism and un touchability are recognized by the railway authorities, it is the very limit.
('90', 45, 2, 14, 82340) If any passenger wishes to impose restrictions on himself, he is at liberty to do so at his own expense and suffer, maybe, even hunger and thirst.
('90', 45, 2, 15, 82487) But let him not demand special facilities for himself from railway authorities.
('90', 45, 2, 16, 82567) That vegetarians and non vegetarians should be catered for, is another matter.
('90', 45, 2, 17, 82646) That is already being done.
('90', 45, 2, 18, 82674) POONA, March 7, 1946 Harijan, 17 3 1946

('90', 47, 1, 2, 84615) 65. LETTER TO KRISHNACHANDRA
('90', 47, 2, 3, 84644) POONA, March 7, 1946
('90', 47, 3, 4, 84665) KRISHNACHANDRA, I did write a few letters to you.
('90', 47, 3, 5, 84715) And whenever I dictate letters or ask someone to write to you, these too should be looked upon as letters from me.
('90', 47, 3, 6, 84830) A number of letters have now gone from here.
('90', 47, 3, 7, 84875) It cannot be said that anything remains to be answered.
('90', 47, 3, 8, 84931) I do not consider Bhansalibhai’s fast to be right, and nobody in the Ashram has any right to undertake a fast like this.
('90', 47, 3, 9, 85052) I have always said that if one wanted to undetake a fast, one must take my permission.
('90', 47, 3, 10, 85139) The rule still applies.
('90', 47, 3, 11, 85163) It may be asked, what is to be done when I am away.
('90', 47, 3, 12, 85215) The answer is that the Manager of the Ashram should be consulted and, if he is in doubt, then some senior member like Vinobaji or Kishorelalbhai and others should be consulted.
('90', 47, 3, 13, 85392) If there is time to consult me, then it is, of course, better to do so.
('90', 47, 3, 14, 85464) Observance of this rule would save one from any possible conflict of duties.
('90', 47, 3, 15, 85541) I think you should now give up your insistence on buying an ox.
('90', 47, 3, 16, 85605) We may not be able to become the poorest among the poor, but let us try to be like the poor in every way we can.
('90', 47, 3, 17, 85718) Crores of people cannot afford an ox, and there are very few people in India who have good oxen.
('90', 47, 3, 18, 85815) Why should we not try to be like them?
('90', 47, 3, 19, 85854) It would be a sign of perverted reason to cite the instance of the Goseva Sangh in this connection.
('90', 47, 3, 20, 85954) Let us see how much we can achieve with mere manual labour without oxen and without Western machinery.
('90', 47, 3, 21, 86057) You will see that a great deal can be done in this way.

('90', 47, 6, 24, 86176) 66. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('90', 47, 7, 25, 86203) POONA, March 7, 1946 Letters and wires continue to come to me seeking my aid in saving Gen.
('90', 47, 7, 26, 86295) Awari’s life which seems now to be sinking.
('90', 47, 7, 27, 86339) I know Gen.
('90', 47, 7, 28, 86351) He is a lovable worker.
('90', 47, 7, 29, 86375) But I know too that he is often
('90', 48, 0, 1, 86407) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 49
('90', 48, 1, 2, 86450) improperly obstinate.
('90', 48, 1, 3, 86472) The present occasion is a case in point.
('90', 48, 1, 4, 86513) 1 If a man, however popular and great he may be, takes up an improper cause and fasts in defence of the impropriety, if is the duty of his friends (among whom I count myself), fellow workers and relatives to let him die rather than that an improper cause should triumph so that he may live.
('90', 48, 1, 5, 86804) Fairest means cease to be fair when the end sought is unfair.
('90', 48, 1, 6, 86866) Let me say once more where Gen.
('90', 48, 1, 7, 86898) Awari’s end is improper and unfair.
('90', 48, 1, 8, 86934) He may be wholly right in his statement that a great wrong has been perpetrated by the Central Parliamentary Board of the Congress.
('90', 48, 1, 9, 87066) But who can right the wrong?
('90', 48, 1, 10, 87095) Not Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel as Gen.
('90', 48, 1, 11, 87132) Awari tells me he can.
('90', 48, 1, 12, 87155) He is but an individual Sardar 2 thought he has pronounced the decision of the Board.
('90', 48, 1, 13, 87241) A judge cannot review his own judgment.
('90', 48, 1, 14, 87281) The Sardar is out of the picture.
('90', 48, 1, 15, 87315) The Central Board cannot, must not, review its own judgment.
('90', 48, 1, 16, 87376) It has no authority.
('90', 48, 1, 17, 87397) No institution can act capriciously in a well managed democracy.
('90', 48, 1, 18, 87462) Awari and his friends have the right of appeal or review by the Working Committee, then the A. I. C. C.; finally the Congress.
('90', 48, 1, 19, 87589) This procedure may appear to him too long.
('90', 48, 1, 20, 87632) It is not, unless he is fighting for an individual or individuals and not for a principle, as he assures me, he is doing.
('90', 48, 1, 21, 87754) Time always runs in favour of the defence of a principle.
('90', 48, 1, 22, 87812) If the general session of the Congress which is the highest tribunal for vindicating justice decides against Gen.
('90', 48, 1, 23, 87926) Awari, he has to submit to its verdict.
('90', 48, 1, 24, 87966) The Congress is the panchayat.
('90', 48, 1, 25, 87997) Like the king it can do no wrong.
('90', 48, 1, 26, 88031) This is merely a necessary and legitimate concep tion for guidance in the observance of an infallible duty.
('90', 48, 1, 27, 88139) In truth, however, decisions of human organizations in all climes have been sometimes found to be wrong.
('90', 48, 1, 28, 88244) So it may be in the case under discussion.
('90', 48, 1, 29, 88287) Then, but not till then, will Gen.
('90', 48, 1, 30, 88322) Awari have in theory the right, if he chooses to exercise it, to stir public conscience into action by a fast to the finish.
('90', 48, 1, 31, 88447) In practice, it will be ludicrous.
('90', 48, 1, 32, 88482) For the principle behind such action can only euphemistically be so called.
('90', 48, 1, 33, 88558) In democracy even pure men may unconsciously give wrong decisions.
('90', 48, 1, 34, 88625) The remedy is more and purer education, greater awakening of the public and, in such quickened atmosphere, the rise of a number of public workers whose sole duty will be to speak, write and act so as to serve as bright examples for the public.
('90', 48, 2, 35, 88869) 1Vide “Telegram to Secretary, C. P. Provincial Congress Committee”, 20 2 1946 and “Letter to Manchershaw R. Awari”, 24 2 1946 2 Literaly, ‘chief’
('90', 49, 0, 1, 89015) 50 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 49, 1, 2, 89056) Now I hope the friends of Gen.
('90', 49, 1, 3, 89087) Awari will understand me when I say that those who wrongly support him and his fast and thus encourage him will hasten Gen.
('90', 49, 1, 4, 89211) Awari’s death, not those who will not swerve from well recognized canons of justice even for the sake of saving the life of an erring friend.

('90', 49, 2, 8, 89417) 67. SPEECH AT MEETING OF TRUSTEES OF ALL INDIA NATURE CURE FOUNDATION, POONA 1
('90', 49, 3, 9, 89496) March 7, 1946
('90', 49, 4, 10, 89510) Mahatma Gandhi explained that nature cure therapeutics as practised in the cities of India and in the West was not suitable for the masses in the villages of India and that they should be based on the material available in and around the villages as well as in keeping with rural economics.
('90', 49, 4, 11, 89801) Principally the mass awakening was to be made from the point of view of prevention of diseases rather than from the point of view of cure of the same.
('90', 49, 4, 12, 89952) From the latter view point he emphasized the need for evolution of a system of nature cure therapeutics based upon Ramanama and the five elements of Nature : earth, water, air, sun, sky.
('90', 49, 5, 13, 90139) Mahatma Gandhi particularly emphasized the importance of Ramanama as the basis of his system, and its spiritual singnificance in nature cure science.
('90', 49, 5, 14, 90289) He explained that once he started the practice of nature cure of his conception in one the villages around Poona, his idea would evolve a system of therapeutics which can be spread through out the rural population of India.
('90', 49, 6, 15, 90513) Mahatma Gandhi then suggested that Dr. Dinshaw Mehta should undertake a trip to the different parts of India with the idea of studying various nature cure institutions existing in the country.
('90', 49, 7, 16, 90706) From a fascimile : Mahatma, Vol. 7, between pp.

('90', 51, 4, 8, 92970) 71. DRAFT MEMORANDUM TO VICEROY 1
('90', 51, 5, 9, 93004) [On or after March 8, 1946] 2
('90', 51, 6, 10, 93034) We the signatories hereto are deeply grateful to your Excel lency for receiving us at short notice in spite of your multifarious preoccupations.
('90', 51, 6, 11, 93179) The present intention of the Government of the Union of South Africa will, if carried out, degrade us to a status of inferio rity against which we have put up a fight more definitely since 1893, the year in which an attempt was made to disfranchise the Indian community as such in Natal.
('90', 51, 6, 12, 93467) We then looked upon it as a slur not only on the Indians in Natal but also on the mother country.
('90', 51, 6, 13, 93565) Then there was no Union of South Africa.
('90', 51, 6, 14, 93606) The Cape [Town] had practically no Indian question worth the name.
('90', 51, 6, 15, 93673) Orange Free State had banished the few Indian traders it had and prided itself on its thorough anti Asiatic policy.
('90', 51, 6, 16, 93789) The Transvaal had a sprinkling of Indian traders, hawkers and others.
('90', 51, 6, 17, 93859) The location system later known as segregation had its rise there.
('90', 51, 6, 18, 93926) The whites in Natal had deliberately and for their own sake invited the large number of indentured Indians for their sugar and tea plantations.
('90', 51, 6, 19, 94070) This indentured population naturally drew the independent mercantile Indians.
('90', 51, 6, 20, 94148) One would have thought that the advent of Union would mean the union of all the races of South Africa, i.
('90', 51, 6, 21, 94254) e., the African (the Negro), the European and the Asiatics (primarily and principally Indians).
('90', 51, 6, 22, 94350) What a noble tradition such a union would have been for the world.
('90', 51, 6, 23, 94417) But it was not to be.
('90', 51, 6, 24, 94439) On the contrary, the Union became an anti African and anti Asiatic combine.
('90', 51, 6, 25, 94515) Every year of the progress
('90', 51, 7, 26, 94542) 1Vide the preceding item.
('90', 52, 0, 1, 94568) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 53
('90', 52, 1, 2, 94611) of the Union has definitely marked the progress of this combine and the strenuous opposition to it by the Indian settlers and their descendants as will be clearly seen by reference to the appendix A 1
('90', 52, 2, 3, 94812) hereto attached.
('90', 52, 2, 4, 94829) We ask Your Excellency to approach the question from that standpoint and no other.
('90', 52, 2, 5, 94912) The threatened legislation adumbrated by Field Marshal Smuts which has hastily brought the delegation from South Africa is a very large step, perhaps the largest yet made, in the process of consigning the Asiatics to permanent inferiority.
('90', 52, 2, 6, 95152) Political inequality was their end.
('90', 52, 2, 7, 95188) The wedge has now expanded into all round inequality and inferiority.
('90', 52, 2, 8, 95258) Thus there are three segregations in which the whites are inviting segregations of themselves in order to compel the segregation of the other two.
('90', 52, 2, 9, 95405) God has made man one great human family.
('90', 52, 2, 10, 95446) The white races of South Africa would make of it three separate parts.
('90', 52, 2, 11, 95517) We have come all the way from South Africa not to seek protection of individual or property rights, dear as both are, but we have come definitely to ask Your Excellency and the people of the mother country to appreciate the fight for equality of status, which is theirs as much as ours, and to give us as much help as possible for you and them to give.
('90', 52, 2, 12, 95870) What is attempted to be done in South Africa is a denial of the brave declarations made by the British and even the F. M. himself.
('90', 52, 2, 13, 96001) It has given us much pleasure to learn that the withdrawal of the British power in India in favour of elected Indian represent atives is imminent.
('90', 52, 2, 14, 96148) Then we submit that it is Your Excellency’s double and special duty to enunciate and so far as possible enforce that policy in no uncertain terms in connection with the question being submitted to you.
('90', 52, 2, 15, 96350) We submit that the least Your Excellency’s Government can do is to withdraw the High Commissioner from South Africa and to enforce economic and political sanctions.
('90', 52, 2, 16, 96515) We are not unaware that they may mean very little material loss to South Africa.
('90', 52, 2, 17, 96596) We know that counter measures will cause no hardship.
('90', 52, 2, 18, 96650) But our loss we count as nothing compared to the moral value of the enforcement.
('90', 52, 3, 19, 96731) From the original : Pyarelal Papers.
('90', 52, 3, 20, 96768) Courtesy : Pyarelal

('90', 56, 7, 15, 101629) 79. RAMANAMA, THE INFALLIBLE REMEDY 3
('90', 56, 8, 16, 101667) Shri Ganesh Shastri Joshi, vaidya, tells me after reading my article on nature cure 4 in Harijan of 3rd March, 1946, that in Ayurveda too there is ample testimony to the efficacy of Rama nama as a cure for all diseases.
('90', 56, 8, 17, 101887) Nature cure occupies the place of honour and in it Ramanama is the most important.
('90', 56, 8, 18, 101970) When Charaka 5, Vagbhata 6 and other giants of medicine in ancient India wrote, the popular name for God was not Rama but Vishnu.
('90', 56, 8, 19, 102100) I myself have been a devotee of Tulsidas from my childhood and have, therefore, always, worshipped God as Rama.
('90', 56, 8, 20, 102212) But I know that if, beginning with Omkara one goes through the entire gamut of God’s names current in all climes, all countries and all languages, the result is the same.
('90', 56, 8, 21, 102383) He and His Laws are one.
('90', 56, 8, 22, 102408) To observe His Law is, there fore, the best form of worship.
('90', 56, 8, 23, 102469) A man who becomes one with the Law does not stand in
('90', 56, 9, 24, 102522) 1 According to report in The Hindu, 12 3 1946, Aga Khan celebrated “his diamond jubilee” on March 10, 1946. Gandhiji had expressed his inability to be present on the occasion; vide “Letter to Aga Khan”, 10 2 1946 2 ibid 3 Originally written in Gujarati, this appeared as “from Harijanbandhu” published simultaneously with the source.
('90', 56, 9, 25, 102856) 4 Vide “Nature Cure Treatment” 5 Principal exponent of Ayurvedic system of medicine and author of Charaka Samhita 6 An ancient professor of Ayurveda
('90', 57, 0, 1, 103005) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 57, 1, 2, 103046) need of vocal recitation of the name.
('90', 57, 1, 3, 103084) In other words an individual with whom contemplation of God has become as natural as breathing, is so filled with God’s spirit that knowledge of obser vance of the Law becomes second nature as it were with him.
('90', 57, 1, 4, 103295) Such a one needs no other treatment.
('90', 57, 1, 5, 103332) The question then arises as to why, in spite of having this prince of remedies at hand, we know so little about it, and why even those who know do not remember Him or remember Him only by lip service, not from the heart.
('90', 57, 1, 6, 103553) Parrot like repetition of God’s name signifies failure to recognize Him as the panacea for all ills.
('90', 57, 1, 7, 103654) How can they?
('90', 57, 1, 8, 103668) This sovereign is not administered by doctors, vaidyas, hakims, or any other medical practitioners.
('90', 57, 1, 9, 103768) These have no faith in it.
('90', 57, 1, 10, 103795) If they were to admit that the spring of the Holy Ganges could be found in every home, their very occupation or means of livelihood would go.
('90', 57, 1, 11, 103937) Therefore they must perforce rely on their powders and potions as infallible remedies.
('90', 57, 1, 12, 104024) Not only do these provide bread for the doctor, but the patient too seems to feel immediate relief.
('90', 57, 1, 13, 104124) If a medical practitioner can get a few persons to say ‘So and so gave me a powder and I was cured’, his business is estabished.
('90', 57, 1, 14, 104253) Nor, it must be borne in mind, would it really be of any use for doctors to prescribe God’s name to patients unless they themselves were conscious of its miraculous powers.
('90', 57, 1, 15, 104426) Ramanama is no copy book maxim.
('90', 57, 1, 16, 104458) It is something that has to be realized through experience.
('90', 57, 1, 17, 104518) One who has had personal experience alone can prescribe it, not any other.

('90', 61, 4, 7, 109972) 86. SHOCKING IF TRUE 1
('90', 61, 5, 8, 109995) The Joint Secretary of the Gujarat Harijan Sevak Singh, Shri Hemantkumar, writes that apart from Karadi nowhere are temples open to Harijans, and nowhere may they use public wells.
('90', 61, 5, 9, 110176) If this is true, I may say it is a good thing that I have been unable to go to Bardoli.
('90', 61, 5, 10, 110264) 2 How can those Gujaratis, who do not look upon Harijans as part and parcel of themselves, who do not permit them to draw water from public wells nor enter temples for the worship of God, who even attribute epidemics to Harijans 3 and are prepared to beat them for practices which superstition attributes to them, how can they welcome me?
('90', 61, 5, 11, 110603) Or what value can their welcome hold for me?
('90', 61, 5, 12, 110648) I have long since counted myself as Bhangi in my speech, in my actions and above all in mind and spirit.
('90', 61, 5, 13, 110753) Anyone who looks upon them with contempt does the same to me.
('90', 61, 5, 14, 110815) Indeed I hold it an honour to be among he despised Harijans and among the Bhangis.
('90', 61, 5, 15, 110898) Any welcome to me under the circumstances would be tantamount to an insult.
('90', 61, 5, 16, 110974) Therefore I make this request to Gujaratis that they atone for the grievous wrong they continue to do to fellow human beings.
('90', 61, 5, 17, 111100) I shall consider their repentance adequate when they admit Harijans into their fold, and only then will I consider them capable of maintaining swaraj.
('90', 61, 5, 18, 111251) I do hope that the people of Bardoli Taluka will understand and respond to my message in a special manner.
('90', 61, 5, 19, 111358) BOMBAY, March 11, 1946 Harijan, 24 3 1946

('90', 62, 2, 3, 111638) Q. You ask people not to eat polished rice but I fear the disease is too far gone.
('90', 62, 2, 4, 111721) Polished rice is washed again and again and the water thrown away.
('90', 62, 2, 5, 111788) It is then boiled and that water too is emptied into the drain thus depriving the cereal of all its vitamin value.
('90', 62, 2, 6, 111903) The rice thus served, with each grain separate, is pleasant for both the eye and the palate.
('90', 62, 2, 7, 111996) The practice obtains even in students’ hostels.
('90', 62, 2, 8, 112044) How are we to get rid of it?
('90', 62, 3, 9, 112073) A. I am aware of the above mentioned malpratice.
('90', 62, 3, 10, 112122) We live in the poorest of poor countries and are yet unable or unwilling to give up such harmful habits.
('90', 62, 3, 11, 112227) Each one thinks only of himself.
('90', 62, 3, 12, 112260) We look upon our neighbours as strangers instead of as our kith and kin.
('90', 62, 3, 13, 112333) What does it matter to us whether they live or die?
('90', 62, 3, 14, 112385) If they die, it is their own fault.
('90', 62, 3, 15, 112421) If they live, it is accredited to their merit.
('90', 62, 3, 16, 112468) Life and death are not in our hands.
('90', 62, 3, 17, 112505) Therefore let us eat, drink and be merry!
('90', 62, 3, 18, 112547) In such a distorted view of life, we have to follow what we consider to be our duty and believe that what is true will one day be followed.
('90', 62, 3, 19, 112687) Until then, whenever occasion arises, we must proclaim from the house tops what we consider to be right.
('90', 62, 4, 20, 112792) Q. You say that those who eat fish should be provided with the same.
('90', 62, 4, 21, 112861) Does not this entail violence both for him who eats and him who provides the fish ?
('90', 62, 5, 22, 112945) A. Both commit violence.
('90', 62, 5, 23, 112970) So do those who eat vegetabes.
('90', 62, 5, 24, 113001) This kind of violence is inherent in all embodied life, therefore, in man too.
('90', 62, 5, 25, 113080) It is in this condition, and in spite of it, that we have to practise non violence as a duty.
('90', 62, 5, 26, 113174) I have often indicated how we may do so.
('90', 62, 5, 27, 113215) Then man who coerces another not to eat fish commits more violence than he who eats it.
('90', 62, 5, 28, 113303) Fishermen, fish vendors and fish eaters are probably unaware of any violence in their action.
('90', 62, 5, 29, 113397) Even if they were, they might look upon it as unavoidable.
('90', 62, 5, 30, 113456) But the man who uses coercion is guilty of deliberate violence.
('90', 62, 5, 31, 113520) Coercion is inhuman.
('90', 62, 5, 32, 113541) Those who quarrel among themselves, those who will stoop to anything in order to amass wealth, those who exploit or indulge in forced human labour, those who overload or goad or otherwise torture animals, all these knowin gly commit such violence as can easily be stopped.
('90', 62, 5, 33, 113814) I do not consider

('90', 63, 3, 8, 114310) March 11, 1946 The news of the recent events in Bombay has filled me with shame and humiliation as it must have you too.
('90', 63, 3, 9, 114431) Let me hope that none of those who are here took part in these disgraceful happenings.
('90', 63, 3, 10, 114518) but that would not entitle you to my congratulations.
('90', 63, 3, 11, 114572) We have reached a stage when no body can afford to sit on the fence or take refuge in the ‘ambiguous mid dle‘.
('90', 63, 3, 12, 114683) One has to speak out and stand up for one’s convictions.
('90', 63, 3, 13, 114740) Inaction at a time of conflagration is inexcusable.
('90', 63, 3, 14, 114792) Is it too difficult an ideal to follow?
('90', 63, 3, 15, 114832) Let me tell you, however, that this is the only course that will take us safely through the present difficult times.
('90', 63, 3, 16, 114949) It has become the fashion these days to ascribe all such ugly manifestations to the activities of hooligans.
('90', 63, 3, 17, 115058) It hardly becomes us to take refuge in that moral alibi.
('90', 63, 3, 18, 115115) Who are the hooligans after all?
('90', 63, 3, 19, 115148) They are our own contrymen and, so long as any countryman of ours indulges in such acts, we cannot disown responsibility for them consistently with our claim that we are one people.
('90', 63, 3, 20, 115330) It matters little whether those who were responsbile for the happenings are denounced as goondas or praised as patriots—praise and blame must equally belong to us all.
('90', 63, 3, 21, 115498) The only manly and becoming course for those who are aspiring to be free is to accept either whilst doing our duty.
('90', 63, 3, 22, 115614) In eating, sleeping and in the performance of other physical functions, man is not different from the brute.

('90', 67, 2, 3, 122150) March 12/13, 1946 2
('90', 67, 3, 4, 122170) Gandhiji repeated to them the advice 3 he had previously given to some discharged I.N.A. men who had met him in Madras.
('90', 67, 3, 5, 122290) He had told them that it should be derogatory to the dignity and self respect of a soldier to live upon charity.
('90', 67, 3, 6, 122403) The ideal which they should set before themselves was to earn their bread by honest industry.
('90', 67, 3, 7, 122497) The I. N. A. Relief Fund was there but it would be wrong to use it for providing doles.
('90', 67, 3, 8, 122585) He described to them how in South Africa he had provided relief to dependents of satyagrahi prisoners by settling them on Tolstoy Farm where they had to labour according to capacity.
('90', 67, 3, 9, 122768) The merit of this method was that it could be multiplied to any degree without proving costly and burdensome.
('90', 67, 3, 10, 122878) The real test of the I. N. A., he told them, was to come only now.
('90', 67, 3, 11, 122945) In the fighting line there was the romance and incitement, not so in civil life.
('90', 67, 3, 12, 123026) The country was today faced with the spectre of famine.
('90', 67, 3, 13, 123082) Would they help the people to fight it with the same courage, cohesion, doggedness and resourcefulness which they had shown on the battlefield?
('90', 67, 3, 14, 123226) Would they show the same diligence, mastery and skill in handling the spade, the pickaxe and the hoe as they did in shouldering the rifle?
('90', 67, 3, 15, 123365) Digging of wells and breaking stony ground to grow food, and plying the wheel and the shuttle to clothe the naked was the nation’s need today.
('90', 67, 3, 16, 123508) Would they respend to the call?
('90', 67, 3, 17, 123540) They had physical stamina, discipline and, what was more, a feeling of solidarity and oneness, untainted by narrow communalism.
('90', 67, 3, 18, 123668) All that ought to put them in a singular position of vantage for introducing non violent discipline and organization among the masses.
('90', 67, 3, 19, 123803) Constructive activity could absorb every one of the I. N. A. men who was willing and worthy of his name.
('90', 67, 3, 20, 123908) If they took up that work, not one of them need or would remain unemployed.

('90', 68, 1, 2, 124910) 94. HIGH HANDEDNESS EXPOSED
('90', 68, 2, 3, 124938) The Bombay High Court has just delivered an illuminating judgment, allowing two habeas corpus applications of H. K. Shah and B. E. Sathe against detention orders extended from time to time.
('90', 68, 2, 4, 125128) Chief Justice Stone and Justice Lokur have delivered a considered judgment setting at liberty the two applicants who were evidently illegally detained and might have remained under detention but for the fact that Advocate Purushottam Trikumdas assisted them to bring their cases before the Bombay High Court.
('90', 68, 2, 5, 125437) I have just time to give below the few important extracts from the judgment.
('90', 68, 3, 6, 125514) After observing that the two affidavits filed by Mr. Simms, Home Secretary, Government of Bombay, in relation to the two accused cannot be distinguished from each other except for the numbers at the tops, the learned judges go on to say :
('90', 68, 4, 7, 125753) In the case of Mr. Sathe, there is no suggestion in the reasons given that he assisted or supported any underground organization or organized anything underground, though it is suggested that he assisted the activities of an organization, the object of which was to commit acts of sabotage, and even if it is to be presumed that such an organization would work underground, the very fact that these two affidavits of Mr. Simms are in identical terms, though they deal with the circumstances of two different cases, demonstrates a very casual approach to the grave responsibilities and duties, which devolve on every Government servant charged with these wide powers of detention without trial.
('90', 68, 4, 8, 126447) In Gokhale’s case, a full bench of this High Court had occasion to comment upon detention orders being made on cyclostyled forms inappropriate to the facts of the particular case, and it now appears that, unless checked, the era of the cyclostyled affidavits is about to dawn.
('90', 68, 4, 9, 126724) Even passing over such irregular features in Mr. Simms‘s affidavits as referring to an affidavit without stating whose affidavit it is he refers to, his affidavit does not even state that all the circumstances of the petitioner’s case were fully considered before the extension orders of the 7th January, 1946, were made.
('90', 68, 4, 10, 127046) Commenting upon the further affidavit of Mr. Simms which he filed after declining to attend the court in order to submit himself to cross examination, the judges observe :
('90', 68, 5, 11, 127218) That is a very remarkable document for anyone to file who has been given an opportunity by the Court to attend the Court in order to give viva voce
('90', 69, 0, 1, 127366) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 69, 1, 2, 127407) evidence.
('90', 69, 1, 3, 127417) It is even more remarkable by its omission than by what it says, for it leaves unchallenged the affidavits for the 22nd February of the two petitioners filed in answer to Mr. Simms’s two affidavits which are in identical terms, and which the last affidavit seeks to amend.
('90', 69, 1, 4, 127690) Referring to the extension orders, the learned judges go on to observe :
('90', 69, 2, 5, 127763) But once the original order has run its course, the legislature has provided certain safeguards for the protection of the persons detained.
('90', 69, 2, 6, 127903) Before the six months expired, the person detained will have received the notice giving him the grounds for his detention, and he may have a representation under Section 7. The extension order itself has to be made within thirty days immediately preceding the expiry of the previous order and, lastly, there is added to subjective satisfaction an objective test that the detaining authority shall have further considered all the circumstances of the case.
('90', 69, 2, 7, 128359) In our opinion emphasis is to be placed on the word “all”, and the question at once arises what is the nature of “all the circumstanes” which have to be considered.
('90', 69, 2, 8, 128524) That must be a question of law.
('90', 69, 2, 9, 128556) [Upholding] 1 the defence plea that the detaining authority had not considered all the circumstances of the case, the judges observe :
('90', 69, 3, 10, 128691) Mr. Purushottam Trikumdas advanced various heads of circumstances which he submits is obligatory for the detaining authority to consider.
('90', 69, 3, 11, 128829) In our opinion it is clear that such circumstances must include :
('90', 69, 4, 12, 128895) 1. A consideration of the matters and things which the detenu did, or was suspected of doing, when the original order was made.
('90', 69, 5, 13, 129023) 2. These matters and things must be considered in conjunction with, and in the highlight of, the present state of affairs.
('90', 69, 5, 14, 129146) That is to say, the state of affairs existing in India at the date when the proposed extension order is to be made.
('90', 69, 6, 15, 129262) 3. A cosideration of any representation which the person detained may have made under Section 7 (4), and consideration of the person detained since his detention, and the present state of his health.
('90', 69, 7, 16, 129462) Turning again to the circumstances of the two cases before us, having given the whole position our careful cosideration, we are not prepared to accept the affidavits of Mr. Simms filed on either of these petitions as affording any reliable answer to the assertion of the petitioners that all the circumstances of their cases have not been considered in the light of the state of the state of affairs current in India on the 7th January, 1946. On that date,
('90', 69, 8, 17, 129919) 1 The source has “Holding that“.
('90', 70, 0, 1, 129952) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 71
('90', 70, 1, 2, 129995) as the petitioners point out, there was no successful prosecution of a war for the mass movement to hinder, and the various committees of the Congress, previously unlawful, had been legalized, and the members of the Working Committee of the Congress Party and its leader had been released from dentention.
('90', 70, 1, 3, 130301) These are all circumstances which already ought to have been considered before the renewal orders of the 7th January, 1946, were made.
('90', 70, 1, 4, 130436) The judges then draw attention to the fact that Mr. Simms did not state that H. E. the Governor had considered the papers and agreed to the extension orders of 7th January, 1946, being made.
('90', 70, 1, 5, 130627) The judges say :
('90', 70, 2, 6, 130644) It is extremely significant that His Excellency did not consider and agree to the making of these extension orders though he had considered and agreed to the making of all the orders in both the cases in 1944 and 1945. If he had done so when the orders of the 7th January, 1946 were made, it is inconceivable that Mr. Simms should not have stated that most important fact which is bound to inspire confidence that any order which has been so considered and agreed to has been made after due care, attention and consideration.
('90', 70, 2, 7, 131170) Therefore they hold that the two petitioners have
('90', 70, 3, 8, 131220) successfully challenged the two extension orders of the 7th of January as not being validly made, because, having referred to the facts stated by the petitioners, it is impossible to come to the conclusion that the detaining authority complied with the objective test of having cosidered all the circumstances of the petitioners’ cases.
('90', 70, 3, 9, 131557) That being so, it is our clear duty to order their immediate release.
('90', 70, 3, 10, 131627) In my opinion the released men are entitled to damages for illegal detention.
('90', 70, 3, 11, 131705) This, however, may be debatable.
('90', 70, 3, 12, 131738) But there can be no doubt that all persons similarly detained, no matter in which province, should immediately be discharged without a doubt.
('90', 70, 3, 13, 131880) There is no danger of the Government being overturned by reason of the discharges.
('90', 70, 3, 14, 131963) BOMBAY, March 13, 1946 Harijan, 17 3 1946

('90', 74, 3, 7, 137025) Truth itself is God, and non violence is just a synonym for truth.
('90', 74, 4, 8, 137092) People ought to be prepared to uphold truth and non violence at all costs, even at the cost of death, just as they would be prepared to sacrifice their lives for God, as was stated in the bhajan.
('90', 74, 5, 9, 137288) Briefly referring to the recent disturbance in Bombay, he said that those who were responsible for looting did it in ignorance and under misguidance.
('90', 74, 5, 10, 137438) They did not do it of their own free will.

('90', 74, 5, 14, 137663) On the other hand, only truth and non violence would achieve the freedom of India.
