('90', 75, 8, 13, 139626) 102. COMMUNAL UNITY AND NON UNTOUCHABILITY IN THE I. N. A.
('90', 75, 9, 14, 139685) The Azad Hind movement in East Asia solved many problems.
('90', 75, 9, 15, 139743) And one of them was the major and intricate problem of communal unity.
('90', 75, 9, 16, 139814) Although efforts towards this direction were made ever since the inception of the movement in 1942, it became a reality only after the arrival of Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose.
('90', 75, 9, 17, 139988) There was another question and that was of untouchability, though on a minor scale.
('90', 75, 9, 18, 140072) Anyhow this ill too was remedied as a result of universal training of Indians in the I.N.A. camps and offices after Netaji‘s arrival.
('90', 75, 9, 19, 140206) Netaji had asked for ‘total mobilization‘ for the coming armed struggle for India‘s freedom.
('90', 75, 9, 20, 140299) To this call .
('90', 75, 9, 21, 140314) all sections of the community.
('90', 75, 9, 22, 140345) offered their service as .
('90', 75, 9, 23, 140372) volunteers.
('90', 75, 9, 24, 140384) Some of these volunteers were absorbed in the Azad Hind Sangh, the party behind the Azad Hind Fauj and the Azad Hind Government.
('90', 75, 9, 25, 140513) Others– a majority of the volunteers–joined the ranks of the Fauj.
('90', 75, 9, 26, 140580) The Sangh had a network of branches throughout East Asia.
('90', 75, 9, 27, 140638) In every branch workers consisting of Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs and Christians.
('90', 75, 9, 28, 140715) lived together ate, at the same table and worked together.
('90', 75, 9, 29, 140774) Same was the case in the Indian National Army.

('90', 76, 1, 4, 140974) The natural question is: Now that these soldiers have returned, will the same comradeship persist?
('90', 76, 1, 5, 141073) It ought to.

('90', 79, 0, 1, 146284) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 79, 1, 2, 146325) The singing of Ramdhun is the most important part of congregational prayer.
('90', 79, 1, 3, 146401) The millions may find it difficult to correctly recite and understand the Gita verses and the Arabic and Zend Avesta prayers, but everybody can join in chanting Ramanama or God’s name.
('90', 79, 1, 4, 146586) It is as simple as it is effective.
('90', 79, 1, 5, 146622) Only it must proceed from the heart.
('90', 79, 1, 6, 146659) In its simplicity lies its greatness and the secret of its universality.
('90', 79, 1, 7, 146732) Anything that millions can do together becomes charged with a unique power.
('90', 79, 1, 8, 146808) I congratulate you on your success in the mass singing of Ramdhun without any previous training.
('90', 79, 1, 9, 146905) But it is capable of further improvement.
('90', 79, 1, 10, 146947) You should practise it in your homes.
('90', 79, 1, 11, 146985) I am here to testify that when it is sung in tune to the accompaniment of tala, the triple accord of the voice, the accompaniment and thought creates an atmosphere of ineffable sweetness and strength which no words can describe.
('90', 79, 2, 12, 147214) Gandhiji said that my prayer, will power and mental concentration were developed.
('90', 79, 2, 13, 147296) This lesson he had learnt during his experience over many years, from the time he first started satyagraha.
('90', 79, 3, 14, 147404) I introduced the practice of having congregational prayer some time before the commencement of the South African satyagraha struggle.
('90', 79, 4, 15, 147538) He said that in India there were only a few foreigners, and the native population numbered millions.
('90', 79, 4, 16, 147639) Yet the former dominated over the latter.
('90', 79, 4, 17, 147681) In South Africa, on the other hand, Indians were few while Europeans and the natives there numbered several millions.
('90', 79, 5, 18, 147799) The Indian community there was faced with a grave peril.
('90', 79, 5, 19, 147856) We did all that was humanly possible.
('90', 79, 5, 20, 147894) All methods of seeking redress, agitation through the Press and the platform, petitions and deputations were tried but proved of no avail.
('90', 79, 5, 21, 148033) What was the Indian community consisting of a mere handful of illiterate indentured labourers mostly, with a sprinkling of free merchants, hawkers, etc., to do in the midst of an overwhelming majority of Negroes and whites?
('90', 79, 5, 22, 148257) The whites were fully armed.
('90', 79, 6, 23, 148286) What could a handful of Indians .
('90', 79, 6, 24, 148320) do against the armed might of the South African Government?
('90', 79, 6, 25, 148380) The utmost that they could do was to plead with the Government in power.
('90', 79, 6, 26, 148453) The richer sections might even send deputations to England.
('90', 79, 7, 27, 148513) 1 This paragraph is from The Bombay Chronicle.

('90', 80, 1, 2, 148639) Beyond that they could not go.
('90', 80, 1, 3, 148670) In these circumstances there was nothing that one could do.
('90', 80, 1, 4, 148730) He could not give guns in the hands of this handful of men and say : “Fight”.
('90', 80, 1, 5, 148808) He could not drill them into an army and then parade them.
('90', 80, 2, 6, 148867) It was clear that if the Indians were to come into their own, they must forge a weapon which would be different from, and infinitely superior to, the force which the white settlers commended in such ample measure.
('90', 80, 2, 7, 149081) It was then that I introduced congregational prayer in Phoenix and Tolstoy Farm as a means for a training in the use of the weapon of satyagraha or soul force.
('90', 80, 3, 8, 149241) As a practising satyagrahi and the author of satyagrahas, he could say that its seed lay in prayers.
('90', 80, 3, 9, 149342) Satyagraha could be pitted against all earthly powers for it was a divine power.
('90', 80, 3, 10, 149423) 2 The root of satyagraha is in prayer.
('90', 80, 3, 11, 149462) A satyagrahi relies upon God for protection against the tyranny of brute force.
('90', 80, 3, 12, 149542) Why should you then be always afraid of the British or anybody playing you false?
('90', 80, 3, 13, 149624) If someone deceives you, he will be the loser.
('90', 80, 3, 14, 149671) The fight of satyagraha is for the strong in spirit, not the doubter or the timid.
('90', 80, 3, 15, 149754) Satyagraha teaches us the art of living as well as dying.
('90', 80, 3, 16, 149812) Birth and death are inevitable among mortals.
('90', 80, 3, 17, 149858) These higher attributes of how to live worthily and lay down one’s life nobly, were what satyagraha could teach man.
('90', 80, 3, 18, 149975) A person who did not understand these twin arts was no true satyagrahi.
('90', 80, 3, 19, 150047) 3 In the vast world every creature had to live, work and die.
('90', 80, 3, 20, 150109) It was a very common phenomenon.
('90', 80, 3, 21, 150142) But these creatures could not realize the potent force that could be derived from God.
('90', 80, 3, 22, 150229) That was because they did not know the art of sacrificing their lives, which satyagraha involved.
('90', 80, 3, 23, 150327) Gandhiji said that so far as purely animal functions like eating and breeding and living and dying were concerned, there was no difference between man and beast and birds.
('90', 80, 3, 24, 150499) But man rose above them all, for he alone could recognize the good and the true, he alone could realize God.
('90', 80, 3, 25, 150608) 4 What distinguishes the man from the brute is his conscious striving to realize the spirit within.
('90', 80, 3, 26, 150708) The last eighteen verses of the second chapter of the Gita which are recited at the prayer give in a nutshell the secret of the art of living.
('90', 80, 3, 27, 150851) It is given there in the form of a description of a sthitaprajna or the man of steady wisdom, i.
('90', 80, 3, 28, 150948) e., a satyagrahi, in reply to Arjuna’s query to Lord Krishna.
('90', 80, 3, 29, 151010) The art of dying follows as a corollary from the art of living.

('90', 81, 0, 1, 151313) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 81, 1, 2, 151354) Death must come to all.
('90', 81, 1, 3, 151378) A man may die of a lightning stroke or as a result of a heart failure or failure of respiration.
('90', 81, 1, 4, 151475) But that is not the death that a satygarahi can wish for or pray for himself.
('90', 81, 1, 5, 151553) The art of dying for a satyagrahi consists in facing death cheerfully in the performance of one’s duty.
('90', 81, 1, 6, 151657) That is an art which the people of Bombay apparently have not yet learnt.
('90', 81, 2, 7, 151731) Referring to the mutiny of the ratings of the R. I. N. in Bombay and the distrubances that followed, Mahatma Gandhi said that everything that was done during these days was motivated by a desire for freedom.
('90', 81, 2, 8, 151939) But those who took part in these did not know the art of satyagraha.
('90', 81, 2, 9, 152008) Unfortunately many buildings were looted and burnt, many people were assaulted and many died.
('90', 81, 3, 10, 152102) Judged from these standards, the men who died in the recent disturbances had thrown away their lives.
('90', 81, 3, 11, 152204) It was a waste of many lives.
('90', 81, 3, 12, 152234) There was nothing worthy or artistic in looting ships, and exercising violence on the foreigners who were going about their business.
('90', 81, 3, 13, 152368) The men who did it were no satyagrahis.
('90', 81, 3, 14, 152408) The men who looked on without helping were also no satyagrahis.
('90', 81, 3, 15, 152472) It is not enough not to want to hurt or take the life of your enemy.
('90', 81, 3, 16, 152541) You are no satyagrahis, if you remain silent or passive spectators while your enemy is being done to death.
('90', 81, 3, 17, 152649) You must protect him even at the cost of your life.
('90', 81, 3, 18, 152701) If thousands in India learnt that art, the face of India would be changed and no one would be able to point his finger of scorn at her non violence as being a cloak for weakness.
('90', 81, 3, 19, 152880) We would not then try to shift blame for ugly happenings on the hooligan elements.
('90', 81, 3, 20, 152963) We would convert and control the hooligan elements too.
('90', 81, 3, 21, 153019) We are passing through a crisis in our history.
('90', 81, 3, 22, 153067) Danger besets us on all sides.
('90', 81, 3, 23, 153098) But we shall convert it into our opportunity, if we realize the power of satyagraha than which there is nothing more potent on earth.
('90', 81, 4, 24, 153232) In a brief reference to the impending Cabinet Mission to India, the Mahatma counselled patience.
('90', 81, 4, 25, 153329) He would indicate the next step, if the mission failed to implement the pledges and promises made to India.

('90', 82, 1, 2, 153633) 109. THOUGHTLESSNESS 1
('90', 82, 2, 3, 153656) [Q.] You are aware that pari passu with the growth of popular outbreaks, the lawlessness of the military is also becoming more and more brutal.
('90', 82, 2, 4, 153800) You have condemned the hooliganism of the masses but you say nothing about the brutality of the military.
('90', 82, 2, 5, 153906) [A.] This is a specimen of thoughtlessness.
('90', 82, 2, 6, 153950) People have no right to commit excesses whereas the military is the very embodiment of madness.
('90', 82, 2, 7, 154046) Condemnation of military madness would be meaningless when the very institution of the army is condemned.
('90', 82, 2, 8, 154152) But criticism of their conduct becomes necessary as a warning to the Government.
('90', 82, 2, 9, 154233) There is a time and occasion for everything.
('90', 82, 2, 10, 154278) It would be out of place when condemning popular excesses.
('90', 82, 2, 11, 154337) What is the duty of a satyagrahi general?
('90', 82, 2, 12, 154379) Should he reform his own army or that of the opponent?
('90', 82, 2, 13, 154434) If he reforms his own, the power of the opposing force is sterilized.
('90', 82, 2, 14, 154504) If the process continues over a sufficiently long period, the opponent is ipso facto completely transformed.
('90', 82, 2, 15, 154613) The critic’s remark can only be meant for me.
('90', 82, 2, 16, 154659) Others have already condemned military excesses.
('90', 82, 2, 17, 154708) In my opinion, we have not as yet got sufficient material to judge them.
('90', 82, 2, 18, 154781) I expect that this is being prepared.
('90', 82, 2, 19, 154819) The duty of the people, however, is to turn the searchlight inwards.
('90', 82, 2, 20, 154888) Too much brooding over the wrongs of others is apt to lead one imperceptibly to act likewise.
('90', 82, 2, 21, 154982) It would then be a case of the pot calling the kettle black.

('90', 82, 3, 25, 155320) The person who erected the temple has wasted his resources by misusing them, the villagers who are drawn there are misled, and I am being insulted in that the whole of my life has been caricatured in that temple.
('90', 82, 3, 26, 155533) The meaning that I have given to worship is distorted.
('90', 82, 3, 27, 155588) Worship of the charkha lies in plying it for a living or as a sacrifice for ushering in swaraj.
('90', 82, 3, 28, 155684) The Gita is worshipped not by parrot like recitation but by following its teaching.
('90', 82, 3, 29, 155768) Recitation is good and proper only as an aid to action according to its teaching.
('90', 82, 3, 30, 155850) A man is worsh ipped only to the extent that he is followed, not in his weaknesses but

('90', 86, 1, 2, 160520) 115. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, BOMBAY 1
('90', 86, 2, 3, 160560) March 15, 1946
('90', 86, 3, 4, 160575) Announcing that this was his parting speech, Gandhiji said that he had been told that on the previous day many people did not understand what he said.
('90', 86, 3, 5, 160726) He asked those present, if they could follow Hindustani.
('90', 86, 3, 6, 160783) On their assenting, he congratulated them and said that it was the good fortune of India that there were so many languages in it.
('90', 86, 3, 7, 160913) These languages were not barbarous or something to be discarded.
('90', 86, 3, 8, 160978) They were great languages; but in places like Bombay it was necessary for the people to know more than one language.
('90', 86, 3, 9, 161095) Bombay’s women folk had some knowledge of both Gujarati and Marathi merely by living together.
('90', 86, 3, 10, 161190) But he wanted that they must make some special effort.
('90', 86, 3, 11, 161245) They must learn their mother tongue; otherwise it would amount to treachery.
('90', 86, 3, 12, 161322) They must also know Hindustani.
('90', 86, 3, 13, 161354) Every man in whose heart burnt the flame of Indian freedom must know Hindustani.
('90', 86, 3, 14, 161435) In places like Bombay it would be necessary to know a third language also.
('90', 86, 4, 15, 161510) Gandhiji said, he was leaving Bombay the next day.
('90', 86, 4, 16, 161561) Therefore he wanted to give them a parting message.
('90', 86, 4, 17, 161613) He wanted to tell them about nature cure.
('90', 86, 4, 18, 161655) He had written about that subject but had not done much work.
('90', 86, 4, 19, 161717) Nature cure was not like a doctor giving medicine in a bottle.
('90', 86, 4, 20, 161780) It was really the natural way of keeping health and happiness.
('90', 86, 4, 21, 161843) They might be surprised to hear him say so; all the same he would assert that Ramanama was an item in nature cure.
('90', 86, 4, 22, 161958) It is not claimed that nature cure can cure all diseases.
('90', 86, 4, 23, 162016) No system of medicine can do that, or else we should all be immortals.
('90', 86, 4, 24, 162087) But it enables one to face and bear down with unperturbed equanimity and peace of mind an illness which it cannot cure.
('90', 86, 4, 25, 162207) If once we decide that what cannot be shared by the millions should be taboo for us, we are driven to nature as the only cure —all for the rich and the poor alike.
('90', 86, 4, 26, 162371) In the armoury of the nature curist, Ramanama is the most potent weapon.
('90', 86, 4, 27, 162444) Let no one wonder at it.
('90', 86, 4, 28, 162469) A noted Ayurvedic physi cian 3 told me the other day : ‘All my life I have been administering drugs.
('90', 86, 4, 29, 162570) But since you have prescribed Ramanama as a cure for phys ical ailments, it has occurred to me that what you say has too the authority of Vagbhata and Charakha.
('90', 86, 4, 30, 162731) The recitation of Ramanama as a remedy for spiritual ailments is as old as the hills.
('90', 86, 4, 31, 162817) But the greater
('90', 86, 5, 32, 162833) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter—I”.
('90', 86, 5, 33, 162880) The text has been collated with the report in the The Bombay Chronicle, 16 3 1946. The meeting was held at Rungta House.

('90', 87, 0, 1, 163149) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 87, 1, 2, 163190) includes the less.
('90', 87, 1, 3, 163209) And my claim is that the recitation of Ramanama is a sovereign remedy for our physical ailments also.
('90', 87, 1, 4, 163311) A nature cure man won’t tell the patient : ‘Invite me and I shall cure you of your ailment.’ He will only tell about the all healing principle that is in every being and how one can cure oneself by evoking it and making it an active force in his life.
('90', 87, 1, 5, 163563) If India could realize the power of that principle, not only would be free but we would be a land of healthy individuals too—not the land of epidemics and ill health that we are today.
('90', 87, 1, 6, 163748) For a long time he had been preaching that if all India learnt the doctrine of satyagraha, it would get freedom.
('90', 87, 1, 7, 163861) He was so convinced of it that if the whole world opposed him, he would still assert it.
('90', 87, 1, 8, 163950) He was equally convinced that Ramanama could help a man in ill health.
('90', 87, 1, 9, 164021) 1 The potency of Ramanama is however subject to certain conditions and limitations.
('90', 87, 1, 10, 164105) Ramanama is not like black magic.
('90', 87, 1, 11, 164139) If someone suffers from surfeit and wants to be cured of its aftereffects so that he can again indulge himself at the table, Ramanama is not for him.
('90', 87, 1, 12, 164289) Ramanama can be used only for a good, never for an evil end, or else thieves and robbers would be the greatest devotees.
('90', 87, 1, 13, 164410) Ramanama is for the pure in heart and for those who want to attain purity and remain pure.
('90', 87, 1, 14, 164501) It can never be a means for self indulgence.
('90', 87, 1, 15, 164546) The remedy for surfeit is fasting, not prayer.
('90', 87, 1, 16, 164593) Prayer can come in only when fasting has done its work.
('90', 87, 1, 17, 164649) It can make fasting easy and bearable.
('90', 87, 1, 18, 164688) Similarly the taking of Ramanama will be a meaningless farce when at the same time you are drugging your system with medicines.
('90', 87, 1, 19, 164816) A doctor who uses his talent to pander to the vices of his patient degrades himself and his patient.
('90', 87, 1, 20, 164917) What worse degradation can there be for man than that, instead of regarding his body as an instrument for worshipping his Maker, he should make it the object of adoration and waste money like water to keep it going anyhow.
('90', 87, 1, 21, 165140) Ramanama on the other hand purifies while it cures, and, therefore, it elevates.
('90', 87, 1, 22, 165221) Therein lies its use as well as its limitation.
('90', 87, 2, 23, 165269) Gandhiji explained that he had been practising nature cure even from the days when he was a barrister.
('90', 87, 2, 24, 165372) But the realization had come to him late in life that he could use it for work in the villages, for the service of the hungry millions.
('90', 87, 2, 25, 165508) Harijan, 7 4 1946

('90', 89, 1, 2, 167371) 119. TALK WITH A CASUAL VISITOR [On or before March 16, 1946] In the case of the ordinary method of treatment, the patient comes to the doctor to take drugs that would cure him.
('90', 89, 1, 3, 167549) The doctors prescribe the drug.
('90', 89, 1, 4, 167581) With the relief of abnormal symptoms in the patient, his function ends and with that his interest in the patient.
('90', 89, 1, 5, 167695) The nature cure man does not ‘sell a cure’ to the patient.
('90', 89, 1, 6, 167754) He teaches him the right way of living in his home which would not only cure him of his particular ailment but also save him from falling ill I future.
('90', 89, 1, 7, 167906) The ordinary doctor or vaidya is interested mostly in the study of disease.
('90', 89, 1, 8, 167982) The nature curist is interested more in the study of health.
('90', 89, 1, 9, 168043) His real interest begins where that of the ordinary doctor ends; the eradication of the patient’s ailment under nature cure marks only the beginning of a way of life in which there is no room for illness or disease.
('90', 89, 1, 10, 168259) Nature cure is thus a way of life, not a course of ‘treatment’.
('90', 89, 1, 11, 168323) Harijan, 7 4 1946

('90', 89, 3, 22, 168898) The motive behind seems to me to divide them from the so called touchables.
('90', 89, 3, 23, 168974) The reason lies with the latter.
('90', 89, 3, 24, 169007) If touchables had not misbehaved themselves, there would have been no division possible.
('90', 89, 3, 25, 169096) And even though the Congress has been championing them all these years, have the savarna Hindu masses improved their manners?
('90', 89, 3, 26, 169222) The answer has to be ‘No’ even though there has been considerable improvement.
('90', 89, 3, 27, 169301) The Congress influence is most powerful for ending foreign rule.
('90', 89, 3, 28, 169366) It is weak on social matters.
('90', 89, 3, 29, 169396) Therefore, without entering into an unholy competition with the foreign Government, it is necessary for the reformers to do their duty by the Harijans until the bar sinister is completely removed.

('90', 91, 1, 2, 171514) 123. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS BOMBAY, March 16, 1946 Shri Sriramulu is an unknown poor Congressman and servant of humanity working in Nellore.
('90', 91, 1, 3, 171655) He has been labouring single handed for the cause of the Harijans of that place.
('90', 91, 1, 4, 171736) There was a time when high hope was entertained about removal of untouchability and other social work in Nellore.
('90', 91, 1, 5, 171850) An ashram was built near Nellore but for a variety of causes the activity received a set back.
('90', 91, 1, 6, 171945) Deshabhakta Konda Venkatappayya was, and still is, though very old, the moving spirit in connection with these activities.
('90', 91, 1, 7, 172068) It is in this place that Shri Sriramulu has been quietly and persistently working for the removal, root and branch, of untouchability.
('90', 91, 1, 8, 172203) He has been trying to have a temple opened to Harijans.
('90', 91, 1, 9, 172259) He asked me the other day whether, in order to awaken public conscience in favour of such opening, he could, if all other efforts failed, undertake a fast.
('90', 91, 1, 10, 172415) I sent him my approval.
('90', 91, 1, 11, 172439) 1 Now the place is astir.
('90', 91, 1, 12, 172465) But some persons have asked me to advice Shri Sriramulu to suspend his fast for removing legal difficulties of which I have no knowledge.
('90', 91, 1, 13, 172603) I have been unable to give such advice.
('90', 91, 1, 14, 172643) As I am anxious that an unobtrusive servant of humanity may not die for want of public knowledge and support, I bespeak the interest of the journalists of the South, if not all India, to find out for themselves the truth of the matter and, if what I say is borne out by facts, shame by public exposure the opposing parties into doing the right and save a precious life.
('90', 91, 2, 15, 173013) Harijan, 24 3 1946

('90', 93, 1, 2, 176220) made available where it is most needed.
('90', 93, 1, 3, 176260) Distribution is the real problem.
('90', 93, 1, 4, 176294) Unless it is tackled, there is danger that the food will rot in the ports while people are dying in the interior.
('90', 93, 1, 5, 176408) At present it seems almost a hopeless task through the present corruption.
('90', 93, 1, 6, 176483) A Government official sent a note the other day showing how it would be at least two months between the arrival of the food ships in the ports and the food actually reaching the affected areas.
('90', 93, 1, 7, 176677) In the mean time what are the people to do?
('90', 93, 1, 8, 176721) I have, therefore, suggested that they should utilize the sub soil water to grow whatever they can by their own efforts.
('90', 93, 1, 9, 176842) If crores take up the cue, they can do much to save themselves even before the food arrives from outside.
('90', 93, 2, 10, 176948) Horace next told Gandhiji that the F. A. U. are developing work of a more permanent nature for the upliftment of Bengal villages.
('90', 93, 2, 11, 177078) For instance, they are trying to attack the problem of poverty from four or five different angles simultaneously.
('90', 93, 2, 12, 177192) They had discussed the question with Pandit Jawaharlal Nahru who had approved of the idea for two reasons.
('90', 93, 2, 13, 177299) With the coming of freedom, he felt, we might help in post war economic rehabilitation so that the high expectations entertained by the people of the national government might not be belied.
('90', 93, 2, 14, 177490) Besides a body of people from the West serving the people here would act as an antidote to racial feeling which might otherwise oversweep the country in the first flush of freedom.
('90', 93, 2, 15, 177671) Gandhiji agreed entirely with Pandit Nahru.
('90', 93, 2, 16, 177715) Any person who does such work is worth his weight in gold.
('90', 93, 2, 17, 177774) Pandit Nehru has done well to point to the danger signal.
('90', 93, 3, 18, 177832) But he felt that the danger was even deeper.
('90', 93, 3, 19, 177877) The face of the picture as he viewed it seemed horrifying.
('90', 93, 3, 20, 177936) The feeling towards Europeans was rising all though the East.
('90', 93, 3, 21, 177998) There were so many complex forces working on the mass mind.
('90', 93, 3, 22, 178058) If the maelstrom broke out, the F. A. U. might have to bear the brunt of it.
('90', 93, 3, 23, 178135) They must be prepared for that sacrifice.
('90', 93, 3, 24, 178177) But whilst they should be prepared for the worst, he wanted them to share with him the hope that all woould be well in the end.
('90', 93, 3, 25, 178305) To see the danger clearly and yet to remain unperturbed in the face of it, trusting to God’s goodness, is true wisdom.
('90', 93, 3, 26, 178424) Harijan, 7 4 1946 125. DECIMAL COINAGE AND ITS COST After due sanction required by Section 153 of the Government of India Act, 1935, a Bill further to amend the Indian Coingage Act, 1906, is said to have been introduced in the Legislative Assembly on the 18th February, 1946. If it becomes law, the rupee will be equivalant to 100 cents instead of 64 pice.
('90', 93, 3, 27, 178781) The consequential changes
('90', 94, 0, 1, 178807) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 95
('90', 94, 1, 2, 178850) will naturally follow.
('90', 94, 1, 3, 178873) The object 1 is stated to be :
('90', 94, 2, 4, 178904) Modern trade and commerce demand speed and simplicity in the methods of computation, to achieve which there is nothing to compete with the decimal system which has gradually displaced all other systems in most of the advanced countries of the world.
('90', 94, 2, 5, 179154) Public opinion has expressed itself largely in favour of the adoption of decimal coinage in India .
('90', 94, 2, 6, 179254) And a note 2says :
('90', 94, 3, 7, 179273) During the transition period when both the .
('90', 94, 3, 8, 179318) coins will circulate side by side and prices might be quoted in terms of either .
('90', 94, 3, 9, 179400) the Bill provides for conversions involving smaller fractions to be made in rupees of any one transaction.
('90', 94, 3, 10, 179507) Shri Kishorelal Mashruwala has studied the question carefully and has come to the conclusion that whilst in theory the introduction of the decimal coinage may be defensible, in practice, for some years to come, the poor will be sacrificed as usual in the interests of the modern trade, i.
('90', 94, 3, 11, 179796) e., the rich merchants.
('90', 94, 3, 12, 179820) It is unnecessary here to summarize his convincing argument in support.
('90', 94, 3, 13, 179892) It is given in full in the columns of the Harijanbandhu.
('90', 94, 3, 14, 179949) It is sufficient here to state that even in the country of the rulers, the decimal coinage has not been introduced.
('90', 94, 3, 15, 180065) Public opinion there commands respect and affects the decisions of the House of Commons.
('90', 94, 3, 16, 180154) In India, public opinion, such as it is, has very little force and, moreover, the opinion of the millions who will be the sufferers is inarticulate.
('90', 94, 3, 17, 180303) Shri Mashruwala very aptly points out that the poor will be taxed without the odium of additional taxation.
('90', 94, 3, 18, 180411) Wisdom would have suggested that if the power is to be transferred inside of a few months to the representatives of the people, it would be improper for the Government to embark upon an experiment even though claimed to be scientific and yet manifestly against the immediate interests of the poor.
('90', 94, 3, 19, 180709) In a poor country like India, often the immediate is, as in this case, the decisive factor.
('90', 94, 3, 20, 180801) It is to be hoped that the Central Legislative Assembly will throw out the Bill if, on re considration, the Government do not withdraw it.
('90', 94, 4, 21, 180940) POONA, March 17, 1946 Harijan, 24 3 1946

('90', 95, 0, 1, 181065) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 95, 1, 2, 181106) 126. CAN WE AFFORD THE DECIMAL SYSTEM?
('90', 95, 2, 3, 181145) Shri Kishorelal Mashruwala writes : 1
('90', 95, 3, 4, 181183) This letter deserves to be studied.
('90', 95, 3, 5, 181219) He has pointed out a few instances of the immediate impact of decimal system on ordinary people.
('90', 95, 3, 6, 181316) Thoughtful readers can think of other instances which will go to prove that the loss to the poor on introducing the decimal system is likely to be very great.
('90', 95, 3, 7, 181475) It is easy to support the system on scientific grounds.
('90', 95, 3, 8, 181531) But popular dealings are not based [on science].
('90', 95, 3, 9, 181580) India is an unfortunate country where all manner of experiments are carried on in a high handed manner, and at the cost of the public exchequer, and the people have had to suffer in the name of science.
('90', 95, 3, 10, 181783) Would this be the last gift [of the British] to India on the eve of their leaving?
('90', 95, 3, 11, 181866) Even though the purpose of this Bill may be good, it should be abandoned.
('90', 95, 3, 12, 181940) When the people come to power, they may adopt the decimal system.
('90', 95, 3, 13, 182006) They may put up with the losses, if any, in adjusting to it.
('90', 95, 3, 14, 182067) But it is the duty of the Legislature to defeat this Bill.

('90', 96, 6, 16, 183789) 129. A NOTE
('90', 96, 7, 17, 183801) The foregoing statement 2 was issued on the 16th instant.
('90', 96, 7, 18, 183859) A wire was received today from Shri Sriramulu to the effect that he yielded to public pressure and broke his fast 3. I can be glad only if the ending of the fast means that the public has taken over the responsibility of having the temple opened without delay.
('90', 96, 7, 19, 184120) Ramachandra Rao’s letter received by me shows that there is a real legal difficulty about the opening, and the principal trustee is pledged to have the formality gone through and the temple opened.
('90', 96, 7, 20, 184318) It is to be hoped that the temple would be opened with the willing consent of the temple going people.

('90', 99, 1, 2, 187835) humorous chuckle.
('90', 99, 1, 3, 187853) In a way, hard to define, one felt that this man was speaking for India .
('90', 99, 1, 4, 187927) He warned me, nonetheless, that he would be speaking only for himself and not for the Congress.
('90', 99, 1, 5, 188023) Our talk took its start from the Prime Minister’s recognition of India’s right to choose independence.
('90', 99, 1, 6, 188126) This, Gandhi welcomed, and not only this, but the whole tone of the speech.
('90', 99, 1, 7, 188202) He went on : But I can’t forget that the story of Britain’s connection with India is a tragedy of unfulfilled promises and disappointed hopes.
('90', 99, 1, 8, 188345) We must keep an open mind.
('90', 99, 1, 9, 188372) A seeker of truth will never begin by discounting his opponent’s statement as unworthy of trust.
('90', 99, 1, 10, 188469) So I am hopeful, and, indeed, no responsible Indian feels otherwise.
('90', 99, 1, 11, 188538) This time I believe that the British mean business.
('90', 99, 1, 12, 188590) But the offer has come suddenly.
('90', 99, 1, 13, 188623) Will India be jerked into independence?
('90', 99, 1, 14, 188663) I feel today like a passenger who has been hoisted in a basketchair on to a ship’s deck in a stormy sea and has not yet found his feet.
('90', 99, 1, 15, 188799) There should have been some psychological preparation, but even now it is not too late.
('90', 99, 1, 16, 188887) The tide of bitterness had risen high and that is not good for the soul.
('90', 99, 1, 17, 188960) The last two months should have been filled with generous gestures.
('90', 99, 1, 18, 189028) This is a milestone not only in India’s history and Britain’s, but in the history of the whole world.
('90', 99, 1, 19, 189130) Gandhiji’s meaning was clear.
('90', 99, 1, 20, 189160) The British Government had done the right thing, but in its manner of doing it, he missed the big touch.
('90', 99, 1, 21, 189265) When I asked him for concrete illustrations, he chose two.
('90', 99, 1, 22, 189324) The release of the political prisoners had been gradual and was still incomplete.
('90', 99, 1, 23, 189406) [He added :] There was no danger to fear.
('90', 99, 1, 24, 189448) If independence is coming, would these men have opposed it?
('90', 99, 1, 25, 189508) A complete amnesty would have captured the people’s imagination.
('90', 99, 1, 26, 189573) When you are about to transfer power, you should do it boldly.
('90', 99, 1, 27, 189636) He went on to speak of the Salt Tax.
('90', 99, 1, 28, 189673) Its abolition would be a gesture the poorest peasant could understand.
('90', 99, 1, 29, 189744) It would mean even more to him than independence itself.
('90', 99, 1, 30, 189801) Salt in this climate is a necessity of life, like air and water.
('90', 99, 1, 31, 189866) He needs it for himself, his cattle and his land.
('90', 99, 1, 32, 189916) This monopoly will go, the instant we get independence.
('90', 99, 1, 33, 189972) Then why not abolish it today?
('90', 99, 1, 34, 190003) By such acts the Government could have created a feeling among the masses that the new era has already dawned.
('90', 99, 2, 35, 190114) reminded Gandhi that many Englishmen find it hard to understand why Indians prefer independence to Dominion Status.
('90', 99, 2, 36, 190230) His answer was startling.
('90', 99, 2, 37, 190256) There was a time when I used to swear by Dominion Status, and actually preferred it to independence.
('90', 99, 2, 38, 190357) That was my attitude during the first World War.
('90', 99, 2, 39, 190406) I even used, in writing 1 to Lord Chelmsford, the Viceroy of those days, an expression that has often been quoted

('90', 100, 1, 3, 190613) I wanted to evoke in the Indian breast the same loyalty to the British Crown that there is in the breast of an Englishman.
('90', 100, 1, 4, 190736) It was an English footballer who converted me to independence.
('90', 100, 2, 5, 190799) With a laugh, Gandhi explained that he was referring to C. F. Andrews, who had been a notable athlete at Cambridge, as well as a don.
('90', 100, 2, 6, 190933) Gandhi added : Andrews made me understand the significance of the King Emperor’s title.
('90', 100, 2, 7, 191021) The British king is king also in the Dominions, but he is the Emperor of India.
('90', 100, 2, 8, 191101) India alone makes the Empire.
('90', 100, 2, 9, 191131) The Dominions are peopled by your cousins.
('90', 100, 2, 10, 191174) But we Indians, with our different culture and traditions, can never belong to the British family.
('90', 100, 2, 11, 191273) We may belong to a world wide family of nations, but first we must cease to be under dogs.
('90', 100, 2, 12, 191364) So I set myself to win independence.
('90', 100, 2, 13, 191401) You may object that by so doing I am throwing away the protection of the British army and navy.
('90', 100, 2, 14, 191497) India would not need them, if she were truly non violent.
('90', 100, 2, 15, 191555) If, in the glow of freedom, she could live up to that creed, no power on earth would ever cast an evil eye upon her.
('90', 100, 2, 16, 191672) That would be India’s crowning glory and her contribution to the world’s progress.
('90', 100, 2, 17, 191755) If only Englishmen could follow this argument of mine, they would make their offer of independence in a different tone altogether.
('90', 100, 2, 18, 191886) Today they insist that Dominion Staus is the best gift they can possibly bestow : ‘For the world’s sake and for ours as well as your own, you shall have independence today, even as we have it.
('90', 100, 2, 19, 192079) .’ I asked Gandhi to face the anxieties of his English listeners and tell them whether whether Indian independence would make for Britain’s security and the world’s.
('90', 100, 2, 20, 192245) He answered that the British need never fear an independent India.
('90', 100, 2, 21, 192312) If they leave India as willing friends, she in her turn will always remain friendly.
('90', 100, 2, 22, 192397) But Britain, I told him, might hope for some assurance of friendship.
('90', 100, 2, 23, 192467) Would an independent India be willing to enter into an alliance with Britain?
('90', 100, 2, 24, 192545) Gandhi’s answer came promptly : Supposing India said ‘No’, would you make the recognition of India’s independence contingent upon her entering into an alliance with Britain?
('90', 100, 2, 25, 192719) If you did that, it would immediately lower the value of your offer and rob it of all grace.
('90', 100, 2, 26, 192812) The proper attitude is to meet India’s claims as a matter of right, even if she wanted to be unfriendly and pay you back in your own coin.
('90', 100, 2, 27, 192951) No calculations entered into the British mind, when they settled with the Boers at the end 1 of a bloody war, and the Boers have stayed friends ever since.
('90', 100, 2, 28, 193107) I replied that Britain has made up her mind to end the coercive connection with India.
('90', 100, 2, 29, 193194) But living as she does in a perilous would it is inevitable that she should ask the question whether as an ally in a defensive war she would be entitled to use

('90', 101, 1, 2, 193414) India’s strategic bases and ports against India give a reassuring reply?
('90', 101, 1, 3, 193487) Gandhiji answered : Englishmen must learn to be Brahmins, not Banias.
('90', 101, 1, 4, 193557) The Bania, I should explain, is the trader, or as Napoleon put it, the shopkeeper.
('90', 101, 1, 5, 193640) The Brahmin is the man who is intelligent enough to rank the moral above the material values of life.
('90', 101, 1, 6, 193742) A Gujarati novelist has said that Englishmen are soldiers and Brahmins, but not Banias.
('90', 101, 1, 7, 193830) That was a generous verdict, but it was mistaken.
('90', 101, 1, 8, 193880) Englishmen have still to evolve the Brahminical spirit.
('90', 101, 1, 9, 193936) Even the British soldier still calculates and bargains like a Bania, and fails to reach the highest type of courage.
('90', 101, 1, 10, 194053) I still cherish the hope that the British will respond to the non violent spirit of India.
('90', 101, 1, 11, 194144) As the author of that movement, I know what it has meant for the world.
('90', 101, 1, 12, 194216) The non violent spirit is the greatest thing in life.
('90', 101, 1, 13, 194270) I feel it is my responsibility to help my brothers not to degrade themselves by bargaining.
('90', 101, 1, 14, 194362) If you and we can rise to this moral height, no danger can alarm us.
('90', 101, 1, 15, 194431) It is probable that many members of the Congress will not take this view and may be willing to discuss an alliance today.
('90', 101, 1, 16, 194553) But independence would come free as air; don’t let us bargain over it.
('90', 101, 2, 17, 194624) In reply to a further question, whether a defensive alliance might be discussed when independence is ratified by treaty, Gandhi replied : If India feels the glow of independence, she probably would enter into such a treaty of her own free will.
('90', 101, 2, 18, 194869) The spontaneous friendship bet ween India and Britain would then be extended to other powers and among them, they would hold the balance, since they alone would possess moral force.
('90', 101, 2, 19, 195051) To see that vision realized, I want to live for 125 years.
('90', 101, 2, 20, 195110) He said that he hoped for a mutually helpful commercial treaty between a friendly Britain and an independent India.
('90', 101, 2, 21, 195226) For goods that India needed to import, he was even ready to give Britain a preference.
('90', 101, 2, 22, 195313) While we talked of Pakistan, Gandhi said that if no other method of solution succeeded, he was prepared to submit the whole issue to international arbitration.
('90', 101, 2, 23, 195473) Nor should we forget that expedient, if any insoluble question arose between Britain and India, for example, over debts.
('90', 101, 2, 24, 195594) But he saw no blank wall of difficulty ahead.
('90', 101, 2, 25, 195640) His last words were that difficulties make the man.
('90', 101, 3, 26, 195692) Harijan, 14 4 1946
('90', 101, 4, 27, 195711) 1 Brailsford concluded : “I came away with the sense that I had been talking to a brave man who has the courage to believe that human society can be built only on moral principles.
('90', 101, 4, 28, 195892) Amid our preoccupations over military perils, he stands aloof and repeats with unshaken faith his creed that safety is attainable, only when men learn to treat each other as brothers and equals.
('90', 101, 4, 29, 196087) No lesser means will avail.”

('90', 106, 4, 6, 200830) 143. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 2
('90', 106, 5, 7, 200860) Course of events has raised the question of South Africa whiteman’s policy to the highest level.
('90', 106, 5, 8, 200957) Unseen, it holds the seeds of a world war.
('90', 106, 5, 9, 201000) The threatened Land and Franchise Bill which has brought the South African Indian delegation 3 to India, though superficially it affects the Indians of Natal and the Transvaal, is in effect a challenge to Asia and by implication to the Negro races.
('90', 106, 5, 10, 201249) India in her present exalted mood can view it in no other way.
('90', 106, 5, 11, 201312) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru is Indian to the core but, being also an internationalist, he has made us used to looking at everything in the international light instead of the parochial.
('90', 106, 5, 12, 201493) India, weak physically and materially but strong ethically and numerically, has proclaimed from the house tops that her independence would be a threat to no one and no nation, but will be a help to noble effort throughout the world and promise of relief to all its exploited peoples.
('90', 106, 5, 13, 201777) Therefore India regards the contemplated measure of the Union of South Africa as an insult and challenge to them.
('90', 106, 6, 14, 201891) The Indian deputation see in the present measure not merely an assault on Indian property rights but also on their status as free men.
('90', 106, 6, 15, 202026) They do not want merely to exsit in South Africa.
('90', 106, 6, 16, 202076) They need not have sent the deputation all the way to India for that purpose.
('90', 106, 6, 17, 202154) They want to be in South Africa as equals of the European settlers of South Africa.

('90', 107, 2, 27, 204646) 144. FAMINES AND BIRTH RATE
('90', 107, 3, 28, 204674) Sir John McGaw, President, India Office Medical Board, is reported by a correspondent to have said :
('90', 107, 4, 29, 204775) Famines in India will recur; in fact India is today facing perpetual famine.
('90', 107, 4, 30, 204852) Unless something is done to decrease the birth rate in India, the country will be heading straight for a calamity.
('90', 107, 4, 31, 204967) The correspondent asks what I have to say on this grave issue.
('90', 108, 0, 1, 205030) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 109
('90', 108, 1, 2, 205074) For me this and some other ways of explaining away famines in India is to divert the attention from the only cause of recurring famines in this benighted land.
('90', 108, 1, 3, 205234) I have stated 1, and repeat here, that famines of India are not a calamity descended upon us from nature but is a calamity created by the rulers—whether through ignorant indifference or whether consciously or otherwise does not matter.
('90', 108, 1, 4, 205470) Prevention against drought is not beyond human effort and ingenuity.
('90', 108, 1, 5, 205539) Such effort has not proved ineffective in other countries.
('90', 108, 1, 6, 205598) In India a sustained intelligent effort has never been made.
('90', 108, 1, 7, 205659) The bogey of increasing birth rate is not a new thing.
('90', 108, 1, 8, 205714) It has been often trotted out.
('90', 108, 1, 9, 205745) Increase in population is not, and ought not, to be regarded as a calamity to be avoided.
('90', 108, 1, 10, 205835) Its regulation or restriction by artificial methods is a calamity of the first grade whether we know it or not.
('90', 108, 1, 11, 205947) It is bound to degrade the race, if it becomes universal which, thank God, it is never likely to be.
('90', 108, 1, 12, 206048) Pestilence, wars and famines are cursed antidotes against cursed lust which is responsible for unwanted children.
('90', 108, 1, 13, 206162) If we would avoid this three fold curse, we would avoid too the curse of unwanted children by the sovereign remedy of self control.
('90', 108, 1, 14, 206294) The evil consequences of artificial methods are being seen by discerning men even now.
('90', 108, 1, 15, 206381) Without, however, encroaching upon the moral domain, let me say that propagation of the race rabbit wise must undoubtedly be stopped; but not so as to bring greater evils in its train.
('90', 108, 1, 16, 206566) It should be stopped by methods which in themselves ennoble the race.
('90', 108, 1, 17, 206636) In other words, it is all a matter of proper education which would embrace every department of life; and dealing with one curse will take in its orbit all the others.
('90', 108, 1, 18, 206803) A way is not to be avoided because it is upward and therefore uphill.
('90', 108, 1, 19, 206873) Man’s upward progress necessarily means ever increasing difficulty, which is to be welcomed.
('90', 108, 1, 20, 206966) POONA, March 19, 1946 Harijan, 31 3 1946

('90', 114, 10, 24, 216448) 158. CONGRESSMEN APATHETIC
('90', 114, 11, 25, 216475) Q. I am glad that you have expressed yourself in the matter of opening a temple to Harijans in Nellore.
('90', 114, 11, 26, 216579) 1 It should open the eyes of
('90', 114, 12, 27, 216608) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 16 3 1946
('90', 115, 0, 1, 216651) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 115, 1, 2, 216693) many Congressmen.
('90', 115, 1, 3, 216711) The reason given for unwillingness to open the temple was that it might adversely affect the chances of Congress success in the elections.
('90', 115, 2, 4, 216850) A. If this represents the general sentiment, it augurs ill for Congress.
('90', 115, 2, 5, 216923) Even a popular, democratic, India wide organization like the Congress cannot afford to be untrue to its policy (if it may not be called creed) of removing untouchability, root and branch.
('90', 115, 2, 6, 217111) Through out my close contact with the Congress, ever since my return to India in 1915, I have found that the more the Congress has held to its main purpose, the more popular it had become.
('90', 115, 2, 7, 217300) A democratic organization has to dare to do the right at all cost.
('90', 115, 2, 8, 217367) He who panders to the weaknesses of a people degrades both himself and the people and leads them not to democratic but mob rule.
('90', 115, 2, 9, 217496) The line of demarcation between democracy and mobocracy is often thin but rigid and stronger than steel, unbreakable.
('90', 115, 2, 10, 217614) The one leads to life and progress, the other is death, pure and simple.
('90', 115, 2, 11, 217687) In the ultimate analysis, the cause of our fall is to be sought from within and not from without.
('90', 115, 2, 12, 217785) All the empires of the world could not have bent us, if as a people we had been above suspicion and temptation.
('90', 115, 2, 13, 217897) This may not be regarded as a mere truism.
('90', 115, 2, 14, 217940) If we recognize the fundamental facts, we would be true and patient and able to deal with whatever difficulty that may face us whether from within or without.
('90', 115, 2, 15, 218099) Preparedness to lose all elections rather than sacrifice a principle, is the surest way to success at every election.
('90', 115, 2, 16, 218217) The results prove that the policy laid down by the Congress in 1920 has led to success from stage to stage, but only to the extent that the Congress has been true to the fundamentals of the policy, it accepted during that eventful year.
('90', 115, 2, 17, 218454) Untouchability is to go, if India is to live and thrive as a nation.
('90', 115, 2, 18, 218523) POONA, March 21, 1946 Harijan, 31 3 1946

('90', 126, 1, 2, 235988) 176. QUESTION BOX
('90', 126, 2, 3, 236006) Q. What to do when the local Congress machinery refuses to act or work in a way which is effective?
('90', 126, 3, 4, 236106) A. A person who is a real Congressman will, in such circumst ances, himself act singly or in co operation with others purely in a spirit of service and give all the credit to the Congress organization.
('90', 126, 3, 5, 236308) Supposing that many persons acted thus, Congress would rise from day to day.
('90', 126, 3, 6, 236385) Ineffective workers would be shamed into becoming effective, the Congress machinery always remaining clean and intact.
('90', 126, 3, 7, 236504) “In a spirit of service” is here the operative phrase.
('90', 126, 3, 8, 236559) If the spirit is that of aggrandizement, although the work done may be effective, credit will probably go to the aggressor and the Congress will lose.
('90', 126, 3, 9, 236710) That the aggressor will lose in the end need not be stressed.
('90', 126, 4, 10, 236772) Q. What should a Congress worker do when he faces a situation at a place which is outside his area of work?
('90', 126, 5, 11, 236880) A. Areas are prescribed for workers for their weakness, not for their strength.
('90', 126, 5, 12, 236960) For a strong Congress worker all India is the area of his work, and he will be found every time in the area where he is wanted most.
('90', 126, 5, 13, 237093) Naturally he will be never regarded as an intruder or as an officious man.
('90', 126, 5, 14, 237168) Appreciation of the service will be uppermost in the minds of all.
('90', 126, 5, 15, 237235) It would be ludicrous and a sign of impotence, if a Congressman passing through an area not his own and finding a battle royal between two factions does not interpose himself between them, even at the cost of his life, on the untenable plea that the trouble was outside his area.
('90', 126, 5, 16, 237515) Q. Can the same person take up parliamentary work, constru ctive work as distinguished from the parliamentary and the organiz ation work of the Congress, in addition to working for his own livelihood?
('90', 126, 5, 17, 237716) A. He must be a modern Hercules who can effectively do these things at the same time.
('90', 126, 5, 18, 237802) I can conceive the possibility of the same person managing all these departments with a staff of efficient secretaries and clerks working under him.
('90', 126, 5, 19, 237951) The point of the question, however, is wholly different.
('90', 126, 5, 20, 238008) Division of labour is a necessity.
('90', 126, 5, 21, 238043) One man show is always undesirable and is a positive hindrance to a system of organization.
('90', 126, 5, 22, 238135) An organization like the British kingship is not personal.
('90', 126, 5, 23, 238194) “The King is dead.
('90', 126, 5, 24, 238213) Long live the King.” Hence the saying, “the King can do no wrong.” A king as an individual may be
('90', 127, 0, 1, 238311) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 127, 1, 2, 238353) a rascal but personified as an organization he is perfect in the sense the word ‘perfection’ is understood in a given society.
('90', 127, 1, 3, 238480) The moral is that however inefficient the persons in charge may be in the begin ning stages, in a progressive organization, persons taking charg should be above board and should put the organization first, themselves last.
('90', 127, 1, 4, 238703) If an attempt is made to organize work through rascals, the organiza tion will always have rescals at its head.
('90', 127, 1, 5, 238815) Q. August 1942 has brought a psychological change in the public mind.
('90', 127, 1, 6, 238885) They do not await orders from the Congress for observance of days, etc.
('90', 127, 1, 7, 238957) Other parties often take advantage of this spontaneous effort and associate their programme with it, while official local Congress either keeps mum or inactive.
('90', 127, 1, 8, 239118) It also often happens that programmes and policies as laid down by the Working Committee are not automatically adopted by the Provincial Congress Committees or are sometimes worked out half heartedly.
('90', 127, 1, 9, 239319) Some also refuse to create a machinary for it, till they are officially called upon to do so.
('90', 127, 1, 10, 239413) In such circumstances, what is expected of Congressmen?
('90', 127, 1, 11, 239469) A. This is a good question.
('90', 127, 1, 12, 239497) If Congressmen have really learnt to act for themselves since August 1942, it is a great thing.
('90', 127, 1, 13, 239593) But I do not believe it.
('90', 127, 1, 14, 239618) Those only act for themselves who think for themselves.
('90', 127, 1, 15, 239674) It does not matter whether in doing so they make mistakes.
('90', 127, 1, 16, 239733) A child often stumbles before it begins to walk.
('90', 127, 1, 17, 239782) Therefore the effort ceases to be spontaneous or individual when one associates with any programme that comes his way.
('90', 127, 1, 18, 239901) The secret of the August resolution was that when the Congress as an organization ceased to function every Congressman became his own master, which is wholy different from becoming a pawn in any other person’s or group’s or party’s game.
('90', 127, 1, 19, 240139) The second part of the question shows also that 1942 did not teach Congressmen to think and act independently.
('90', 127, 1, 20, 240250) If they had learnt that lesson truly and well, any programme laid down by the Working Committee would be followed by Congressmen whole heartedly and the response from Provincial Committees and all constituent elements would be spon taneous, such that the whole organization would move like one man.
('90', 127, 1, 21, 240549) Such was my expectation in 1942. That it was not so fulfilled is a matter of history.
('90', 127, 1, 22, 240635) That the people acted somehow, without being paralysed by the wholesale onslaught of the Govern ment, stands to their credit.
('90', 127, 1, 23, 240761) How much more creditable it would have been, if they had fully carried out the policy of non violence explicitly laid down in that resolution!
('90', 127, 1, 24, 240904) If my argument is correct, it
('90', 128, 0, 1, 240934) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 129
('90', 128, 1, 2, 240978) follows that Congressmen with understanding would follow implicitly laid down in the resolution!
('90', 128, 1, 3, 241075) If my argument is correct, it follows that Congressmen with understanding would follow implicitly the Working Committee’s resolutions without reference to the action of their neighbours.
('90', 128, 1, 4, 241262) When organizational effort stops or is neutra lized or becomes ineffective, every individual belonging to it holds him self responsible for the activity of his organization and then gradually builds it up.
('90', 128, 2, 5, 241468) Q. When sporadic strikes are such as cannot be supported by the Congress, what should Congressmen and the public do to put an end to them?
('90', 128, 3, 6, 241607) A. In the first place, if the Congress organization were complete, there would be no sporadic strikes, and any other strike would be unjustified for the simple reason that a people’s organiza tion must shoulder the burden of every justifiable strike within the sphere of that organization.
('90', 128, 3, 7, 241897) But today unhappily the Congress, powerful as it is, has not attained that supreme position.
('90', 128, 3, 8, 241990) Hence every sporadic strike has to be judged on merits irrespective of the party that has made itself responsible for it.
('90', 128, 3, 9, 242112) And, when a strike is indefensible on merits, the Congress and the public should unequivocally condemn it.
('90', 128, 3, 10, 242219) The natural result would be that the men on strike would go back to work.
('90', 128, 3, 11, 242293) If the strike is justified, the institution against which it has been declared would be likewise condemned, if it employs black legs or other questionable means to force strikers into submission.
('90', 128, 3, 12, 242489) URULI [ KANCHAN], March 23, 1946 Harijan, 31 3 1946
('90', 128, 4, 13, 242541) 177. CAPITALISM AND STRIKES How should capital behave when labour strikes?
('90', 128, 4, 14, 242616) This question is in the air and has great importance at the present moment.
('90', 128, 4, 15, 242692) One way is that of suppression named, or nicknamed, ‘American’.
('90', 128, 4, 16, 242756) It consists in suppression of labour through organized goondaism.
('90', 128, 4, 17, 242822) Everybody would consider this as wrong and destructive.
('90', 128, 4, 18, 242878) The other way, right and honourable, consists in considering every strike on its merits and giving labour its due—not what capital considers as due but what labour itself would so consider and enlightened public opinion acclaim as just.
('90', 128, 4, 19, 243115) One preliminary question will justly arise : why should there be a strike at all in any well regulated concern?
('90', 128, 4, 20, 243227) Strikes ought to be
('90', 129, 0, 1, 243247) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 129, 1, 2, 243289) impossible when there is perfect understanding between capital and labour, mutual respect and recognition of equality.
('90', 129, 1, 3, 243408) And since differences there would be sometimes between employers and employed even in the best regulated concerns, why should there not be a system of arbitration between the parties so that they will always readily carry out in perfect good faith awards of arbitrators?
('90', 129, 1, 4, 243679) But we have to consider things not as they should be but as they are.
('90', 129, 1, 5, 243749) As time progresses, the labour world is getting more insistent in its demands which are daily increasing, and it does not hesitate to resort to violence in its impatient enforcement of those demands.
('90', 129, 1, 6, 243949) New methods of enforcing them are being employed.
('90', 129, 1, 7, 243999) Workers do not hesitate to injure the property of the employers, dislocate machinery, harass old men and women who would not join the strike and forcibly keep out black legs.
('90', 129, 1, 8, 244174) In these circumstances, how are the employers to behave?
('90', 129, 1, 9, 244231) In my opinion, employers and employed are equal partners even if employees are not considered superior.
('90', 129, 1, 10, 244335) But what we see today is the reverse.
('90', 129, 1, 11, 244373) The reason is that the employers harness intelligance on their side.
('90', 129, 1, 12, 244442) They have the superior advantage which concentration of capital bring with it, and they know how to make use of it.
('90', 129, 1, 13, 244558) One individual rupee has very little potency, but when money combines as capital, the combine derives a power different from and far in excess of the mere sum total of the individual rupees.
('90', 129, 1, 14, 244749) A million drops individually are negligible.
('90', 129, 1, 15, 244794) But in combination they make the ocean carrying on its bosom a fleet of ocean hounds.
('90', 129, 1, 16, 244880) Whilst capital in India is fairly organized, labour is still in a more or less disorganized condition in spite of unions and their federation.
('90', 129, 1, 17, 245023) Therefore it lacks the power that true combination gives.
('90', 129, 1, 18, 245081) Moreover it lacks intelligence, so much so that individuals fight against individuals, unions against unions.
('90', 129, 1, 19, 245191) Lack of intelligence leads to its exploitation by selfish and unscrupulous men even to the point of creating and promoting mischief.
('90', 129, 1, 20, 245324) They know no better, being ignorant of the secret of non violence.
('90', 129, 1, 21, 245391) The net result is that the workers suffer.
('90', 129, 1, 22, 245434) If labour were to understand the working of non violence, the power generated by combination would any day exceed the power of dead metal in the hands of a few capitalists.
('90', 129, 1, 23, 245607) Hence my advice to the employers would be that they should willingly regard workers as the real owners of the concerns which they fancy they have created.
('90', 129, 1, 24, 245762) They should further regard it as their duty to equip the employees with sound education that would draw out the
('90', 130, 0, 1, 245874) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 131
('90', 130, 1, 2, 245918) intelligence dormant in them and gladly promote and welcome the power that this combination of the workers gives them.
('90', 130, 1, 3, 246037) This noble work cannot be done in a day by the employers.
('90', 130, 1, 4, 246095) Meanwhile what should those do who have to face the destruction wrought by strikers in their concerns?
('90', 130, 1, 5, 246198) I would unhesitatingly advise such employers that they should at once offer the strikers full control of the concern which is as much the strikers’ as theirs.
('90', 130, 1, 6, 246357) They will vacate their premises not in a huff but because it is right, and, to show their goodwill, they would offer the employees the assistance of their engineers and other skilled staff.
('90', 130, 1, 7, 246547) The employers will find in the end that they will lose nothing.
('90', 130, 1, 8, 246611) Indeed their right action will disarm opposition, and they will earn the blessings of their men.
('90', 130, 1, 9, 246708) They will have made proper use of their capital.
('90', 130, 1, 10, 246757) I would not consider such action as benevolent.
('90', 130, 1, 11, 246805) It would be an intelligent use by the capitalists of their resources and honest dealing in regard to the employees whom they would have converted into honourable partners.
('90', 130, 1, 12, 246977) URULI [ KANCHAN], March 1946 Harijan, 31 3 1946

('90', 134, 1, 2, 253407) 184. WASTEFULNESS 1
('90', 134, 2, 3, 253427) Correspondence continues to pour in saying that stored food material, being declared unfit for human consumption, is thrown away.
('90', 134, 2, 4, 253557) Skimmed milk also is thrown away for want of custom and condensed milk is lying idle owing to ignorance.
('90', 134, 2, 5, 253662) Accumulation of food material at the ports will not mitigate distress unless it is promptly taken to the places where it is immediately required.
('90', 134, 2, 6, 253808) Worse than this, however, is the triple waste going on now side by side with ever growing famine conditions.
('90', 134, 2, 7, 253917) All such waste takes place for lack of a living contact between the people and the rulers.
('90', 134, 2, 8, 254008) URULI [ KANCHAN], March 24, 1946 Harijan, 31 3 1946
('90', 134, 3, 9, 254060) 185. HAND WEAVING AND HAND SPINNING 2
('90', 134, 4, 10, 254098) Shri Jajuji writes to say that whilst on the one hand hand spun yarn is piling up, on the other handloom weavers are day by day giving up hand spun yarn in preference to mill yarn.
('90', 134, 4, 11, 254279) An appeal to the weavers through the columns of Harijan, whether in English or in any of the Indian languages, will be good for nothing.
('90', 134, 4, 12, 254416) Hardly any weaver reads Harijan and, if attempt is made to read it out to him, he will not take inte rest in it.
('90', 134, 4, 13, 254529) Hence the task of speaking to the weavers on the suicidal effect of abandoning hand spun yarn devolves upon the devoted heads of Charkha Sangh workers.
('90', 134, 4, 14, 254681) They have to reason out to the weavers how they will be ultimately responsible for killing their own occupation by excluding hand spun yarn.
('90', 134, 4, 15, 254822) As soon as the mill owners can do so profitably, they will certainly stop selling mill yarn and will weave it themselves.
('90', 134, 4, 16, 254944) They are not philanthropists.
('90', 134, 4, 17, 254974) They have set up mills in order to make money.
('90', 134, 4, 18, 255021) They will stop selling their yarn to handloom weavers, if they find weaving is more profitable.
('90', 134, 4, 19, 255117) Therefore it is a question of time when handloom weavers will be starved.
('90', 134, 4, 20, 255191) These are really fed by hand spinners even as they in their
('90', 134, 5, 21, 255251) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.
('90', 134, 5, 22, 255282) 2 Originally written in Gujarati, this appeared as “form Harijanbandhu” published simultaneously with the source.
('90', 135, 0, 1, 255396) 136 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 135, 1, 2, 255438) turn are fed by handloom weavers.
('90', 135, 1, 3, 255472) They are twins, complementary of each other.
('90', 135, 1, 4, 255517) This fact should be brought home to the weavers by the Charkha Sangh.
('90', 135, 1, 5, 255587) With loving patience and knowledge they should try to appreciate the difficulties of the weavers and learn how to remove them.
('90', 135, 1, 6, 255714) Acharya Vinoba has pointed out one remedy, namely, to double and twist the yarn at the same time that the cones are unwound.
('90', 135, 1, 7, 255839) If this practice becomes universal, there would be no untwisted hand spun yarn available for weaving.
('90', 135, 1, 8, 255941) It is found by experience that twisted hand spun yarn is any day as weavable as mill spun yarn, if indeed it is not more so.
('90', 135, 1, 9, 256066) Since the time of my discharge from my last imprisonment, I have been proclaiming as vehemently as I can that the workers should master the art of weaving as well as they have mastered the art of spinning.
('90', 135, 1, 10, 256272) Had they not taken to spinning themselves, they would not have solved the many difficulties of spinners.
('90', 135, 1, 11, 256377) They have now to make up for past neglect, however unconscious it may have been, by learning the art of weaving and by practising it assiduously.
('90', 135, 1, 12, 256523) Then and then only will they understand the difficulties that professional weavers experience in weaving hand spun yarn and be able to solve them.

('90', 136, 1, 2, 256765) 186. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, URULI KANCHAN 1
('90', 136, 2, 3, 256812) March 24, 1946 This is good 2 , because it show that those who need nature cure treatment are coming forward to avail themselves of it.
('90', 136, 3, 4, 256948) If the work proceeded according to plan, Gandhiji explained, he intended to stay for at least four months in the year in their midst.
('90', 136, 3, 5, 257082) During his absence his colleagues would continue to direct and guide them according to his instructions.
('90', 136, 3, 6, 257187) [He said:] The practice of nature cure does not require high academic quali fications or much erudition.
('90', 136, 3, 7, 257292) Simplicity is the essence of universality.
('90', 136, 3, 8, 257335) Nothing that is meant for the benefit of the rich only.
('90', 136, 3, 9, 257391) But India lives in her seven lakhs of villages—obscure, tiny, out of the way villages—where the population in some cases hardly exceeds a few hundreds, very often not even a few scores.
('90', 136, 3, 10, 257577) I would like to go and settle down in some such village.
('90', 136, 3, 11, 257634) That is real India, my India, for which I live.
('90', 136, 3, 12, 257682) You cannot take to these humble people the parapher nalia of highly qualified doctors and hospital equipment.
('90', 136, 3, 13, 257792) In simple, natural remedies and Ramanama lies their only hope.
('90', 136, 4, 14, 257855) He had been told that there was hardly any disease in Uruli[ Kanchan].
('90', 136, 4, 15, 257926) Probably what was meant was that no epidemic was prevalent, that being the popular conception of disease.
('90', 136, 4, 16, 258032) But, from the cases that had come to him during the last two days, it was clear that ill health there was in plenty in Uruli.
('90', 136, 4, 17, 258158) He told the villagers: If you do as I ask you to, Uruli will become an ideal village, to see which people will come from far.
('90', 136, 4, 18, 258284) Man’s physical body is composed of five natural elements, i.
('90', 136, 4, 19, 258345) e., air, water, earth, fire or tejas (the energizing principle) and ether (space).
('90', 136, 4, 20, 258428) The soul quickens it.
('90', 136, 4, 21, 258450) The most essential of these is air.
('90', 136, 4, 22, 258486) Man can live without food for several weeks, without water for some time, but without air he cannot live for more than a few minutes.
('90', 136, 4, 23, 258620) God has, therefore, made air universally available.
('90', 136, 4, 24, 258672) Shortages of food or water there may be at times but of air never.
('90', 136, 4, 25, 258739) In spite of it we foolishly deprive ourselves of God’s
('90', 136, 5, 26, 258794) 1 This is extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter—I”.
('90', 136, 5, 27, 258849) 2 The reference is to increase in number of patients from 30 to 43.
('90', 137, 0, 1, 258917) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 137, 1, 2, 258959) blessings of fresh and pure air by sleeping within doors with doors and windows shut.
('90', 137, 1, 3, 259045) One may shut the doors and windows, if he is afraid of thieves at night.
('90', 137, 1, 4, 259118) But why should one shut oneself up?
('90', 137, 1, 5, 259154) To get fresh air, one must sleep in the open.
('90', 137, 1, 6, 259200) But it is no good sleeping in the open only to breathe dust and dirt laden air.
('90', 137, 1, 7, 259280) The place where you sleep must be free from both.
('90', 137, 1, 8, 259330) Some people cover their faces as a protection against dust and cold.
('90', 137, 1, 9, 259399) It is a remedy worse than the disease.
('90', 137, 1, 10, 259438) Then there is the evil habit of breathing through the mouth.
('90', 137, 1, 11, 259499) Mouth is the organ of ingestion.
('90', 137, 1, 12, 259532) It is not the organ of breathing.
('90', 137, 1, 13, 259566) The air passing through the nasal passages is filtered and purified and at the same time warmed up before it enters the lungs.
('90', 137, 1, 14, 259693) Anyone who fouls the air by spitting about carelessly, throwing refuse and rubbish or otherwise dirtying the ground, sins against man and nature.
('90', 137, 1, 15, 259839) Man’s body is the temple of God.
('90', 137, 1, 16, 259872) Anyone who fouls the air that is to enter that temple desecrates it.
('90', 137, 1, 17, 259941) He takes the name of Rama in vain.
('90', 137, 2, 18, 259976) In the end, he warned them that they should be prepared to find in him a hard task master.
('90', 137, 2, 19, 260067) If he stayed in their midst, he would neither spare himself nor them.
('90', 137, 2, 20, 260137) He would visit their homes, inspect their streets, their drains, their kitchens, their latrines.
('90', 137, 2, 21, 260234) He would tolerate neither dust nor dirt anywhere.
('90', 137, 2, 22, 260284) Harijan, 7 4 1946
('90', 137, 3, 23, 260302) 187. WHY BHANGI QUARTERS?
('90', 137, 4, 24, 260328) Friends are puzzled over my keen desire to reside in Bhangi quarters in the cities or towns I may visit.
('90', 137, 4, 25, 260433) To ask why I have not entertained that desire all these years would be more pertinent.
('90', 137, 4, 26, 260520) To answer why I did not have the desire long ago must be reserved for a future occasion.
('90', 137, 4, 27, 260609) Just now I must answer why the desire has come upon me at all.
('90', 137, 4, 28, 260672) I have for some time been saying that we must all be Bhangis or untouchables.
('90', 137, 4, 29, 260750) But it has worried me that I have not accorded the statement with corresponding action.
('90', 137, 4, 30, 260838) It may not be possible to establish complete accordance with the wish.
('90', 137, 4, 31, 260909) But it ought to be done so far as possible.
('90', 137, 4, 32, 260953) Whilst this thought was agitating me, I got the news, which I have already shared with the readers, that in Gujarat
('90', 137, 5, 33, 261069) 1 Originally written in Hindi, this appeared as “from Harijan Sevak” Published simultaneously with the source.
('90', 138, 0, 1, 261180) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 139
('90', 138, 1, 2, 261224) only one well and one temple is shared with Harijans and this in Karadi.
('90', 138, 1, 3, 261297) 1 Whether the news is true or not is immaterial here.
('90', 138, 1, 4, 261351) The material thing is the reaction produced on my mind by the news.
('90', 138, 1, 5, 261419) To be angry was madness.
('90', 138, 1, 6, 261444) The news quickened the desire for residence in untouchables’quarters.
('90', 138, 1, 7, 261514) I said to myself: ‘If I lived apart from Harij ans, what right had I to question the action of others who went further in their adherence to untouchability?
('90', 138, 1, 8, 261671) But whether the others changed their mode or not was not for me to judge.
('90', 138, 1, 9, 261745) If it was my duty to reside in Harijan quarters, I must perform it irrespective of the reaction of the step on the others.’ This is the thought which is possessing me and goading me to the adumbrated action.
('90', 138, 1, 10, 261953) Consequently I have asked Sheth R. D. Birla to arrange, if at all possible, for my residence in untouchables’ quarters when I happen to be in Bombay.
('90', 138, 1, 11, 262103) I have also wired to Sheth G. D. Birla to arrange likewise for Delhi, and Shri Brijkishen Chandiwala has already asked for my approval of some arrangement he has made 2. It goes without saying that I must not impose myself on Harijans anywhere.
('90', 138, 1, 12, 262348) I must not wound their feelings, if they will not tolerate my presence in their midst.
('90', 138, 1, 13, 262435) But I fear no such thing.
('90', 138, 1, 14, 262461) Incidentally I notice that some critics rejoice that I shall no longer reside in the Birla House.
('90', 138, 1, 15, 262559) They do not know that I have been accepting their hospitality for years.
('90', 138, 1, 16, 262632) I have accepted donations from them for my many constructive activities.
('90', 138, 1, 17, 262705) The critics do not know of the changes they have imperceptibly made in their life; nor need they or the public in general know these.
('90', 138, 1, 18, 262839) Such changes are never made for show.
('90', 138, 1, 19, 262877) At the same time it is perfectly true that there were wide differences between them and me in outlook.
('90', 138, 1, 20, 262980) This is no cause for sorrow or wonder.
('90', 138, 1, 21, 263019) All true change comes from within.
('90', 138, 1, 22, 263054) Any changes brought about by pressure is worthless.
('90', 138, 1, 23, 263106) I am neither so vain nor so foolish as to hope that all would follow me.
('90', 138, 1, 24, 263179) And who can say whether I am right or others in what we are doing ?
('90', 138, 1, 25, 263247) It is enough, if all of us abide by what we consider to be right.
('90', 138, 1, 26, 263313) We are all His creatures to do His will, not ours.
('90', 138, 1, 27, 263364) Doing so, we should all be friends to one another.
('90', 138, 1, 28, 263415) URULI[ KANCHAN], Macrh 25, 1946 Harijan, 31 3 1946

('90', 139, 0, 1, 263599) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 139, 1, 2, 263641) 188. WHY ONE MORE BURDEN?
('90', 139, 2, 3, 263667) Why have I got involved in nature cure in the evening of my life?
('90', 139, 2, 4, 263733) This question is being asked of me by several people.
('90', 139, 2, 5, 263787) Had I not enough work on my hands already?
('90', 139, 2, 6, 263830) Was I not too old to take up new things?
('90', 139, 2, 7, 263871) Could anyone expect me to add to my existing burdens?
('90', 139, 2, 8, 263925) All these are pertinent questions demanding my careful consideration.
('90', 139, 2, 9, 263995) But they did not evoke any echo within me.
('90', 139, 2, 10, 264038) The still small voice within me whispers: Why bother about what others say?
('90', 139, 2, 11, 264114) I have given you a colleague like Dr. Dinshaw who understand you, and whom you understand.
('90', 139, 2, 12, 264205) You have confidence in your capacity, having followed nature cure as a hobby for over half a century.
('90', 139, 2, 13, 264307) If you hide this talent and do not make use of it, you will be as a thief.
('90', 139, 2, 14, 264382) It will ill become you.
('90', 139, 2, 15, 264406) Remember the teaching of the first verse of Ishopanishad and surrender all you have to Me.
('90', 139, 2, 16, 264497) There is nothing that really belongs to you.
('90', 139, 2, 17, 264542) Only you fancied that something was yours.
('90', 139, 2, 18, 264585) It is all Mine.
('90', 139, 2, 19, 264601) Give it also to My creatures like the rest.
('90', 139, 2, 20, 264645) It will not in any way jeopardize your other work provided only that you have cultivated perfect detachment.
('90', 139, 2, 21, 264754) You have entertained the desire to live up to 125 years.
('90', 139, 2, 22, 264811) Its fulfilment or otherwise should not be your concern.
('90', 139, 2, 23, 264867) Yours is only to understand and do your duty and “be careful for nothing” 2. These are the thoughts that haunt me.
('90', 139, 2, 24, 264982) It is my third day in this village.
('90', 139, 2, 25, 265018) The number of patients who come for help is daily increasing.
('90', 139, 2, 26, 265080) They feel happy, and I feel happy in serving them.
('90', 139, 2, 27, 265131) I am receiving the co operation of the local people.
('90', 139, 2, 28, 265184) I know that if I can enter the hearts of the people here, illness will be banished and this village will become a model of cleanliness and health.
('90', 139, 2, 29, 265331) But if this does not happen, what is that to me?
('90', 139, 2, 30, 265380) I have only to do the behest of the Master.
('90', 139, 2, 31, 265424) URULI [ KANCHAN], March 25, 1946 Harijan, 31 3 1946
('90', 139, 3, 32, 265476) 1 Originally written in Hindi, this appeared as “from Harijan Sevak” published simultaneously with the source.
('90', 139, 3, 33, 265587) 2 Phillippians, “Permits for the Transvaal”
