('90', 140, 11, 19, 266125) URULI KANCHAN, March 25, 1946
('90', 140, 12, 20, 266155) BHAI VALLABHBHAI I have your letter.
('90', 140, 12, 21, 266192) The League’s ways are strange.
('90', 140, 12, 22, 266223) We cannot have two meetings.
('90', 140, 12, 23, 266252) Let the League arrange one.
('90', 140, 12, 24, 266280) There is no harm, if they get the credit for it.
('90', 140, 12, 25, 266329) Purushottamdas will show you the letter I have written 1 to him.
('90', 140, 12, 26, 266394) If the meeting called by the League is to be held on Sunday, and if you think it would be inadvisable for me to go there on the same day, please send me a wire.
('90', 140, 12, 27, 266555) Telegrams were delivered here.
('90', 140, 12, 28, 266586) We can even get a telephone connection if we want, but why go in for all that trouble for only six days?
('90', 140, 12, 29, 266691) My business in naturopathy is flourishing.
('90', 140, 12, 30, 266734) I can lose nothing in it.
('90', 140, 12, 31, 266760) And it helps to advance my other work.
('90', 140, 12, 32, 266799) If I find I have some capital with me and do not use it, what a big fool should I be?
('90', 140, 12, 33, 266885) One must hope to live and work for 125 years.
('90', 140, 12, 34, 266931) For the rest, God alone is the master of life and death.
('90', 140, 12, 35, 266988) I am positive that my duty is to stay in the Bhangi quarters.
('90', 140, 12, 36, 267050) You must get over the difficulties.

('90', 152, 4, 9, 286330) 205. IMPLICATIONS OF ‘QUIT INDIA’ In terms of non violence, ‘Quit India’ is a healthy, potent cry of the soul.
('90', 152, 4, 10, 286441) It is not a slogan.
('90', 152, 4, 11, 286461) It means the end, through means purely truthful and non violent, of foreign rule and domination.
('90', 152, 4, 12, 286558) It does not mean foreigner’s destruction but his willing conversion to Indian life.
('90', 152, 4, 13, 286642) In this scheme, there is no room for hatred of the foreigner.
('90', 152, 4, 14, 286704) He is a man, even as we are.
('90', 152, 4, 15, 286733) It is fear of him that gives rise to harted.
('90', 152, 4, 16, 286778) Fear gone, there can be no hatred.
('90', 152, 4, 17, 286813) Thus his conversion implies our conversion too.
('90', 152, 4, 18, 286861) If we cease to be inferiors, he cannot be our superior.
('90', 152, 4, 19, 286917) His arsenals and his weapons, typified in their extreme in the atom bomb, should have no terror for us.
('90', 152, 4, 20, 287021) It follows that we may not covet them.
('90', 152, 4, 21, 287060) We often make the mistake of thinking that we must first have things before we cease to covet them.
('90', 152, 4, 22, 287160) This tempting argument leads to the prolongation of the agony.
('90', 152, 4, 23, 287223) Must I do all the evil I can, before I learn to shun it?
('90', 152, 4, 24, 287280) Is it not enough to know the evil to shun it?
('90', 152, 4, 25, 287326) If not, we should be sincere enough to admit that we love evil too well to give it up.
('90', 152, 4, 26, 287413) Let us assume that foreign rule is ended.
('90', 152, 4, 27, 287455) What should the foreigner do?
('90', 152, 4, 28, 287485) He could hardly be considered free when he was protected by British arms.
('90', 152, 4, 29, 287559) As a free man he will discover that it was wrong to possess privileges which the millions of India could not enjoy.
('90', 152, 4, 30, 287675) He will live doing his duty as behoves a son of India.
('90', 152, 4, 31, 287730) He will no longer live at India’s expense.
('90', 152, 4, 32, 287773) On the contrary, he will give India all his talents and by his services render himself indispensable to the land of his adoption.
('90', 152, 4, 33, 287903) If this is true of the European, how much more true must it be for those Anglo Indians and others who have adopted Europen manners and customs in order to be classed as Europeans demanding
('90', 152, 5, 34, 288092) 1 Gandhiji, however, says “Tulsidas”.
('90', 153, 0, 1, 288130) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 153, 1, 2, 288172) preferential treatment?
('90', 153, 1, 3, 288196) All such people will find themselves ill at ease, if they expect continuation of the favoured treatment hitherto enjoyed by them.
('90', 153, 1, 4, 288326) They should rather feel thankful that they will be disburdened of preferential treatment to which they had no right by any known canon of reasoning, and which was derogatory to their dignity.
('90', 153, 1, 5, 288518) We have all—rulers and ruled—been living so long in a stifling,unnatural atmosphere that we might well feel in the beginning that we have lost the lungs for breathing the invigorating ozone of freedom.
('90', 153, 1, 6, 288720) If the reality comes in an orderly, that is, a non violent manner, because the parties feel that it is right, it will be a revealing lesson for the world.
('90', 153, 1, 7, 288875) URULI [ KANCHAN], March 29, 1946 Harijan, 7 4 1946

('90', 154, 1, 2, 290517) place in society.
('90', 154, 1, 3, 290535) If they succeeded in teaching them the correct way of life, they would have taught them all they needed.
('90', 154, 1, 4, 290640) Today they were steeped in the Stygian darkness of ignorance and superstition.
('90', 154, 1, 5, 290719) With the removal of that, women would make freedom worth while.
('90', 154, 2, 6, 290783) He cited the good example of Kanu Gandhi who had said that in his camp, soon to be started, it would be his aim to teach the students how to battle against famine by tilling the ground, scavenging, cooking, bringing their own expenses with them, so that they need not be a liability on anyone.
('90', 154, 2, 7, 291077) Women have to work in famine areas with this ideal.
('90', 154, 2, 8, 291129) It is ours to mitigate, not to aggravate the burden.
('90', 154, 3, 9, 291182) Asked as to what work he would lay most emphasis on, so far as women were concerned, Gandhiji felt that sanitation and hygiene, owing to the lack of knowledge of which our people suffered so greatly, should take first place.
('90', 154, 3, 10, 291407) Then there were evil customs which had to go, the useless expenditure on jewellary; and he made everyone laugh by his graphic description of a much bejewelled woman patient with a huge nose ring, earring necklace, bracelets and anklets complete who had visited him as a patient that very morning!
('90', 154, 3, 11, 291704) It was hard to know what should come first.
('90', 154, 3, 12, 291748) “Really all work in its own place is of equal importance.” There is the very great necessity of teaching women the care and upbringing of children, discipline in their own lives in every department including eating.
('90', 154, 3, 13, 291964) He placed maternity almost last in comparison with the above mentioned.
('90', 154, 3, 14, 292036) But nothing could be achieved without friendship with the women.
('90', 154, 3, 15, 292101) That was the first and basic desideratum.
('90', 154, 4, 16, 292143) The pay of workers had caused much discussion.
('90', 154, 4, 17, 292190) For Gandhiji it was the spirit of the worker that meant everything.
('90', 154, 4, 18, 292258) Inasmuch as the labourer was worthy of his hire, a decent living wage must be paid; but it was the work and not the pay that should attract.
('90', 154, 5, 19, 292399) Were the women to be given the wheel as a revolutionary weapon as, he had said it was, in the hands of a Jawaharlal?
('90', 154, 5, 20, 292516) The answer was ‘No’ How could it be such in the hands of an ignorant woman?
('90', 154, 5, 21, 292592) But if every women in India span, then a silent revolution would certainly be created of which a Jawaharlal could make full use.
('90', 154, 5, 22, 292721) Unless steam generated was put to proper use, the engine would not run and the person generating the steam might himself be scalded by it even unto death.
('90', 154, 6, 23, 292876) Amongst the members were some staunch femininists who were anxious for women alone to run the show.
('90', 154, 6, 24, 292976) To them Gandhiji said that the men who were there were serving the memory of one who was instinctively a villlage woman.
('90', 154, 6, 25, 293097) Long before he himself had taken to village life as being the ideal life for service, Kasturba has shown her preference for it.
('90', 154, 6, 26, 293225) Her heart was in Phoenix even in the far off South African days when he himself worked in a town.
('90', 154, 6, 27, 293323) The men who were honouring her memory were only serving until such time as women were ready to take their place.

('90', 160, 3, 16, 303153) 212. QUESTION BOX Q. Horse racing is going on in many important cities.
('90', 160, 3, 17, 303225) It is alike a lure for high and low, rich and poor, and it leads to moral degradation and, in some cases, penury.
('90', 160, 3, 18, 303339) Many Princes spend lakhs of their people’s money on buying race horses.
('90', 160, 3, 19, 303411) What steps should our new government take to check this evil?
('90', 160, 3, 20, 303473) A. There is no doubt whatsoever about the evil.
('90', 160, 3, 21, 303521) The good it is supposed to do is extremely doubtful.
('90', 160, 3, 22, 303574) And, at this time of growing distress in the country, it is criminal.
('90', 160, 3, 23, 303644) The new national government can do a great deal to check the evil.
('90', 160, 3, 24, 303711) But let us recognize their limita tions.
('90', 160, 3, 25, 303752) Being popular, i.
('90', 160, 3, 26, 303770) e., people’s governments, they will never be able to go far in advance of popular opinion.
('90', 160, 3, 27, 303861) That is specially a function belonging to reformers.
('90', 160, 3, 28, 303914) But these governments can certainly, by their own example, rob the evil of the stamp of fashion that the bureaucracy has set upon it even to the point of wasting public money on the luxury.
('90', 160, 3, 29, 304104) The Princes will copy the example of good manners that the national governments may set.
('90', 160, 4, 30, 304193) Q. We find that the Congress is reluctant to select women representatives on a large scale for elective bodies.
('90', 160, 4, 31, 304305) It is surely just and necessary that more women are taken into the various bodies.
('90', 160, 4, 32, 304388) How would you deal with the question?
('90', 160, 5, 33, 304426) A. I am not enamoured of equality or any other proportion in
('90', 161, 0, 1, 304487) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 161, 1, 2, 304529) such matters.
('90', 161, 1, 3, 304543) Merit should be the only test.
('90', 161, 1, 4, 304574) Seeing, however, that it has been the custom to decry women, the contrary custom should be to prefer women, merit being equal, to men even if the preference should result in men being entirely displaced by women.
('90', 161, 1, 5, 304787) It would be a dangerous thing to insist on membership on the ground merely of sex.
('90', 161, 1, 6, 304870) Women and for that matter any group should disdain patronage.
('90', 161, 1, 7, 304932) They should seek justice, never favour.Therefore the proper thing is for women as indeed for men to advance the spread not of English or Western education among them, but such education on general lines through their provincial languages as will fit them for the numerous duties of citizenship.
('90', 161, 1, 8, 305227) For men to take a lead in this much needed reform would be not a matter of favour but a simple act of belated justice due to women.

('90', 162, 1, 2, 306603) 214. IS NETAJI ALIVE?
('90', 162, 2, 3, 306625) Some years ago it was announced 2 in the newspapers that Subhas Chandra Bose had died.
('90', 162, 2, 4, 306712) I believed the report.
('90', 162, 2, 5, 306735) Later the news was proved to have been incorrect.
('90', 162, 2, 6, 306785) Since then I have had a feeling that Netaji could not leave us until his dream of swaraj had been fulfilled.
('90', 162, 2, 7, 306894) To lend strength to this feeling was the knowledge of Netaaji’s great ability to hoodwink his enemies and even the world for the sake of his cherished goal.
('90', 162, 2, 8, 307051) These were the only reasons for my belief that he was alive.
('90', 162, 2, 9, 307112) I have not the ability for foretelling the future.
('90', 162, 2, 10, 307163) I have no strength except what comes from insistence on truth.
('90', 162, 2, 11, 307226) Non violence too springs from the same insistence.
('90', 162, 2, 12, 307277) God alone knows absolute truth.
('90', 162, 2, 13, 307309) Therefore I have often said, Truth is God.
('90', 162, 2, 14, 307352) It follows that man, a finite being, cannot know absolute truth.
('90', 162, 2, 15, 307417) Therefore I had nothing but my instinct to tell me that Netaji was alive.
('90', 162, 2, 16, 307491) No reliance can be placed on such unsupported feeling.
('90', 162, 2, 17, 307546) On the other hand, there is strong evidence to counteract the feeling.
('90', 162, 2, 18, 307617) The British Government is party to that evidence.
('90', 162, 2, 19, 307667) Habibur Rahman has said, he was present at the time of Netaji’s death and has brought back his charred wrist watch.
('90', 162, 2, 20, 307783) Another of his companions, Shri Iyer, met and told me that my instinct was wrong and I should abandon the feeling that Subhas Chandra was alive.
('90', 162, 2, 21, 307928) In the face of these proofs I appeal to everyone to forget what I have said 3 and, believing in the evidence before them, reconcile themselves to the fact that Nataji has left us.
('90', 162, 2, 22, 308108) All man’s ingenuity is as nothing before the might of the One God.
('90', 162, 2, 23, 308175) He alone is Truth and nothing else stands.

('90', 164, 1, 2, 310271) 217. KASTURBA SMARAK TRUST There were two meetings at Uruli Kanchan: on the 28th, 29th and 30th March; one of the Agents 1 of this Trust and the other of the Executive.
('90', 164, 1, 3, 310440) The meeting of the Agents was the first of its kind.
('90', 164, 1, 4, 310493) The Agents had many interesting questions.
('90', 164, 1, 5, 310536) Why could not the Agents be members of the legislatures?
('90', 164, 1, 6, 310593) The obvious answer is that, if they are to do justice to their work, they should have no time for legis lative duties.
('90', 164, 1, 7, 310712) The decisive reason is that the villagers will have a wrong example set to them,if they have members of legislatures to look up to.
('90', 164, 1, 8, 310844) Whatever the sphere of work they choose, they should not be non entities.
('90', 164, 1, 9, 310918) It should be remembered that the Agents have displaced the committees that were appointed for the last year.
('90', 164, 1, 10, 311027) If they cover the whole Province, they have their work cut out from them.
('90', 164, 1, 11, 311101) If they cannot cope with it, they have to run model shibirs 2 in one or more places to prepare women workers for villages.
('90', 164, 1, 12, 311224) These may be teachers, nurses, spinners, weavers, sanitarians, etc.
('90', 164, 1, 13, 311292) Work by women among women in the villages of India is an unbeaten track.
('90', 164, 1, 14, 311365) Men are hardly fit for it.
('90', 164, 1, 15, 311392) But the women have so long remained without experiences of such work that it is difficult, especially in the initial stages.
('90', 164, 1, 16, 311517) If the Agent attempt at intensity and confine their activity to certain centres, they will find the work to be simple and instructive.
('90', 164, 1, 17, 311652) Then they have their advisers.
('90', 164, 1, 18, 311683) They are not meant to be ornamental.
('90', 164, 1, 19, 311720) Their advice should always be at the disposal of the Agents.
('90', 164, 1, 20, 311781) If they are well chosen, they must prove towers of strength to the Agents in their difficult task.
('90', 164, 1, 21, 311880) The experiment of having women only as Agents is new.
('90', 164, 1, 22, 311934) It can only succeed if they are wisely guided by the Centre and ably advised by the advisers.
('90', 164, 1, 23, 312028) Much as it is to be wished that they too were women, the fear is that in the beginning they will be mostly men.
('90', 164, 1, 24, 312140) The advisers should never aspire to be more than such and never be less.
('90', 164, 1, 25, 312213) It should never aspire to be more than such and never be less.
('90', 164, 1, 26, 312276) It shoud be their proud privilege to give the Agents their advice whenever it is sought.
('90', 164, 1, 27, 312365) The members of the defunct committee, it is
('90', 164, 2, 28, 312409) 1 Vide “Speech at Kasturba Gandhi Nsational Memorial Trust Women Agents’ Meeting, Uruli Kanchan”, 28 3 1946 2 Camps

('90', 165, 2, 5, 312950) 218. TEN SUGGESTIONS WORTH CONSIDERING A worker has made some suggestions for meeting the threatened calamity.
('90', 165, 2, 6, 313061) I give them below with only some minor changes.
('90', 165, 2, 7, 313109) Possibly some of the suggestions might have been made earlier in one form or the other.
('90', 165, 2, 8, 313197) I have not taken that into consideration.
('90', 165, 2, 9, 313239) The best of suggestion can be misused by a dishonest person.
('90', 165, 2, 10, 313300) Let us hope that the scorching heat of the Holi fire will burn out the impurities in all of us.
('90', 165, 2, 11, 313396) 1. There should be a strict and impartial machinery to prevent the removal of even a single grain or a blade of grass unless enough stock of foodgrains and fodder is reserved for the requirement of the entire rural population including the cattle and livestock for the whole year.
('90', 165, 2, 12, 313677) 2. There should be no difference between the purchase and the sale prices of foodgrains.
('90', 165, 2, 13, 313766) The sale prices should be kept on par with the purchase prices.
('90', 165, 2, 14, 313830) The overhead charges should be borne by the Government alone.
('90', 165, 2, 15, 313892) 3. Foodgrains should be made easily available in every locality at controlled prices.
('90', 165, 2, 16, 313978) There should be no need for futile treks of five to seven miles and returning with empty hands as at present.
('90', 165, 2, 17, 314088) 4. Arrangements should be made to provide work according to one’s capacity and to pay remuneration in the form of foodgrains and or clothes as the case may be to those who do not have neccessary cash to purchase them.
('90', 165, 2, 18, 314306) 5. The pay of all categories of low paid employees should be raised to meet the cost of living without waiting for any demands or agitations, but payment may be made in the form of food grains.
('90', 165, 2, 19, 314500) 6. Items of current expenditure in the budget should be pruned to provide sustenance to the people.
('90', 165, 2, 20, 314600) Cuts in the salaries of highly paid official should be introduced, if neccessary.
('90', 166, 0, 1, 314682) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 167
('90', 166, 1, 2, 314726) 7. The post war scheme or other such projects could be easily suspended till the crisis blows over.
('90', 166, 1, 3, 314826) 8. It should be so planned that public donations flow into a central pool from where they are canalized for combating starvation and also for increasing food production.
('90', 166, 1, 4, 314996) 9. It should be considered the sacred duty of a Government to strive sincerely to provide livelihood to the people in some form or the other.
('90', 166, 1, 5, 315138) 10. Eating houses or meal counters should be introduced where a person without any discrimination of caste and creed can get a meal at the lowest cost or by offering some sort of labour instead.
('90', 166, 1, 6, 315333) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 31 1 1946

('90', 179, 4, 18, 339939) This news left a bad taste in my mouth.
('90', 179, 4, 19, 339979) This was the genesis of our correspondence.
('90', 179, 4, 20, 340023) I think that it is an extremely bad example.

('90', 180, 1, 5, 340961) All the papers that you have sent to the Sardar and are now sending to me simply show how in my opinion you have been instrumental, however unwittingly, in, as I would put it, corrupting public life.

('90', 181, 5, 8, 342969) MUNNALAL, Your letter is bad.
('90', 181, 5, 9, 342999) You should not spend a sleepless night to write such a letter in the morning.
('90', 181, 5, 10, 343077) What can you have to do with Qutub Minar or the Assembly Hall?

('90', 181, 5, 16, 343373) I have not kept you chained.
('90', 181, 5, 17, 343402) I do not look upon you as a child, but you behave like one.
('90', 181, 5, 18, 343462) Stop writing and stop discussing and go on silently doing work and nothing but work and that in a spirit of service or yajna.
('90', 181, 5, 19, 343588) So many things are waiting to be done and you are tempted to go and see idle shows.
('90', 181, 5, 20, 343672) Inspect the houses of Harijans, meet all residents of Harijan localities, do carding, punai 1 , tunai 22, spinning, weaving, go through the language editions of Harijan and correct the mistakes in them, improve your Urdu, teach Abha, Gita, Prabha, etc., improve your temper, learn the Gita and master Sanskrit.

('90', 185, 2, 10, 350360) 244. KASTURBA LEPROSY WORK This work has been going on under Prof.
('90', 185, 2, 11, 350427) T. N. Jagadisan’s supervision since May 19, 1945. He has produced a short summary of the work done from to day.
('90', 185, 2, 12, 350539) Dr. T. S. S. Rajan is the chairman of the committee specially formed for this work.
('90', 185, 2, 13, 350623) Dr. V. P. Ramaswami has specially trained himself for the work under Dr. R. G. Conhrane.
('90', 185, 2, 14, 350712) He is doing out patient work as well as conducting surveys of villages.
('90', 185, 2, 15, 350784) The first survey in Kandachipuram schools of 655 children revealed that apart from leprosy there was a high incidence of scabies and guinea worm.
('90', 185, 2, 16, 350930) Over 100 children have to be followed up and 30 40 treated for leprosy.
('90', 185, 2, 17, 351002) In Madavilagam village, 18 definite case of leprosy have been discovered out of 539 inhabitants.
('90', 185, 2, 18, 351099) Four of thes are infective, and fourteen neural.
('90', 185, 2, 19, 351148) Infection is spread by indiscriminate contact of infective cases with children.
('90', 185, 2, 20, 351228) In Adukkam village, 15 cases have found out of a population of 323. Five of these are infective.
('90', 185, 2, 21, 351325) Two other places have 29 and 15 definite cases respectively of which 9 are lepromatons.
('90', 185, 2, 22, 351413) Dr. Ramaswami has also surveyed five more villages and has so far detected 300 cases out of which 157 only, being women or children under seven years, can benefit from the Trust.
('90', 185, 2, 23, 351592) T. N. Jagadisan’s summary points out that poor men patients though in need of attention cannot get the benefit of the funds.
('90', 185, 2, 24, 351717) This defect cannot be removed by any departure from the terms of the Trust, but the professor can easily raise a small fund locally and bring them within the scope of his work.
('90', 185, 2, 25, 351894) NEW DELHI, April 4, 1946 Harijan, 14 4 1946

('90', 186, 1, 2, 351982) 245. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('90', 186, 2, 3, 352010) NEW DELHI, April 4, 1946
('90', 186, 3, 4, 352035) Many foreign and local newspaper reporters have been good enough to come to me to ask questions on the topic of the day.
('90', 186, 3, 5, 352156) A newspaper man myself, I can sympathize with their desire.
('90', 186, 3, 6, 352216) But they should sympathize and co operate with me in the delicate mission of adviser to the Cabinet Mission when I tell them that I cannot be advising and broadcasting to the world on the matters covered by my advice.
('90', 186, 3, 7, 352434) Such a course is calculated to defeat the purpose in view.
('90', 186, 3, 8, 352493) Anyway these friends will attribute my silence not to any discourtesy on my part but to my desire for successful termination of the labours of the Cabinate Mission.

('90', 186, 4, 10, 352688) 246. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, NEW DELHI 1
('90', 186, 5, 11, 352731) April 4, 1946
('90', 186, 6, 12, 352745) Gandhiji said, though his prayers contained selected verses from different religions, their purport remains the same.
('90', 186, 6, 13, 352863) He wanted people to come to the prayers with calm and peaceful mind and participate in Ramdhun.
('90', 186, 6, 14, 352959) Thanking the people for maintaining silence, Gandhiji said that the Sanskrit solakas that were recited in the prayer had been culled from those chapters of the Gita 2 in which Lord Krishna lays down before Arjuna the characterstics of a sthitaprajna.
('90', 186, 6, 15, 353210) [Gandhiji continued.] If swaraj is to be won through the non violent strength of the millions, they must in some measure develop in them the qualities of a sthitapajna or the man of steady wisdom.
('90', 186, 7, 16, 353407) The ideal is not meant for jnanis 3 only; it is for all, even ordinary lay people.
('90', 186, 7, 17, 353490) Lord Krishna himself is depicted in the Mahabharata as a charioteer actually driving a team of white horses while his pupil Arjuna, to whom the Gita discourses are addressed is pictured as being plebian in his mental make up and outlook.
('90', 186, 8, 18, 353728) 1 The speech is extracted from Pyarelal’s “Prayer Discourses” in Harijan.
('90', 186, 8, 19, 353802) The opening paragraph is form The Hindustan Times.
('90', 186, 9, 20, 353853) 58 3 Men of knowledge
('90', 187, 0, 1, 353875) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 187, 1, 2, 353917) then are the characteristics of a sthitaprajna?
('90', 187, 1, 3, 353965) He is one who withdraw his senses from the objects of the senses behind the shield of the spirit, as a tortoise does its limbs under its shell.
('90', 187, 1, 4, 354109) A man whose wisdom is not steady is liable to be betrayed into anger, evil thoughts or abuse.
('90', 187, 1, 5, 354203) On the contrary, the man with the steady wisdom will remain equally unaffected by adulation or abuse.
('90', 187, 1, 6, 354305) He will realize that abuse fouls only the tongue that utters it, never the person against whom it is hurled.
('90', 187, 1, 7, 354414) A man of steady wisdom will, therefore, never wish ill to anyone, but will pray even for his enemy with his last breath.
('90', 187, 1, 8, 354535) Is it too difficult an ideal to follow?
('90', 187, 1, 9, 354575) On the contrary, the conduct laid down in it is the only conduct worthy of the dignity of human beings.
('90', 187, 1, 10, 354679) Today our minds are clouded by delusion.
('90', 187, 1, 11, 354720) In our ignorance, we quarrel with one another and indulge in rowdyism against our own brethren.
('90', 187, 1, 12, 354816) For such as these there is neither salvation nor swaraj.
('90', 187, 1, 13, 354873) Self discipline or rule over self is the first condition for self rule or swaraj.
('90', 187, 1, 14, 354955) All might find it difficult to correctly recite the Gita verses which are in Sanskrit.
('90', 187, 1, 15, 355042) But all can take part in the singing of Ramdhun.
('90', 187, 1, 16, 355091) The mass singing of Ramdhun to the accompaniment of tala is prayer reduced to its simplest terms.
('90', 187, 1, 17, 355189) ‘But how can non Hindus take part in it?
('90', 187, 1, 18, 355230) The question was once raised.
('90', 187, 1, 19, 355260) I laugh within myself, when someone objects that Rama or the chanting of Ramanama is for the Hindus only, [and asks] how can Mussalmans, therefore, take part in it.
('90', 187, 1, 20, 355425) Is there one God for the Mussalmans and another for the Hindus, Parsis or Christians?
('90', 187, 1, 21, 355511) No, there is only one omnipotent and omnipresent God.
('90', 187, 1, 22, 355565) He is named variously, and we remember Him by the name which is most familiar to us.
('90', 187, 1, 23, 355650) My Rama, the Rama of our prayers, is not the historical Rama, the son of Dasaratha, the King of Ayodhya.
('90', 187, 1, 24, 355755) He is the eternal, the unborn, the one without a second.
('90', 187, 1, 25, 355812) Him alone I worship, His aid alone I seek, and so should you.
('90', 187, 1, 26, 355874) He belongs equally to all.
('90', 187, 1, 27, 355901) I, therefore, see no reason why a Mussalman or anybody should object to taking His name.
('90', 187, 1, 28, 355990) But he is in no way bound to recognize God as Ramanama.
('90', 187, 1, 29, 356046) He may utter to himself Allah or Khuda so as not to mar the harmony of the sound.
('90', 187, 2, 30, 356128) Gandhiji strongly deprecated the wastage of food on marriages and other ceremonial occasions, and said that those who indulged in such extravagant habits
('90', 188, 0, 1, 356282) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 189
('90', 188, 1, 2, 356326) were the enemies of the people and unfit even to pray.
('90', 188, 2, 3, 356381) Tracing the cause of famine and the other national calamities that occur in our day to day life as due to our past sins, Gandhiji added that if people did not commit sins, there would be no famine even if there were no rains.
('90', 188, 2, 4, 356607) He emphasized the importance of morning prayer.
('90', 188, 2, 5, 356655) Referring to day before yesterday’s incident 2
('90', 188, 3, 6, 356702) Mahatmaji said: There was orderliness until I came.
('90', 188, 3, 7, 356754) But such arrangement ought to have continued till I left the place.
('90', 188, 3, 8, 356822) All of a sudden people rushed towards us with the result I was also slightly injured.
('90', 188, 3, 9, 356908) It was my own fault as the injury was caused by my chappals.
('90', 188, 3, 10, 356969) But an innocent volunteer was badly injured.
('90', 188, 3, 11, 357014) In future, nobody should get up till I leave this place.
('90', 188, 3, 12, 357071) People should give up the habit of touching other’s feet.
('90', 188, 3, 13, 357129) They should not swarm towards us.
('90', 188, 3, 14, 357163) After all we are not monkeys, we are human beings.
('90', 188, 4, 15, 357214) Harijan, 28 4 1946; also Hindustan, 5 4 1946, and The Hindustan Times, 5 4 1946
('90', 188, 5, 16, 357294) 247. WHAT IS IN A NAME?
('90', 188, 6, 17, 357318) Q. From the psychological point of view, I think, the name ‘Harijan’ instills into the minds of the people to whom it is applied a feeling of inferiority, however sacred that name may be.
('90', 188, 6, 18, 357506) This feeling is very difficult to wipe out from them—to whatever extent they are advanced—if they are always called ‘Harijan’.
('90', 188, 6, 19, 357633) Similarly if a man in the street is asked about a ‘Harijan’, the first thing he will speak of is ‘untouchability and the Depressed Class’.
('90', 188, 6, 20, 357772) Would it not be possible to save the ‘Harijan’ from involuntarily acquiring such an inferiority feeling, and other people from thinking about them without the ‘qualification’ usually ascribed to them?
('90', 188, 6, 21, 357973) Would it not be preferable to choose a name which could also bring in its fold people from other sects?
('90', 188, 6, 22, 358077) A. This subject was years ago dealt with in the pages of Young India.
('90', 188, 6, 23, 358147) The name ‘Harijan’ has sacred associations.
('90', 188, 6, 24, 358191) It was suggested by a Harijan as a substitute for Asprishya (untouchable), Dalita (depressed), or for the different categories of ‘untouchables’ such as Bhangis, Mehtars, Chamars, Pariahs, etc.
('90', 188, 6, 25, 358385) 3 The Government
('90', 188, 7, 26, 358402) 1 This paragraph is form The Hindustan Times, and that which follows is translated from Hindustan.
('90', 188, 7, 27, 358501) 2 Vide footnote 1, “Advice to Bhangls”, 3 4 1946 3 Vide “My Notes”, Sub title The Bengal Murder”
('90', 189, 0, 1, 358598) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 189, 1, 2, 358640) officers put them in a schedule and, therefore, called them the Scheduled Classes, thus making confusion worse confounded.
('90', 189, 1, 3, 358763) Those who were not untouchables were classed among the Scheduled and the ones who could be so called were excluded.
('90', 189, 1, 4, 358879) We have now arrived at a stage, thanks to the Government policy, when to be included among the Scheduled Classes is to be coveted.
('90', 189, 1, 5, 359010) The Government have created a separate electorate agitating for seats in all elective institutions.
('90', 189, 1, 6, 359110) I do not mind such ambition, if it carries honest merit with it.
('90', 189, 1, 7, 359175) But it becomes positively mischievous, when seats are coveted irrespective of merit.
('90', 189, 1, 8, 359260) The wish to be so educated as to be qualified for the highest post is to be appreciated and encouraged, the wish to be appointed to such a post on the basis of belonging to a caste or a class is essentially to be deprecated and discouraged.
('90', 189, 1, 9, 359501) The real remedy has been suggested by me.
('90', 189, 1, 10, 359543) The feeling of inferiority must go.
('90', 189, 1, 11, 359579) It is going, but too slowly.
('90', 189, 1, 12, 359608) The process can be accelerated, if every Hindu would deliberately shed his superiority and in practice become a Harijan or, if you like, a master, the lowest class among Harijans.
('90', 189, 1, 13, 359788) Then we all will become true children of God as the word ‘Harijan’ means.
('90', 189, 1, 14, 359862) Until this is done, no matter which word signifies ‘untouchables’, it will smell of inferiority.
('90', 189, 1, 15, 359959) The process has to be carried out thoroughly in every walk of life till the last trace of untouchability is removed.
('90', 189, 1, 16, 360076) When that happy day arrives, every quarter will be a Harijan quarter and cleanliness of the heart and the home will be the order of the day.
('90', 189, 1, 17, 360217) NEW DELHI, April 5, 1946 Harijan, 14 4 1946
('90', 189, 2, 18, 360261) 248. WHAT IS THE LAW?
('90', 189, 2, 19, 360283) ‘Confused’ writes : I grant that Italy, Germany and Japan have lost their power; but is the loss due to their faith in violence, as you would say 1, or is it due to their exhaustion brought about by fortunes of war?
('90', 189, 2, 20, 360499) Will you hold that Britain, Russia and America have been successful because of their non violence?
('90', 189, 2, 21, 360598) Thus argues a correspondent whom I have paraphrased without diminishing the force of his argument.
('90', 189, 2, 22, 360697) The questioner has failed to perceive that in the writing quoted by him, I have said nothing about
('90', 189, 3, 23, 360796) 1Vide “Extract from Talk With A Friend”, 3 3 1946
('90', 190, 0, 1, 360846) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 191
('90', 190, 1, 2, 360890) the so called victorious Powers.
('90', 190, 1, 3, 360923) But I have said elsewhere that their victory is an empty boast, if they do not learn the lesson while there is time and do not shape their life in accordance with the law of non violence.
('90', 190, 1, 4, 361111) I believe wholly in the truth that “those who take the sword will perish by the sword”.
('90', 190, 1, 5, 361199) There is no doubt that the victors employed the same means as the vanquished.
('90', 190, 1, 6, 361277) There was only a question of degree.
('90', 190, 1, 7, 361314) The victorious parties already seem to be on the verge of quarrelling among themselves.
('90', 190, 1, 8, 361402) If another war has not already begun, it is because no one is ready to enter upon it.
('90', 190, 1, 9, 361488) After all men are not machines.
('90', 190, 1, 10, 361520) They cannot be continually fighting without being reduced to the state of beasts.
('90', 190, 1, 11, 361602) One has to hope, for the sake of humanity, that they will do some hard thinking and discover the truth that the common man, of whom the world is composed, gains nothing by cutting his fellowman’s throat and that the fruits of peace are infinitely superior to those of war.
('90', 190, 1, 12, 361875) Ingenuity employed in devising methods of destruction lowers, whereas when employed in devising ways of building it befits mankind.
('90', 190, 1, 13, 362007) NEW DELHI, April 5, 1946 Harijan, 14 4 1946

('90', 191, 6, 10, 362436) 250. LETTER TO SIR STAFFORD CRIPS
('90', 191, 7, 11, 362470) HARIJAN MANDIR, April 5, 1946
('90', 191, 8, 12, 362500) DEAR SIR STAFFORD,
('90', 191, 9, 13, 362519) Many thanks for your affectionate letter 2. Sudhir has given me
('90', 191, 10, 14, 362583) 1 Which, inter alia, read : “When you and I met at my bungalow on Monday last, and again at the office on Wednesday, you were.
('90', 191, 10, 15, 362710) prepared to have a personal talk with Mr. Jinnah.
('90', 191, 10, 16, 362760) the position has not yet sufficiently clarified .

('90', 193, 0, 1, 366415) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 193, 1, 2, 366457) my mind since yesterday.
('90', 193, 1, 3, 366482) India has accorded to the released I. N. A. men a right royal welcome.
('90', 193, 1, 4, 366553) They have been acclaimed as national heroes.
('90', 193, 1, 5, 366598) Everybody seems to have been swept off his feel before the rising tide of popular sentiment.
('90', 193, 1, 6, 366691) I must, however, frankly confess to you that I do not share this indiscriminate hero worship.
('90', 193, 1, 7, 366785) I admire the ability, sacrifice and partriotism of the I. N. A. and Netaji Bose.
('90', 193, 1, 8, 366866) But I cannot subscribe to the method which they adopted and which is incompatible with the one followed by the Congress for the last twenty five years for the attainment of independence.
('90', 193, 1, 9, 367053) Yesterday I spoke 1 to you of a sthitaprajna, i.e., “the man of steady wisdom”, i.
('90', 193, 1, 10, 367136) e., a satyagrahi.
('90', 193, 1, 11, 367154) If we accept that ideal, we would not regard anybody as our enemy; we must shed all enmity and ill will.
('90', 193, 1, 12, 367259) That ideal is not meant for the select few—the saint or the seer only—it is meant for all.
('90', 193, 1, 13, 367350) I have descri bed myself as a scavenger, having become one, not only in name but in fact, while I was in Phoenix.
('90', 193, 1, 14, 367464) It was there that I took up the bucket and the broom, impelled by the inner urge to identify myself with the lowest of the low.
('90', 193, 1, 15, 367592) As a humble fellow toiler then let me bear witness that anyone, even a simple minded villager who wants to, and tries, can attain the state of mental equipoise described in the Gita verses which are recited at the prayer.
('90', 193, 1, 16, 367814) We all lose our sanity at times, though we in peace.
('90', 193, 1, 17, 367867) It is a higher and more difficult work.
('90', 193, 1, 18, 367907) We have to die performing our duty and without killing.
('90', 193, 1, 19, 367963) For that we shall need to cultivate the attributes of a sthitaprajna as set forth in the Gita.
('90', 193, 1, 20, 368058) Far more potent than the strength of the sword is the strength of satyagraha.
('90', 193, 1, 21, 368136) I said so to the I.N.A. men and they were happy to tell me, as I was to hear, that they had realized this and would hereafter strive to serve India as true soldiers of non violence under the Congress flag.
('90', 193, 1, 22, 368342) NEW DELHI, April 8, 1946.

('90', 193, 3, 24, 368431) 1Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting, New Delhi”, 4 4 1946
('90', 194, 0, 1, 368485) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 195
('90', 194, 1, 2, 368529) 253. LET US PRAY There is little doubt that India is about to reach her cherished goal of political independence.
('90', 194, 1, 3, 368643) Let the entrance be prayerful.
('90', 194, 1, 4, 368674) Prayer is not an old woman’s idle amusement.
('90', 194, 1, 5, 368719) Properly understood and applied, it is the most potent instrument of action.
('90', 194, 1, 6, 368796) Let us then pray and find out what we have meant by non violence, and how we shall retain the freedom gained by its use.
('90', 194, 1, 7, 368917) If our non violence is of the weak, it follows that we shall never be able, by such non violence,, to retain freedom.
('90', 194, 1, 8, 369035) But it follows also that we shall not, for some length of time, at any rate, be able to defend ourselves by force of arms, if only because we have neither them nor the knowledge of their use.
('90', 194, 1, 9, 369227) We have not even the requisite discipline.
('90', 194, 1, 10, 369270) The result is that we shall have to rely upon another nation’s help, not as equals but as pupils upon their teachers, if the word ‘inferiors’ jars upon our ears.
('90', 194, 1, 11, 369432) Hence there is nothing but non violence to fall back upon for retaining our freedom even as we had to do for gaining it.
('90', 194, 1, 12, 369553) This means exercise of non violence against all those who call themselves our opponents.
('90', 194, 1, 13, 369642) This should not mean much for a man who has used himself to non violence for nearly three decades.
('90', 194, 1, 14, 369741) It is summed up in “die for your honour and freedom” instead of “kill if necessary and be killed in the act”.
('90', 194, 1, 15, 369851) What does a brave soldier do ?
('90', 194, 1, 16, 369882) He kills only if necessary and risks his life in the act.
('90', 194, 1, 17, 369940) Non violence demands greater courage and sacrifice.
('90', 194, 1, 18, 369992) Why should it be comparatiely easy for a man to risk death in the act of a killing and almost super human for him to do so in the act of sparing life?
('90', 194, 1, 19, 370143) It seems to be gross self deception to think that we can risk death, if we learn and practice the art of killing, but cannot do so otherwise.
('90', 194, 1, 20, 370285) But for the hypnotism induced by the repetition of an untruth we should not grossly deceive ourselves.
('90', 194, 1, 21, 370388) But the critic or the scoffer will ask, why bring in prayer if the matter is so simple as you put it.
('90', 194, 1, 22, 370490) The answer is that prayer is the first and the last lesson in learning the noble and brave art of sacrificing self in the various walks of life culminating in the defence of one’s nation’s liberty and honour.
('90', 194, 1, 23, 370699) Undoubtedly prayer requires a living faith in God.
('90', 194, 1, 24, 370750) Successful satyagraha is inconceivable without that faith.
('90', 194, 1, 25, 370809) God may be called by
('90', 195, 0, 1, 370830) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 195, 1, 2, 370872) any other name so long as it connotes the living Law of Life—in other words, the Law and the Law giver rolled into one.
('90', 195, 1, 3, 370992) NEW DELHI, April 6, 1946 Harijan, 14 4 1946
('90', 195, 2, 4, 371036) 254. NOTES
('90', 195, 3, 5, 371047) EATING WITH HARIJANS 1
('90', 195, 4, 6, 371070) Q. How can a vegetarian caste Hindu sit down to food in the home of a meat eating Harijan ?
('90', 195, 5, 7, 371162) A. A vegetarian caste Hindu can eat vegetarian food in the home of a meat eating Harijan.
('90', 195, 5, 8, 371252) Inter dining does not imply that one should eat everything that is put before one.
('90', 195, 5, 9, 371335) All that is necessary is that the food, the plates on which it is served, and the hands that have cooked it should be clean.
('90', 195, 5, 10, 371460) The same applies to water.
('90', 195, 5, 11, 371487) Nor does inter dining mean that people should eat out of the same plate or drink out of the same glass.
('90', 195, 5, 12, 371591) There should be no breach of hygiene.
('90', 195, 6, 13, 371629) RAMANAMA
('90', 195, 7, 14, 371638) Q. Is it not enough to have Ramanama in one’s heart, or is there something special in its recitation ?
('90', 195, 8, 15, 371741) A. I believe there is special merit in the recitation of Ramanama.
('90', 195, 8, 16, 371808) If anyone knows that God is in truth residing in his heart, I admit that for him there is no need for recitation.
('90', 195, 8, 17, 371922) But I have not known such a person.
('90', 195, 8, 18, 371958) On the contrary, my personal experience tells me that there is something quite extraordinary in the recitation of Ramanama.
('90', 195, 8, 19, 372082) Why or how is not necessary to know.

('90', 195, 10, 23, 372348) Nor need all draw payments because a certain scale is allowed.
('90', 195, 10, 24, 372411) The scale fixes the limit up to which they may draw.
('90', 195, 10, 25, 372464) It will be ludicrous for a monied man to draw the full or any payment.
('90', 195, 10, 26, 372535) The payments are meant for those who cannot easily afford to render free

('90', 196, 5, 14, 373665) He now contemplates abolition within three months or so.
('90', 196, 5, 15, 373722) I know that nothing can be done by a single official, however strong or able he may be, unless he is supported by his superiors.
('90', 196, 5, 16, 373851) And so I invoke your assistance in this humanitarian work.
('90', 196, 5, 17, 373910) But more even than that is the consideration that I put before the Cabinet Delegation, viz., that independence should be ushered in with the greatest good grace which the poorest villager in the remotest village can at once realize.

('90', 198, 1, 2, 376642) 257. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, NEW DELHI
('90', 198, 3, 3, 376683) April 6, 1946
('90', 198, 4, 4, 376697) Twenty seven years ago when the late Swami Shraddhanandji2
('90', 198, 5, 5, 376756) was alive, satyagraha against the Rowlatt Act was inaugurated on this day.
('90', 198, 5, 6, 376831) History was made the following week.
('90', 198, 5, 7, 376868) For the first time the entire masses of India from one end to the other rose like one man.
('90', 198, 5, 8, 376959) It was an entirely spontaneous demonstration.3 I had myself not imagined that its outcome could be so miraculous.
('90', 198, 5, 9, 377073) I could feel God’s hand in this miracle.
('90', 198, 6, 10, 377114) That was the time when Hindus and Muslims for the time forgot
('90', 198, 7, 11, 377176) all their difference.
('90', 198, 7, 12, 377198) The Ali Brothers4 and I used to go all over the country together like blood brothers.
('90', 198, 7, 13, 377284) We spoke with one voice and delivered the message of Hindu Muslim unity and swaraj to the masses.
('90', 198, 7, 14, 377382) We resolved that thereafter we should address our prayers to God alone, instead of the British Government, and so satyagraha was born in India after it was first initiated in South Africa.
('90', 198, 7, 15, 377571) On April 13, unarmed civilians were subjected to firing.
('90', 198, 7, 16, 377628) The Ali brothers readily fell in with the programme of a national day of fasting and prayer.
('90', 198, 7, 17, 377721) People fasted on the 6th and 13th of April.
('90', 198, 7, 18, 377765) They realized that they were all children of the one God, destined to live together and die together in the land of their birth, which was India.
('90', 198, 7, 19, 377911) They asemebled together in their thousands and offered prayers in temples, churches and mosques.
('90', 198, 7, 20, 378008) The climax was reached when in Delhi a monster gathering, consisting of both Hindus and Mussalman, was held in the Juma Mosque and was addressed by the late Swami Shraddhanand.
('90', 198, 7, 21, 378185) It was a glorious day in India’s histroy, the memory of which we shall always treasure.
('90', 198, 8, 22, 378273) But the situation has changed today.
('90', 198, 8, 23, 378310) We have gone wrong
('90', 198, 9, 24, 378329) 1 Gandhiji spoke in Hindustani.
('90', 198, 9, 25, 378361) The Harijan report, which appeared under the
('90', 198, 10, 26, 378406) title “The Sacred Week” by Pyarelal, has been collated with the Hindi version in Harijan Sevak published simultaneously with the source.
('90', 198, 11, 27, 378543) 2 Munshiram Manekchand (1856 1926), known as Mahatma Munshiram
('90', 198, 12, 28, 378606) before he became a sannyasi; as member of Aryasamaj, he took active part in public activities in Delhi and the Punab; was assassinated on December 24, 1926.

('90', 199, 0, 1, 378945) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 199, 1, 2, 378987) somewhere.
('90', 199, 1, 3, 378998) The hearts of Hindus and Muslims are sundered.
('90', 199, 1, 4, 379045) The air is poisoned with communal bitternes and rancour.
('90', 199, 1, 5, 379102) A section of the Muslims has begun to claim that they are a separate nation.
('90', 199, 1, 6, 379179) This, however, is not the time to go into the reason for it.
('90', 199, 1, 7, 379240) I confess that it baffles my understanding.
('90', 199, 1, 8, 379284) Since then we commence our proceedings as today,with prayer 1. If we believe in prayer, we cannot fly at one another’s throat, or regard anybody as our enemy.
('90', 199, 1, 9, 379443) At Amritsar people lost their heads.
('90', 199, 1, 10, 379480) But we promptly confessed our mistake and made expiation for it by fasting and praying to God for foregiveness.
('90', 199, 1, 11, 379592) To err is human.
('90', 199, 1, 12, 379609) By confessing we convert our mistakes into stepping stones for advance.
('90', 199, 1, 13, 379681) On the contrary, a person who tries to hide his mistake becomes a living fraud and sinks down.
('90', 199, 1, 14, 379776) Man is neither brute nor God but a creature of God striving to realize his divinity.
('90', 199, 1, 15, 379861) Repentance and self purification are the means.
('90', 199, 1, 16, 379909) The moment we repent and ask God for forgiveness for our lapse, we purged of our sin and new life begins for us.
('90', 199, 1, 17, 380022) True repentance is an essential prerequisite of prayer.
('90', 199, 1, 18, 380078) Prayer is not mere lip service.
('90', 199, 1, 19, 380110) It must express itself through action.
('90', 199, 1, 20, 380149) How shall we then pray during the Sacred Week?
('90', 199, 1, 21, 380196) We can pray by purging our hearts of any taint of communal hatred and ill will that might be lurking there and invoking God’s aid for the same.
('90', 199, 1, 22, 380340) Achievement of communal harmony would thus be one form of prayer.
('90', 199, 1, 23, 380406) Then we can pray by doing sacrificial spinning for the attainment of non violent swaraj.
('90', 199, 1, 24, 380495) I have a vivid recollection of how in 1919 every home in the Punjab hummed with the music of the spinning wheel.
('90', 199, 1, 25, 380608) A mountain of yarn was presented to me on one occasion during my tour, which was never equalled before, nor has it been since, except recently at Madura during my Madras tour.
('90', 199, 1, 26, 380784) What are the sisters of the Punjab doing today?
('90', 199, 1, 27, 380832) That is the question which you must ask yourselves during this week of introspection.
('90', 199, 1, 28, 380918) If the four hundred millions of India took spinning in earnest, and span for sacrifice, i.
('90', 199, 1, 29, 381009) e., not for self, with the name of God in their hearts and with common purpose of winning India’s freedom through non violence, their united effort would not only bring us freedom assuredly, but also provide us the means for safeguarding it after it is won, and enable us to point the way out of darkness to the whole world.
('90', 199, 2, 30, 381334) 1 This sentence and the paragraph that precedes are translated from Harijan Sevak.
('90', 200, 0, 1, 381417) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 201
('90', 200, 1, 2, 381461) The other day I was talking 1 to the I. N. A. men in the Red Fort.
('90', 200, 1, 3, 381528) We were discussing as to what they should do on their release.
('90', 200, 1, 4, 381591) They assured me that they would, on their release, serve India as true soldiers of non violence under the Congress flag.
('90', 200, 1, 5, 381712) I told them that today a true soldier of India is he who spins to clothe the naked, and tills the soil to grow more food to meet the threatening food crisis.
('90', 200, 1, 6, 381870) The Congress has declared that she would carry on the struggle for India’s independence through the method of non violence.
('90', 200, 1, 7, 381994) But she has not yet decided whether she would adhere to that method for the protection of that freedom against possible foreign aggression.
('90', 200, 1, 8, 382134) To me it is a self evident truth that if freedom is to be shared equally by all— even physically the weakest, the lame and the halt—they must be able to contribute an equal share in its defence.
('90', 200, 1, 9, 382329) How that can be possible when reliance is placed on armaments, my plebeian mind fails to understand.
('90', 200, 1, 10, 382430) I therefore, swear and shall continue to swear by non violence, i.e, by satyagraha or soul force.
('90', 200, 1, 11, 382528) In it physical incapacity is no handicap and even a frail woman or a child can put herself or himself on equal terms against a giant, armed with the most powerful weapons.
('90', 200, 1, 12, 382700) The eighteen fold constructive programme with the spinning wheel as its centre is the concrete expression of that spirit in organized society.
('90', 200, 1, 13, 382843) Let us realize that spirit by devoting ourselves prayerfully to the carrying out of the constructive programme during the National Week.

('90', 201, 0, 1, 383717) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 201, 1, 2, 383759) 259. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, NEW DELHI 1
('90', 201, 2, 3, 383802) April 7, 1946
('90', 201, 3, 4, 383816) Mahatma Gandhi referred to his visit to the Quakers’ silent prayer meeting this morning, and said that people at this meeting sat in absolute silence for half an hour.
('90', 201, 3, 5, 383984) They were busy in worship of God and realized the sense of God’s presence in their midst.
('90', 201, 3, 6, 384074) Mahatma Gandhi said that he had himself felt the presence of God during silence.
('90', 201, 3, 7, 384155) He asked the people to observe silence once a week as it played an important part in the individual’s life.
('90', 201, 4, 8, 384263) Gandhiji described how his own experience tallied with that of the Quakers.
('90', 201, 4, 9, 384339) Emptying of the mind of all conscious process of thought, and filling it with the spirit of God unmanifest, brings one ineffable peace and attunes the soul with the infinite.
('90', 201, 5, 10, 384514) The question may, however be raised: Should not one’s whole life be an unbroken hymn of praise and prayer to the Maker?
('90', 201, 5, 11, 384634) Why then have a separate time for prayer at all?
('90', 201, 5, 12, 384683) Brother Lawrence testified that “with him the set times of prayers were no different from other times, that he retired to pray according to the directions of his superior, but that he did not want such retirement, nor asked for it.
('90', 201, 5, 13, 384915) because his greatest business did not divert him from God.” Gandhiji does not question that view.
('90', 201, 5, 14, 385013) He observed: I agree that if a man could practise the presence of God all the twenty four hours, there could be no need for a separate time for prayer.
('90', 201, 5, 15, 385165) When the mind is compeletely filled with His spirit one cannot harbour ill will or hatred towards anyone and reciprocally the enemy will shed his enemity and become a friend.
('90', 201, 5, 16, 385340) It is not my claim that I have always succeded in converting enemies into friends, but in numerous cases it has been my experience that when the mind is filled with His peace all hatred ceases.
('90', 201, 5, 17, 385534) An unbroken succession of world teachers since the beginning of time have borne testimory to the same.
('90', 201, 5, 18, 385637) I claim no merit for it.
('90', 201, 5, 19, 385662) I know it is the due entirely to God’s grace.
('90', 201, 5, 20, 385708) Let us then in the Sacred Week seek His grace through the communion of silence and, maybe, the experience will abide us ever afterwards.
('90', 201, 6, 21, 385845) Harijan, 28 4 1946; also The Bombay Chronicle, 8 4 1946
('90', 201, 7, 22, 385901) 1 The speech is extracted from Pyarelal’s “Communion of Silence”.
('90', 201, 7, 23, 385967) The opening paragraph is from The Bombay Chronicle.
('90', 202, 0, 1, 386019) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 203
('90', 202, 1, 2, 386063) 260. VANASPATI AND GHEE
('90', 202, 2, 3, 386087) Sardar Sir Datar Singh has been putting up a fight on behalf of the cow in India.
('90', 202, 2, 4, 386169) The cow includes the buffalo.
('90', 202, 2, 5, 386199) In that case both can live.
('90', 202, 2, 6, 386227) If the baffalo includes the cow then both die.“The cow is the mother of prosperity.” To understand how this is so, the reader should see Shri Satis Chandra Das Gupta’s two instructive volumes 1 .
('90', 202, 2, 7, 386423) Here I want to confine myself to ghee which is in danger of being swamped by vanaspati, as the so called vegetable ghee is called.
('90', 202, 2, 8, 386554) In reality ghee is pure animal product.
('90', 202, 2, 9, 386594) One thoughtlessly uses the expression vegetable ghee or vanaspati, but it is a contradiction in terms.
('90', 202, 2, 10, 386697) Sardar Datar Singh has shown in a considered note that the sale of vanaspati has risen from 26,000 tons in 1937 to 1, 37,000 tons in 11945, i.e., it has increased more than 400 percent during seven years.
('90', 202, 2, 11, 386902) Pari passu the ghee industry has declined.
('90', 202, 2, 12, 386945) Those who would study the whole note should procure a copy from Sardar Datar Singh or the Goseva Sangh in Wardha.
('90', 202, 2, 13, 387059) I condense below the Sardar’s conclusions:
('90', 202, 3, 14, 387102) 1. Vanaspati as an article of diet is a very poor substitute for ghee.
('90', 202, 3, 15, 387173) It not only lacks absorption by the hunan system, but has no vitamin potency.
('90', 202, 4, 16, 387251) 2. Due to its similarity with ghee in texture and flavour, most of it is being used as an adulterant or is passed off as genuine ghee, and is, therefore, a great menace to ghee.
('90', 202, 5, 17, 387429) 3. Due to great margin of profit in this industry, it has developed from 26 thousands tons per annum in 1937 to 105 thousands tons in 1943, and there are proposals afoot to at least double this production in the near future.
('90', 202, 6, 18, 387654) 4. The ghee industry is India’s greatest cottage industry involving production of 2,30, 00, 000 maunds of ghee per annum at a cost of one hundred crores of rupees.
('90', 202, 7, 19, 387818) 5. The destruction of the ghee industry will not only adversely affect the welfare of the cultivators, but it will have a very delecterious effect on the cattle industry upon which the prosperiy of the whole nation directly depends.
('90', 202, 7, 20, 388051) In order to overcome the difficulties explained above, the following remedial measures are suggested:
('90', 202, 8, 21, 388153) 1The Cow in India
('90', 203, 0, 1, 388171) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 203, 1, 2, 388213) 1. If, due to some reasons, the Government cannot actually ban the manufacture altogether of vanaspati, it must at least be brought under strict control immediately.
('90', 203, 1, 3, 388379) 2. All manufacturers and wholesale and retail dealers of vanaspati should be licensed.
('90', 203, 1, 4, 388466) Such person should not be permitted to trade in or stock ghee on their premises.
('90', 203, 1, 5, 388547) 3. It should be made compulsory to colour all vanaspati at the source of its manufacture in India, and to colour all such imported product immediately on its landing at an Indian port.
('90', 203, 1, 6, 388732) Manufacturers must mix ten per cent of til oil with vanaspati.
('90', 203, 1, 7, 388795) The advantage of this would be that, if pure ghee is adultereated with vanaspati containing 10% til 1 oil, the detection will become extremely simple.
('90', 203, 1, 8, 388946) The presence of til oil can be most easily detected by well known chemical reactions.
('90', 203, 1, 9, 389032) 4. The addition of synthetic essences to give vanaspati a semblance of ghee should be prohibited.
('90', 203, 1, 10, 389130) 5. Persons selling food products in the preparation of which they use vanaspati should be required, under marketing law, to display a sign to that effect.
('90', 203, 1, 11, 389285) The presence of vanaspati on the premises not displaying the sign should be made an offence under law.
('90', 203, 1, 12, 389388) This will eradicate the evil of halwais 2 and confectioners using vanaspati for their preparations and passing them off as made from genuine ghee.
('90', 203, 1, 13, 389535) 6. Vanaspati should not be allowed to go in the market under names such as ‘Vegetable Ghee’ or ‘Vanaspati Ghee’ or any other name which is apt to deceive the customers as to its real origin of composition.
('90', 203, 1, 14, 389741) 7. Vanaspati should not be allowed to be marketed in packages of the same pattern as used for packing ghee and all pakages containing vanaspati should be distinctly labelled.
('90', 203, 1, 15, 389916) It is clear that the mischief arises principally from the greed of the very persons who worship the cow.
('90', 203, 1, 16, 390021) Vanaspati is wholly superfluous.
('90', 203, 1, 17, 390054) Oils may be refined of injurious property, but they do not need to be solidified nor need they be made to look like ghee.
('90', 203, 1, 18, 390176) An honest manufacturer will not stoop to counterfeits.
('90', 203, 1, 19, 390231) The market is flooded with them.
('90', 203, 1, 20, 390264) Counterfeit coins are heavily punishable.
('90', 203, 1, 21, 390306) Why not counterfeit ghee, since the genuine article is much more precious than coins?
('90', 203, 1, 22, 390392) But the sovereign remedy lies in all round honesty
('90', 203, 2, 23, 390443) 1 Sesame 2 Sweetmeat sellers
('90', 204, 0, 1, 390472) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 205
('90', 204, 1, 2, 390516) among dealers who are in a hurry to become rich even at the cost of the health of the nation.
('90', 204, 1, 3, 390610) NEW DELHI, April 8, 1946 Harijan, 14 4 1946

('90', 216, 3, 9, 409751) 283. TALK WITH SIR STAFFORD CRIPPS
('90', 216, 4, 10, 409786) NEW DELHI, April 10, 1946 After a few preliminaries I told Sir Stafford that I had come in response to the message he had sent and added “I am at your service now.”
('90', 216, 5, 11, 409951) CRIPPS : I am glad you have been good enough to come for this chat.
('90', 216, 5, 12, 410019) The whole thing is off the record and let us have a free and frank talk.
('90', 216, 5, 13, 410092) Will you please let me have your appraisal of the situation ?
('90', 216, 6, 14, 410154) GANDHIJI : It is too soon for me to give any definite appraisal.
('90', 216, 6, 15, 410219) Day to day developments are as much within your knowledge as mine.
('90', 216, 6, 16, 410286) So far as I am able to say, you and the Mission have come out with two objectives —the setting up of a machinery for framing the new constitution and the formation of an Interim Government at the Centre.
('90', 216, 6, 17, 410490) Are you hopeful of solving both the problems on this visit ?
('90', 216, 7, 18, 410551) C. I am quite hopeful.
('90', 216, 7, 19, 410574) I can tell you that we do not mean to go back from this country without solving both of them.
('90', 216, 8, 20, 410668) G. Cutting across both those problems is the issue of Pakistan.
('90', 216, 8, 21, 410732) If you are hopeful of solving both those problems it means that you have in the first instance to reach a decision on the issue of Pakistan.
('90', 216, 9, 22, 410873) C. Yes, you are right.
('90', 216, 9, 23, 410896) I would only add that we propose to reach a decision on the preliminary issue by bringing about an agreement.
('90', 216, 10, 24, 411006) G. The prospects of an agreement do not seem to look bright.
('90', 216, 10, 25, 411067) You have no doubt been reading the statements and interviews given recently by Jinnah and the speeches which have been made at the Muslim Legislators’ Convention.
('90', 216, 11, 26, 411230) C. Of course, I have.
('90', 216, 11, 27, 411252) They breathe fire and brimstone.
('90', 216, 11, 28, 411285) But you can take it from me that they do not disturb us.
('90', 216, 11, 29, 411342) I am quite accustomed to such things in my own
('90', 217, 0, 1, 411389) 218 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 217, 1, 2, 411431) country.G. That may be so.
('90', 217, 1, 3, 411458) But the effect of such statements and utterances may not be the same in this country as it is in your country with seasoned politics.
('90', 217, 2, 4, 411592) C. When I find a person getting louder and more violent in his denunciations of his opponents.
('90', 217, 2, 5, 411687) I get the feeling, as with your experience you will get under the same circumstances, that he is beginning to recognise that the extreme case for which he stands is becoming desperate.
('90', 217, 2, 6, 411872) G. I am very glad that the Mission whose advent to and presence in this country are the immediate provocation for these intensified denunciations, is not taking them at their face value.
('90', 217, 2, 7, 412059) But you were mentioning that you hoped to reach a solution on Pakistan by agreement.
('90', 217, 2, 8, 412144) In the present tempers of the two main parties, particu larly of the Muslim League, it is difficult to see how an agreement could be reached.
('90', 217, 3, 9, 412286) C. Has not the issue been reduced to a narrow one ?
('90', 217, 3, 10, 412338) The question is about the machinery for the administration of common subjects like defence, foreign affairs, etc.
('90', 217, 3, 11, 412452) Jinnah says that arrangements for their administration should be made by treaty between Pakistan and the rest of India.
('90', 217, 3, 12, 412572) The Congress says you must have a federal centre for administering them.
('90', 217, 3, 13, 412645) The gulf between these two points of view is by no means unbridgeable.
('90', 217, 3, 14, 412716) G. But are not the two points of view fundamentally different ?
('90', 217, 3, 15, 412780) The one is thinking of two independent sovereign states having treaty relation with each other, while the other is thinking in terms of a single federal State in which these common subjects would be assigned for administration to a Centre.
('90', 217, 4, 16, 413020) C. That of course is so; but where differences of opinion of such a nature do crop up it is quite possible for the two parties to come to an agreement if only they will meet, sit down and try to arrive at a solution by a process of give and take.
('90', 217, 4, 17, 413267) From my experience I could tell you that the issue is dispute and the difference to be reconciled cannot be considered too difficult for arriving at an agreed solution.
('90', 217, 4, 18, 413436) In international affairs much bigger issues between Governments have been and are being settled by that process.
('90', 217, 4, 19, 413549) It will be necessary for the Congress and the League each to come down a bit and meet.
('90', 217, 4, 20, 413636) G. Where are they to meet ?
('90', 217, 4, 21, 413664) What is the half way house that you want them to meet at ?
('90', 217, 5, 22, 413723) C. There is something like a confederation and a confederal Centre.
('90', 218, 0, 1, 413791) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 219
('90', 218, 1, 2, 413835) G. Would not a confederal Centre mean merely a gathering of representatives of Governments of Independent States ?
('90', 218, 2, 3, 413950) C. Yes.
('90', 218, 2, 4, 413958) G. And there would be no legislature of other auxiliary things which you find in a Centre of the usual type ?
('90', 218, 4, 5, 414068) G. What about the sanction behind the decision which such a confederate machinery will take ?C. No doubt it will be a loose unit.
('90', 218, 4, 6, 414198) But it is
('90', 218, 5, 7, 414208) unnecessary for me to point out to you that the States of the American Union formed first a confederation which later on developed into a federation.
('90', 218, 5, 8, 414358) There is no reason why a similar thing should not happen in India.
('90', 218, 6, 9, 414425) G. But you forget, however, some rather fundamental differences between the two cases.
('90', 218, 6, 10, 414512) In the case of America the states were independent units which first formed a loose kind of union.
('90', 218, 6, 11, 414611) They found that union did not satisfy their requirements and therefore developed the closer federal union that now exists.
('90', 218, 6, 12, 414734) In India we have now a unitary state with a common Centre.
('90', 218, 6, 13, 414793) You propose to scatter the units in this state.
('90', 218, 7, 14, 414841) C. Oh, no.
('90', 218, 7, 15, 414852) No, I am not scattering them.
('90', 218, 8, 16, 414882) G. When I said you are now scattering them I did not intend to convey that you personally were doing or wanted to do so.
('90', 218, 8, 17, 415003) I am only trying to put to you my understanding of the proposal that you apparently have under consideration, of forming a confederal union between the proposed Pakistan and the rest of India.
('90', 218, 8, 18, 415196) To resume what I was saying, the units of the existing unitary Indian State will, if the Pakistan idea is accepted, be scattered and then given the option of grouping themselves as they like into two or more independent States and come together in a loose confederation in the hope that later on the deficiencies of such a confederal arrangement will compel them to convert the confederal into a closer federal union.
('90', 218, 8, 19, 415614) In other words the ultimate development visualised is, so far as inter relations between the units and the administration on common subjects are concerned, to bring them into more or less the condition in which they are today.
('90', 218, 9, 20, 415841) C. I see your point, but if agreement has to be arrived at, we cannot altogether justify an acceptable or accepted solution on the basis of argument alone.
('90', 218, 9, 21, 415997) We have got to take psychological considerations into account.
('90', 218, 9, 22, 416060) All the same I do not wish you to take away from this conversation the idea that I am finally committed to the solution being found in the shape of a confederation.
('90', 218, 10, 23, 416225) G. I understand, but what psychological consideration are you
('90', 219, 0, 1, 416287) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 219, 1, 2, 416329) thinking of ?
('90', 219, 2, 3, 416343) C. Rightly or wrongly the Muslims have now very widespread amongst them the fear of Hindu domination and if India is to get on peacefully in the future they have to be convinced that the political system that is to be set up will be one which will remove this fear.
('90', 219, 3, 4, 416609) G. I am all for doing everything that in reason is possible for removing this fear.
('90', 219, 3, 5, 416693) But in the conditions of this country and taking into account the members of Muslims involved and the manner in which they are distributed it is difficult for anybody to agree that the removal of this fear can be accomplished only or even most successfully by setting up an independent State where, though the Muslims may be in a majority, there will be a very large population ofnon Muslims to reckon with.
('90', 219, 3, 6, 417101) What are the grounds for your hope that an agreement could be reached between the parties and how could the reaching of such an agreement be furthered ?
('90', 219, 4, 7, 417254) C. Between you and me, I may tell you that in spite of all the violent speeches that have been made within the last two days at the Muslim Convention, leading representatives of the Muslim community are, even as we are talking now furiously thinking as to how best they could moderate their published demands so as to arrive at a settlement with the other party and if a gentleman like you could go round Delhi and speak to your Muslim friends and bring them round to realise that if they did not show a spirit of accommodation they stood the risk of the decision of the Mission going against them on the issue of Pakistan, it would be of great assistance.
('90', 219, 5, 8, 417911) G. All advice which may come from people like me is suspect in Muslim circles.
('90', 219, 5, 9, 417990) Emotionally worked up as Muslim sentiment is today, the more effective method of making them climb down from their extravagantly high perch is for you or other members of the Mission giving to Jinnah as early as you can a broad hint that there was no likelihood of Pakistan being agreed to by the Mission or His Majesty’s Government.
('90', 219, 6, 10, 418324) C. No doubt that would be more effective, but the time is not yet for your making known even in an informal way what might be our ultimate decision even if we had reached one already.
('90', 219, 7, 11, 418508) G. I should have thought that there could be no hesitation in this matter.
('90', 219, 7, 12, 418583) With all the background of your history in this country, your present position and the state system you have built up, it is impossible for a person like me to imagine that if you were put on your conscience and asked to give a fair decision on the merits your judgment would be in favour of dividing the country into two or more
('90', 220, 0, 1, 418913) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 221
('90', 220, 1, 2, 418957) independent States.
('90', 220, 2, 3, 418977) C. I quite appreciate your point of view, but where agreement has to be arrived at, it may be necessary for the party even with the strongest case agreeing to accept something less than what it may rightly be considered entitled to in order to avoid a possible decision against them.
('90', 220, 2, 4, 419261) Often in my practice at the Bar, parties with a very strong case for whom I was appearing have come to me and said, “no doubt our case is very strong, but we do not know what the judge might finally decide.
('90', 220, 2, 5, 419468) Meanwhile the other side is offering to compromise on terms which although less than what we are rightfully entitled to are still sure and certain.
('90', 220, 2, 6, 419616) We have to place this against a possible adverse finding of the judge.
('90', 220, 2, 7, 419687) Shall we accept those terms ?”
('90', 220, 3, 8, 419718) G. If the two main protagonists do come to a settlement, nothing could be more satisfactory.
('90', 220, 3, 9, 419811) But the danger of a compromise is that the terms may be such, especially when they are dictated by pressure from a third party, as would not in the long run satisfy or be in the interests of the one party or the other or perhaps even both.
('90', 220, 4, 10, 420051) C. There is that point no doubt but has not it happened in Indian history already that the country has settled down to decisions which when given did not please any party, as the Communal Award for instance.
('90', 220, 4, 11, 420259) G. The Communal Award has no doubt been aquiesced in though everybody not excluding the Muslims have been loudly complaining against it.
('90', 220, 4, 12, 420396) But its successful enforcement is due primarily to the fact that the British have been in power and also strong enough to force down even an unpopular decision of that sort.
('90', 220, 4, 13, 420570) The conditions will, however, be very different if on the issue of Pakistan you give a decision of a similar nature.
('90', 220, 4, 14, 420687) India will be declared independent.
('90', 220, 4, 15, 420723) You will not be here to face the risk that will inevitably follow such a decision.
('90', 220, 4, 16, 420806) You will not be doing a service to the country by giving a decision which will intensify communal conflict and lead perhaps to a civil war, the responsibility for tackling which will not be yours.
('90', 220, 4, 17, 421003) So any decision that you give has more chance of being implemented successfully after you leave if it is one which is justifiable on the merits.
('90', 220, 4, 18, 421148) If on the other hand it is one which attempts merely to decide the dispute between two antagonists by denying to each a portion of his claim, whatever the merits may be, it will leave a trail of trouble behind.

('90', 221, 0, 1, 421603) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('90', 222, 1, 2, 424010) C. We shall no doubt go into this question.

('90', 223, 0, 1, 426370) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
