('90', 223, 5, 17, 428422) That protection was largely given by the Indian army and even from the commencement of the new regime, we shall have, according to the Commander in chief, an Indian Army which would be quite capable of providing fully for the internal defence requirements of the country.
('90', 223, 6, 18, 428694) C. There is the other point that the treaties were made by the British Crown and therefore except with their consent the obligations could not be transferred by the Crown to any other authority.
('90', 224, 0, 1, 428889) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 225
('90', 224, 1, 2, 428933) G. I have already said that you have effected these transfers twice in recent history.
('90', 224, 1, 3, 429020) On the first occasion Rulers of States were not even consulted, I believe.
('90', 224, 1, 4, 429095) That was in 1858 when the Crown took over the relations with Indian States from the East India Company and administered those relations through the Governor General in Council, that is the Government of India.
('90', 224, 1, 5, 429305) In 1935 this arrangement gave place to a new one under which the Crown withdrew the powers from the Governor General in Council and vested them in a Crown Representative.
('90', 224, 1, 6, 429476) Under independent India both the Governor General in Council and the Crown Representative will presumably disappear.
('90', 224, 1, 7, 429593) Their places will have to be taken by the new Government of what is now British India.
('90', 224, 1, 8, 429680) If the transfer of paramountcy to this new Government could be effected with consent of Indian States and on terms, perhaps, which might be made more acceptable to them than those on which paramountcy is exercised today by the Crown Representative it will be to the good, but if all or some of the States should hesitate as regards this transfer it has to be made in spite of such hesitation, for otherwise not merely the defence and foreign policy of India, but even the efficient internal administration of common economic and other matters will become almost impossible.
('90', 224, 2, 9, 430254) C. Formerly it was the Governor General that was controlling the Indian States.
('90', 224, 3, 10, 430334) G. You are mistaken.
('90', 224, 3, 11, 430355) The authority that was in law responsible for the conduct of relations with Indian States was, from 1858 to 1935, the Governor General in Council and not the Governor General.
('90', 224, 4, 12, 430531) C. But then the Governor General under that system was an autocrat and exercised all powers.
('90', 224, 5, 13, 430624) G. That may have been so but I thought you were placing insistence on the letter of the treaties and on the legal position as regards the obligations of paramountcy and you cannot deny that from those two points of view the authority concerned was the Governor General in Council and not the Governor General up to 1935.
('90', 224, 6, 14, 430945) C. Have nothing more to say on the subject of Indian States.
('90', 224, 7, 15, 431006) G. There is one point I would like to draw your attention to.
('90', 224, 7, 16, 431068) The enormous proportions which communal tension has reached in the country are directly traceable to separate electorates.
('90', 224, 7, 17, 431191) You cannot have healthy political life in any country where the electorates which
('90', 225, 0, 1, 431273) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 225, 1, 2, 431315) should exercise the sovereign controlling power are based upon religion, race, creed or caste.
('90', 225, 1, 3, 431410) If in connection with the negotiations you are now engaged in, it is possible as part of the agreement which you propose to see arrived at between the parties you can put pressure on them for substituting joint electorates for separate electorates, it will be a service of incalculabe value to the future political development of India.
('90', 225, 2, 4, 431747) C. I am all with you as regards separate electorates.
('90', 225, 2, 5, 431801) But don’t you think that we should rather not touch that question but leave it to the Interim Government and the constitution making body ?
('90', 225, 3, 6, 431941) G. The immediate matter for settlement no doubt is the issue of Pakistan, the formation of an Indian Government and the convening of a constitution making body.
('90', 225, 3, 7, 432102) But I thought it would be helpful to the Interim Government and the constitution making body if while pressure is being applied on both parties for a settlement on the major issue of Pakistan this important problem of electorates is also tackled and that even if a final decision is not arrived at on it now the way could be paved for a fairly satisfactory solution at the proper time.
('90', 225, 3, 8, 432488) Let me add that separate electorates are unhealthy not only to the Government of a united India; in fact if Jinnah has his way about Pakistan—which God forbid—separate electorates will prove a greater headache to Pakistan than to Hindustan.
('90', 225, 3, 9, 432729) The Muslim minority in the Hindustan of Jinnah’s conception will be 20 millions against a Hindu population in the same area of about 150 millions.
('90', 225, 3, 10, 432876) On the other hand the non Muslim minority in Pakistan will be 44 millions against a Muslim population therein of about 70 millions.
('90', 225, 4, 11, 433008) C. Oh !
('90', 225, 4, 12, 433016) That is Jinnah’s Pakistan !

('90', 226, 3, 4, 433962) In that hymn there is an assurance that whom God protects, no power on earth can injure.
('90', 226, 3, 5, 434051) The message of that hymn has a particular relevancy in the present times when the whole world is plunged in strife.
('90', 226, 3, 6, 434167) Although the war has ended, the causes that bought it about still continue.
('90', 226, 3, 7, 434243) This is not peace; it is only silent preparation for another war.
('90', 226, 3, 8, 434309) Look at the mutual recrimination, abuse and threats of violence that poison the atmosphere in Delhi itself.
('90', 226, 3, 9, 434417) But, if you have faith in God, you will remain unaffected by all these threats and abuse, and feel secure in the assurance that not a hair of your head will be injured so long as you are under God’s protecting care.
('90', 226, 3, 10, 434633) There is a saying to the effect that the outer is only the reflection of the inner.
('90', 226, 3, 11, 434717) If you are good, the whole world will be good to you.
('90', 226, 3, 12, 434771) On the contrary, if you feel tempted to regard anybody as evil, the odds are that the evil is within you.
('90', 226, 3, 13, 434877) The Choudhari Saheb 2 has had great regard for me.
('90', 226, 3, 14, 434928) If, therefore, somebody comes and tells me that he has abused the Hindus and called them names, I must refuse to believe it or think ill of him.
('90', 226, 3, 15, 435073) How can a person who till yesterday was like a blood brother to me turn all of a sudden into a hater of Hindus?
('90', 226, 3, 16, 435185) I would rather think that some Hindus has exasprated him by their behavior and made him lose his balance.
('90', 226, 3, 17, 435291) Similarly I am quite sure that if the Choudhary Saheb were to meet me today and I were to ask him if he really believed that the whole mass of Hindus had turned bad overnight, he would laugh at the remarks attributed to him and dismiss them as absured.
('90', 226, 3, 18, 435544) We must neither think evil about others nor suspect others of thinking evil about us.
('90', 226, 3, 19, 435630) Proneness to lend ear to evil reports is a sign of lack of faith.

('90', 228, 4, 7, 437531) 288. TALK WITH I. N. A. PRISONERS 1
('90', 228, 5, 8, 437567) April 11,1946
('90', 228, 6, 9, 437581) What particularly delighted Gandhiji during both these visits 2 was to see so many officers and men representing so meny different religions and races of India drawn together in a common cause—the cause of India’s freedom—and living together like members of one family.
('90', 228, 6, 10, 437851) It was like a whiff of fresh invigorating air from the free India that is to be.
('90', 228, 6, 11, 437932) The absence of the third party had enabled them to obliterate all communal distinctions and develop a perfect spirit of comaraderie in exile, but in detention, these distinctions were again being brought home to them.
('90', 228, 7, 12, 438150) “We never felt any distinction of creed or religion in the I. N. A.” remarked one of them.
('90', 228, 7, 13, 438241) “But here we are faced with ‘Hindu tea’ and ‘Mussalman tea’.
('90', 228, 7, 14, 438302) What are we to do?” Gandhiji asked: Why do you suffer it?
('90', 228, 8, 15, 438360) “No, we do not,” they replied.
('90', 228, 8, 16, 438391) “We mix ‘Hindu tea’ and Musalman tea’ exactly half and half, and then serve.
('90', 228, 8, 17, 438468) The same with food.
('90', 228, 8, 18, 438488) Gandhiji replied (laughing): That is very good.
('90', 228, 9, 19, 438536) Harijan, 21 4 1946
('90', 228, 10, 20, 438555) 289. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, NEW DELHI April 11, 1946
('90', 228, 11, 21, 438611) Summing up his reactions of his second visit 4, Gandhiji, in course of his remarks at the evening prayer, narrated how Col.
('90', 228, 11, 22, 438735) Niranjan Singh Gill, speaking for the I.N.A. prisoners in the Red Fort, had told him that they were finally convinced that India could not win or retain her independence except through non violence.
('90', 228, 12, 23, 438934) 1 This and the following items are extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”.
('90', 228, 12, 24, 439012) Pyarelal explains that Gandhiji met “some 35 I.N.A. prisoners.
('90', 228, 12, 25, 439075) detained in the Red Fort”.
('90', 228, 12, 26, 439102) According to report in The Bombay Chronicle, 12 4 1946, Gandhiji, who was accompanied by Vallabhbhai Patel and Pyarelal, met the officers in the afternoon for about half an hour.
('90', 228, 12, 27, 439281) 2 The earlier visit was at Kabul lines on April 4, 1946; vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting, New Delhi”, 5 4 1946 3Vide also the following item.
('90', 228, 12, 28, 439422) 4Vide the preceding item.
('90', 229, 0, 1, 439448) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 229, 1, 2, 439490) They had further assured him that after their release they would serve India as true soldiers of non violence.
('90', 229, 1, 3, 439601) “We shall disdain to depend on anybody’s charity for our support,” they had told him.
('90', 229, 1, 4, 439687) “We would rather dig the ground and till the land than compromise our self respect by living on subscriptions.” Gandhiji said : I told them that they would be sadly disillusioned, if they thought that a free India would be able to provide them all those emoluments, honours and perquisites which a foreign Government gave to the army men by the exploitation of the masses, while education, public health and the allied nation building activities were starved.
('90', 229, 1, 5, 440147) India was a poor country, her children were born in poverty and grew up in poverty into anaemic, stunted specimens of humanity.
('90', 229, 1, 6, 440275) If they wanted to become true soldiers of India, they must be prepared to share her destitution and try to ameliorate it to the best of their capacity, not expect to be pampered at the cost of the poor.
('90', 229, 1, 7, 440478) A true soldier would prefer death to charity.
('90', 229, 1, 8, 440524) In reply, they assured me that Netaji had inculcated upon them the twin lessons of poverty and equality.
('90', 229, 2, 9, 440629) Among us, officers and men live together and dine together without any distinction.
('90', 229, 2, 10, 440713) There is no high, no low.
('90', 229, 3, 11, 440739) Continuing, Mahatma Gandhi mentioned how he had asked the military officer in charge of the camp whether the I.N.A. personnel were well behaved.
('90', 229, 3, 12, 440884) The officer had replied that he was very pleased with their behaviour.
('90', 229, 3, 13, 440955) The I.N.A. people on their part had no complaint to make about the treatment they were receiving.
('90', 229, 3, 14, 441053) He considered all that to be a very healthy sign.
('90', 229, 3, 15, 441103) He interpreted it as indication of things to come.
('90', 229, 3, 16, 441154) A free India would not want to harbour bitter memories against anyone and would like to make friends with all including the Britishers.
('90', 229, 4, 17, 441290) In conclusion, he referred to the labours of the Cabinet Mission and suggested that all should pray during the National Week so that God might guide them as well as the people into right at this critical juncture in India’s history.
('90', 229, 5, 18, 441523) Harijan, 21 4 1946; also The Bombay Chronicle, 12 4 1946
('90', 229, 6, 19, 441580) 1 What follows is from The Bombay Chronicle.

('90', 230, 1, 2, 441669) 290. WHAT ABOUT WOMEN?
('90', 230, 2, 3, 441692) I am glad to read your reply 2 to the complaint that enough women have not been put up for elections or selected for official posts.
('90', 230, 2, 4, 441825) Neither in the ministries and legislatures nor in local bodies is merit given first cosideration in the matter of selection of candidates.
('90', 230, 2, 5, 441964) Consideration in the matter of selection of candidates.
('90', 230, 2, 6, 442020) Consideration of caste, community and province come into the picture and are the determinig factors.
('90', 230, 2, 7, 442121) The argument proffered in favour of such action is that none of these interest can be ignored.
('90', 230, 2, 8, 442216) If the argument holds, what about the interests of women ?
('90', 230, 2, 9, 442275) The above is from the letter 3 of an esteemed sister.
('90', 230, 2, 10, 442329) The sister’s argument boils down to this, that where everything is on a wrong basis, another wrong will not matter.
('90', 230, 2, 11, 442445) But, if we go on thus, the evil will grow and we shall be hopelessly caught in a vicious circle.
('90', 230, 2, 12, 442542) My appeal to women, therefore, is that they should intelligently become the personi fication of renunciation and thereby not only adorn but also raise the status of their sex and the nation.
('90', 230, 2, 13, 442733) So long as considerations of caste and community continue to weigh with us and rule our choice, women will be well advised to remain aloof and thereby build up their prestige.
('90', 230, 2, 14, 442909) The question is as to how best this can be done.
('90', 230, 2, 15, 442958) Today few women take part in politics and most of these do not do independent thinking.
('90', 230, 2, 16, 443046) They are content to carry out their parents’ or their husband’s behests.
('90', 230, 2, 17, 443119) Realizing their dependence, they cry out for women’s rights.
('90', 230, 2, 18, 443180) Instead of doing this, however, women workers should enrol womenas voters, impart or have imparted to them practical education, teach them to think indepen dently, release them from the chains of caste that bind them so as to bring about a change in them which will compell men to realize women’s strength and capacity for sacrifice and give her places of honour.
('90', 230, 2, 19, 443544) If they will do this, they will purify the present unclean atmosphere.
('90', 230, 2, 20, 443615) So much for women.
('90', 230, 2, 21, 443634) As to men, they should consider it their duty to come out of the impure atmosphere wherever it exists.
('90', 230, 2, 22, 443737) They will not beguided by cosiderations of caste and community, if these are banished from their own minds.
('90', 230, 2, 23, 443845) The best and easiest way to achieve this is for both men
('90', 230, 3, 24, 443902) 1 Originally written in Gujarati, this appeared as from “Harijanbandhu” published simultaneously with the source.
('90', 230, 3, 25, 444016) 2 Vide ”Hindustani” 3 Of which only extracts are reproduced here.
('90', 231, 0, 1, 444082) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 231, 1, 2, 444124) and women to stoop to conquer by becoming Harijans and that too of the last class., i.e., Bhangis or Mehtars.
('90', 231, 1, 3, 444234) Where capable women have been left out, men should make amends.
('90', 231, 1, 4, 444298) It is their duty to give such encouragement to women as will enable them to outshine men.

('90', 232, 3, 11, 446691) 293. FASTING IN THE AIR 1
('90', 232, 4, 12, 446717) Fasting has become a veritable epidemic.
('90', 232, 4, 13, 446758) The blame lies at your door.
('90', 232, 4, 14, 446787) So writes a correspondent and adds :
('90', 232, 5, 15, 446824) One can understand the efficacy of a fast for purpose of inward purification as also for the outward.
('90', 232, 5, 16, 446926) But fasts are undertaken nowadays for an increment in one’s own pay or in that of one’s group, for being selected as a candidate for the Assembly or for various other causes.
('90', 232, 5, 17, 447101) You encourage one man for fasting for the removal of untouchability and yet you are willing to let another die who is doing the same for a different cause.
('90', 232, 5, 18, 447257) Is this not injustice ?
('90', 232, 5, 19, 447281) Should you not lay down rules as to when to fast and when not to, what should be its duration, should fruit juices be taken or only water ?
('90', 232, 5, 20, 447421) You talk of the inner voice where you are concerned.
('90', 232, 5, 21, 447474) Would it not really be best, if you were to stop undertaking fasts yourself and stop others too?
('90', 232, 5, 22, 447571) There is force in the above argument.
('90', 232, 5, 23, 447609) It is, however, impossible to lay down rules.
('90', 232, 5, 24, 447655) Experience alone can suggest rules.
('90', 232, 5, 25, 447691) In particular cases it is open to a person to frame his own law or he can refer to me, if he believes me to be an authority.
('90', 232, 5, 26, 447816) I have had the temerity to claim that fasting is an infallible weapon in the armoury of satyagraha.
('90', 232, 5, 27, 447916) I have used it myself, being the author of satyagraha .
('90', 232, 5, 28, 447972) Anyone whose fast is related to satyagraha should seek my permission and obtain it in writing before embarking on it.
('90', 232, 5, 29, 448090) If this advice is followed, there is
('90', 232, 6, 30, 448127) 1 Originally written in Gujarati, this appeared as “from Harijanbandhu” published simultaneously with the source.
('90', 233, 0, 1, 448241) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 233, 1, 2, 448283) no need for framing rules, at any rate, in my lifetime.
('90', 233, 1, 3, 448339) One general principle, however, I would like to enunciate.
('90', 233, 1, 4, 448398) A satyagrahi should fast only as a last resort when all other avenues of redress have been explored and have failed.
('90', 233, 1, 5, 448515) There is no room for imitation in fasts.
('90', 233, 1, 6, 448556) He who has no inner strength should not dream of it, and never with attachment to success.
('90', 233, 1, 7, 448647) But, if a satyagrahi once undertakes a fast from conviction, he must stick to his resolve whether there is a chance of his action bearing fruit or not.
('90', 233, 1, 8, 448799) This does not mean that fasting cannot bear fruit [or is fruitless] 1. He who fasts in the expectation of fruit generally fails.
('90', 233, 1, 9, 448928) And even if he does not seemingly fail, he loses all the inner joy which a true fast holds.
('90', 233, 1, 10, 449020) Whether one should take fruit juice or not depends on one’s physical powers of endurance.
('90', 233, 1, 11, 449110) But no more fruit juice than is absol utely necessary for the body should be taken.
('90', 233, 1, 12, 449194) He probably has the greatest inner strength who takes only water.
('90', 233, 1, 13, 449260) It is wrong to fast for selfish ends, e.
('90', 233, 1, 14, 449301) for increase in one’s own salary.
('90', 233, 1, 15, 449335) Under certain circumstances it is permissible to fast for an increase in wages on behalf of one’s group.
('90', 233, 1, 16, 449440) Ridiculous fasts spread like plague and are harmful.
('90', 233, 1, 17, 449493) But when fasting becomes a duty, it cannot be given up.
('90', 233, 1, 18, 449549) Therefore I do fast when I consider it to be necessary and cannot abstain from it on any score.
('90', 233, 1, 19, 449645) What I do myself I cannot prevent others from doing under similar circumstances.
('90', 233, 1, 20, 449726) It is common kowledge that the best of good things are often abused.
('90', 233, 1, 21, 449795) We see this happening every day.

('90', 234, 11, 25, 451386) It culminated in the Jallianwala Bagh massacre, when Gen.
('90', 234, 11, 26, 451444) Dyer with a party of fifty sepoys opened fire on an unarmed people and the wounding of thrice that number.

('90', 248, 3, 6, 471435) The Government of India has suggested to Provincial Governments that in order to ensure continuous supplies, it would be desirable to enforce compulsory levies on agricultural produce in surplus districts.
('90', 248, 3, 7, 471641) This question of a compulsory levy is greatly agitating the public mind.
('90', 248, 3, 8, 471714) It is said that the control price fixed by the Government is too low and should be raised.
('90', 248, 3, 9, 471805) The answer to that is, that the price structure is an all India affair and it is not possible to raise the price in any particular province without affecting the structure as a whole.
('90', 248, 3, 10, 471989) There is bound to be a black market where selfish people can buy foodstuffs at higher prices to satisfy their individual needs.
('90', 248, 3, 11, 472117) No compulsion would be necessary if cultivators realize that it us their social and patriotic duty to do their utmost to feed their brothers and sisters.
('90', 248, 3, 12, 472271) I ask you to appeal to him at this critical juncture not to hoard, not to sell in the black market but to supply in the greatest measure possible to the Government stores.
('90', 248, 3, 13, 472443) We are doing our very best to encouragee the ‘Grow More Food’ and ‘Grow More Vegitables’ campaigns in the United Provinces.
('90', 248, 3, 14, 472567) The various suggestions 3 made by you have all been adopted.

('90', 249, 3, 11, 474219) And I must say that I know of no such example as my friend adverts to, if only because pubic men can ill afford to face a boycott by Indian Pressmen.
('90', 249, 3, 12, 474369) What has happened with me and, so far as I am aware, with others too is that they and I found it necessary at times to give special interviews to foreign journalists when it has been found necessary in the interest of the common cause to gate messages across the seas.
('90', 249, 3, 13, 474638) It is impossible in the present circumstances to do otherwise.
('90', 249, 3, 14, 474701) It would be as foolish to invite a boycott by foreign journalists as by Indian.
('90', 249, 3, 15, 474781) Any industrious person will find out that Indian journalists have been more often than not preferred by Indian pubic men again for the sake of the common cause.
('90', 249, 3, 16, 474942) As a fellow journalist I would urge journalists, whether Indian or foreign, to prefer their particular causes to their employers’ pockets or to descending to recriminations or personalities.

('90', 251, 4, 27, 479832) 1 From puni, meaning a sliver 2 The Hindi original appeared in Harijan Sevak, 21 4 1946
('90', 252, 0, 1, 479920) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 253
('90', 252, 1, 2, 479964) A. The question is apt.
('90', 252, 1, 3, 479988) Why should a minister draw Rs. 1,500 and a chaprasi or a teacher Rs. 15 p.
('90', 252, 1, 4, 480063) But the question cannot be solved by the mere raising of it.
('90', 252, 1, 5, 480124) Such differences have existed for ages.
('90', 252, 1, 6, 480164) Why shoud an elephant require an enormous quantity of food and a mere grain suffice for the ant?
('90', 252, 1, 7, 480261) The question carries its own answer.
('90', 252, 1, 8, 480298) God gives to each one according to his need.
('90', 252, 1, 9, 480343) If we could as definitely know the variations in the needs of men as those of the elephant and the ant, no doubts would arise.
('90', 252, 1, 10, 480470) Experience tells us that differences in requirements do exist in society 1 .
('90', 252, 1, 11, 480547) But we do not know the law governing them.
('90', 252, 1, 12, 480590) All therefore that is possible today is to try to reduce the differences as far as possible.
('90', 252, 1, 13, 480683) The reduction can be brought about by peacefu agitation and by the creation of public opinion.
('90', 252, 1, 14, 480778) It cannot be done by force or by duragraha in the name of satyagraha.
('90', 252, 1, 15, 480848) The ministers are the people’s men.
('90', 252, 1, 16, 480884) Their wants even before they took office were not those of chaprasis.
('90', 252, 1, 17, 480954) I would love to see a chaprasi become worthy of holding the office of a minister and yet not increase his needs.
('90', 252, 1, 18, 481067) It should also be clearly understood that no minister need draw up to the maximum of the salary fixed.
('90', 252, 1, 19, 481170) It is worth while pondering over one thing that arise out of the questions.
('90', 252, 1, 20, 481246) Is it possible for the chaprasi to support himself and his family on Rs. 15 p.
('90', 252, 1, 21, 481325) without taking bribe?
('90', 252, 1, 22, 481347) Should he not be given enough to keep him above temptation?
('90', 252, 1, 23, 481407) The remedy for this is that as far as possible we should we our own chaprasis.
('90', 252, 1, 24, 481486) But even so if we need them we must pay them enough for their requirements.
('90', 252, 1, 25, 481562) In this way the big gulf that exists between a minister and a chaprasi will be bridged.
('90', 252, 1, 26, 481650) It is another matter as to why the pay of the ministers has been raised from Rs. 500 to 1,500 p.m.
('90', 252, 1, 27, 481749) But this is nothing as compared with, and does not solve, the main problem.
('90', 252, 1, 28, 481825) With the solution of the latter it will ipso facto be solved.

('90', 253, 5, 10, 482503) 305. “ROMAN URDU” If there is Roman Urdu, why nat Roman Hindi?
('90', 253, 5, 11, 482566) The next step will be to Romanize the alphabets of all the languages of India.
('90', 253, 5, 12, 482645) They have done this for Zulu which had no alphabet of its own.
('90', 253, 5, 13, 482708) The attempt in India would be on a par with the attempt to foist Esperanto on the world.
('90', 253, 5, 14, 482797) It cannot succeed in the near future.
('90', 253, 5, 15, 482835) Believers in the Roman script in the place of all the known Indian scripts will have a circle of adherents but the movement cannot permeate the masses.
('90', 253, 5, 16, 482987) It should not.
('90', 253, 5, 17, 483002) Crores of people need not become so lazy as not to learn their own respective scripts.
('90', 253, 5, 18, 483089) A laudable attempt is being made not to replace the alphabets in vogue in India but to teach Nagari in addition in the hope that in course of time millions may learn to read the Indian languages in the Nagari character.
('90', 253, 5, 19, 483309) And since Urdu characters cannot for well known reasons be replaced by Nagari, it should be learnt by all the patriots who love their country too well to find the learning of the Urdu alphabet a burden.
('90', 253, 5, 20, 483512) All these attempts seem to me to be worthy.
('90', 253, 5, 21, 483556) With all my readiness to grasp new ideas, I have failed to find a substantial reason for inducing the spread of the Roman alphabet for the purpose of replacing the Nagari or Urdu script.
('90', 253, 5, 22, 483743) It is true that in the Indian Army, the Roman alphabet has been largely used.
('90', 253, 5, 23, 483821) I should hope that the Indian soldier, if he is saturated with the national spirit , will not mind learning both Nagari and Urdu charachers.
('90', 253, 5, 24, 483962) After all, amid the ocean of Indian humanity, the Indian soldier is a mere drop.
('90', 253, 5, 25, 484043) He must shed the Eng lish mode.
('90', 253, 5, 26, 484075) Probably the reason for Romanizing Urdu will be found in the English officer being too lazy to learn to read Urdu or Nagari characters.

('90', 257, 5, 10, 490623) In a moment of introspection the poet asks himself: O man, why have you left off taking God’s name?
('90', 257, 5, 11, 490723) You have not given up anger or lust or greed, but you have forgotton truth.
('90', 257, 5, 12, 490799) What a tragedy to save worthless pennies and to let go the priceless gem of God’s love!
('90', 257, 5, 13, 490887) Why would you not, O fool, renounce all vanities and throw yourself on the grace of God alone?
('90', 257, 5, 14, 490982) This does not mean that if one has wealth, it should be thrown away and wife and children should be turned out of doors.
('90', 257, 5, 15, 491103) It simply means that one must give up attachment to these things and dedicate one’s all to God and make use of His gifts to serve Him only.
('90', 257, 5, 16, 491243) It also means that if we take His name with all our being we are automatically weaned from all lust, untruth and baser passions.
('90', 257, 6, 17, 491372) 1 Raghavendra Sheshappa Pachapurkar (1896 1958); popularly known as Baba Raghavadas; hailed from Konkan but settled down in Gorakhpur; joined Congress in 1920; established various institutions for social, moral uplift of the people; started Geeta Press at Gorakhpur.

('90', 258, 0, 1, 491915) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 259
('90', 258, 1, 2, 491959) In the first shloka 1 of Ishopanishad that is repeated every day at the beginning of the prayer, one is asked to dedicate everything to God and then use it to the required extent.
('90', 258, 1, 3, 492139) The principal condition laid down is that one must not covet what belongs to another.
('90', 258, 1, 4, 492225) These two maxims contain the quintessence of the Hindu religion.
('90', 258, 1, 5, 492290) In another shloka which is recited during the morning prayer it is said: I do not ask for temporal power, nor do I ask to go to heaven, nor even to attain nirvana 2 .
('90', 258, 1, 6, 492457) What I ask for is that I may be able to relieve the pain of those who are in pain.
('90', 258, 1, 7, 492540) The pain might be physical, mental or spiritual.
('90', 258, 1, 8, 492589) Spiritual pain due to slavery to one’s passions is sometimes greater even than physical.
('90', 258, 1, 9, 492678) But God does not come down in person to relieve suffering.
('90', 258, 1, 10, 492737) He works through human agency.
('90', 258, 1, 11, 492768) Therefore, prayer to God to enable one to relieve the sufferings of others must mean a longing and readiness on one’s part to labour for it.
('90', 258, 1, 12, 492909) The prayer, you will note, is not exclusive.
('90', 258, 1, 13, 492954) It is not restricted to one’s own caste or community.
('90', 258, 1, 14, 493008) It is all inclusive.
('90', 258, 1, 15, 493029) It comprehends the whole of humanity.
('90', 258, 1, 16, 493067) Its realization would thus mean the establishment of the Kingdom of Heaven on earth.
('90', 258, 1, 17, 493152) Harijan, 28 4 1946

('90', 259, 1, 2, 494038) Indian Army ranks.
('90', 259, 1, 3, 494057) Some of the latter had seen him at Poona and sought his advice 1 .
('90', 259, 1, 4, 494124) Gandhiji had told them that it was open to them to give notice to the authorities that though they were in their pay their loyalty was mortgaged to India, not to the King of England.

('90', 260, 1, 2, 496462) 313. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING April 16, 1946
('90', 260, 2, 3, 496507) Speaking after prayers on Tuesday evening Gandhiji explained the meaning of swadeshi.
('90', 260, 2, 4, 496593) It hurt him deeply to see that after 25 years of repeeated exhortations the people had still not taken to swadeshi.
('90', 260, 2, 5, 496709) Some people regarded Indian mill cloth as swadeshi.
('90', 260, 2, 6, 496761) In his opinion, khadi alone was real swadeshi.
('90', 260, 2, 7, 496808) The machinery in the mills was not made in India.
('90', 260, 2, 8, 496858) Supposing in a free India they had their own engineers and were able to produce the machinery in India, he would still not call it swadeshi.
('90', 260, 2, 9, 496999) He did not want anything that might ruin the villages.
('90', 260, 2, 10, 497054) Honest servants of the people would devote themselves to the service of the villages and to that purpose become poor with the poorest.
('90', 260, 3, 11, 497189) Gandhiji expected all of them to take at least to khadi.
('90', 260, 3, 12, 497246) What was the use of their attending the prayers, if they did not follow what they heard there?
('90', 260, 3, 13, 497341) He had cried himself hoarse over khadi for the last 25 years.
('90', 260, 3, 14, 497403) But his non violence taught him that he was to go on proclaiming what he considered to be the truth.
('90', 260, 3, 15, 497504) It was not for him to lose temper or feel disappointed if the people did not listen to him.
('90', 260, 4, 16, 497596) They might well ask him how they were to wear khadi when they could not get it in the khadi bhandars.
('90', 260, 4, 17, 497698) Lack of khadi in the bhandars was of his doing.
('90', 260, 4, 18, 497746) Just as foreign cloth even if it appeared to be cheap was not cheap in reality, similarly khadi produced at one place and sold at another could not serve the purpose that it was intended to serve.
('90', 260, 4, 19, 497943) It was no use their wearing khadi without grasping the spirit behind it.
('90', 260, 4, 20, 498016) Khadi had been called the livery of swaraj.
('90', 260, 4, 21, 498060) It gave the wearer a certain respectable status.
('90', 260, 5, 22, 498109) But if khadi was to be the symbol of non violence and the livery of swaraj it had to be produced and used locally.
('90', 260, 5, 23, 498224) Therefore he had asked the bhandars not to import khadi from other provinces.
('90', 260, 5, 24, 498302) He had also asked them to sell it in exchange for yarn and to see that those who span for wages also wore khadi themselves.
('90', 260, 5, 25, 498426) They were not to accept the yarn from those spinners who span for wages but did not wear khadi themselves even though it might result in a temporary shortage of khadi.
('90', 260, 5, 26, 498594) People were taking to the idea, but during the transition stage, some inconvenience might be experienced.
('90', 260, 5, 27, 498700) The remedy was that they should spin for themselves and even engage handloom weavers for weaving khaddar.
('90', 260, 5, 28, 498806) There were many rich people in Delhi who could easily undertake this work.
('90', 260, 5, 29, 498881) The Hindustan Times, 17 4 1946

('90', 261, 12, 17, 499741) To me it seemed clear that the
('90', 261, 13, 18, 499772) 1 Husband of Subhas Chandra Bose’s niece Bela.

('90', 266, 2, 3, 507878) HARIJAN MANDIR, NEW DELHI, April 18, 1946
('90', 266, 3, 4, 507920) DEAR PRAKASAM, I wrote the enclosed note 1 for Harijan.
('90', 266, 3, 5, 507976) It absolutely represents my confirmed view which I told you personally.
('90', 266, 3, 6, 508048) But the members of the Working Committee were here last night, among them Pandit Nehru and others.
('90', 266, 3, 7, 508147) They had seen a copy of my note and they all thought that I should not publish it.
('90', 266, 3, 8, 508230) I defended it strenuously but on turning it over in my mind last night I came to the conclusion that I would be taking perhaps an undue advantage of my public position to air my personal view.
('90', 266, 3, 9, 508423) Instead, therefore, of allowing the note to be published in Harijan, I feel I should satisfy my conscience by sending a copy to you and letting you make what use you like of it.
('90', 266, 3, 10, 508601) I would, however, like to emphasize the fact that if you allow yourself to be chosen as Prime Minister or hold any office or even be a member of Parliament, it will be bad for the country and of course for yourself.
('90', 266, 3, 11, 508817) As I have said in the note, it will be apparent to you that your reconsideration against your minstership of your philosophy will be perfectly valueless and ludicrous.
('90', 266, 4, 12, 508985) Yours, BAPU SHRI T. PRAKASAM RAJAH STREET THYAGARAYANAGAR MADRAS

('90', 270, 3, 4, 515480) In talking to a friend the other day who was suggesting an expedient to solve the political tangle, contrary to his inner conviction of the wrong of it, Gandhiji told him that it was unworthy for a man of faith ever to believe that anything but evil could be born out of a poisonous germ.

('90', 270, 3, 6, 515924) There was no poison there, no hatred, no fear.

('90', 270, 4, 9, 516080) 328. SOVEREIGN REMEDY
('90', 270, 5, 10, 516102) Your new note in nature cure—reciting of Ramanama as the sure remedy—leaves me completely bewildered.
('90', 270, 5, 11, 516204) The modern youth refrains from challenging some of your views out of toleration.
('90', 270, 5, 12, 516285) Their attitude may be summed up in the following : ‘Well, Gandhiji has taught us a whole lot of things; he has elevated us to unimaginable heights; he has, above all, brought swaraj within our reach; why not ‘suffer’ his Ramanama ‘fad’?
('90', 270, 6, 13, 516522) Inter alia you have said the following :
('90', 270, 7, 14, 516563) “No matter what the ailment from which a man may be suffering, recitation of Ramanama from the heart is the sure cure” (Harijan, 3 3 ’46) 3
('90', 270, 8, 15, 516703) “Man should seek out and be content to confine he means of cure to the five elements of which the body is composed, i.
('90', 270, 8, 16, 516822) e., earth, water, akasha 4, sun and air” (Harijan, 3 3 ’46).
('90', 270, 9, 17, 516883) “And my claim is that the recitation of Ramanama is a sovereign remedy for our physical ailments also” (Harijan, 7 4 ’46).
('90', 270, 10, 18, 517006) At first, when you introduced this new note in the system of nature cure, I thought you were merely putting in other words a kind of psycho therapy or Christian Science based on faith.
('90', 270, 10, 19, 517191) I interpreted my first quotation above in that light.
('90', 270, 10, 20, 517245) The second sentence quoted above is difficult to grasp.
('90', 270, 10, 21, 517301) After all, it
('90', 270, 11, 22, 517315) 1 Reproduced from Amrit Kaur’s report entitled “The Lesson of the Cross”, dated “New Delhi, Good Friday, 1946”.

('90', 271, 0, 1, 517594) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 271, 1, 2, 517636) is physically impossible for medicines to be composed of anything but the five elements to which you refer, and which you say must be the sole means of cure.
('90', 271, 1, 3, 517794) If faith is what you insist on I have no quarrel; it is necessary for the patient to co operate in getting well also by faith.
('90', 271, 1, 4, 517921) But it is difficult to accept that faith alone would cure “our physical ailment also”.
('90', 271, 1, 5, 518008) Two years ago, my little daughter was struck by infantile paralysis; it was the most modern treatment that saved the child from becoming a cripple for life.
('90', 271, 1, 6, 518165) You would agree that it would not avail to ask a two and a half year old child to recite Ramanama to be rid of infantile paralysis; and I would like to see you persuade any mother to do the recitation (and recitation alone) on her child’s behalf.
('90', 271, 1, 7, 518412) The authority from Charka 1 that you have quoted in the issue of March 24, 2 leaves me cold; you have taught me not to accept anything, however ancient and however authoritative it may be, if it does not appeal to my heart.
('90', 271, 1, 8, 518636) Thus writes a teacher of youth.

('90', 274, 3, 5, 523226) By clinging to the letter of the pledge we often come to observe it only in form.
('90', 274, 3, 6, 523308) The spirit is the real thing which alone makes us aware of our understanding of it.

('90', 274, 3, 9, 523610) I see there is a subtle pride in being content with the observance of a vow in its spirit.
('90', 274, 3, 10, 523701) I therefore do not deceive myself.
('90', 274, 3, 11, 523736) Literally according to my vow I gave up animal milk for all time, but since by milk is generally meant buffalo’s or cow’s milk and also because at the time of taking the vow I was not at all aware of any other milk, I took advantage of my own ignorance and started taking goat’s milk.
('90', 274, 3, 12, 524021) Even then it did hurt my soul but some how I consoled my mind.
('90', 274, 3, 13, 524084) Had I been able to stick to my resolve of abjuring all animal milk, possibly I might have been freed of this body.

('90', 276, 10, 17, 527069) Speaking after prayers on Friday, Gandhiji referred to his latest love—nature cure.
('90', 276, 10, 18, 527153) He had believed in it for years.
('90', 276, 10, 19, 527186) He felt that what he had shared with his freind and close associates so far should be shared with the masses poor villagers.
('90', 276, 10, 20, 527311) He had been thinking of the villagers in particular in connection with the Kasturba 2 work.
('90', 276, 11, 21, 527403) Medical help had become an elaborate and costly affair nowadays.
('90', 276, 11, 22, 527468) Those who could afford it called in a doctor who wrote out a prescription in a language unintelligible to the layman.
('90', 276, 11, 23, 527586) The latter carried the prescription to the chemist, took the medicine and counted upon it to cure him.
('90', 276, 11, 24, 527689) Apart from the utility of this method of treatment, it was beyond the reach of the masses.
('90', 276, 12, 25, 527780) During his recent tour of Bengal and Madras lots of people had joined the prayers and in the mass singing of Ramdhun.
('90', 276, 12, 26, 527898) He had since introduced Ramanama in
('90', 276, 13, 27, 527934) 1 The addressee’s second, to Gangi.

('90', 277, 6, 17, 529191) Shri S. A. Ayer of the Azad Hind Government came to discuss with Gandhiji the other day the question of issuing a news bulletin in the Roman script for the I. N. A. as proposed by the central I. N. A. Relief Committee.
('90', 277, 6, 18, 529410) “The men had got used to the Roman script while they were in the Indian Army and so retained it when they were operating in South East Asia.” You forget that you are not working in South East Asia today, but in India.
('90', 277, 6, 19, 529628) May I ask if these men ever write to their wives and children in the Roman script?
('90', 277, 7, 20, 529711) Never, they write one and all in Hindi, Urdu, Tamil or any of the other Indian scripts.
('90', 277, 7, 21, 529799) This means that they all know one or the other Indian script.
('90', 277, 7, 22, 529861) I could understand your wanting to adopt the Roman script as a temporary makeshift if we had no script of our own.
('90', 277, 7, 23, 529976) But to adopt the Roman script for Hindustani which has got two acknowledged scripts
('90', 277, 8, 24, 530060) 1 Viz., physical, mental and spiritual 2 Reproduced from Pyarelal’s report entitled “Cultural Conquest and Roman Script” dated “New Delhi, April 20, 1946” 3 ibid
('90', 278, 0, 1, 530222) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 279
('90', 278, 1, 2, 530266) is only a sign of the psychological conquest that the English have made over us.
('90', 278, 1, 3, 530347) In order to conquer the English who had conquered you, you adopted the English garb, i.
('90', 278, 1, 4, 530435) e., Roman script, for your bulletins in South East Asia.
('90', 278, 1, 5, 530492) You should have discarded this symbol of the cultural conquest and insisted on having your bulletin in the two Indian scripts rather than in Roman.
('90', 278, 1, 6, 530640) The latter was primarilly adopted for the sake of the British officers and men who had to learn Hindustani in order to rule over us.
('90', 278, 1, 7, 530773) They solved the difficulty presented by the permutations and combinations of the Urdu alphabet and tempted us by their typerwriters, telegraph and printing machines which use Roman script.
('90', 278, 1, 8, 530962) We succumbed.
('90', 278, 1, 9, 530976) We may not hark back to the symbol of our cultural conques when we are out to end India’s slavery in toto.
('90', 278, 1, 10, 531083) When you served in the British army it was with the prospect of getting rewards in the form of decorations, comfortable pay and pensions, grants of land, etc.
('90', 278, 1, 11, 531242) But now you don’t want such temptations.
('90', 278, 1, 12, 531283) You serve only for the independence and honour of your country.

('90', 278, 4, 26, 532411) These organizations, besides taking up the improvement of their institutions as envisaged by the Government of India, in the
('90', 278, 5, 27, 532536) 1 Agricultural expert and pioneer of animal husbandry in the Punjab
('90', 279, 0, 1, 532604) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 279, 1, 2, 532646) present threatened famine conditions can come to the country’s help by production of more milk in the institutions.
('90', 279, 1, 3, 532762) The number of well organized gashalas and pinjrapoles can be taken as half, i.
('90', 279, 1, 4, 532841) e., 1,500. The cattle may be classified as: 1. Good dairy type 20% 1,20,000 2. Fair type—good for breeding, though not highly productive 20% 1,20,000 3. Old, infirm and unfit for further breeding 60% 3,60,000 It is the first and second class that could be exploited for milk production and breeding.
('90', 279, 1, 5, 533141) Out of these 2,40,000 half will be milch and half dry.
('90', 279, 1, 6, 533196) Better feeding, management, organization, etc., would mean an increase in production of 1,20,000 seers or, say, 3,000 maunds of milk per day.
('90', 279, 1, 7, 533338) In order to achieve this end immediately, a skeleton plan is suggested below: 1. Productive animals should be separated from those that are aged, infirm or otherwise useless.
('90', 279, 1, 8, 533513) The latter should be removed to rural areas, preferably to forest rakhs 1 in order to relieve congestion and allow better feeding of productive.
('90', 279, 1, 9, 533658) Their care, as well as that of dry stock farms, may be in the hands of a committee.
('90', 279, 1, 10, 533742) 2. For the achievement of this end, the stock should be divided in the following manner: a.
('90', 279, 1, 11, 533834) Milch animals about to calve should be kept at the goshala premises.
('90', 279, 1, 12, 533903) Dry animals fit for breeding should be kept on the lands, if any, belonging to the goshala in the neighbourhood or may provided for at a place from where they could be returned when about to calve, and the animals which go dry in the goshala, should be sent there.
('90', 279, 1, 13, 534168) 3. The congestion relieved, goshalas and pinjrapoles will have enough space to house cattle properly, feed them scientifically and carry out other improvements.
('90', 279, 1, 14, 534329) 4. To further help, encourage and stimulate these institutions in this direction, it is suggested to help them financially by giving them 50% reduction on concentrates and fodder on the condition that these institution will increase their

('90', 281, 4, 8, 537546) 340. NOTES 2
('90', 281, 5, 9, 537559) ‘SILK KHADI’
('90', 281, 6, 10, 537572) If particle payment in yarn is necessary for buying cotton khadi why shoud the same not apply to ‘silk khadi’?
('90', 281, 6, 11, 537683) There can be only one answer to this question.
('90', 281, 6, 12, 537730) Silk khadi too is khadi and its purchase should, therefore, also be contingent on the requisite payment of yarn.
('90', 281, 7, 13, 537843) WHY ONLY YARN?

('90', 285, 2, 3, 544582) April 20, 1946 I attach far more importanc to the cultural aspect of education than to the literary 2. Culture is the foundation, the primary thing which the girls ought to get from here.
('90', 285, 2, 4, 544770) It should show in the smallest detail of your conduct and personal behaviour, how you sit, how you walk, how you dress, etc., so that anybody might be able to see at a glance that you are the products of this institution.
('90', 285, 2, 5, 544992) Inner culture must be reflected in your speech, the way in which you treat visitor and guests, and behave towards one another and your teachers and elders.
('90', 285, 2, 6, 545148) I was pleased too that you walked all the distance to and from Bhangi Nivas, when you came to see me.
('90', 285, 2, 7, 545250) But if you came only to please me, your trudging had no merit.
('90', 285, 2, 8, 545313) It will do you no good.
('90', 285, 2, 9, 545337) You must make it a rule to prefer walking to using a conveyance.
('90', 285, 2, 10, 545402) Motor car is not for the millions.
('90', 285, 2, 11, 545437) You will therefore shun it.
('90', 285, 2, 12, 545465) Million cannot afford even train journey.
('90', 285, 2, 13, 545507) Their world is their village.
('90', 285, 2, 14, 545537) It is a very small thing but if you faithfully adhere to this rule it will transform your entire life and fill it with a sweetness that natural simplicity carries with it.
('90', 285, 2, 15, 545709) Education here won’t qualify you for luxurious living.
('90', 285, 2, 16, 545764) I want the Harijan girls here to show such a degree of culture that everybody should feel ashamed to regard them as untouch ables.
('90', 285, 2, 17, 545895) That is the goal of the Harijan Sevak Sangh’s activities.
('90', 285, 2, 18, 545953) This institution should demonstrate to the whole world the heights to which Harijans can rise, if they are free from the incubus of untouch ability and conversely the sacrilege and inhumanity of the institution of untouchability itself.

('90', 289, 1, 2, 552726) 350. “HARIJAN” IN URDU SCRIPT
('90', 289, 2, 3, 552756) Harijan is variously described as ‘Harijan Sevak’ when it is the Hindustani and Harijanbandhu when it is the Gujarati edition.
('90', 289, 2, 4, 552883) Hindustani was Hindi when it was Nagari type only.
('90', 289, 2, 5, 552934) Now, for reasons already known, it is Hindustani in the two scripts—Nagari and Urdu.
('90', 289, 2, 6, 553019) The Urdu edition would have been published simultaneously, if the arrangement could have been completed.
('90', 289, 2, 7, 553124) But there were difficulties of official permission and type to be surmounted.
('90', 289, 2, 8, 553202) Litho printing became well nigh impossible, and expert advice favoured Urdu type.
('90', 289, 2, 9, 553284) The type could not be had for the wanting.
('90', 289, 2, 10, 553327) But it is now hoped definitely to bring out the Urdu edition on 5th May next.
('90', 289, 2, 11, 553405) Whilst the matter in the three editions is not as a rule mere translation, one of another, and to an extent differs in the three editions, the Nagari and Urdu will be the same, word for word.
('90', 289, 2, 12, 553597) An endeavour will be made to produce Hindustani which will neither be Sanskritized Hindi nor Persianized Urdu.
('90', 289, 2, 13, 553708) Whether the Hindustani will be popular or not will depend as much upon the writers for the Hindustani Harijan as upon its readers.

('90', 291, 8, 18, 557882) 354. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING April 21, 1946
('90', 291, 9, 19, 557927) Gandhiji had noticed that several men and women did not take part in beating time with Ramdhun.
('90', 291, 9, 20, 558023) He pulled them up in his after prayer discourses on Sunday.
('90', 291, 9, 21, 558083) There was nothing to be ashamed of in repeating the name of God and in beating time with it.
('90', 291, 9, 22, 558176) Modesty was an admirable virtue, but out of place it became a fault.
('90', 291, 10, 23, 558245) Reverting to the subject of the previous evening, i.
('90', 291, 10, 24, 558298) e., nature cure, Gandhiji spoke about pure water, the second in importance among the five natural elements, the first one being air about which he had spoken on Saturday 3 .
('90', 291, 10, 25, 558472) Large numbers of men and women in this country drank impure water and washed their clothes with and bathed in water which made the body and the clothes dirtier than before.
('90', 291, 11, 26, 558645) 1 Of Karaikudi 2 Amritlal V. Thakkar (1869 1951); joined Servants of India Society in 1914; established Bhil Seva Mandal in 1923; President, Gujarat Antyaja Seva Mandal: Secretary, Harijan Sevak Sangh; General Secretary, Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Trust; established Bharatiya Adimjati Sevak Sangh 3 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 20 4 1946
('90', 292, 0, 1, 558995) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 293
('90', 292, 1, 2, 559039) Will any of you care to bathe or wash your clothes in the gutter water?
('90', 292, 1, 3, 559111) Yet many of the small tanks where people bathe and wash and even drink from are no cleaner than the gutter.
('90', 292, 1, 4, 559219) Nature is lenient.
('90', 292, 1, 5, 559238) If often does not punish us for our sins immediately.
('90', 292, 1, 6, 559292) Thus we can go on breathing impure air and drinking impure water over long periods without any dramatic ill effects.
('90', 292, 1, 7, 559409) But there is not the slightest doubt that such a thing lowers the vitality and makes one fall an easy prey to disease.
('90', 292, 2, 8, 559528) Gandhiji told the audience what he had seen on the banks of the sacred Ganges at Hardwar.
('90', 292, 2, 9, 559618) People went there to wast off their sins, but they made the place so dirty that it could not even wash their bodies clean.
('90', 292, 2, 10, 559741) He used to find it difficult to bathe at Har ki Pauri if he was at all late.
('90', 292, 2, 11, 559818) People evacuated on the banks and did not even care to cover it up with sand.
('90', 292, 2, 12, 559896) They made the bathing ghat filthy, strewing flowers were trampled under the feet and so on.
('90', 292, 2, 13, 559988) It was a painful state of affairs, a thing of which Indains had real cause to be ashamed.
('90', 292, 3, 14, 560078) He had taken up the new job of advising people on nature cure.
('90', 292, 3, 15, 560141) A doctor had to go through five years of hard studies before he could begin to treat patients.
('90', 292, 3, 16, 560236) Not so the nature cure man.
('90', 292, 3, 17, 560264) Speaking about himself he said he had picked up the essentials of nature cure by reading a few books and talking to experts in the line.
('90', 292, 3, 18, 560401) Experience and experimentation had made up the rest.
('90', 292, 3, 19, 560454) They could all do the same and became their own doctors.
('90', 292, 3, 20, 560511) People had a notion that what was simple was no good.
('90', 292, 3, 21, 560565) A spinning wheel was simple.
('90', 292, 3, 22, 560594) It was, therefore, condemned as primitive and crude.
('90', 292, 3, 23, 560647) A mill cost a lot and was elaborate.
('90', 292, 3, 24, 560684) It was an indication of progress.
('90', 292, 3, 25, 560718) If this was their view, he was afraid they would have no use for him as he was but a simple minded villager and a believer in the philosophy of simplicity.
('90', 292, 3, 26, 560874) But he knew that most of them were simple minded men and women like him and though they lived in a city, they had not lost all contact with the villages.
('90', 292, 3, 27, 561028) Therefore, he felt emboldened to place nature cure before them.
('90', 292, 4, 28, 561092) Pure air and pure water were the first essentials, and of course Ramanama was there all the time.
('90', 292, 4, 29, 561190) A man who repeated Ramanama and thereby cleansed his inner being could not tolerate the filth outside.
('90', 292, 4, 30, 561293) If millions took to Ramanama in real earnest there would be no riots, which were a social malady, and there would be no illnesses.
('90', 292, 4, 31, 561424) The Kingdom of Heaven would come on earth.
('90', 292, 4, 32, 561467) The Hindustan Times, 22 4 1946

('90', 293, 1, 2, 561540) 355. MINISTERS’ DUTY
('90', 293, 2, 3, 561561) It is legitimate to ask what Congress ministers will do for khaddar and other village industries now that they are in office.
('90', 293, 2, 4, 561687) I should broaden the question and apply it to all the Provincial Government of India.
('90', 293, 2, 5, 561773) Poverty is common to all the provinces and so are means of alleviation in terms of the masses.
('90', 293, 2, 6, 561868) Such is the experience of both the A. I. S. A. and the A. I. V. I. A. A suggestion has been made that there should be a separate minister for the work, as, for proper organization, it will occupy all the time of one minister.I dread to make the suggestion, for we have not yet outlived the English scale of expenditure.
('90', 293, 2, 7, 562188) Whether a minister is separately appointed or not, a department for the work is surely necessary.
('90', 293, 2, 8, 562286) In these times of scarcity of food and clothing, this department can render the greatest help.
('90', 293, 2, 9, 562381) The ministers have experts at their disposal through the A. I. S. A. and the A. I. V. I. A. It is possible to clothe today the whole of India in khadi on the smallest outlay and in the shortest time possible.
('90', 293, 2, 10, 562590) Each Provincial Government has to tell the villagers that they must manu facture their own khaddar for their own use.
('90', 293, 2, 11, 562708) This there will undoub tedly be a surplus for the cities at least to a certain extent which, in its turn, will reduce the pressure on the local mills.
('90', 293, 2, 12, 562859) The latter will then be able to take part in supplying the want of cloth in other parts of the world.
('90', 293, 2, 13, 562961) How can this result be brought about?
('90', 293, 2, 14, 562999) The Governments should notify the villagers that they will be expected to manufacture khaddar for the needs of their villages within a fixed date after which no cloth will be supplied to them.The Govern ments in their turn will supply the villagers with cotton seed or cotton wherever required, at cost price and the tools of manufacture also at cost, to be recovered in easy instalments payable in, say five years or more.
('90', 293, 2, 15, 563423) They will supply them with instructors wherever necessary and undertake to buy surplus stock of khaddar, provided that the villagers in question have their cloth requirement supplied from their own manufacture.
('90', 293, 2, 16, 563634) This should do away with cloth shortage without fuss and with very little overhead charges.
('90', 293, 2, 17, 563726) The villages will be surveyed and a list prepared of things that can be manufactured locally with little or no help and which may be required for village use or for sale outside, such for instance, as ghani 1 pressed oil and cakes, burning oil prepared through ghanis, hand 
('90', 293, 3, 18, 564001) 1 Oil press
('90', 294, 0, 1, 564013) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 295
('90', 294, 1, 2, 564057) pounded rice, tad gud 1, honey, toys, mats, hand made paper, village soap, etc.
('90', 294, 1, 3, 564137) If enough care is thus taken, the villages, most of them as good as dead or dying, will hum with life and exhibit the immense possibilities they have of supplying most of their wants themselves and of the cities and towns of India.
('90', 294, 1, 4, 564369) Then there is the limitless cattle wealth of India suffering from criminal neglect.
('90', 294, 1, 5, 564453) Goseva Sangh, as yet not properly experienced, can still supply valuable aid.
('90', 294, 1, 6, 564531) Without the basic training the villagers are being starved for education.
('90', 294, 1, 7, 564605) This desideretum can be supplied by the Hindustani Tamil Sangh.
('90', 294, 1, 8, 564669) The experiment was already commenced by Congress Govern ments but it was interrupted by the resignations of the Congress ministries.
('90', 294, 1, 9, 564802) 2 The thread can be easily resumed now.

('90', 294, 3, 12, 564907) SUGAR AND SWEETMEATS
('90', 294, 4, 13, 564928) Q. The suggar ration in Bombay has just been reduced by 25 per cent.
('90', 294, 4, 14, 564997) Would it not have been fairer to reduce sweetmeat shops’ rations rather than cut down the individual’s?
('90', 294, 4, 15, 565101) A. It is always well to cut down the ration of sweet vendors rather than that of individuals.
('90', 294, 4, 16, 565195) In these hard times I would not mind if sweet making were even prohibited.
('90', 294, 4, 17, 565270) Sweetmeats are not a necessary part of a wholesome diet.
('90', 294, 5, 18, 565327) WHITE BREAD AND BROWN
('90', 294, 6, 19, 565349) Q. Up till January it was obligatory to mix ten per cent of bran with wheat flour.
('90', 294, 6, 20, 565432) Later the rule was obolished.
('90', 294, 6, 21, 565462) Should it not be reinforced?
('90', 294, 6, 22, 565491) A. I am a witness to the age old rivalry between white and whole meal brown bread.
('90', 294, 6, 23, 565574) People are attracted by whiteness.
('90', 294, 6, 24, 565609) I nurse the belief that Negro is not drawn by it.
('90', 294, 6, 25, 565659) Be that as it may, it is a fact that special effort is made to make bread look white.
('90', 294, 6, 26, 565745) Fortunately, only city dwellers indulge in such fads.
('90', 294, 6, 27, 565799) Doctors say that one chapati of whole meal flour is more tasty and contains more nourishment than two to five chapatis made out of refined flour.
('90', 294, 6, 28, 565945) And in these days it

('90', 295, 1, 2, 566176) is our duty to use whole meal, because all flour saved is flour gained.
('90', 295, 1, 3, 566248) From one point of view it is even more than that.

('90', 295, 1, 8, 566617) ROWDYISM IN ELECTIONS Q. You are no doubt aware of the rowdyism resulting in severe damage during one of the recent elections in Bombay.
('90', 295, 1, 9, 566754) Does it become the teacher of ahimsa to keep silent on such an occasion?
('90', 295, 1, 10, 566827) A. I do not want to enter into the question of whether silence becomes me or not.
('90', 295, 1, 11, 566909) If the rowdyism is not a forerunner of what the future holds, it will be wrong to take note of it.
('90', 295, 1, 12, 567008) Such sporadic clashes should not worry us.
('90', 295, 1, 13, 567051) The education of the masses in ahimsa can make way gradually.
('90', 295, 1, 14, 567113) It may be that it will develop from the lessons learnt from such happenings.
('90', 295, 1, 15, 567190) But it may be that this rowdyism is symptomatic of an epidemic.
('90', 295, 1, 16, 567254) Many people imagine that they alone are right and everyone else wrong, and they do not consider that there is anything unworthy in forcing their point of view down others’ throats.
('90', 295, 1, 17, 567435) This error has to be rectified.
('90', 295, 1, 18, 567467) If we are in the right we must have infinite patience.
('90', 295, 1, 19, 567522) Just now we seem unable to see our own mistakes.
('90', 295, 1, 20, 567571) Those who lack the faculty of reason, or who desire to live for the sake of enjoy ment, can never see the error.
('90', 295, 1, 21, 567684) If there are many such, then we must conclude that our non violence has been a weapon of the weak, himsa masquerading in the guise of ahimsa.
('90', 295, 1, 22, 567826) If this weakness conti nue we shall have to go through rivers of blood once the British rule goes.
('90', 295, 1, 23, 567925) We may even come under the sway of some other foreign power or it may be that with internecine warfare the weaker side will have to submit to the one that has the mightier weapons.
('90', 295, 1, 24, 568106) If we are unfortunate enough to witness such streif, believers in non violence will joyfully die in the effort to stop it and thereby live.
('90', 295, 1, 25, 568246) My hope is that the masses have sufficiently imbibed the spirit of ahimsa and that when the British go there may be a little fight here and there and then we shall settle down as brothers giving a lesson of peace to the world.
('90', 295, 1, 26, 568473) Only those who fought in Bombay know what good they achieved by fighting.
('90', 295, 1, 27, 568547) I am ignorant of who fought and what the fight was about and what were the gains if any.

('90', 297, 8, 23, 571885) 362. TALK WITH A ZAMINDAR 2
('90', 297, 9, 24, 571913) [Before April 23, 1946] 3
('90', 297, 10, 25, 571939) “Where shall we stand when India is independent?” asked a friend representing the landholders’ interests, the other day during his visit to Gandhiji.” You wil be as free as any scavenger, but whether you will be able to retain all the privileges which you are enjoying under the British Government is a question you can answer for yourself.
('90', 297, 11, 26, 572280) 1 Jayakrishna P. Bhansali 2 This and the following item are reproduced from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” dated “New Delhi, April 23, 1946”.
('90', 298, 0, 1, 572418) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 299
('90', 298, 1, 2, 572462) We realize that we shall secure our salvation at the hands of Indian leaders, not the British Government.
('90', 298, 1, 3, 572568) Everybody believes that today.
('90', 298, 1, 4, 572599) Even the British Government feel that they cannot do otherwise than to leave India to settle her own affairs.
('90', 298, 2, 5, 572709) The landholders derived their charter of rights and privileges from the Permanent Settlement which was of the nature of a contract between the British and the zamindars, but they are quite willing to negotiate an agreement with the leaders of the country on the future of their rights.
('90', 298, 2, 6, 572995) Being a non violent man by nature I cannot countenance the usurpation of anybody’s just rights.
('90', 298, 2, 7, 573091) But some of the extraordinary privileg that pass muster under the British rule are themselves in the nature of an usurpation.
('90', 298, 2, 8, 573217) The history of British rule is a history of usurpation.
('90', 298, 2, 9, 573273) Those who helped the British Government in this process got certain rights as a reward for their services.
('90', 298, 2, 10, 573380) These cannot be insisted upon.
('90', 298, 2, 11, 573411) Many ancient zamindaris 1 existed long before the advent of the British and were exercising sovereign power, as a produce of indigenous social and economic system of long standing.
('90', 298, 2, 12, 573592) Don’t you think they have a title to continue their existence?
('90', 298, 2, 13, 573655) They are trying their best to discharge a philanthropic function in the shape of founding educational and social institutions.
('90', 298, 2, 14, 573782) Anything that is ancient and consistent with moral values has a title to be retained.
('90', 298, 2, 15, 573868) Per contra anything that does not conform to more values has to go.
('90', 298, 2, 16, 573936) Wrong has no prescriptive right to exist merely because it is of long standing.
('90', 298, 2, 17, 574016) If those who are on your zamindaris feel one with you and you with them, like members of a family, you have nothing to fear from anybody.
('90', 298, 3, 18, 574154) We want even handed justice.
('90', 298, 3, 19, 574183) We have no objection to an indepedent Indian Government abolishing all manner of vested interests.
('90', 298, 3, 20, 574282) But let there be no discrimin ation against the zamindars especially.
('90', 298, 3, 21, 574352) We only want a conciliatory gest ure, an assurance that you won’t wipe us out as a class, without giving us a sporting chance to vindicate our existence.
('90', 298, 3, 22, 574506) A just man need have no fear of any kind from an independent.
('90', 298, 3, 23, 574568) India may, however, fall into unjust hands.
('90', 298, 3, 24, 574612) Every Congressman is not an angel, nor is everyone who is not a Congressman a devil.
('90', 298, 3, 25, 574697) Let us hope that, if Congress comes into power, it will try to be more than just.
('90', 298, 3, 26, 574779) Otherwise all the good that it might have done would disappear in the twinkling of an eye.
('90', 298, 4, 27, 574870) I do not deny that there are bad boys amongst us.
('90', 298, 4, 28, 574920) But you can cure us.
('90', 298, 5, 29, 574941) 1 Absentee landlordism
('90', 299, 0, 1, 574964) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 299, 1, 2, 575006) only wish that nothing should be done without consulting us.

('90', 299, 1, 4, 575093) 1 Harijan, 28 4 1946
('90', 299, 2, 5, 575114) 363. TALK WITH MISSIONARIES [Before April 23, 1946]
('90', 299, 3, 6, 575166) Another group of friends presented Gandhiji with a poser: “Could he guaranteed that under independence the right of proselytization would be guaranteed by a statue?” This provoked the counter question, “Did they really believe in the ideal of independence or was their support to the independence ideal only for a consideration?” In the latter case, he would say, remarked Gandhiji, that they believed neither in independence nor in religion.
('90', 299, 3, 7, 575609) Who could suppress the voice of truth if it filled one’s being?
('90', 299, 3, 8, 575673) And of what avail was a statutory gurantee if there was not the fire within to bear witness to truth?
('90', 299, 4, 9, 575775) “It is true, no one can suppress the voice of truth,” interpolated one of them.
('90', 299, 4, 10, 575855) “We want a guarantee from you that no attempt would be made to suppress it.” I cannot give you that guarantee because I have no authority.
('90', 299, 5, 11, 575994) It was the function of religion, he continued, to save the temporal power from losing its soul; religion did not depend upon it for protection.
('90', 299, 5, 12, 576138) And he cited to them the illustraction of Daniel, the servant of God, who used to pray behind closed doors.
('90', 299, 5, 13, 576246) But when Darius the King issued a decree prohibiting the worship of any God or man save himself under a penalty, he began to pray to God publicly, the windows of his chamber being open so that all could see him praying.
('90', 299, 5, 14, 576466) He was thrown into the hungry lion’s den but came out unscathed.
('90', 299, 5, 15, 576531) The result was that the King rescinded his former decree which was ‘unalterable’ under the laws of Medes and Persians and made another decree to the effect that in every dominion of his kingdom, “men tremble and fear before the God of Daniel, for he is the living God and steadfast as ever.” And “so Daniel prospered in the reign of Darius and in the reign of Cyrus.” That was the only true way of proselytization and it needed no guarantee, statutory or otherwise.
('90', 299, 5, 16, 576997) It was its own seal and sanction.
('90', 299, 5, 17, 577031) To take a leaf from the history of our own times, remember the words of the late Lord Salisbury who, when in office, had told a missionary deputation about [sic] China that they were a poor specimen if for their mission they sought the protection of British guns.
('90', 299, 5, 18, 577295) Harijan, 28 4 1946
('90', 299, 6, 19, 577314) 1 Gandhiji concluded the interview, pointing in a mute petition of mercy, as it were, to the heap of papers in front of him awaiting disposal.

('90', 308, 8, 13, 590856) Dry, finely powdered earth rubbed on the body cleansed the skin.
('90', 308, 8, 14, 590921) Mud applied to the body and allowed to dry could cure many skin diseases.

('90', 308, 8, 17, 591114) Finally he took the case in his hands, covered the boy’s body with mud and made him run about naked.
('90', 308, 8, 18, 591215) The boy was cured in eight to ten days.
('90', 308, 9, 19, 591255) Gandhiji said that earth was full of miraculous properties and it was as useful in man’s life as any other thing could be.

('90', 309, 3, 7, 592655) 380. THE MONKEY NUISANCE 1
('90', 309, 4, 8, 592682) People get weary of the trouble caused to them by monkeys.
('90', 309, 4, 9, 592741) In their hearts they wish them dead.
('90', 309, 4, 10, 592778) They are inwardly pleased if anyone kills them.
('90', 309, 4, 11, 592826) At the same time they will oppose their slaughter.
('90', 309, 4, 12, 592877) A friend who is well acquainted with the scriptures writes that monkeys ruin the crops, they even kidnap children, carry away articles, and eat up fruit, etc.
('90', 309, 4, 13, 593036) Their number is daily increasing.
('90', 309, 4, 14, 593070) I am asked as to what non violence dictates in the matter.
('90', 309, 4, 15, 593129) My ahimsa is my own.
('90', 309, 4, 16, 593150) I am not able to accept in its entirety the doctrine of non killing of animals.
('90', 309, 4, 17, 593230) I have no feeling in me to save the lives of animals which devour or cause hurt to man.
('90', 309, 4, 18, 593318) I consider it wrong to help in the increase of their progeny.
('90', 309, 4, 19, 593380) Therefore, I will not feed ants, monkeys or dogs.
('90', 309, 4, 20, 593430) I will never sacrifice a man’s life in order to save theirs.
('90', 309, 4, 21, 593491) Thinking along these lines I have come to the conclusion that to do away with monkeys where they have become a menace to the well being of man is pardonable.
('90', 309, 4, 22, 593649) Such killing becomes a duty.
('90', 309, 4, 23, 593678) The question may arise as to why this rule should not also apply to human beings.
('90', 309, 4, 24, 593760) It cannot because, however bad, they are as we are.
('90', 309, 4, 25, 593812) Unlike the animal, man has been given the faculty of reason.

('90', 310, 1, 2, 594098) 381. DRAFT AND NOTE ON PROPOSED PROCLAMATION ON SALT 1
('90', 310, 2, 3, 594153) (A) THE PROCLAMATION
('90', 310, 3, 4, 594174) In order that the poorest in the land may feel that independence is coming and as an earnest of their bona fides, the Government of India declare that the Salt Tax is abolished from today.
('90', 310, 3, 5, 594363) To that end the inspectors of .
('90', 310, 3, 6, 594395) 2 shall withdraw from their scenes of activity and the villagers will be notified by beat of drum and otherwise that they are at liberty to manufacture salt wherever they can for themselves or for sale.
('90', 310, 3, 7, 594598) Other instructions about the State manufacture and sale of salt will be issued in due course.
('90', 310, 4, 8, 594692) (B) NOTE ON THE PROPOSED PROCLAMATION ON SALT When the Salt Tax is abolished the monopoly goes likewise.
('90', 310, 4, 9, 594797) Individuals should be free to manufacture salt for consumption or sale.
('90', 310, 4, 10, 594869) Therefore, while there would be no monopoly in law, the Government will by their better organizing power and scientific skill be able to create a virtual monopoly.
('90', 310, 4, 11, 595033) They will not allow private corporations to make manufacture and sale of salt a source of profiteering.
('90', 310, 4, 12, 595137) It will be a legitimate paying business in the hands of the State.
('90', 310, 4, 13, 595204) Consumption of the article is so universal that the profit of even a pie on every seer would bring in a natural income to the State.
('90', 310, 4, 14, 595337) Every dealer in salt will be required to take out a licence for selling salt in his shop.
('90', 310, 4, 15, 595427) [A] dealer is not to be confused with a hawker.
('90', 310, 4, 16, 595475) A hawker who carried salt on his person will be free to sell without a licence.
('90', 310, 4, 17, 595555) This will free the individual manufacturer and seller from interference.
('90', 310, 4, 18, 595628) Government will add to the revenue also by putting a heavy, though not a prohibitive, customs duty on foreign salt, whether British or otherwise.
('90', 310, 4, 19, 595774) Whilst anxiety has been shown in this note to show how salt may be made to yield legitimate revenue to the State, equal if not greater
('90', 310, 5, 20, 595909) 1 In response to Gandhiji’s suggestion about the abolition of the Salt Tax Sir Archibald Rowlands, Finance Member of the Viceroy’s Executive Council, had met Gandhiji on April 5, 1946. The draft and the note were sent to Sir Archibald in compliance with his request.
('90', 310, 5, 21, 596176) The Transfer of Power, however, places the proclamation just after Gandhiji’s letter to the Viceroy dated April 6, 1946. For Gandhiji’s correspondence in this connection vide “Letter to Lord Pethoick Lawrence”, 2 4 1946 and 374 5. 2 Omission as in the source

('90', 312, 4, 7, 598491) 384. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING April 25, 1946
('90', 312, 5, 8, 598536) Speaking after the prayers, Gandhiji introduced Badshah Khan as a fakir and a man of God.
('90', 312, 5, 9, 598626) He had come to Delhi in connection with the meeting of the Working Committee of which he was a member.
('90', 312, 5, 10, 598729) But he was essentially a man of God.
('90', 312, 5, 11, 598766) His company was satsang, hallowed company for them as it was for him.
('90', 312, 6, 12, 598836) Gandhiji told the audience of a letter he had received from a correspondent criticizing Mr. Kanu Gandhi and the way he led Ramdhun.
('90', 312, 6, 13, 598968) Ramdhun should be in the heart; where was the need for all the external show, the correspondent had asked.
('90', 312, 6, 14, 599075) There was no doubt, observed Gandhiji, that Ramanama should come from the heart.
('90', 312, 6, 15, 599156) But the external things were an indication of what was within.
('90', 312, 6, 16, 599219) Supposing everyone struck a different note while reciting prayers in the mosque or during the chanting of hymns in the church, it would utterly ruin the solemnity of the service.
('90', 312, 6, 17, 599398) There was a right way of doing everything and prayers were no exception.
('90', 312, 7, 18, 599471) A gentleman, Gandhiji proceeded, had sent him a book describing how namaz 1
('90', 312, 8, 19, 599547) should be offered.
('90', 312, 8, 20, 599566) While turning over the pages of that book he came across a sentence in it which was to the effect that prayer said in congregation was 27 times as effective as prayer said by oneself.
('90', 312, 8, 21, 599750) If they all joined in the prayer whole heartedly and methodically it would gather momentum in geometric progression and so transform the atmosphere that riots in Delhi would become an impossibility.
('90', 312, 8, 22, 599949) The Hindustan Times, 26 4 1946
