('90', 313, 0, 1, 600011) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 313, 1, 2, 600053) 385. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('90', 313, 2, 3, 600081) NEW DELHI, April 26, 1946 Mr. Hoover’s 1 flying visit to India has excited considerable interest and possibly hope.
('90', 313, 2, 4, 600197) Whilst all the help that America and other countries can send to India, struggling against starvation, must be welcome, my endeavour has been to find ways and means to make ourselves self supporting.
('90', 313, 2, 5, 600397) the moment people give way to panic, starvation is a certainty in spite of a continuous line of steamers off loading grain from outside on India’s wharves.
('90', 313, 2, 6, 600553) Conversely, every grain from abroad sent as a matter of duty to self reliant India, honestly and manfully braving the threatening danger, will be twice blessed.
('90', 313, 2, 7, 600714) Let Mr. Hoover’s visit serve as a reminder to Government servants, monied men and grain merchants that they must think all the time of their duty to the masses.
('90', 313, 2, 8, 600875) Nature never fails those who will help themselves.
('90', 313, 2, 9, 600926) Harijan, 5 5 1946
('90', 313, 3, 10, 600944) 386. NON VIOLENT VOLUNTEER CORPS 2
('90', 313, 4, 11, 600979) Some time ago an attempt was made, at my instance, to form shanti dals 3 but nothing came of it.
('90', 313, 4, 12, 601076) This lesson, however, was learnt, that the membership, in its very nature, of such organizations could not be large.
('90', 313, 4, 13, 601193) Ordinarily, the efficient running of a large volunteer corps based on force implies the possibility of the use of force in the event of breach of discipline.
('90', 313, 4, 14, 601351) In such bodies little or no stress is laid on a man’s character.
('90', 313, 4, 15, 601416) Physique is the chief factor.
('90', 313, 4, 16, 601446) The contrary must obtain in non violent bodies in which character or soul force must mean everything and physique must take second place.
('90', 313, 4, 17, 601584) It is difficult to find many such persons.
('90', 313, 4, 18, 601627) That is why non violent corps must be small, if they are to be efficient.
('90', 313, 4, 19, 601701) Such brigades may be scattered all over; there may be one each for a village or a mohalla 4. The members must know one another well.
('90', 313, 4, 20, 601834) Each corps will select its own head.
('90', 313, 4, 21, 601871) All the members will have the same status, but where
('90', 313, 5, 22, 601924) 1 Herbert Hoover, Chairman of the United States Famine Emergency Committee 2 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 5 5 1946. 3 Peace Corps 4 Locality
('90', 314, 0, 1, 602093) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 315
('90', 314, 1, 2, 602137) everyone is doing the same work there must be one person under whose discipline all must come, or else the work will suffer.
('90', 314, 1, 3, 602262) Where there are two or more brigades the leaders must consult among themselves and decide on a common line of action.
('90', 314, 1, 4, 602380) In that way alone lies success.
('90', 314, 1, 5, 602412) If non violent volunteer corps are formed on the above lines, they can easily stop trouble.
('90', 314, 1, 6, 602504) These corps will not require all the physical training given in akhadas 1 but a certain part of it will be necessary.
('90', 314, 1, 7, 602622) One thing, however, should be common to members of all such organizations and that is implicit faith in God.
('90', 314, 1, 8, 602731) He is the only Companion and Doer.
('90', 314, 1, 9, 602766) Without faith in Him these peace brigades will be lifeless.
('90', 314, 1, 10, 602826) By whatever name one calls God, one must realize that one can only work through His strength.
('90', 314, 1, 11, 602920) Such a man will never take another’s life.
('90', 314, 1, 12, 602963) He will allow himself, if need be, to be killed and thereby live through his victory over death.
('90', 314, 1, 13, 603060) The mind of the man in whose life the realization of this law has become a living reality will not be bewildered in a crisis.
('90', 314, 1, 14, 603186) He will instinctively know the right way to act.
('90', 314, 1, 15, 603235) In spite, however, of what I have said above I would like to give some rules culled from my own experience : 1. A volunteer may not carry any weapons.
('90', 314, 1, 16, 603386) 2. The members of a corps must be easily recognizable.
('90', 314, 1, 17, 603441) 3. Every volunteer must carry bandages, scissors, needle and thread, surgical knife, etc., for rendering first aid.
('90', 314, 1, 18, 603557) 4. He should know how to carry and remove the wounded.
('90', 314, 1, 19, 603612) 5. He should know how to put out fires, how to enter a fire area without getting burnt, how to climb heights for rescue work and descend safely with or without his charge.
('90', 314, 1, 20, 603784) 6. He should be well acquainted with all the residents of his locality.
('90', 314, 1, 21, 603856) This is a service in itself.
('90', 314, 1, 22, 603885) 7. He should recite Ramanama ceaselessly in his heart and persuade others who believe in it to do likewise.
('90', 314, 1, 23, 603993) There are many who, whether from mental laziness or from having fallen into a bad habit believe that God is and will help us unasked.
('90', 314, 1, 24, 604127) Why then is it necessary to recite His name?
('90', 314, 1, 25, 604172) It is true that if
('90', 314, 2, 26, 604191) 1 Gymnasiums
('90', 315, 0, 1, 604204) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 315, 1, 2, 604246) God is, He is, irrespective of our belief.
('90', 315, 1, 3, 604289) But realization of God is infinitely more than mere belief.
('90', 315, 1, 4, 604349) That can come only by constant practice.
('90', 315, 1, 5, 604390) This is true of all science.
('90', 315, 1, 6, 604419) How much more true of the science of all sciences !
('90', 315, 1, 7, 604471) Man often repeats the name of God parrot wise and expects fruit from so doing.
('90', 315, 1, 8, 604550) The true seeker must have that living faith which will not only dispel the untruth of parrot wise repetition from within him but also from the hearts of others.
('90', 315, 1, 9, 604711) NEW DELHI, April 26, 1946 Harijan, 5 5 1946
('90', 315, 2, 10, 604755) 387. WHITED SEPULCHRES?
('90', 315, 3, 11, 604779) I am a woman but feel I must write to you about this matter.
('90', 315, 3, 12, 604840) About three months ago a man who said he was .
('90', 315, 3, 13, 604887) .’s servant came here.
('90', 315, 3, 14, 604910) One evening he brought a car and asked me if I had ever been in one and if not, would I not go with him for an outing?
('90', 315, 3, 15, 605029) It never entered my head to suspect him and I acceded to his request.
('90', 315, 3, 16, 605099) I was first taken to .
('90', 315, 3, 17, 605122) where I was gagged and later we proceeded to a house in.
('90', 315, 3, 18, 605179) For some days every effort was made to commit an outrage on me.
('90', 315, 3, 19, 605243) Then one day a wealthy merchant and Congress leader of .
('90', 315, 3, 20, 605300) came and asked me to go and enjoy life with him in .
('90', 315, 4, 21, 605353) Later one day I was rescued by a friend of my father’s with the help of the police.
('90', 315, 4, 22, 605437) I have received more than one such letter 2 accusing some Congressmen of immorality.
('90', 315, 4, 23, 605522) It would not be wisdom to believe that they are all untrue and ignore the complaint.
('90', 315, 4, 24, 605607) It has never been claimed that every Congressman is a model of virtue.
('90', 315, 4, 25, 605678) But it is a matter of pride that the public expect a high standard of morality from Congressmen.
('90', 315, 4, 26, 605775) All kinds of immorality are prevalent among us.
('90', 315, 4, 27, 605823) It is a reformer’s duty to try to wean from error those who are justly accused of misbehaviour.
('90', 315, 4, 28, 605919) There are limits to immorality, if any can be claimed to pass muster.
('90', 315, 4, 29, 605989) If what has been related is true, every man has to ask himself how far he is justified in seeking to satisfy his lust at the expense of innocent girls.

('90', 316, 1, 2, 606340) 388. SWARAJ THROUGH SPINNING 1
('90', 316, 2, 3, 606371) An A. I. S. A. worker writes thus : 2
('90', 316, 3, 4, 606409) You have said that we must make the spinners self sufficient and that to obtain swaraj through their activity is the aim of the A. I. S. A. .
('90', 316, 3, 5, 606551) This way lies swaraj, you say.
('90', 316, 3, 6, 606582) I admit it is right for spinners to learn well all the processes.
('90', 316, 3, 7, 606648) The quality of yarn and cloth will also improve.
('90', 316, 3, 8, 606697) But how can we win our freedom this way?
('90', 316, 3, 9, 606738) How are we to bring home this lesson to the spinners?
('90', 316, 3, 10, 606792) Imagine, if all the spinners understood the inner meaning of the wheel and span willingly and not under pressure, what an India there would be!
('90', 316, 3, 11, 606936) The awakening of crores of women spinners would ipso facto produce lakhs of khadi weavers.
('90', 316, 3, 12, 607027) Imagine too the numbers of men and women workers needed to bring about this awakening!
('90', 316, 3, 13, 607114) If such a time comes, textile mills, even if any were working, would have to rely on foreign countries for the sale of their produce.
('90', 316, 3, 14, 607248) They would not, as they do today, hold imperialistic sway over the villages and cities.
('90', 316, 3, 15, 607336) There would be Hindu Muslim unity, all would be truthful, there would be no need to tell anyone to wear khadi, for no cloth other than home spun would be available.
('90', 316, 3, 16, 607501) That swaraj is hidden in this revolutionary change should be self evident to seeing eyes.
('90', 316, 3, 17, 607591) The question may imply that such a consummation is impossible.
('90', 316, 3, 18, 607654) If such is the question, it means that swaraj through non violent means is impossible.
('90', 316, 4, 19, 607741) Another question asked is how the spinners are to be given the requisite education.
('90', 316, 4, 20, 607825) To seek out the right answer is the main work of the A. I. S. A. Enough research has not so far been done.
('90', 316, 4, 21, 607932) It is the duty of every A. I. S. A. worker to try to solve the puzzle.
('90', 316, 4, 22, 608003) Now that we have Congress ministries in several provinces the work should be easy.
('90', 316, 4, 23, 608086) Let the workers throw themselves heart and soul into it.
('90', 316, 4, 24, 608143) They will never succeed if they look all the time to the Central Office for help and guidance.
('90', 316, 4, 25, 608238) NEW DELHI, April 26, 1946 Harijan, 5 5 1946

('90', 317, 7, 24, 609529) Nobody knew who the miscreant 5 was, said Gandhiji, nor would it be right to venture a guess.
('90', 317, 7, 25, 609623) It might be presumed at first flush, that because the victim in this case was a Hindu boy the assailant must be a Muslim and vice versa.
('90', 317, 8, 26, 609760) 1 The addressee had invited Gandhiji to visit a camp she had organized at Pimple, a village in Maharashtra.

('90', 318, 0, 1, 610206) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 319
('90', 318, 1, 2, 610250) Such speculation, in my opinion, is not only idle but mischievous.
('90', 318, 1, 3, 610317) We should rather ask ourselves as to how we would have or should have acted, if we were present on the scene.
('90', 318, 2, 4, 610427) To remain passive witnesses to the dastardly attack would cowardly.
('90', 318, 2, 5, 610495) Should they, then, whip out a knife and pay back the miscreant in his own coin?
('90', 318, 2, 6, 610575) Both these courses would be wrong, observed Gandhiji.
('90', 318, 2, 7, 610629) The only becoming course, he told them, would be to plead with the miscreant not to stain his hands with innocent blood.
('90', 318, 2, 8, 610750) If in doing so they themselves become victims of the miscreant’s anger, they should not mind but should rather welcome it.
('90', 318, 2, 9, 610873) Such an occasion should provide them with an opportunity to test the sincerity of their daily attendance at the prayer meetings.
('90', 318, 2, 10, 611002) When passions rise high and panic and mass hysteria lay hold on the people, it is up to the man of prayer to keep his head above the storm and refuse to sink to the level of the brute.
('90', 318, 2, 11, 611187) We should pray to God to help us to keep down the hatred and anger in the heart.
('90', 318, 2, 12, 611268) To be able to conquer anger and hatred and all other baser passions is the fruit of prayer.
('90', 318, 2, 13, 611360) It is braver far to disarm the miscreant with cool determination devoid of anger than to counter him with a dagger, to prevent an angry word from escaping one’s lips than to indulge in abuse.
('90', 318, 3, 14, 611552) He recalled another instance of assault on a harmless German during the Victory Day disturbances in Delhi that had been brought to his notice the day before.
('90', 318, 3, 15, 611710) The madness at the time was directed against Englishmen and Europeans.
('90', 318, 3, 16, 611781) In his opinion, it was not less cowardly.
('90', 318, 3, 17, 611823) We should pity the ruffian.
('90', 318, 3, 18, 611851) A Maulana who saw me just before I started for the prayer was telling me how a number of newspapers were fanning the flames of communal hatred day after day and week after week.
('90', 318, 3, 19, 612029) They are the real culprits.
('90', 318, 3, 20, 612057) To incite murder is as bad if not worse than the murder itself.
('90', 318, 3, 21, 612121) The actual murderer is very often an ignorant tool, victim of mischievous propaganda.
('90', 318, 4, 22, 612207) But even such propaganda could take effect only in a vitiated atmosphere.
('90', 318, 4, 23, 612281) In a healthy atmosphere it would be sterilized.
('90', 318, 4, 24, 612329) Panic is the result of fear after all.
('90', 318, 4, 25, 612368) But a man of prayer knows no fear.
('90', 318, 4, 26, 612403) Your prayer is vain repetition if it does not clear the atmosphere of fear, panic and mass hysteria.

('90', 319, 1, 2, 612600) 391. LETTER TO PREMA KANTAK DELHI, April 27, 1946
('90', 319, 2, 3, 612650) PREMA, You have raised three issues in your letter.
('90', 319, 2, 4, 612702) 1. After completing their training in the camp the women are bound to give their services to the Kasturba Trust.
('90', 319, 2, 5, 612815) 2. The Trust is bound to give them work and pay them.
('90', 319, 2, 6, 612869) 3. In every district one mature and experienced woman and one comparatively younger woman should be posted.
('90', 319, 2, 7, 612977) Though these points are not included in the rules of the Trust, as I had promised you before the rules were framed, all the three demands have been accepted.
('90', 319, 2, 8, 613135) At the same time it is also recommended that : 1. Efforts should be made to collect as much money as possible from the place concerned and the district.
('90', 319, 2, 9, 613288) 2. Where work can be done through one mature and experienced woman, only one should be posted, for, posting two women of the same age and experience at the same place is likely to result in conflict between them.
('90', 319, 2, 10, 613501) There should be no objection, however, to posting two women if one of them is elderly and the other young.
('90', 319, 2, 11, 613608) This should be treated as an exception.
('90', 319, 2, 12, 613648) Care should be taken to see that the exception does not become the rule.
('90', 319, 3, 13, 613721) From a photostat of the Gujarati : G. N. 10446. Also C. W. 6885. Courtesy : Prema Kantak
('90', 319, 4, 14, 613810) 392. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('90', 319, 5, 15, 613842) April 27, 1946
('90', 319, 6, 16, 613857) Speaking after the prayers .
('90', 319, 6, 17, 613886) Gandhiji dwelt on the danger of giving credence to panicky reports.
('90', 319, 6, 18, 613954) Newspapers had reported that Bombay was full of panic, Hindus dared not go into Muslim quarters and vice versa, the shops were closed early in the evenings, the streets deserted and the people did not venture out at night for fear of riots breaking out.
('90', 319, 6, 19, 614208) All that had proved to be a Press canard.
('90', 319, 6, 20, 614250) Gandhiji said that these
('90', 319, 7, 21, 614275) 1 The report in The Hindustan Times had been collated with Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” in Harijan.
('90', 320, 0, 1, 614373) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 321
('90', 320, 1, 2, 614417) false reports had reached him only today.
('90', 320, 1, 3, 614459) There was neither any panic nor disturbance worth nothing in Bombay.
('90', 320, 1, 4, 614528) Hindu women and children freely visited and went about in Muslim quarters and vice versa.
('90', 320, 1, 5, 614618) The whole story was faked.
('90', 320, 1, 6, 614645) In Delhi itself a Hindu woman was being driven by a Muslim tonga driver only the day before.
('90', 320, 1, 7, 614738) The driver had expressed amazement and horror at what taking place.
('90', 320, 1, 8, 614806) “Why should there be any quarrel between Hindus and Muslims?” he had asked, and added, “God turns his back on those who quarrel amongst themselves.” That showed, remarked Gandhiji, how dangerous it was to give credence to panicky rumours.
('90', 320, 1, 9, 615045) The lesson to be learnt from all this is, that we should not be afraid, because people will always frighten the timid, not the brave.
('90', 320, 2, 10, 615179) But it was no use making a show of bravery when there was fear in the heart.
('90', 320, 2, 11, 615256) Probably they had all heard about a child playing with a snake without coming to harm.
('90', 320, 2, 12, 615343) But if a grown up person who was afraid of snakes tried to play with one, it would detect fear in the very touch and probably bite him.
('90', 320, 2, 13, 615479) But suppos ing they were afraid and wanted to shed fear, the first condition was that they must not carry any arms.
('90', 320, 2, 14, 615595) They should put faith in God and depend upon Him to protect them.
('90', 320, 2, 15, 615661) The man who was afraid and carried arms repudiated God and made the arms his God.
('90', 320, 3, 16, 615743) Later, Gandhiji reverted to the theme of nature cure and talked about ether.
('90', 320, 3, 17, 615820) Man was made of clay but even clay was prevaded by ether.
('90', 320, 3, 18, 615878) The cavities in the human body, the pores in the human skin were all filled by ether.
('90', 320, 3, 19, 615964) The stars, the sun and the moon were suspended in the void.
('90', 320, 3, 20, 616024) The astronomers said there were many a heavenly body, like the sun and the stars which the human eye could not see.
('90', 320, 3, 21, 616140) Gandhiji wanted them to stretch their mental vision so as to grasp the infinity of ethereal space.
('90', 320, 3, 22, 616239) Ether was the most intangible thing known to man, but it was occupied by something still more intangible, namely, God.
('90', 320, 4, 23, 616358) In nature cure they had to establish contact with ether as with the earth.
('90', 320, 4, 24, 616433) They could sleep under the sky and have as much empty space around them as possible.
('90', 320, 4, 25, 616518) If they attuned themselves to ether they would realize what insignificant little creatures they were and how ill becoming it was for them to quarrel amongst themselves.
('90', 320, 5, 26, 616687) Gandhiji referred to his visit to the Bhangi quarters on Saturday morning.
('90', 320, 5, 27, 616762) He lived on the outskirts of the Bhangi quarters.
('90', 320, 5, 28, 616812) But his was a clean and airy place, where he could live all his life.
('90', 320, 5, 29, 616882) The Bhangi quarters were dirty and filthy.
('90', 320, 5, 30, 616925) Their rooms were dark and ill ventilated.
('90', 320, 5, 31, 616967) There was just one little vantilator in the room, so that he felt suffocated as he entered it.
('90', 320, 5, 32, 617062) It was a shame that their brethren should live in that state.
('90', 320, 5, 33, 617124) Gandhiji told the gathering to visit the Bhangi quarters.
('90', 320, 5, 34, 617182) The Harijans had a right to feel that his claim to be one of them was more than mere idle talk.
('90', 320, 5, 35, 617278) We are all made of earth, ether and the rest of the five elements.
('90', 321, 0, 1, 617345) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 321, 1, 2, 617387) God makes no distinction between man and man.
('90', 321, 1, 3, 617433) By ourselves we are insignificant worms.
('90', 321, 1, 4, 617474) We become great when we reflect His greatness.
('90', 321, 1, 5, 617521) If we are attuned to Him, illness will not touch us.

('90', 323, 2, 3, 620238) NEW DELHI, April 28, 1946
('90', 323, 3, 4, 620264) Gandhiji said that it would have been better if the report had been sent to the Congress leaders.
('90', 323, 4, 5, 620362) The volunteers had been in attendance in his camp.
('90', 323, 4, 6, 620413) Mahtma Gandhi thanked them for the service they had rendered him and his party.
('90', 323, 4, 7, 620493) He knew the volunteers had worked hard and had been doing night and day duty.
('90', 323, 4, 8, 620571) He felt grateful for the love and diligence with which they had served him and his party.
('90', 323, 4, 9, 620661) But what was the use of their serving him if they served not the lowest among the low who were his next door neighbours.
('90', 323, 4, 10, 620782) They kept his place spotlessly clean but the sweepers’ quarters next door were extremely dirty.
('90', 323, 4, 11, 620878) It was their shame as it was his.
('90', 323, 4, 12, 620912) He would not be satisfied till they served the sweepers as they had served him.
('90', 323, 4, 13, 620992) They should rather go and serve the Bhangis who lived next door to him in filth and squalor.
('90', 323, 4, 14, 621085) Such service carried with it its own reward.
('90', 323, 4, 15, 621130) He had come to live in the filth in which they lived.
('90', 323, 4, 16, 621184) The fault was not theirs but of those who had reduced them to that state.
('90', 323, 4, 17, 621258) The quarters provided for them were worse than the worst prison cell that he had seen in India or in South Africa.
('90', 323, 4, 18, 621373) Mahatma Gandhi recalled how he had written to Mr. Birla 2, Mr. Viyogi Hari and Mr. Brijkrishna Chandiwala to make arrangements for his stay in sweepers’ quarters.
('90', 323, 4, 19, 621536) They had done it.
('90', 323, 4, 20, 621554) He was Mr. Birla’s guest even here, as the management and the expenses were Mr. Birla’s.
('90', 323, 4, 21, 621643) The result was that he was neither in Birla House nor in the Bhangi quarters.
('90', 323, 4, 22, 621721) Gandhiji said he had identified himself with the Bhangis mentally, but he could not live like them.
('90', 323, 4, 23, 621821) The Bhangis had a right to feel that his claim was an idle one.
('90', 323, 4, 24, 621885) He would like them to go and work in the Bhangi quarters so that the place became as clean as where he was staying.
('90', 323, 4, 25, 622001) If they went to the Bhangi quarters, not as their patrons or teachers but as their true servants, they would be able to reach their hearts and trans form the look of things in no time.
('90', 323, 4, 26, 622186) The volunteers were not do this by ordering the Bhangis.
('90', 323, 4, 27, 622243) They were to be their humble and silent servants.
('90', 323, 4, 28, 622293) Today those who became volunteers had a lurking desire to be counted as leaders.
('90', 323, 4, 29, 622374) This, he added, was bad.
('90', 323, 4, 30, 622399) Their one ambition should be to serve those whom we have made the lowest of the low.
('90', 323, 5, 31, 622484) The Hindustan Times, 29 4 1946, Hindustan, 29 4 1946, and Harijan, 5 5 1946

('90', 325, 2, 11, 626049) 400. MARCH OF CIVILIZATION
('90', 325, 3, 12, 626076) Q. On page 91 of Harijan 14 4 ’46, 1 it has been argued that the bullock is a living machine and that contact with such harmless animals is a potent factor in the onward march of human civilization.
('90', 325, 3, 13, 626275) The animals are however, made ‘harmless’ by making them ‘impotent’.
('90', 325, 3, 14, 626343) Is this the correct method of the onward march of civilization?
('90', 325, 3, 15, 626407) If we have cows, we must have bulls.
('90', 325, 3, 16, 626444) The bullock is a creation of human selfishness and cruelty.
('90', 325, 3, 17, 626504) If not in thinking man, in the lower animals at any rate, all the force of their nature rages in the fury of the generative desire.
('90', 325, 3, 18, 626636) Therefore, to turn the noble animal, the ‘Vahana of Mahadev’ 2, into a beat of burden is sad.
('90', 325, 4, 19, 626730) A. The writer is logical.
('90', 325, 4, 20, 626756) But such logic would prevent the domestication of the cow.
('90', 325, 4, 21, 626815) For there is probably more cruelty in domesticating the cow than in castrating the bull.
('90', 325, 4, 22, 626904) It is a question of degree.
('90', 325, 4, 23, 626932) Further march of civilization seems to imply increasing domination of man over beast, together with a growingly humane method of using them.
('90', 325, 4, 24, 627073) There are three schools of humanitarians.
('90', 325, 4, 25, 627115) One believes in replacing animal power by the use of any other.
('90', 325, 4, 26, 627179) Another believes in treating animals as fellow beings and making such use of them as a brotherly spirit will permit.
('90', 325, 4, 27, 627296) The third will not make use of lower animals for man’s selfish purpose but will employ instead one’s power and that of fellow beings to the extent that the latter give intelligent and willing use.
('90', 325, 4, 28, 627493) I belong to the third school.
('90', 325, 4, 29, 627523) It is possible
('90', 325, 5, 30, 627538) 1 In V. G. Desai’s article “The Case for the Bullock” 2 Mount of Lord Shiva

('90', 326, 1, 2, 627658) by human labour, judiciously and humanely employed, to do fruit culture to a large extent and even corn culture.
('90', 326, 1, 3, 627771) Indeed, as prisoners we civil resisters in the Transvaal dug up stony ground for converting it into a municipal garden.
('90', 326, 1, 4, 627891) No ploughing would have answered the purpose.
('90', 326, 1, 5, 627937) The ground could yield only to the pickaxe.

('90', 326, 2, 14, 628526) 401. INDEPENDENCE Friends have repeatedly challenged me to define independence.
('90', 326, 2, 15, 628606) At the risk of repetition, I must say that the independence of my dream means Ramarajya, i.e., the Kingdom of God on Earth.
('90', 326, 2, 16, 628730) I do not know what it will be like in Heaven.
('90', 326, 2, 17, 628776) I have no desire to know the distant scene.
('90', 326, 2, 18, 628820) If the present is attractive enough, the future cannot be very unlike.
('90', 326, 2, 19, 628891) In concrete terms, then, the independence should be political, economic and moral.
('90', 326, 2, 20, 628974) ‘Political’ necessarily means the removal of the control of the British army in every shape and form.
('90', 326, 2, 21, 629076) ‘Economic’ means entire freedom from British capitalists and capital, as also their Indian counterparts.
('90', 326, 2, 22, 629181) In other words, the humblest must feel eqaul to the tallest.
('90', 326, 2, 23, 629242) This can take place only by capital or capitalists sharing their skill and capital with the lowliest and the least.
('90', 326, 2, 24, 629358) ‘Moral’ means freedom from armed defence forces.
('90', 326, 2, 25, 629407) My conception of Ramarajya excludes replacement of the British army by a national army of occupation.
('90', 326, 2, 26, 629509) A country that is governed by even its national army can never be morally free and, therefore, its so called weakest member can never rise to his full moral height.

('90', 328, 4, 7, 632360) I want to leave it to the Government, but only after I have come to a decision.

('90', 328, 4, 10, 632510) If a Bhangi also could not clean it, then?

('90', 335, 2, 8, 646168) 414. CERTAIN QUESTIONS
('90', 335, 3, 9, 646191) A London friend has put seven questions on the working of non violence.
('90', 335, 3, 10, 646263) Though similar questions have been dealt with in Young India or Harijan, it is profitable to answer them in a single article, if perchance the answers may prove helpful.
('90', 335, 4, 11, 646433) Q. 1. Is it possible for a modern State (which is essentially based on force) to offer non violent resistance for countering internal as well as external forces of disorder?
('90', 335, 4, 12, 646607) Or is it necessary that people wanting to offer non violent resistance should first of all divest themselves of State authority and place themselves vis a vis the opponent entirely in a private capacity?
('90', 335, 5, 13, 646811) A. It is not possible for a modern State based on force, non violently to resist forces of disorder, whether external or internal.A man cannot serve God and Mammon, nor be ‘temperate and furious’ at the same time.
('90', 335, 5, 14, 647025) It is claimed that a State can be based on non violence, i.
('90', 335, 5, 15, 647085) e., it can offer non violent resistance against a world combination based on armed force.
('90', 335, 5, 16, 647175) Such a State was Ashoka’s.
('90', 335, 5, 17, 647202) The example can be repeated.
('90', 335, 5, 18, 647231) But the case does not become weak even if it be shown that Ashoka’s State was not based on non violence.
('90', 335, 5, 19, 647336) It has to be examined on its merits.
('90', 335, 6, 20, 647373) Q. 2. Do you think that it would be possible for a Congress government to deal with foreign aggression or internal riots in an entirely non violent manner?
('90', 335, 7, 21, 647529) A. It is certainly possible for a Congress government to deal with “foreign aggression or internal riots” in a non violent manner.
('90', 335, 7, 22, 647660) That the Congress may not share my belief is quite possible.
('90', 335, 7, 23, 647721) If the Congress changes its course, the change will prove nothing save that the non violence hitherto offered was of the weak and that the Congress has no faith in State non violence.
('90', 335, 8, 24, 647905) Q. 3. Does not the knowledge that the opponent is wedded to non violence often encourage the bully?
('90', 335, 9, 25, 648005) A. The bully has his opportunity when he has to face non violence of the weak.
('90', 335, 9, 26, 648084) Non violence of the strong is any day stronger
('90', 336, 0, 1, 648131) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 337
('90', 336, 1, 2, 648175) than that of the bravest soldier fully armed or a whole host.
('90', 336, 2, 3, 648237) Q. 4. What policy would you advocate if a section of the Indian people tries to enforce by sword a selfish measure which is not only repugnant to others but also basically unjust?
('90', 336, 2, 4, 648417) While it is possible for an unofficial organization to offer non violent resistance in such a case, is it also possible for the government of the day to do so?
('90', 336, 3, 5, 648577) A. The question assumes a case which can never exist.
('90', 336, 3, 6, 648631) A non violent State must be broad based on the will of an intelligent people, well able to know its mind and act up to it.
('90', 336, 3, 7, 648754) In such a State the assumed section can only be negligible.
('90', 336, 3, 8, 648814) It can never stand against the delibe rate will of the overwhelming majority represented by the State.
('90', 336, 3, 9, 648917) The government of the day is not outside the people.
('90', 336, 3, 10, 648970) It is the will of the overwhelming majority.
('90', 336, 3, 11, 649015) It it is expressed non violently, it cannot be majority of one but nearer 99 against one in a hundred.
('90', 336, 4, 12, 649118) Q. 5. Is not non violent resistance by the militarily strong more effective than that by the militarily weak?
('90', 336, 5, 13, 649228) A. This is a contradiction in terms.
('90', 336, 5, 14, 649265) There can be no non violence offered by the militarily strong.
('90', 336, 5, 15, 649328) Thus, Russia in order to express non violence has to discard all her power of doing violence.
('90', 336, 5, 16, 649422) What is true is that if those, who were at one time strong in armed might, change their mind, they will be better able to demonstrate their non violence to the world and, therefore, also to their opponents.
('90', 336, 5, 17, 649629) Those who are strong in non violence will not mind whether they are opposed by the militarily weak people or the strongest.
('90', 336, 6, 18, 649753) Q. 6. What should be the training and discipline for a non violent army?
('90', 336, 6, 19, 649826) Should not certain aspects of conventional military training form a part of the syllabus?
('90', 336, 7, 20, 649916) A. A very small part of the preliminary training received by the military is common to the non violent army.
('90', 336, 7, 21, 650025) These are discipline, drill, singing in chorus, flag hoisting, signalling and the like.
('90', 336, 7, 22, 650113) Even this is not absolutely necessary and the basis is different.
('90', 336, 7, 23, 650179) The positively necessary training for a non violent army is an immovable faith in God, willing and perfect obedience to the chief of the non violent army and perfect inward and outward co operation between the units of the army.
('90', 336, 8, 24, 650408) Q. 7. Is it not better under the existing circumstances that countries like India and England should maintain full military efficiency while resolving to give non violent resistance a reasonable trial before taking any military step?
('90', 336, 9, 25, 650642) A. The foregoing answers should make it clear that under no
('90', 337, 0, 1, 650702) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 337, 1, 2, 650744) circumstance can India and England give non violent resistance a reasonable chance whilst they are both maintaining full military efficiency.
('90', 337, 1, 3, 650886) At the same time it is perfectly true that all military powers carry on negotiations for peaceful adjustment of rival disputes.
('90', 337, 1, 4, 651014) But here we are not discussing preliminary peace parleys before appealing to the arbitrament of war.
('90', 337, 1, 5, 651115) We are discussing a final substitute for armed conflict called war, in naked terms, mass murder.
('90', 337, 1, 6, 651212) SIMLA, May 2, 1946 Harijan, 12 5 1946

('90', 338, 4, 9, 653084) If we have faith in God we simply would not care to know beforehand how He may dispose of us.

('90', 339, 0, 1, 654867) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 339, 1, 2, 654909) getting tired of it, just as one is not tired of repeating the name of God.
('90', 339, 1, 3, 654985) Hypocrites too have the name of God on their lips but what we use is it if they carry a knife under their arms?
('90', 339, 1, 4, 655097) If Ramanama comes out of the heart one would never feel tired of it.
('90', 339, 1, 5, 655166) So never mind if I repeat endlessly whatever I want to say.
('90', 339, 1, 6, 655226) It is bound to have its impact on you.
('90', 339, 1, 7, 655265) The first mantra of the Ishopanishad says that God pervades the universe and it is man’s duty to surrender his all to God in the first instance.
('90', 339, 1, 8, 655410) There is nothing which he can call his own.
('90', 339, 1, 9, 655454) Having made the surrender man is to take out of it what he may require for his legitimate needs but not a whit more.
('90', 339, 1, 10, 655571) He must not covet what belongs to others.
('90', 339, 1, 11, 655613) Take my instance.
('90', 339, 1, 12, 655631) I have been housed here in a palatial building.
('90', 339, 1, 13, 655679) For fear of your embarrassing affection I had to seek Government’s hospitality and they put me up here.
('90', 339, 1, 14, 655783) That however does not mean that since the Government have placed a big bungalow at my disposal I am free to make use of the whole of it.
('90', 339, 1, 15, 655920) Tolstoy, in one of his inimitable parables, has answered the question, how much land a man requires.
('90', 339, 1, 16, 656021) The Devil tempts a man by granting him a boon that all the land that he can circumscribe by running around shall be his.
('90', 339, 1, 17, 656142) The man runs and runs, goades by his greed and in the end when the sun is just sinking below the horizon, he reaches back the starting point only to drop down dead.
('90', 339, 1, 18, 656307) Six feet of the earth is all the land that he requires for his burial.
('90', 339, 1, 19, 656378) If, therefore, I were to delude myself with the belief that I needed the whole of this bungalow and took possession of it, I would be set down as a fool.
('90', 339, 1, 20, 656532) Only a perverse nature can interpret the verse to mean that after making a ceremony of offering everything to God one can indulge oneself in the good things of life to an unlimited extent.
('90', 339, 1, 21, 656721) That would be a travesty of its true meaning.
('90', 339, 1, 22, 656767) I would far rather like to see a man dressed in old, mended clothes than in gaudy new ones.
('90', 339, 1, 23, 656859) To wear torn clothes is a sign of laziness and therefore a matter of shame, but to wear patched clothes proclaims your poverty or renunciation and industry.
('90', 339, 1, 24, 657016) Similarly, if someone gives me Rs. 25,000 and I spend it on my person I am a robber and thief.
('90', 339, 1, 25, 657111) I can use only enough for my bare needs.
('90', 339, 1, 26, 657152) That would be the teaching of the Ishopanishad.
('90', 339, 1, 27, 657200) If you understand this you will achieve great things.

('90', 340, 6, 13, 657724) 419. IS KHADI TOTTERING?
('90', 340, 6, 14, 657749) To those who have no faith khadi is tottering.
('90', 340, 6, 15, 657796) In reality it is gaining ground.
('90', 340, 6, 16, 657829) From being the poor man’s staff of life, it is trying to become the non violent means of gaining independence.
('90', 340, 6, 17, 657940) The difficulty is fairly clearly expressed in the following paragraphs 3 from a letter from Tamil Nadu.
('90', 340, 6, 18, 658044) The A. I. S. A. is faced with two problems now.
('90', 340, 6, 19, 658092) The one is to keep on the khadi production on the present methods.
('90', 340, 6, 20, 658159) The other is to give re orientation to our activity related to artisans and their villages where we seve.
('90', 340, 6, 21, 658265) The commercial production as it is, is seriously affected in the last few months owing to competition of the uncertified merchants in khadi.
('90', 340, 6, 22, 658406) The uncertified merchants buy the yarn from our spinners who spin with better cotton supplied by us.
('90', 340, 6, 23, 658507) They buy khadi woven by the weavers...
('90', 340, 6, 24, 658546) for by giving extra wages .
('90', 340, 6, 25, 658574) The khadi thus bought is sold .
('90', 340, 6, 26, 658606) at higher prices.
('90', 340, 6, 27, 658624) There are more than fifty uncertified khadi dealers in this area.
('90', 340, 6, 28, 658690) Among these are Congressmen also, who occupy places in the Congress Executive.
('90', 340, 6, 29, 658769) We are not able to influence the artisans against being exploited by the uncertified merchants.
('90', 340, 6, 30, 658865) They simply say that they are not able to resist the temptation of higher wages for inferior labour and with no conditons that we impose with regard to quality and their wearing khadi, etc.
('90', 340, 6, 31, 659055) This tendency among the artisans is a great impediment and obstacle in approaching them with our ideal of village reconstruction through the charkha.
('90', 340, 6, 32, 659205) The present method of khadi production has to be sacrificed if
('90', 340, 7, 33, 659268) 1 This is written on a letter from Premabehn Kantak dated May 2, 1946. 2 ibid 3 Of which only extracts are reproduced here
('90', 341, 0, 1, 659391) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 341, 1, 2, 659433) it hinders re orientation.
('90', 341, 1, 3, 659460) This requires faith and alertness which faith brings.
('90', 341, 1, 4, 659514) Faith never accrues to the lazy.
('90', 341, 1, 5, 659547) Uncertified khadi dealers are a powerful menace to khadi whether from the standpoint of the poor man or of non violence.
('90', 341, 1, 6, 659668) For the dealer knows only his own pocket and nothing else matters to him.
('90', 341, 1, 7, 659742) Of course, he goes to the weaver and the spinner and makes all kinds of promises, not knowing that if he killed the A. I. S. A. he would kill himself.
('90', 341, 1, 8, 659893) The pity of it all is that Congressmen become willing tools in the hands of these uncertified dealers.
('90', 341, 1, 9, 659996) They have brought into being an association of specialists.
('90', 341, 1, 10, 660056) Yet they do not know that they are willingly or unwillingly killing the goose that lays the golden egg.
('90', 341, 1, 11, 660160) They have a right to do so in any case, more so if they do not believe in khadi as the non violent insturment of swaraj.
('90', 341, 1, 12, 660281) It has been suggested to me that the policy of the A. I. S. A. can be changed only after consultation with Congressmen.
('90', 341, 1, 13, 660401) This is wrong in the nature of things.
('90', 341, 1, 14, 660440) The A. I. S. A. is composed of Congressmen.
('90', 341, 1, 15, 660484) Though created by the Congress, it is an autonomous body.
('90', 341, 1, 16, 660542) It can be disowned by the Congress at any time but while it is owned it must be trusted to do the right thing in terms of swaraj.
('90', 341, 1, 17, 660672) Part payment in yarn is a potent cause of worry to Congressmen.
('90', 341, 1, 18, 660736) This should not be so, if they believe that khadi is a symbol of non violence and all that it implies.
('90', 341, 1, 19, 660839) If such is not the belief the clause about compulsory wear of khadi should be given up.
('90', 341, 1, 20, 660927) Moreover, khadi furnishes the acid test of public honesty.
('90', 341, 1, 21, 660986) It is a great effort to find the best way of inducing honesty in public dealings, for it means coming in close and selfless touch with the millions of men and women in the villages.
('90', 341, 1, 22, 661168) The upshot of it all is that workers like the writer have to carry on their work with full faith in their mission and leave the result in the hands of God.
('90', 341, 1, 23, 661324) SIMLA, May 3, 1946 Harijan, 12 5 1946

('90', 345, 2, 4, 667974) 426. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('90', 345, 3, 5, 668002) SIMLA, May 4, 1946 Pressmen are inquiring already why my large party is going back.
('90', 345, 3, 6, 668086) This is a personal question.
('90', 345, 3, 7, 668115) I would rather avoid answering it, but in these days of publicity and speculation the question can not be evaded.
('90', 345, 3, 8, 668229) The reason is purely moral, if it may not be described as spiritual.
('90', 345, 3, 9, 668298) My task as a self appointed adviser to all the parties concerned is the most delicate at the present moment.
('90', 345, 3, 10, 668407) The Simla venue was declared all of a sudden.
('90', 345, 3, 11, 668453) It dawned on me that if I was to go to Simla, I must go without the usual party, even though Harijan work might suffer.
('90', 345, 3, 12, 668573) Had I succeeded in carrying conviction to the members of my party, they would have remained behind in Delhi.
('90', 345, 3, 13, 668682) 1 The time within which the decision was to be taken was only a few hours on the 1st instant.
('90', 345, 3, 14, 668776) They were anxious for my well being.
('90', 345, 3, 15, 668813) The whole moral purpose would be defeated, if I did not carry their mind with me.
('90', 345, 3, 16, 668895) They, therefore, came to Simla.
('90', 345, 3, 17, 668927) But the matter was still agitating me.
('90', 345, 3, 18, 668966) So I conferred with Pyarelal yesterday.
('90', 345, 3, 19, 669006) 2 He felt convinced that I should be left free to put myself solely in God’s keeping, if I was to work under as much detachment as was possible for me.
('90', 345, 3, 20, 669158) The best part of the afternoon was devoted to prayerful discussion that the party should go back to the heat of Delhi and await me there to rejoin me when I descended.
('90', 345, 3, 21, 669326) This is the sole reason without reservation.
('90', 345, 4, 22, 669371) The Hindustan Times, 5 5 1946, and Harijan, 12 5 1946
('90', 345, 5, 23, 669425) 427. LETTER TO MAJOR SHORT
('90', 345, 6, 24, 669452) May 4, 1946
('90', 345, 7, 25, 669464) DEAR MAJOR SHORT, I have your letter and the note on procedure.
('90', 345, 8, 26, 669528) 1 Vide “A Talk”, 1 5 1946 2 Vide “Talk With Agatha Harrison”, 3 5 1946
('90', 346, 0, 1, 669599) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 347
('90', 346, 1, 2, 669643) The note is something quite different from what you said yesterday.
('90', 346, 1, 3, 669711) For one thing it does not contemplate independence.
('90', 346, 1, 4, 669763) It seems to take Pakistan for granted.
('90', 346, 1, 5, 669802) As I said yesterday nothing can be done so long as the British Army of occupation remains.

('90', 348, 4, 20, 673892) 431. A HARIJAN’S LETTER 1
('90', 348, 5, 21, 673918) A Harijan friend complains bitterly about my article on sweepers’ strike 2. His first complaint is that I have given up the sweet name ‘Harijan’ and used “Bhangi” instead.
('90', 348, 5, 22, 674090) The criticism shows the sensi tive nature of the correspondent.
('90', 348, 5, 23, 674154) It was a Gujarati untouchable in the first instance, who suggested the name ‘Harijan’ to me and I willingly adopted it.
('90', 348, 5, 24, 674274) This does not, however, mean that a current word for any sub caste may never be used.
('90', 348, 5, 25, 674360) I count myself a Harijan and it pleases me to call myself a Bhangi among them, because that is the lowest caste of Harijans.
('90', 348, 5, 26, 674485) When I stayed recently in the sweepers’ quarters in Delhi, the Harijans there too complained against the use of the word ‘Bhangi’.
('90', 348, 5, 27, 674616) They suggested ‘Mehtar’.
('90', 348, 5, 28, 674641) I tried to make them understand that it mattered little as to which of the current words was used for the same occupation.
('90', 348, 5, 29, 674764) In spite of being considered the lowest occupation, it was in fact the highest inasmuch as it protected health and they should be indifferent to the name.
('90', 348, 5, 30, 674919) Whatever the origin of the word may be, ‘Bhangi’ is, in my opinion, another name for ‘Shivji’ 3. Whether you call a sweeper a Mehtar or a ‘Bhangi’, like ‘Shivji’ he

('90', 352, 4, 6, 681265) It is impossible to answer every letter.
('90', 352, 4, 7, 681306) Every communication is read but not by me.
('90', 352, 4, 8, 681349) If I attempted to do so I would be unable to render any service.
('90', 352, 4, 9, 681414) My staff put before me only what I should see.
('90', 352, 4, 10, 681461) Much of the post does not merit replies, but questions of public interest are answered in Harijan.
('90', 352, 4, 11, 681560) Personal correspondence has to be rigidly restricted.
('90', 352, 4, 12, 681614) I receive a large number of requests for blessings on the occasion of marriages which I am hesitant to send.
('90', 352, 4, 13, 681723) I have already stated publicly that my blessings should be asked for only such marriages where one of the contracting parties is a Harijan.
('90', 352, 4, 14, 681863) But in reality where is the need for blessings?
('90', 352, 4, 15, 681911) Those marriages which are undertaken for the sake of joint service carry their own blessings.
('90', 352, 4, 16, 682005) Those entered upon for self satisfaction are wholly unworthy of any.
('90', 352, 4, 17, 682074) In any event, in these days of famine, no money should be spent on feasts and enjoyment.
('90', 352, 4, 18, 682163) Weddings will continue, but is it not possible for the event to take place quietly and without fuss?

('90', 353, 6, 12, 683602) 440. DRAFT LETTER TO LORD PETHICK LAWRENCE 3
('90', 353, 7, 13, 683647) Confidential THE RETREAT,
('90', 353, 8, 14, 683673) SIMLA, May 6, 1946
('90', 353, 9, 15, 683692) DEAR LORD PETHICK LAWRENCE,
('90', 353, 10, 16, 683720) My colleagues and I followed with care the proceedings of the Conference yesterday and tried to understand what our conversations were leading us to.
('90', 353, 10, 17, 683870) I confess to feeling somewhat mystified and disturbed at the vagueness of our talks and some of the assumptions underlying them.
('90', 353, 10, 18, 683999) While we would like to associate ourselves with every effort to explore ways and means of finding a basis for agreement, we must not deceive ourselves, the Cabinet Mission or the representatives of the Muslim League into the belief that the way the Conference has so far proceeded furnishes hope of success.
('90', 353, 10, 19, 684307) Our general approach to the questions before us was stated briefly in my letter to you of April 28. We find that this approach has been largely ignored and a contrary method has been followed.
('90', 353, 10, 20, 684500) We realize that some
('90', 353, 11, 21, 684521) 1Which occurred on May 6 2 This appeared in Harijan under “Notes”, 12 5 1946. 3 This was drafted for Abul Kalam Azad by Jawaharlal Nehru and was revised by Gandhiji.
('90', 354, 0, 1, 684687) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 355
('90', 354, 1, 2, 684731) assumtions have to be made in the early stages as otherwise there can be no progress.
('90', 354, 1, 3, 684817) But assumptions which ignore or run contrary to 1 fundamental issues are likely to lead to misunderstandings during the later stages.
('90', 354, 2, 4, 684951) In my letter of April 28, I stated that the basic issue before us was that of Indian independence and the consequent withdrawal of the British army from India, for there can be no independence so long as there is foreign army on Indian soil.
('90', 354, 2, 5, 685193) We stand for the independence of the whole of India now and not in the distant or near futre.
('90', 354, 2, 6, 685287) Other matters are subsidiary to this and can be fully discussed and decided by the Constituent Assembly.
('90', 354, 2, 7, 685392) At the Conference yesterday I referred to this again and we were glad to find that you and your colleagues, as well as the other members of the Conference, accepted independence as the basis of our talks.
('90', 354, 2, 8, 685597) It was stated by you that the Constituent Assembly would finally decide about the nexus or other relationship that might be established between a free India and England.
('90', 354, 2, 9, 685767) While this is perfectly true, it does not affect the position now and that is, the acceptance of Indian independence now.
('90', 354, 2, 10, 685889) If that is so, then certain consequences inevitably follow.
('90', 354, 2, 11, 685949) We felt yesterday that there was no appreciation of these consequences.
('90', 354, 2, 12, 686021) The Constituent Assembly is not going to decide the question of independence; that question must be and, we take it, has been decided now.
('90', 354, 2, 13, 686160) That Assembly will represent the will of the free Indian nation and give effect to it.
('90', 354, 2, 14, 686247) It is not going to be bound by any previous arrangements.
('90', 354, 2, 15, 686305) It has to be preceded by a Provisional Government, which must function, as far as possible, as a Government of free India, and which should undertake to make all arrangements for the transitional period.
('90', 354, 2, 16, 686509) In our discussions yesterday repeated references were made to ‘groups’ of provinces functioning together, and it was even suggested that such group would have an executive and legislative machinery.
('90', 354, 2, 17, 686708) This method grouping has not so far been discussed by us but still our talks seemed to presume all this.
('90', 354, 2, 18, 686813) I should like to make it very clear that we are entirely opposed to any executive or legislative machinery for a group of provinces or units of the Federation.
('90', 354, 2, 19, 686973) That will mean a sub federation, if not something more, and we have already told you that we do not accept this.
('90', 354, 2, 20, 687086) It would result in creating three layers of executive and legislative bodies, an arrangement which will be cumbrous, static and disjointed, leading to continuous friction.
('90', 354, 2, 21, 687258) We are not aware of any such arrangement in any country.
('90', 354, 2, 22, 687315) We are emphatically of the opinion that it is not open to the Conference to entertain any suggestions for a division of India.
('90', 354, 2, 23, 687442) If that is to come, it should come through the Constituent Assembly free of any infuence of the present Paramount Power.
('90', 354, 3, 24, 687563) Another point we wish to make clear is that we do not accept the proposal for
('90', 354, 4, 25, 687641) 1 The words in italics are in Gandhiji’s hand.
('90', 354, 4, 26, 687688) 2 This paragraph is in Gandhiji’s hand.
('90', 355, 0, 1, 687728) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 355, 1, 2, 687770) parity as between groups in regard to the executive or the legislature.
('90', 355, 1, 3, 687842) We realize that everything possible should be done to remove fears and suspicions from the mind of every group and community.
('90', 355, 1, 4, 687968) But the way to do this is not by unreal methods which go against the basic principles of democracy on which we hope to build up our constitution.
('90', 355, 2, 5, 688114) Yours sincerely,

('90', 355, 5, 8, 688215) SIMLA, May 6, 1946
('90', 355, 6, 9, 688234) MANILAL, I got your letter, in fact, two letters.
('90', 355, 6, 10, 688284) I see that your work is progressing well.
('90', 355, 6, 11, 688326) No good work is accomplished in a day.
('90', 355, 6, 12, 688365) A job that can be finished in one day cannot be of much value.
('90', 355, 6, 13, 688428) We must, therefore, cultivate patience, and for that we should learn non attachment.
('90', 355, 6, 14, 688513) Non attachment implies faith that only good results can follow from good actions.
('90', 355, 6, 15, 688595) This firm faith should make us indifferent to the results.
('90', 355, 6, 16, 688654) We are certain that the sun will rise tomorrow and do not worry.
('90', 355, 6, 17, 688719) We should have still deeper faith about the results of good works.
('90', 355, 6, 18, 688786) There is bound to come a day when the sun will not rise; but there can be no time when a good deed will not bear good fruit.
('90', 355, 6, 19, 688911) Hence you should go on with your work in the faith that the people will one day see its merit.
('90', 355, 6, 20, 689006) Sanitation comes first, because it covers most of the other things.
('90', 355, 6, 21, 689074) I do not have your letter before me while writing these lines.
('90', 355, 6, 22, 689137) If, therefore, I have missed any point, ask me again.

('90', 364, 7, 28, 702310) 459. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('90', 364, 8, 29, 702340) SIMLA, May 7, 1946
('90', 364, 9, 30, 702359) Mahatma Gandhi, in his speech at today’s prayer meeting, commended the quiet which prevailed after his appeal to the audience on the two previous evenings.
('90', 364, 10, 31, 702515) 1 Secretary, A. I. S. A. 2 Satis Chandra Das Gupta
('90', 365, 0, 1, 702566) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 365, 1, 2, 702608) He asked them all if they could sing in tune and keep proper time to join in the Ramdhun.
('90', 365, 1, 3, 702698) It was a good habit to cultivate and if they did it from the heart and intelligently they would realize that God’s blessings were in it.
('90', 365, 1, 4, 702835) If they co operated in a pure thing it would help them to co operate with their neighbours in all that pertained to the common weal.
('90', 365, 2, 5, 702968) Strange rumours had come to him, he said, in regard to his permanent staff having left.
('90', 365, 2, 6, 703056) Some people were foolish enough to believe that there had been some domestic quarrel.
('90', 365, 2, 7, 703142) Those who lived with him were not made of such stuff.
('90', 365, 2, 8, 703196) Others imagined that because his staff had left, the negotiations had broken down.
('90', 365, 2, 9, 703279) This too was wholly untrue.
('90', 365, 2, 10, 703307) They left, as Gandhiji had said before 2, because they understood that he wanted to be alone with God as his only help.
('90', 365, 2, 11, 703427) Even so he was not without help.
('90', 365, 2, 12, 703460) It had been so throughtout his life.
('90', 365, 2, 13, 703497) In South Africa, too, all kinds of people had helped him including Boers, Africans and Europeans.
('90', 365, 3, 14, 703595) The address .
('90', 365, 3, 15, 703609) contained a scathing denunciation of the speculation fever which had seized Simla.
('90', 365, 3, 16, 703692) He interpreted it as a sign of cowardice.
('90', 365, 3, 17, 703734) He tried to impress upon them that it arose from fear.
('90', 365, 3, 18, 703789) He himself was a coward in his early youth.
('90', 365, 3, 19, 703833) He had learnt to shed his cowardice through the recitation of Ramanama.
('90', 365, 3, 20, 703905) 3 It was cowards who died many times before their death.
('90', 365, 3, 21, 703962) Fear of disease killed more men that disease itself.
('90', 365, 3, 22, 704015) He appealed to newspapermen also not to spread false news.

('90', 366, 4, 6, 705633) NON VIOLENCE AND KHADI The Congress Constitution is undergoing a radical change.
('90', 366, 4, 7, 705714) The supreme change that is desirable for the sake of avoiding untruth and hypocrisy is to remove the words “legitimate and peaceful” from the first article of the Congress Constitution as also the clause about khadi.
('90', 366, 4, 8, 705931) 1 Experience shows that the people who form the bulk of Congressmen are not wedded either to truth and non violence or to khadi.
('90', 366, 4, 9, 706060) As an ardent lover of truth and non violence and khadi as their symbol, I make bold to suggest that these clauses should go.
('90', 366, 4, 10, 706185) It will be open to anyone to be truthful and non violent and to wear khadi if he or she chooses to.
('90', 366, 4, 11, 706285) Only there will be no deception practised on India or the world.
('90', 366, 4, 12, 706350) Paradoxical as it may appear we shall be more truthful 2, more non violent and better khadi lovers with the suggested amendment than without.
('90', 366, 4, 13, 706492) It should be remembered that I myself had at one time moved the removal of these clauses.
('90', 366, 4, 14, 706582) I was glad I was defeated.
('90', 366, 4, 15, 706609) It was wrong to be glad.
('90', 366, 4, 16, 706634) I shall be sorry if my suggestion is rejected even now.
('90', 366, 4, 17, 706690) Let it not be said of us that we prize hypocrisy above truth.
('90', 366, 5, 18, 706752) COCKTAIL PARTIES We seem to be on the eve of attaining independence!
('90', 366, 5, 19, 706821) Should we ape bad European manner and customs and still prize in dependence?
('90', 366, 5, 20, 706898) It would be a sad day for India and the world, if the price we are to pay for independence is cocktail parties and the like.
('90', 366, 5, 21, 707023) What do the famishing millions know of such parties?
('90', 366, 5, 22, 707076) Let it not be said of us that our monied men were gay whilst those from whom they made money were famishing for food.

('90', 371, 4, 7, 716378) 465. AYURVEDA AND NATURE CURE 1
('90', 371, 5, 8, 716410) Vaidya Vallabhram, Professor of Ayurveda and Vanaspati Shastra 2 writes : 3
('90', 371, 6, 9, 716486) Cure through Ayurveda is based on the five elements.
('90', 371, 6, 10, 716539) Pathya (diet cure) is a scientific term of the greatest importance in Ayurveda.
('90', 371, 6, 11, 716619) Its real meaning is that freedom from disease depends on a proper observance of the laws of nature.
('90', 371, 6, 12, 716719) I have no doubt whatsoever that the repetition of Ramanama and pure living are the best and the cheapest preventives of disease.
('90', 371, 6, 13, 716848) The tragedy is that doctors, hakims and vaidyas do not make use of Ramanama as the sovereign of cures.
('90', 371, 6, 14, 716951) There is no place given to it in current Ayurvedic literature except in the shape of a charm which will drive people further into the well of superstition.
('90', 371, 6, 15, 717107) Ramanama has in fact no connection with superstition.
('90', 371, 6, 16, 717161) It is nature’s supreme law.
('90', 371, 6, 17, 717189) Whoever observes it is free from disease and vice versa.
('90', 371, 6, 18, 717246) The same law which keeps one free from disease applies also to its cure.
('90', 371, 6, 19, 717319) An apt question is as to why a man who recites Ramanama regularly and leads a pure life should ever fall ill.
('90', 371, 6, 20, 717429) Man is by nature imperfect.
('90', 371, 6, 21, 717457) A thoughtful man strives after perfection, but seldom attains it, for he stumbles on the way, though unwittingly.
('90', 371, 6, 22, 717571) The whole of God’s law is embodies in a pure life.
('90', 371, 6, 23, 717622) The first thing is to realize one’s limi tations.
('90', 371, 6, 24, 717672) It should be obvious that the moment one transgresses those limits one falls ill.
('90', 371, 6, 25, 717754) Thus a balanced diet eaten in accordance with needs gives one freedom from disease.
('90', 371, 6, 26, 717838) How is one to know what is the proper diet for one?
('90', 371, 6, 27, 717890) Many such problems can be imagined.
('90', 371, 6, 28, 717926) The purport of all this is that everyone should be his own doctor and find

('90', 373, 2, 4, 720878) A. There is much confusion of thought in this question.

('90', 391, 11, 19, 750695) 496. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 3
('90', 391, 12, 20, 750727) May 12, 1946
('90', 391, 13, 21, 750740) Referring to the spate of false rumours which filled the air, viz., that there had been a breakdown in the talks, that the Cabinet Mission were returning home without doing anything and Indian leaders would again return empty handed as they did from the Simla Conference 4 last time, Gandhiji said that this was not a conference like the one they had last year.
('90', 391, 13, 22, 751102) If he understood the English language aright, the Cabinet Mission was here to find out how best they could implement their decision to quit, i.
('90', 391, 14, 23, 751246) 1 Addressee’s wife 2 One word is illegible here.
('90', 391, 14, 24, 751295) 3 Reproduced from Pyarelal’s “A Simla Diary” 4 Held in June July, 1945; vide
('90', 392, 0, 1, 751372) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 393
('90', 392, 1, 2, 751416) e., remove their power from India.
('90', 392, 1, 3, 751451) It was their duty, if they could, to try to bring about agreement between the Congress and the Muslim League.
('90', 392, 1, 4, 751561) The Conference was being held for that purpose.
('90', 392, 1, 5, 751609) If people were united, no power on earth could have ruled over them but the tragedy was that they had their differences.
('90', 392, 1, 6, 751730) But even if the Conference failed in its purpose, no one need be disappointed.
('90', 392, 1, 7, 751809) Those who have faith in God must be patient and brave.
('90', 392, 1, 8, 751864) Supposing they were going to be deceived, they must stand up and face the consequences bravely.
('90', 392, 1, 9, 751960) Gandhiji said he had no reason to believe that the Cabinet Mission was here to deceive them.
('90', 392, 1, 10, 752053) They were trying to leave in an orderly manner so that Indians may be able to live in peace.
('90', 392, 1, 11, 752146) There was no need to worry.
('90', 392, 1, 12, 752174) Man had to do his duty.
('90', 392, 1, 13, 752198) God had given him strength and discernment to do so.
('90', 392, 1, 14, 752251) But results were always in God’s hands.
('90', 392, 2, 15, 752291) Last in their anxiety for their own future they might forget their duty towards those whom they had condemned as the lowest of the sweepers’ quarters.
('90', 392, 2, 16, 752442) The report which the latter brought him filled him (Gandhiji) with anger and grief.
('90', 392, 2, 17, 752526) He would have loved to go there himself.
('90', 392, 2, 18, 752567) Unfortunately he could not now negotiate hills and therefore could not walk so far to see them himself.
('90', 392, 2, 19, 752671) He thought it a crime to sit in rickshaws especially for an able bodied man.
('90', 392, 2, 20, 752748) He disliked even a motor car.
('90', 392, 2, 21, 752778) He wanted always to use his legs, the means of locomotion that God had given him.
('90', 392, 2, 22, 752860) Last night he walked, but the hill seemed unending.
('90', 392, 2, 23, 752912) It was impossible for him, much as he would have liked to do so, to live in the Harijan Nivas here.
('90', 392, 2, 24, 753012) He had heard of it before and what Badshah Khan told him confirmed it, namely, that the quarters in which they were forced to live were not fit for animals, much less for human beings.
('90', 392, 2, 25, 753197) Some of them had been to see him in the morning with a long tale of woe.
('90', 392, 2, 26, 753270) It was the bounden duty of the residents of Simla to look into their grievances and have them redressed.
('90', 392, 3, 27, 753375) He had heard too that the Khadi Bhandar at Simla might have to be closed down, because the Simla public were too lazy and too ununderstanding to spin the requisite quota of yarn.
('90', 392, 3, 28, 753554) He told them that he still maintained that swaraj hung on the thread of hand spun yarn.
('90', 392, 3, 29, 753642) Even if they got political swaraj, as they were going to, they would never be able to maintain it without khadi which was the truest symbol of non violence.
('90', 392, 3, 30, 753799) If they hoped to maintain swaraj through force, they were hopelessly mistaken.
('90', 392, 3, 31, 753878) Someone stronger would come and wrest their freedom from them.
('90', 392, 3, 32, 753941) It was in the hands of the public in Simla to keep the Bhandar going and he hoped they would do so.
('90', 392, 3, 33, 754041) Punjabi women were the first to offer him yarn in the old days.
('90', 392, 3, 34, 754105) Let them live up to their reputation.
('90', 392, 3, 35, 754143) For himself, he would rather lose their money and close down every Bhandar, if need be, but swaraj never.
('90', 392, 3, 36, 754249) Harijan, 19 5 1946
('90', 393, 0, 1, 754268) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 393, 1, 2, 754310) 497. A GOOD REMINDER An anonymous friend has taken the trouble of collecting apposite extracts from the Book of Job and Psalms.
('90', 393, 1, 3, 754438) As they are a perpetual reminder to all of us, I gladly give them below.
('90', 393, 1, 4, 754511) 1 The moral I draw from the sheaf is that since man is only dust and at best grass, he had better pass the few moments he is on this earth in the service of his fellow creatures.
('90', 393, 1, 5, 754690) I am hoping that the sender has not collected the Biblical verses to show the futility of all work, which is a doctrine of laziness and parasitism.
('90', 393, 1, 6, 754838) SIMLA, May 13, 1946 Harijan, 19 5 1946
('90', 393, 2, 7, 754877) 498. SLIGHTING SWARAJ?
('90', 393, 3, 8, 754900) Since the decision that khadi could only be purchased by giving a certain quota of yarn came into being, it has become very hard for a man like myself .
('90', 393, 3, 9, 755053) to find the requisite time for spinning.
('90', 393, 3, 10, 755094) Nevertheless I have been spinning 11 2 hours daily in order to be true to my pledge.
('90', 393, 3, 11, 755179) I had no slivers left the other
('90', 393, 4, 12, 755211) day and, therefore, went to the khadi Bhandar to buy some.
('90', 393, 4, 13, 755270) I was asked by the Manager either to come to the Bhandar in order to make my own slivers or do the carding there and make the slivers at home.
('90', 393, 4, 14, 755413) Now it is impossible for me with my very limited living space to slivers at home nor has a man like me the time to go and make them at the Bhandar.
('90', 393, 4, 15, 755561) I said, “Either give me slivers or else I shall have to give up spinning.” I was told I was at liberty to do what I considered proper.
('90', 393, 4, 16, 755696) The above letter 3 requires an answer.
('90', 393, 4, 17, 755735) The plight of the writer is the same as that of the many who live in the slums of Bombay.
('90', 393, 4, 18, 755825) If our people were not so easily satisfied, the landlords of Bombay would not relegate poor families to one small living room each.
('90', 393, 4, 19, 755957) Lakhs live in this way and thus make it possible for the rich to have their Malabar Hill and Chowpatty.
('90', 393, 4, 20, 756061) The spinning wheel shows us the way to remedy these conditions.
('90', 393, 4, 21, 756125) If this were not so, it would have no place in my life.
('90', 393, 4, 22, 756181) A few people may carve out their way by the sword, but the crores cannot.

('90', 401, 10, 22, 766867) NEW DELHI, [May 15, 1946] 2
('90', 401, 11, 23, 766895) Echoing Badshah Khan’s word at the end of the prayers, Gandhiji said it was a travesty of true religion to consider one’s own religion as superior and others’ as inferior.
('90', 401, 11, 24, 767067) All religions enjoined worship of the one God who was all prevasive.
('90', 401, 11, 25, 767136) He was present even in a drople of water or in a tiny speak of dust.
('90', 401, 11, 26, 767205) Even those who worship idols, worship not the stone of which it is made; they try to see God who resides in it.
('90', 401, 12, 27, 767317) Similarly it was a libel to call the Paris fire worshippers or sun worshippers.
('90', 401, 13, 28, 767397) 1 Reproduced from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” 2 From the reference to the Cabinet Delegation’s announcement being made within “twenty six hours’.
('90', 401, 13, 29, 767542) The announcement was made on May 16, 1946.
('90', 402, 0, 1, 767585) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 403
('90', 402, 1, 2, 767629) The Parsi hymn which Dr. Dinshaw Mehta had recited corresponded to the Gayatri 1 of the Hindus.
('90', 402, 1, 3, 767725) It was nothing but puree worship of God.
('90', 402, 1, 4, 767766) The various religion were like the leaves on a tree.
('90', 402, 1, 5, 767819) No two leaves were alike, yet there was no antagonis between the branches on which they grew.
('90', 402, 1, 6, 767913) Even so, there is an underlying unity in the varity which we see in God’s creation.
('90', 402, 2, 7, 767997) Speculation as to the contents of the impending announcement of the Cabinet Mission had reached a feverish height with the return from Simla of the Mission and other members of the Tripartite Conference.
('90', 402, 2, 8, 768201) Friends had been asking, remarked Gandhiji, as to what the message was likely to contain.
('90', 402, 2, 9, 768291) He did not know, nor did he speculate.
('90', 402, 2, 10, 768330) It was no use giving thought as to what it would contain.
('90', 402, 2, 11, 768388) A man of prayer could not do otherwise.
('90', 402, 2, 12, 768428) Good or bad, they would know all in another twenty six hours.
('90', 402, 2, 13, 768490) It would then be open to them to accept or reject it.
('90', 402, 2, 14, 768544) Instead of looking outwards let them inward and ask God what their duty was in either event.
('90', 402, 2, 15, 768637) For him and them in the meanwhile, it should be enough to know that Cabinet Delegation had come all the way leaving their hearth and home to find out in what manner British rule was to end and when the last British soldier was to leave India, and not whether or not to leave India.
('90', 402, 2, 16, 768919) It was necessary for them to find out whether the Congress and the Muslim League could be brought together.
('90', 402, 2, 17, 769027) British rule had separate them and if they (the Cabinet Mission) failed it was small wonder.
('90', 402, 2, 18, 769120) They were bound to come together soon after the British hold on India had demonstrably ceased.
('90', 402, 2, 19, 769215) The Cabinet Delegation’s concern was to quite India without a moment’s delay.
('90', 402, 2, 20, 769293) But supposing the reverse happens they will be the losers, not we.
('90', 402, 2, 21, 769360) We have chosen the path of self suffering.
('90', 402, 2, 22, 769403) We rise through our suffering.
('90', 402, 2, 23, 769434) That is nature’s law.
('90', 402, 2, 24, 769456) He who clings to his sordid self or family interests loses.
('90', 402, 2, 25, 769516) Man is sent into the world to perform his duty even at the cost of his life if necessary.
('90', 402, 2, 26, 769606) We must therefore be braced for any suffering that may come in the performance of duty.
('90', 402, 2, 27, 769694) All of us, Hindus and Mussalmans, constitute an integral whole.
('90', 402, 2, 28, 769758) If someone errs all must suffer for it.
('90', 402, 2, 29, 769798) God has so ordered this world that no one can keep his goodness or badness exclusively to himself.
('90', 402, 2, 30, 769897) The whole world is like the human body with its various members.
('90', 402, 2, 31, 769962) Pain in one member is felt in the whole body.
('90', 402, 2, 32, 770008) Rot in one part must inevitably poison the whole system.
('90', 402, 2, 33, 770065) Let us, therefore, cease to think in terms of individual and think in terms of the whole country.
('90', 402, 2, 34, 770163) We must put faith in God and be careful for nothing.
('90', 402, 2, 35, 770216) We hold our destiny in our own hands and no one but ourselves can make or mar it.
('90', 402, 2, 36, 770298) Harijan, 26 5 1946

('90', 407, 0, 1, 776041) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 407, 1, 2, 776083) 522. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('90', 407, 2, 3, 776115) May 17, 1946 2
('90', 407, 3, 4, 776130) Taking as his text the song 3 sung by Shrimati Sucheta Kripalani about “the land that was without sorrow and suffering,” Gandhiji proceeded to examine the Cabinet Mission’s pronouncement in the light of the ideal set forth in that song.
('90', 407, 3, 5, 776367) How far was Cabinet Mission’s pronouncement calculated to enable them to realize that ideal?
('90', 407, 3, 6, 776460) The poet says we are citizens of a country in which there is neither sorrow nor suffering.
('90', 407, 3, 7, 776551) Where is such a country to be found in this world?
('90', 407, 3, 8, 776602) I confess, throughout my wandering I have not come across such a country so far.
('90', 407, 3, 9, 776683) The poet has latter described the condition for the attainment of that ideal state.
('90', 407, 3, 10, 776767) It is easy to observe them individually.
('90', 407, 3, 11, 776808) For one who really and truly is pure at heart, there is no sorrow or suffering.
('90', 407, 3, 12, 776888) but it is a difficult state for the millions to attain.
('90', 407, 3, 13, 776944) Nevertheless we want India to be such a country.
('90', 407, 4, 14, 776993) He had asked them on the previous day to examine independently of other people’s opinions the statement of the Cabinet Delegation when they saw it.
('90', 407, 4, 15, 777141) They should examine it from the point of view of a country which would be without sorrow or suffering.
('90', 407, 4, 16, 777244) He would give them his own reactions.
('90', 407, 4, 17, 777282) He, however, did not want to contradict himself by asking them to follow his ideas if they did not appeal to them.
('90', 407, 4, 18, 777397) Everyone should think for himself and herself.
('90', 407, 4, 19, 777444) They were to weigh opinions and adopt only those they had assimilated.
('90', 407, 5, 20, 777515) He had glanced at the document casually on the previous night as soon as it was received.
('90', 407, 5, 21, 777605) He had read it carefully in the morning.
('90', 407, 5, 22, 777646) It was not an award.
('90', 407, 5, 23, 777667) The Mission and the Viceroy had tried to bring the parties together but they could not bring about an agreement.
('90', 407, 5, 24, 777780) So they had recommended to the country what in their opinion was worthy of acceptance by the Constituent Assembly.
('90', 407, 5, 25, 777895) It was open to that body to vary it, reject it or improve upon it.
('90', 407, 5, 26, 777962) There was no ‘take it or’ business about their recommendations.
('90', 407, 5, 27, 778026) If there were restrictions, the Constituent Assemby would not be a sovereign body, free to frame a constitution of independence for India.
('90', 407, 5, 28, 778165) Thus the Mission has suggested for the Centre certain subjecs.
('90', 407, 5, 29, 778228) It was open to the Assembly by the majority vote of Muslims and non Muslims separately, to add to them or even reduce them.
('90', 407, 5, 30, 778352) And it was open to the Assembly to abolish the distiction which the Mission had felt forced to recognize.
('90', 407, 5, 31, 778458) Similarly about grouping.
('90', 407, 5, 32, 778484) The provinces were free to reject the very idea of grouping.
('90', 407, 5, 33, 778545) No province could be forced against its will
('90', 407, 6, 34, 778590) 1 Reproduced from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” 2 From The Hindustan Times, 18 5 1946 3 Vide “The Hymn”
('90', 408, 0, 1, 778691) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 409
('90', 408, 1, 2, 778735) to belong to a group, even if the idea of grouping was accepted.
('90', 408, 1, 3, 778800) He instanced only two things to illustrate this point.
('90', 408, 1, 4, 778855) He had not exhausted the list of things which seemed to him to be open to objection or improvement.
('90', 408, 2, 5, 778955) Subject to the above interpretation, which he held was right, he told them that the Mission had brought forth something of which they had every reason to be proud.
('90', 408, 3, 6, 779119) There were some, he proceeded, who said the English were incapable of doing the right thing.
('90', 408, 3, 7, 779212) He did not agree with them.
('90', 408, 3, 8, 779240) The Mission and the Viceroy were godfearing as they themselves claimed to be.
('90', 408, 3, 9, 779318) It was beneath their dignity as men to doubt a person before he was proved to be untrue to his work.
('90', 408, 3, 10, 779419) The late Charlie Andrews was very inch of him an Englishman who had died slaving for India.
('90', 408, 3, 11, 779511) It would be grievously wrong to doubt in advance every one of his contrymen.
('90', 408, 4, 12, 779588) Whatever the wrong done to India by the British rule, if the statement of the Mission was geniune, as he believed it was, it was in discharge of an obligation which they had declared the British owed to India, namely, to get off India’s back.
('90', 408, 4, 13, 779831) It contained the seed to convert this land of sorrow into one without sorrow and suffering.
('90', 408, 4, 14, 779923) Harijan, 26 5 1946
('90', 408, 5, 15, 779942) 523. INERVIEW TO U BA PE 1
('90', 408, 6, 16, 779969) NEW DELHI, May 18, 1946
