('90', 409, 0, 1, 780502) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 409, 1, 2, 780544) 524. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('90', 409, 2, 3, 780576) NEW DELHI, May 18, 1946
('90', 409, 3, 4, 780600) Pursuing the theme of the previous day’s song 2 , Gandhiji asked.
('90', 409, 3, 5, 780666) how they were to convert India, which was today the home of sorrow and suffering into the ideal country about which the poet had sung.
('90', 409, 3, 6, 780801) The reply he said was furnished by the song about the sermon of the trees which had just been sung.
('90', 409, 3, 7, 780901) In tha song one is asked to take the lesson from the trees which themselves suffer the fierce rays of the sun and give shade to those who take shelter under them.
('90', 409, 3, 8, 781064) To those who throw stones at them, they respond by dropping fruit.
('90', 409, 3, 9, 781131) That is true philanthropy.
('90', 409, 3, 10, 781158) To learn that philanthropy we are asked in that song to go to Harijan.
('90', 409, 3, 11, 781229) Today society has condemned Harijans to a life of fifth and degradation.
('90', 409, 3, 12, 781302) That is not their shame but our shame.
('90', 409, 3, 13, 781341) Society has treated them as untouchables and condemned them to live in ghettos and yet they continue to render invaluable service to society for a mere pittance.
('90', 409, 3, 14, 781503) It was open to them to take more lucrative avocations as some of them have done.
('90', 409, 3, 15, 781584) The fact that vast majority of them have chosen not to, resounds to their credit.
('90', 409, 4, 16, 781666) If they could show that spirit of service in spite of their ignorance and backwardness, he asked, how much more spirit of selfless service and sacrifice ought the so called savarna classes to show?
('90', 409, 5, 17, 781864) He had remarked in his previous day’s address that he saw the germs of the realization of the ideal envisaged by the poet in the song that had been sung on that day, in the announcement of the Cabinet Mission.
('90', 409, 5, 18, 782074) But it was subject to the condition that it meant what it said.
('90', 409, 5, 19, 782138) He likened that announcement to a promissory note, whose worth depended entirely on its genuineness and validity.
('90', 409, 5, 20, 782252) If the promise inscribed on a promissory note is not honoured, the note is worth nothing and fit only to be torn to pieces and thrown away.
('90', 409, 6, 21, 782392) Truth meant everything to him.
('90', 409, 6, 22, 782423) He had said that he would not purchase even swaraj at the cost of truth, because swaraj so purchased would be illusory.
('90', 409, 6, 23, 782543) It was his hope and prayer, in which he invited the audience to join him, that the announcement of the Cabinet Mission would be finally hounoured in letter and in spirit, and that God
('90', 409, 7, 24, 782727) 1 Reproduced help in Burma’s struggle.
('90', 409, 7, 25, 782766) 2 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 17 5 1946
('90', 410, 0, 1, 782811) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 411
('90', 410, 1, 2, 782855) would help the members of the Mission to discharge their promissory note even as He had done for His devotees in days of old.
('90', 410, 1, 3, 782981) Harijan, 26 5 1946

('90', 414, 4, 7, 788703) 532. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('90', 414, 5, 8, 788735) NEW DELHI, May 19, 1946
('90', 414, 6, 9, 788759) Gandhiji said that if they had carefully followed and assimilated Badshah Khan’s remarks 2 they would know that the object of prayer was not to please God, who does not want our prayers or praise, but to purify ourselves.
('90', 414, 6, 10, 788981) God is omnipresent.
('90', 414, 6, 11, 789001) There is not an atom in the universe without His presence.
('90', 414, 6, 12, 789060) The process of self purificattion consists in a conscious realization of His presence within us.
('90', 414, 6, 13, 789157) There is no strength greater than that which such realization gives.
('90', 414, 7, 14, 789226) It had pleased him to see so many of them coming to attend the prayers, he said.
('90', 414, 7, 15, 789307) But it would hurt him if he found that they had come just for fun, or, what would be worse still, to hear his politicaal views.
('90', 414, 7, 16, 789435) As a rule politics should not be permitted to intrude upon prayer.
('90', 414, 7, 17, 789502) He, however, could not avoid referring to current political topics sometimes in the course of his after prayer discourses because life could not be divided into water tight compartments.
('90', 414, 7, 18, 789689) Presence of God had to be felt in every walk of life.
('90', 414, 7, 19, 789743) If they thought that as soon as they left the prayer ground they could live and behave anyhow, their attendance at the prayers was useless.
('90', 414, 7, 20, 789883) If that interest in the prayers was genuine, the next day’s prayers, he hoped, would be as numerously attended as on the day he spoke, although he would not be speaking on account of his Monday silence.
('90', 414, 7, 21, 790086) Harijan, 26 5 1946
('90', 414, 8, 22, 790105) 1 Reproduced from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” 2 Badshah Khan’s theme was that the object of prayer was to purge ourselves of all dross and baseness.

('90', 415, 3, 4, 790350) MADRAS,
('90', 415, 4, 5, 790358) February 21, 1946
('90', 415, 5, 6, 790376) MY DEAR BAPU,
('90', 415, 6, 7, 790390) What you said about me publicly has, like the churning of the ocean, brought up all the poison, and you have to swallow it like Rudra!
('90', 415, 6, 8, 790525) I know you can.
('90', 415, 6, 9, 790541) But it has made my old longing for peace too strong to resist.
('90', 415, 6, 10, 790604) I haven’t the strength to stand it any longer.
('90', 415, 6, 11, 790651) I bore much all these days.
('90', 415, 6, 12, 790679) I struggled hard to work without minding the calumniators but I give it up now.
('90', 415, 6, 13, 790759) I have often asked myself the question : ‘Is it worth while?’ I feel it is not.
('90', 415, 6, 14, 790839) I must yield to the longing of my heart not to be misunderstood.
('90', 415, 6, 15, 790904) Why should I be thought to be seeking ‘power’ when it is not the case at all?
('90', 415, 6, 16, 790982) I must prove it, although the proof is one that leaves no good behind but the mere proof.
('90', 415, 6, 17, 791072) Now that the urgent job of selections for the legislature is all over, let me leave the scene.
('90', 415, 6, 18, 791167) For my place (the University seat) there is Sambamurti available.
('90', 415, 6, 19, 791233) He has not been given any seat nor did he apply.
('90', 415, 6, 20, 791282) The position he has occupied in Andhra’s public life for over a quarter of a century, the unrivalled manner in which he fulfilled his duties as Speaker and his drive and energy are well known, and it would be wrong to leave him out.
('90', 415, 6, 21, 791515) He can easily take my place in the nomination for the University.
('90', 415, 6, 22, 791581) I beg of you to approve of my action and pass it on at once to Sardar so that he may do the needful.
('90', 415, 6, 23, 791682) Nominations must be officially filed before 1st March.
('90', 415, 9, 24, 791737) I slept over this last night and am posting it this morning.

('90', 416, 1, 2, 791985) APPENDIX II
('90', 416, 2, 3, 791997) VALLABHBHAI PATEL’S MESSAGE TO FOREIGN PRESS 1
('90', 416, 3, 4, 792044) BOMBAY,
('90', 416, 4, 5, 792052) March 4, 1946 Being a witness to the recent happenings in Bombay, I can say, nothing like it has happened within this generation.
('90', 416, 4, 6, 792182) The destruction of property was wantonly thoughtless.
('90', 416, 4, 7, 792236) There is no doubt that what happened was a direct outcome of the lessons of the war that has only officially closed, and an echo of what is happening in the West.
('90', 416, 4, 8, 792399) The inequality which still seems to reign supreme and which it was hoped would die out, was galling for the Indian Ratings and resentment of distincion between Europeans and Indians made them impatient to the point of hurling what was bound to be a futile defiance on the part of an ill armed few against overwhelming odds fully armed.
('90', 416, 5, 9, 792735) The populace, whose sympathy has always been with the fighters against imperialism, readily joined hands and brushed aside the wise counsels of leaders who love liberty no less than they.
('90', 416, 6, 10, 792923) It was not without the greatest difficulty that I persuaded the Ratings to surrender unconditionally, giving them at the same time the assurance that whatever was just in their cause would be championed by the Congress, that so far as was humanly possible, full justice would be done and that there would be no victimization.
('90', 416, 6, 11, 793249) I am only hoping that the authorities will not hark back to old, worn out methods and senselessly insist on false prestige.
('90', 416, 7, 12, 793373) Those who seek to uphold imperialism and perpetuate inequalities can ill afford to talk of prestige, much less of vindicating it in the present awakening and consequent determined opposition of which the recent events were convincing evidence.
('90', 416, 8, 13, 793617) As a confirmed believer in the method of truth and non violence adopted by the Congress for the past quarter of a century, I deplored the destruction of property, incendiarism, stopping of locomotives and insult and injury to whitemen, but they must not be used so as to postpone the declaration of independence even by a day.
('90', 416, 9, 14, 793944) The national Congress will, of course, insist on the observance of truth and non violent ways by the people but insistence on these ways will lie in the mouths of those who have constantly denied both or either in their dealings especially with exploited peoples such as those of India.
('90', 416, 10, 15, 794231) We have been looking forward to the coming of the official Deputation and
('90', 416, 11, 16, 794305) 1Vide “Message to Foreign Press”, 5 3 1946
('90', 417, 0, 1, 794348) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 417, 1, 2, 794390) only hope that it is coming with the determined purpose of withdrawing British rule from all India and laying the foundations for a lasting friendship between Great Britain and India while there is yet a moment left.
('90', 417, 1, 3, 794607) Let not history record that it was too late.
('90', 417, 2, 4, 794652) The Bombay Chronicle, 5 3 1946
('90', 417, 3, 5, 794683) APPENDIX III SOUTH AFRICAN INDIAN DEPUTATION’S MEMORANDUM TO THE VICEROY 1
('90', 417, 4, 6, 794758) NEW DELHI,
('90', 417, 5, 7, 794769) March 12, 1946
('90', 417, 6, 8, 794784) MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY,
('90', 417, 7, 9, 794815) We, the undersigned, Sorabjee Rustomjee, Sooba Rama Naidoo, Azum shah Ahmed Mirza and Ahmed Sadek m.
('90', 417, 7, 10, 794916) kajee, delegates of the South African Indian Congress, duly appointed at its seventeenth session of the Conference held in Cape Town from the 8th to 13th February, 1946, together with members co opted, being South African Indians at present in India, under authority of the resolution of the Conference, respectfully beg to submit to you this statement on the proposed legislation, as announced by Field Marshal Smuts, in Union Parliament on 21st January, 1946, when he made known the intention of the Union Government to introduce legislation this session adversely affecting Indians in Natal and the Transvaal.
('90', 417, 7, 11, 795529) 2. We are deeply grateful to Your Excellency for receiving us at short notice in spite of your multifarious pre occupations.
('90', 417, 7, 12, 795654) 3. The present intention of the Government of the Union of South Africa will, if carried out, degrade us to a status of inferiority against which we have put up a fight more definitely since 1893, the year in which an attempt was made to disfranchise the Indian community as such in Natal.
('90', 417, 7, 13, 795944) We then looked upon it as a slur not only on the Indians in Natal but also on the Mother Country.
('90', 417, 7, 14, 796042) Then there was no Union of South Africa.
('90', 417, 7, 15, 796083) The Cape had practically no Indian question worth the name.
('90', 417, 7, 16, 796143) Orange Free State had banished the few Indian traders it had, and prided itself on its thorough anti Asiatic policy.
('90', 417, 7, 17, 796260) The Transvaal had a sprinkling of Indian traders, hawkers and others.
('90', 417, 7, 18, 796330) The “location” system, later known as segregation, had its rise there.
('90', 417, 7, 19, 796401) The whites in Natal had deliberately, and for their own sake, invited the large number of indentured Indians for their sugar and tea plantations and other industries.
('90', 417, 7, 20, 796568) In their wake followed the traders and others, and the Indian population today is therefore a composite one.
('90', 417, 7, 21, 796677) 4. One would have thought that the advent of Union would mean the union of
('90', 417, 8, 22, 796752) 1Vide “Draft Memorandum to Viceroy”, 8 3 1946 and “Statement to the Press”
('90', 418, 0, 1, 796827) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 419
('90', 418, 1, 2, 796871) all the races of South Africa, i.
('90', 418, 1, 3, 796905) e., the African (the Bantu), the European and the Asiatics (primarily and principally Indians).
('90', 418, 1, 4, 797001) What a noble tradition such a union would have been for the world!
('90', 418, 1, 5, 797068) But it was not to be.
('90', 418, 1, 6, 797090) On the contrary, the Union became an anti African and anti Asiatic combine.
('90', 418, 1, 7, 797166) Every year of the progress of the Union has definitely marked the progress of this combine, and the strenuous opposition to it by the Indian settlers and their descendants, as will be clearly seen by reference to the Appendix A hereto attached.
('90', 418, 1, 8, 797411) 5. We ask Your Excellency to approach the question from that standpoint and no other.
('90', 418, 1, 9, 797497) The threatened legislation adumbrated by Field Marshal Smuts, which has hastily brought the delegation from South Africa, is a very large step, perhaps the largest yet made, in the process of consigning the Asiatics to permanent inferiority.
('90', 418, 1, 10, 797739) The wedge has now extended into all round inequality and inferiority.
('90', 418, 1, 11, 797809) Thus there are zones of segregation, one of which the whites are reserving for themselves in order to force by legal compulsion the segregation of the other races.
('90', 418, 1, 12, 797973) God has made man “one great human family”.
('90', 418, 1, 13, 798016) The white races of South Africa would make of it three separate parts based on colour.
('90', 418, 2, 14, 798103) 6. Bad enough as the threatened land legislation is, the prospective franchise legislation is worse.
('90', 418, 2, 15, 798204) It is a mockery of franchise and a poignant reminder of the low status to be accorded to us—so low that we are not to be deemed even fit enough to choose one of our own as our representative.
('90', 418, 3, 16, 798396) 7. We have come all the way from South Africa not to seek protection of individual or property rights, dear as both are, but we have come definitely to ask Your Excellency and the people of the Mother Country to appreciate the fight for equality of status, which is theirs as much as ours, and to give us as much help as possible for you and them to give.
('90', 418, 3, 17, 798752) What is attempted to be done in South Africa is a denial of the brave declarations made by the British and even the Field Marshal himself.
('90', 418, 4, 18, 798891) 8. It has given us much pleasure to learn that the withdrawal of the British power in India in favour of elected Indian representatives is imminent.
('90', 418, 4, 19, 799040) Then may we ask whether it is not Your Excellency’s double and special duty to enunciate your stand in favour of equality and, so far as possible, enforce it in no uncertain terms?
('90', 418, 5, 20, 799221) 9. The announcement of the intention of the Union Government to introduce legislation so alarmed the Indian community that the South African Indian Congress at its Conference aforesaid resolved to send a deputation to Field Marshal Smuts.
('90', 418, 5, 21, 799460) This deputation made representations to him not to proceed with the intended legislation, and to convene a Round Table Conference of the Union Government and the Government of India in fulfilment of the recommendation of the Natal Indian Judicial Commission made in March 1945. This request was refused by him, whereupon the Conference, after deliberating at great length, adopted the following resolution :
('90', 419, 0, 1, 799868) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 419, 1, 2, 799910) CAPE TOWN,
('90', 419, 2, 3, 799921) February 12, 1946 This Conference of the South African Indian Congress, after having heard the report of the deputation that waited on the Prime Minister, expresses its grievous disappointment at his refusal to abandon the proposed legislation and to convene a Round Table Conference between India and South Africa.
('90', 419, 2, 4, 800237) This conference interprets this refusal as the very negation of the principle of solving human problems by negotiations and mutual discussions and as indicating a legislative design of repressing the community and settling its fate at the altar of political expediency and sacrificing it to appease extreme white reactionaries in this country.
('90', 419, 2, 5, 800581) The legislation dealing with land tenure and communal representation to be introduced by the Prime Minister, which is totally unacceptable, is an insult to the national honour and dignity of the Indian nation.
('90', 419, 2, 6, 800791) This Conference of the South African Indian Congress, having regard to the Prime Minister’s refusal, resolves to mobilize all the resources of the Indian people in this country in order to take every measure possible to secure the lapsing of the Pegging Act and to oppose the proposed legislation of the Government by :
('90', 419, 3, 7, 801111) 1. Sending a deputation to India :
('90', 419, 4, 8, 801146) (a) to urge the Government of India for convening of a Round Table Conference between the Governments of India and South Africa;
('90', 419, 5, 9, 801275) (b) failing which to request the Government of India (i) to withdraw the office of its High Commissioner in South Africa, (ii) to apply economic sanctions against South Africa;
('90', 419, 6, 10, 801452) (c) to carry out a campaign of propaganda in India to secure the fullest support of India’s millions;
('90', 419, 7, 11, 801554) (d) to invite Indian leaders to come to South Africa.
('90', 419, 8, 12, 801608) 2. Sending deputations to America, Britain and other parts of the world.
('90', 419, 9, 13, 801681) 3. Proceeding immediately to prepare the Indian people of South Africa for a concerted and prolonged resistance, the details of which this Conference instructs its Executive to prepare for submission and action to its constituent bodies.
('90', 419, 10, 14, 801919) 10. We would, therefore, ask Your Excellency to use your influence to secure the holding of a Round Table Conference between the two Governments to settle, in the words of the Natal Indian Judicial Commission, “all matters affecting Indians in South Africa”.
('90', 419, 10, 15, 802178) But should your efforts in this connection unhappily fail, then we ask, in terms of our resolution herein before embodied, to withdraw the office of the High
('90', 420, 0, 1, 802336) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 421
('90', 420, 1, 2, 802380) Commissioner for India in the Union of South Africa and to enforce economic and political sanctions.
('90', 420, 1, 3, 802481) We are not unaware that they may mean very little material loss to South Africa.
('90', 420, 1, 4, 802562) We know that counter measures will cause us hardship.
('90', 420, 1, 5, 802616) But our loss we would count as nothing compared to the moral value of the enforcement of the sanctions.
('90', 420, 2, 6, 802720) We have the honour to be,
('90', 420, 3, 7, 802746) Your Excellency’s obedient servants, SORABJEE RUSTOMJEE (LEADER) S. R. NAIDOO A. S. M. KAJEE A. A. MIRZA

('90', 420, 5, 10, 802936) APPENDIX IV LETTER FROM SECURITY PRISONERS 1
('90', 420, 6, 11, 802981) DUM DUM CENTRAL JAIL,
('90', 420, 7, 12, 803003) January 17, 1946
('90', 420, 8, 13, 803020) MAHATMAJI,
('90', 420, 9, 14, 803031) We offer you our allegiance—to you personally for your ideal and methods and to you as the leader of the nation.
('90', 420, 9, 15, 803144) We had liquidated the Jugantur Party and joined the Congress without any party reservation.
('90', 420, 10, 16, 803236) We started working honestly and sincerely; and our doubts and differences melted away particularly in view of the ever developing policy of the Congress during the War.
('90', 420, 10, 17, 803405) But we were arrested in May 1941. .
('90', 420, 10, 18, 803441) Just after our arrest we had some correspondence with you.
('90', 420, 10, 19, 803500) You then wrote : “I have no difficulty in accepting your limitations of non violence.
('90', 420, 10, 20, 803586) If worked honestly, it will automatically expand.” Now we can say, we have no difficulty in accepting your non violence—not only as the best means for achieving Indian revolution but also for saving the common man of the world as against the rising world Fascism based on naked violence.
('90', 420, 11, 21, 803874) We have been working in and with the Congress since 1921—of course retaining a second love sometimes dormant and sometimes dominant.
('90', 420, 11, 22, 804007) In 1938 we outgrew that and made the Congress our only vehicle for serving the cause of Indian independence.
('90', 420, 11, 23, 804116) Now we believe your method and programme is the only right way to be followed.
('90', 420, 12, 24, 804195) 1Vide “Letter to Sir Frederick Burrows”, 10 3 1946. Only extracts are reproduced here.
('90', 421, 0, 1, 804282) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 421, 1, 2, 804324) We hope, the moment of the psychological break away from the past world not be allowed to slip away and, under your inspiration and insistence, every effort would be directed to organizing the masses on the basis of your 18 point programme.
('90', 421, 2, 3, 804565) After our release we shall be working with the outlook stated above.
('90', 421, 2, 4, 804634) We shall try to stay with you for some time before we start work here.
('90', 421, 2, 5, 804705) In our future work we shall seek your guidance and help.
('90', 421, 3, 6, 804762) Before concluding we must say a few words regarding our detention.
('90', 421, 3, 7, 804829) The Government plea of terrorism is wholly false.
('90', 421, 3, 8, 804879) Even before our arrest, Sir Nazimuddin, then Home Minister, personally told us his police reports had confirmed his personal information that we were doing nothing but Congress work.
('90', 421, 3, 9, 805062) This was barely two months before our arrest.
('90', 421, 3, 10, 805108) In 1943, as Premier, he made almost the same statement in the Assembly.
('90', 421, 3, 11, 805180) This bogey of terrorism is simply a police trick—to serve a double purpose—to misrepresent us to the public and thus to create difficulties for work, and secondly to keep a broad hint that terrorist groups are still active so that guileless and sincere young men may be duped, and an atmosphere of terrorism kept up to serve imperialist purposes as against the Congress programme.
('90', 421, 3, 12, 805561) There has been no case of terrorism in Bengal since 1934, and it is simply insulting our intelligence as well as our patriotism to say that we are thinking—or for that matter any other political group is thinking— of terrorism at this hour of the day.
('90', 421, 4, 13, 805813) Yours sincerely, ARUN CHANDRA GUHA BHUPENDRA KUMAR DATTA

('90', 421, 7, 16, 805942) APPENDIX V CLEMENT ATTLEE’S SPEECH 1
('90', 421, 8, 17, 805979) March 15, 1946
('90', 421, 9, 18, 805994) I find from our friends in this House who had been out to India and returned, from letters received from Indians and from Englishmen in India of all points of view, complete agreement on the fact that India is today in a state of great tension and that this is indeed a critical moment.
('90', 421, 9, 19, 806281) At the present moment the idea of nationalism is running very fast in India past to the present position.
('90', 421, 9, 20, 806387) The temperature of 1946 is not the temperature of 1920, 1930 or even 1942. The slogans of earlier days are discarded.
('90', 421, 9, 21, 806505) Sometimes words that seemed at that time to Indians to express the height
('90', 421, 10, 22, 806579) 1Vide “Interview to United Press of India”, 16 3 1946 and “Interview to H. N. Brailsford”, 17 3 1946
('90', 422, 0, 1, 806680) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 423
('90', 422, 1, 2, 806724) of their aspirations are set on one side and other words and ideas thrust forward.
('90', 422, 2, 3, 806807) I would like today, therefore, not to stress so much the differences between the Indians, but let us all realize that .
('90', 422, 2, 4, 806927) there is this underlying demand among all the Indian people .
('90', 422, 2, 5, 806989) It is worth remembering .
('90', 422, 2, 6, 807015) a nation of 40,00,000 people that twice sent her sons to die for freedom .
('90', 422, 2, 7, 807090) should herself have freedom to decide her own destiny (cheers).
('90', 422, 3, 8, 807154) My colleagues are going to India with the intention of using their utmost endeavours to help her to attain that freedom as speedily and fully as possible.
('90', 422, 3, 9, 807309) What form of government is to replace the present regime is for India to decide, but our desire is to help her to set up forthwith a machinery for making that decision.
('90', 422, 4, 10, 807478) There you have met with the initial difficulty of getting that machinery set up but we are resolved that a machinery shall be set up, and we seek the utmost co operation of all Indian leaders to do so.
('90', 422, 5, 11, 807680) India herself must choose as to what will be her future situation and her position in the world.
('90', 422, 5, 12, 807777) Unity may come through the United Nations or through the Commonwealth but no great nation can stand alone by herself without sharing what is happening in the world.
('90', 422, 5, 13, 807942) I hope that India may elect to remain within the British Commonwealth.
('90', 422, 5, 14, 808013) I am certain that she will find great advantage in doing so, but if she does, she must do it of her own free will, for the British Commonwealth and Empire is not bound together by chains of external compulsion.
('90', 422, 5, 15, 808224) It is a free association of free people.
('90', 422, 6, 16, 808265) If, on the other hand, she elects for independence—and, in our view, she has a right to do so—it will be for us to help to make the transition as smooth and easy as possible.
('90', 422, 7, 17, 808440) We want to set up an Interim Government—one of the purposes of the Bill which has been discussed today—to give the Viceroy greater freedom in order that in the period which is to elapse while a Constitution is being worked out, you may have a government enjoying the greatest possible support in India.
('90', 422, 7, 18, 808743) I would not like to fetter the Viceroy’s decision in any way in regard to the choice of portfolios.
('90', 422, 8, 19, 808843) I am hoping that statesmen of Britain and of princely India will be able to work out a solution of the problem of bringing together the various constitutent parts.
('90', 422, 8, 20, 809007) I do not believe for a moment that the Indian princes would lag behind in the forward march of India.
('90', 422, 9, 21, 809109) I am very well aware of the minority problem in India.
('90', 422, 9, 22, 809164) I think all Indian leaders are realizing more and more that need for getting a settlement.
('90', 422, 9, 23, 809255) and I believe that due provision will be made for them in the Constitution.
('90', 422, 10, 24, 809331) With regard to the treaty, we are not going to hand out for anything for our own advantage which would be to the disavantage of India.
('90', 423, 0, 1, 809466) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 423, 1, 2, 809508) In the mass of Asia, an Asia ravaged by war, we have here the one country that has been seeking to apply the principles of democracy.
('90', 423, 1, 3, 809642) I have always felt myself that political India might be the light of Asia.
('90', 423, 1, 4, 809717) It is most unfortunate at the time when we have to deal with these great political issue .
('90', 423, 1, 5, 809808) we have very grave anxiety over India’s food supply.
('90', 423, 2, 6, 809861) Whatever we can do to assist, we shall do.
('90', 423, 2, 7, 809904) My colleagues are going out to India resolved to succeed, and I am sure everyone will wish them Godspeed.

('90', 424, 15, 17, 811862) APPENDIX VII CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION ON SOUTH AFRICA 1
('90', 424, 16, 18, 811931) The Working Committee of the Indian National Congress are of opinion that the disabilities of the Indian settlers in South Africa constitute a blot on humanity and a slur on the civilization of the West.
('90', 424, 16, 19, 812135) As the submission to His Excellency the Viceroy of the Indian deputation from South Africa shows, the disabilities are an unbroken tale of progressive prejudice against Asiatics defined as “any Turk and any member or a race or tribe whose national home is in Asia but which does not include any member of the Jewish or the Syrian race or a person belonging to the race or class known as the Cape Malay”, and of broken promises and declarations.
('90', 424, 16, 20, 812580) A civilization that requires for its protection a series of legal enactments imposing political and economic restrictions on Coloured and Asiatic peoples must contain seeds of future wars and its own destruction.
('90', 424, 17, 21, 812793) The Committee are of opinion that the contemplated breach of trade relations between India and the Union of South Africa is the mildest step that the Government of India could have taken.
('90', 424, 17, 22, 812981) The Committee would ask the Government of India forthwith to withdraw their High Commissioner, if the Union Government would not suspend the proposed legislation, pending the convening of a Round Table Conference between the two Governments to consider the whole policy of the Union Government against non white peoples of the earth.
('90', 424, 18, 23, 813315) The Committee are painfully surprised to find Field Marshal Smuts, the
('90', 424, 19, 24, 813386) 1Vide “Statement to the Press”
('90', 425, 0, 1, 813417) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 425, 1, 2, 813459) Premier of the Union, dismissing, on the untenable plea of regarding the proposed anti Asiatic Bill as a domestic affair, the right of the Indian Government and, by parity of reasoning, of the other Allied Powers of friendly intervention.
('90', 425, 1, 3, 813698) The Committee hold that at this time of the day it is not open to any State, however powerful it may be, to refuse to listen to the public opinion of the world as voiced through its different States with reference to any legislation regarded by them as of an inhuman character or as amounting to a slur on the self respect of the races comprising such a State.
('90', 425, 2, 4, 814059) The Committee venture to advise the victorious Allies to take notice of the contemplated action of the Government of South Africa inasmuch as the late war would have been fought in vain, if now the persistence by the Union Government of South Africa in the bar sinister against Asiatic races and Coloured people inhabiting that sub continent is maintained.
('90', 425, 2, 5, 814416) To the Indian Deputation from South Africa the Committee would say that whilst they (the Committee) and, indeed, the whole of India, irrespective of parties or communities, are with them in their just struggle and would lend them all the moral weight they can, they should realize that the brunt of the unequal struggle will have to be borne by them, and the Committee feel assured that the Indians in South Africa will worthily carry out the example set by them years ago of vindicating their self respect and that of the Motherland by the noble rule of self suffering.
('90', 425, 2, 6, 814987) The Committee would, however, fain hope, even at the eleventh hour, that in the place of the indefensible law of the jungle, which the policy as revealed by the contemplated legislation enunciates, the Government of the Union of South Africa and its white settlers would listen to reason and the appeal of the moral law by which mankind lives.
('90', 425, 3, 7, 815331) Harijan, 24 3 1946
('90', 425, 4, 8, 815350) APPENDIX VIII VICEROY’S NOTE ON INTERVIEW TO GANDHIJI 1
('90', 425, 5, 9, 815406) April 3, 1946
('90', 425, 6, 10, 815420) I thought the interview with Gandhi, naked except for a dhoti and looking remarkably healthy, was rather a deplorable affair.
('90', 425, 6, 11, 815546) The Secretary of State began with his usual sloppy benevolence to this malevolent old politician, who for all his sanctimonious talks has, I am sure, very little softness in his composition.
('90', 425, 6, 12, 815737) He began with the demand for the abolition of the salt tax, which he led up to by a lot of rather hypocritical sob stuff.
('90', 425, 6, 13, 815859) (In the five yeas I have been in the Government of India, I have never heard from anyone but Gandhi a suggestion that the salt tax was really oppressive, and it brings in nine crores; but Gandhi wants it be removed
('90', 425, 7, 14, 816074) 1Vide “Letter to Purshottamdas Thakurdas”, 23 3 1946
('90', 426, 0, 1, 816127) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 427
('90', 426, 1, 2, 816171) as a sop to his vanity, because he went to prison over it 15 years ago.) 1 He rambled on in his usual rather vague way, approaching the Pakistan issue, by the way of his drunken son who had become Muslim for a while in the hope that it would cure him of drink; spoke of his efforts to meet Jinnah by Rajagopalachari’s formula, and his Bombay talks; and finished with the meant to be plausible proposal that Jinnah should be asked to form a Ministry—the catch being that he would be subject to the Hindu majority in the Central Assembly (I had heard this idea put forward before).
('90', 426, 1, 3, 816751) As usual Gandhi refused to be pinned down to details.
('90', 426, 1, 4, 816805) The interview closed by a little speech of Secretary of State expressing ‘penitence’ for Britain’s misdeeds in the past !
('90', 426, 2, 5, 816927) Wavell—The Viceroy’s Journal, p.

('90', 426, 4, 7, 816972) NOTE ON INTERVIEW TO CABINET MISSION 2
('90', 426, 5, 8, 817011) Secret April 3, 1946, 4 p.m.
('90', 426, 6, 9, 817040) The Secretary of State said that what the Delegation would like best would be to have Mr. Gandhi’s advice as to what he would like to see happen, especially in regard to the position as regards the Muslim League.
('90', 426, 6, 10, 817253) Mr. Gandhi said that he would rather such a question should be put to the authorized representatives of the Congress.
('90', 426, 6, 11, 817371) He had come, in reply to the invitation sent to him, to help and not to hinder and what he was most anxious about was that there should be the right atmosphere.
('90', 426, 6, 12, 817532) He had asked in writing for certain action which would let the people feel that independence was coming.
('90', 426, 7, 13, 817637) The Cabinet Delegation would have a much greater measure of difficulty to contend with than any other mission to India.
('90', 426, 7, 14, 817757) If they meant business, he would advise them to take action which would produce a hearty friendship.
('90', 426, 7, 15, 817858) This could not be done without the release of the prisoners now in British custody.
('90', 426, 7, 16, 817942) The flowers of the Indian nation were in prison—whether they were violent or non violent did not matter, but if the Delegation was sincere, it was bound to release them.
('90', 426, 7, 17, 818112) Jayaprakash Narayan was one of India’s most learned men.
('90', 426, 7, 18, 818169) For the same reasons, the salt tax should be removed.
('90', 426, 7, 19, 818223) Salt should be free for the poor man.
('90', 426, 7, 20, 818261) The humanitarian clause introduced by Lord Halifax as a result of Mr. Gandhi’s movement in
('90', 426, 8, 21, 818352) 1 In the source, Penderel Moon explains : “The tax on salt, which dated back to long before the advent of the British Raj, was so light that no individual was conscious of it as a burden.
('90', 426, 8, 22, 818540) But its abolition was one of Gandhi’s fads, and he had made defiance of the Salt Laws and illegal manufacture of salt—its manufacture was a Government monopoly and the tax was included in the price at which it was sold to the public—the main feature of his Civil Disobedience Movement in 1930.” 2 Vide “ A Note”, 3 4 1946
('90', 427, 0, 1, 818862) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 427, 1, 2, 818904) 1930 had worked well in some places.
('90', 427, 1, 3, 818941) But whatever the legal difficulties were, the tax could be removed, and a message of independence be brought to every village in India.
('90', 427, 1, 4, 819077) He was very sorry, he had received a letter from Mr. Abell saying this could not be done.
('90', 427, 1, 5, 819167) It had been written, if he might say so, unthinkingly.
('90', 427, 1, 6, 819222) Much taxation had been introduced by the Viceroy for war purposes, and he could as easily remove this salt tax.
('90', 427, 2, 7, 819334) Mr. Gandhi said that he had passed 18 days with Mr. Jinnah.
('90', 427, 2, 8, 819394) He claimed to be a sincere friend of the Muslims, but had never been able to appreciate the Pakistan which Mr. Jinnah says he means.
('90', 427, 2, 9, 819527) Mr. Jinnah had never in concrete terms given a definition of Pakistan.
('90', 427, 2, 10, 819598) His Pakistan was a sin which he (Mr. Gandhi) would not commit.
('90', 427, 2, 11, 819661) The substance of Pakistan as he understood it was independence of culture and a legitimate ambition.
('90', 427, 2, 12, 819762) In Rajagopalachari’s Formula he (Mr. Gandhi) had given concrete shape to a proposal to meet this demand.
('90', 427, 2, 13, 819867) He differed from Rajagopalachari, but when the latter produced his Formula, he was on his last legs and said that he accepted it.
('90', 427, 3, 14, 819997) If this was what Mr. Jinnah meant, he accepted it and did so in writing.
('90', 427, 3, 15, 820070) Mr. Gandhi’s conception of Pakistan is there in concrete form.
('90', 427, 3, 16, 820133) If that were put into shape and all the snags removed, it was to form the basis for negotiations and, unless he was reasoned into it, he could not go further because beyond that Pakistan is an untruth.
('90', 427, 4, 17, 820335) The two nation theory is far more dangerous.
('90', 427, 4, 18, 820380) The Muslim population is a population of converts—only a microscopic minority are not.
('90', 427, 4, 19, 820467) They are all descendants of India born people.
('90', 427, 4, 20, 820514) Jinnah is sincere but his logic is utterly at fault especially as a kind of mania possesses him.
('90', 427, 4, 21, 820611) He himself was called a maniac and he, therefore, honoured Jinnah for his mania.
('90', 427, 4, 22, 820692) In 18 days Mr. Gandhij failed to be convinced of this two nation theory.
('90', 427, 4, 23, 820765) He asked Jinnah whether his own son who had gone over to the Muslim religion changed his nationality by doing so.
('90', 427, 4, 24, 820879) Mr. Gandhi’s Formula did not solve the difficulty unless we could get agreement.
('90', 427, 4, 25, 820960) But why should the Delegation worry ?
('90', 427, 4, 26, 820998) They must lie on the bed they had prepared and this situation is a legacy of British rule.
('90', 427, 4, 27, 821089) Wrong does not become right to give it another lease of life.
('90', 427, 4, 28, 821151) If you have undone the past, you must write on a clean slate and cannot have two nations or two Constitution making Bodies.
('90', 427, 4, 29, 821275) The difficulty would not be solved if the Muslim League refused to join the Constitution making Body.
('90', 427, 4, 30, 821377) After having exhausted all friendly resources, if you feel a stage must arrive when you feel you must say that there shall only be one Constitution making Body, you must take the risks of that.
('90', 427, 4, 31, 821571) There must be a considerable interim period.
('90', 427, 4, 32, 821616) What is to happen in the period and what is to happen to your promise?
('90', 427, 4, 33, 821687) Let Mr. Jinnah form the first Government and choose its personnel from elected representatives in the country.

('90', 428, 1, 4, 822049) The food situation is most serious, and you will not be able to deal with this famine without producing a psychological effect on the people.
('90', 428, 1, 5, 822191) The best administrative organization will not help without this.
('90', 428, 2, 6, 822256) Mr. Gandhi said, in reply to questions, that there were two formulae of his, one by Mr. Rajagolapalchari and the other in his correspondence with Mr. Jinnah which had been published.
('90', 428, 2, 7, 822439) The Interim Government must be absolutely national.

('90', 428, 2, 15, 823273) They would then be responsible to the Central Legislature.

('90', 428, 5, 21, 823770) APPENDIX X VICEROY’S NOTE ON INTERVIEW TO GANDHIJI 1
('90', 428, 6, 22, 823823) Tuesday, April 9, 1946 In the afternoon, Gandhi came to see me about the salt tax.
('90', 428, 6, 23, 823906) He professed to be coming purely as a friend of Britain, so that the British would get the credit of removing this unjust tax before the National Government came into power and did so.
('90', 428, 6, 24, 824091) The old humbug, I wonder whether he suspects that a National Government would do nothing of the sort and that the British are easier to bounce.
('90', 428, 6, 25, 824235) I refused, naturally, to commit myself in any way, and merely said, I would look into the matter.
('90', 428, 6, 26, 824333) (He had sent Amrit Kaur to see Q. and try to influence her in helping bounce me.) He then asked for the release of Jayaprakash Narayan, whose wife is apparently one of his followers (‘adopted daughter’, he called her).

('90', 429, 0, 1, 824595) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 429, 1, 2, 824637) I did not commit myself, though I expect we shall have to release him shortly.
('90', 429, 1, 3, 824716) Gandhi then started on the I.N..A. and I told him exactly what the I.N.A. were— the weaklings and cowards of those captured in Malaya—and what folly it had been for Congress to make heroes of such men and to neglect those who had remained true in spite of starvation, ill treatment and torture.
('90', 429, 1, 4, 825011) When we parted, I gave him a warning that the threat of mass movement by Congress was a dangerous weapon, there were still a great many thousand British soldiers in India who did not subscribe to his doctrine of non violence, and might be very violent, if British lives or property suffered.
('90', 429, 1, 5, 825303) He took this with a grin, and was very friendly throughout.

('90', 429, 2, 7, 825397) 241 2 APPENDIX XI LETTER FROM G. RAMACHANDRA RAO 1
('90', 429, 3, 8, 825448) I and my co workers have been trying this method of residing and eating with the Harijans for the last five or six years.
('90', 429, 3, 9, 825570) Our experience proves that it is an efficient method to remove the social isolation of the untouchables.
('90', 429, 3, 10, 825675) But our work is spreading slowly.
('90', 429, 3, 11, 825709) If a man like Bapuji took it up, as he did at Bombay, it is bound to gain wide publicity and attract more workers to the method.
('90', 429, 4, 12, 825838) In this connection, another suggestion might be considered.
('90', 429, 4, 13, 825898) Side by side with the mixing up, an attempt also might be made to discourage the use of labels of caste and creed which raise imaginary barriers between man and man.
('90', 429, 4, 14, 826064) Not only should the practice of untouchability go, but the Harijan should not be allowed to continue a Harijan; he should be united with the general stream of humanity.
('90', 429, 4, 15, 826233) Similarly the Hindu and Muslim differences might be solved by discarding the labels.
('90', 429, 4, 16, 826318) Such an attempt will no longer keep the form of communal harmony, but it would lead to the growth of one humanity.
('90', 429, 4, 17, 826433) Communal harmony presupposes the existence of communities.
('90', 429, 4, 18, 826492) In one humanity no communities exist.
('90', 429, 4, 19, 826530) Though a powerful personality like Gandhiji might harmonize communities for a while, when the personal influence weakened, the communities would clash again.
('90', 429, 4, 20, 826688) So a permanent solution of communal differences is the growth of one humanity outlook rather than communal harmony.
('90', 429, 5, 21, 826804) The growth of one humanity requires the rejection of communal labels.
('90', 429, 5, 22, 826874) Perhaps even the rejection of the labels of religion would involve a change of the belief in god, for every denominational label is associated with faith in a particular form of god.
('90', 429, 5, 23, 827057) But, though every religion talked only of one god, in practice, however, belief in god always deteriorated into sectarianism and fanaticism because god is a falsehood.
('90', 429, 5, 24, 827225) So atheism is the most suitable attitude for the establishment of one humanity.
('90', 429, 6, 25, 827305) 1Vide “Letter to G. Ramchandra Rao”, 9 4 1946
('90', 430, 0, 1, 827351) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 431
('90', 430, 1, 2, 827395) In order to set up happy human relations, communal harmony is the utmost limit to which the theistic mind can be stretched inasmuch as belief in god has to be somehow preserved.
('90', 430, 1, 3, 827573) But communal harmony is beset with definite drawbacks; so the desirability of atheism as the best means to establish one humanity and thereby to lay strong foundations for permanent peace in human relations might be considered.
('90', 430, 2, 4, 827801) An Atheist with Gandhi, pp.
('90', 430, 3, 5, 827829) APPENDIX XII WOODROW WYATT’S NOTE ON DISCUSSION WITH GANDHIJI 1
('90', 430, 4, 6, 827893) 1. He thinks that the Cabinet Mission has come with the intention of getting off India’s back.
('90', 430, 4, 7, 827988) Their function here is to devise a means of doing it gently.
('90', 430, 4, 8, 828049) He agreed that it should also be their function to precipitate a situation in which Indians must decide the future structure of India themselves.
('90', 430, 5, 9, 828195) 2. It would be wrong, if the three Cabinet Ministers were to imagine that they could arrive at a just and fair solution of India’s problems.
('90', 430, 5, 10, 828336) They cannot, and it is not their affair.
('90', 430, 6, 11, 828377) 3. If the British were to make a decision, and impose it, it would be overturned as soon as they had gone.
('90', 430, 7, 12, 828484) 4. Pakistan is a British creation.
('90', 430, 7, 13, 828519) (Incidentally, so is the famine.) He agreed that it would be much better for Congress to concede Pakistan than for the British.
('90', 430, 7, 14, 828647) If Congress conceded it, it would be something much more glorious.
('90', 430, 7, 15, 828714) 5. He thinks there may well have to be a blood bath in India before her problems are solved.
('90', 430, 7, 16, 828807) He would urge non violence on Congress but does not expect them to observe it.
('90', 430, 7, 17, 828886) The only thing he expects from Congress in the event of civil war is that they will fight decently and take one tooth for one tooth, and not a hundred teeth for one tooth as the British do.
('90', 430, 7, 18, 829076) 6. The Interim Government should be formed on the basis of the Central Legislature; members of the Central Legislature should nominate the members of the Executive Council.
('90', 430, 7, 19, 829249) Nominated members of the official block must be left out of the picture.
('90', 430, 7, 20, 829322) If the Central Legislature nominated people who were not members of the Central Legislature, then seats would have to be found for them in the Central Legislature.
('90', 430, 7, 21, 829486) 7. He would urge on Congress that they should offer seats on the Executive Council to the Muslim League., 8. If the British do not wish to accept the nominations of Congress, then they should accept the nominations of the Muslim League.
('90', 430, 7, 22, 829723) He would then tell Congress that they must play fair with the Muslim League.

('90', 431, 1, 2, 829891) 9. He agrees that it might well be unfair for the British to form an Interim Government and not give it its support.
('90', 431, 1, 3, 830008) They should certainly advise it in any case.
('90', 431, 2, 4, 830053) 10. He thinks it would be reasonable to announce that after a certain date there will be no British support for the Interim Government so forcing the Interim Government to solve India’s internal problems before that date.

('90', 431, 4, 6, 830312) APPENDIX XIII
('90', 431, 5, 7, 830326) WINSTON CHURCHILL’S SPEECH 1
('90', 431, 6, 8, 830355) The world is very ill.
('90', 431, 6, 9, 830378) This is the time when hatred is rife in the world and when many mighty branches of the human family, victors or vanquished, innocent or guilty, are plunged in bewilderment, distress or ruin.
('90', 431, 6, 10, 830569) Two fearful wars in our lifetime have torn the heart out of its grace and culture.
('90', 431, 7, 11, 830652) Measureless injury has been done to much that the 19th century would have called ‘Christian civilization’, for all the leading nations have been racked by stresses which have blunted their sensibilities and have destroyed their agreeable modes of social intercourse.
('90', 431, 8, 12, 830919) Only science has rolled forward, whipped by the fierce winds of mortal war, and science has placed in the hands of men agencies of destruction far beyond any development of their commonsense or virtue.
('90', 431, 9, 13, 831121) In a world where over production of food was formerly from time to time a problem, famine has laid its gaunt fingers upon the peoples of many lands and scarcity upon all.
('90', 431, 10, 14, 831292) The psychic energies of mankind have been exhausted by the tribulations through which they have passed and are still passing.
('90', 431, 10, 15, 831418) It is not only bloodletting that has weakened and whitened us.
('90', 431, 11, 16, 831481) The vital springs of human inspiration are, for the moment, drained.
('90', 431, 11, 17, 831550) There must be a period of recovery.
('90', 431, 11, 18, 831586) Mankind cannot, in its present plight bear new shocks and quarrels without taking to altogether cruder and primordial forms.
('90', 431, 12, 19, 831711) Yet we do not know that the hatred and confusion which are found will not confront us with even harder trial than those we have so narrowly and painfully survived.
('90', 431, 13, 20, 831875) In many countries, where even united efforts would fall short of what is needed, party strife and faction is fomented or machine made and skeleton fanatics rave at each other about their rival ideologies.
('90', 431, 14, 21, 832080) All the while, the ordinary folk of every country show themselves kindly and
('90', 431, 15, 22, 832157) 1Vide “Independence”
('90', 432, 0, 1, 832178) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 433
('90', 432, 1, 2, 832222) brave and serviceable to their fellow men.
('90', 432, 1, 3, 832265) Yet, they are driven against one another by forces and organizations and doctrines as wantonly and remorselessly as they ever were in the ages of absolute emperors and kings.
('90', 432, 2, 4, 832440) There never was a time when breathing space was more needed, a blessed convalescence, a truce of God and man.
('90', 432, 3, 5, 832550) Harijan, 5 5 1946 APPENDIX XIV
('90', 432, 4, 6, 832581) SUGGESTED POINTS FOR AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE CONGRESS AND THE MUSLIM LEAGUE 1
('90', 432, 5, 7, 832657) 1. There shall be an All India Union Government and Legislature dealing with Foreign Affairs, Defence, Communications, Fundamental Rights and having the necessary powers to obtain for itself the finances it requires for these subjects.
('90', 432, 6, 8, 832893) 2. All the remaining powers shall vest in the provinces.
('90', 432, 7, 9, 832950) 3. Groups of provinces may be formed and such Groups may determine the provincial subjects which they desire to take in common.
('90', 432, 8, 10, 833078) 4. The Groups may set up their own Executives and Legislatures.
('90', 432, 9, 11, 833142) 5. The Legislature of the Union shall be composed of equal proportions from the Muslim majority provinces and from the Hindu majority provinces whether or not these or any of them have formed themselves into Groups, together with representatives of the States.
('90', 432, 10, 12, 833403) 6. The Government of the Union shall be constituted in the same proportion as the Legislature.
('90', 432, 11, 13, 833498) 7. The constitutions of the Union and the Groups (if any) shall contain a provision whereby any province can by a majority vote of its Legislative Assembly call for a reconsideration of the terms of the constitution after an initial period of ten years and at ten yearly intervals thereafter.
('90', 432, 12, 14, 833791) For the purpose of such reconsideration a body shall be constituted on the same basis as the original Constituent Assembly and with the same provisions as to voting and shall have power to amend the constitution in any way decided upon.
('90', 432, 13, 15, 834028) 8. The constitution making machinery to arrive at a constitution on the above basis, shall be as follows :
('90', 432, 14, 16, 834135) A. Representatives shall be elected from each Provincial Assembly in proportion to the strength of the various parties in that Assembly on the basis of 1/10th of their numbers.
('90', 432, 15, 17, 834312) B. Representatives shall be invited from the States on the basis of their population in proportion to the representation from British India.
('90', 432, 16, 18, 834453) 1Vide “Letter to Sir Stafford Cripps”, 8 5 1946
('90', 433, 0, 1, 834501) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 433, 1, 2, 834543) C. The Constituent Assembly so formed shall meet at the earliest date possible in New Delhi.
('90', 433, 2, 3, 834636) D. After its preliminary meeting at which the general order of business will be settled, it will divide into three sections, one section representing the Hindu majority provinces, one section representing the Muslim majority provinces and one representing the States.
('90', 433, 3, 4, 834904) E. The first two sections will then meet separately to decide the provincial constitutions for their Groups and, if they wish, a Group constitution.
('90', 433, 4, 5, 835053) F. When these have settled it will be open to any province to decide to opt out of its original Group and go into the other Group or to remain outside any Group.
('90', 433, 5, 6, 835215) G. Thereafter the three bodies will meet together to settle the constitution for the union on the lines agreed in paragraphs 1 7 above.
('90', 433, 6, 7, 835351) H. No major point in the Union constitution which affects the communal issue shall be deemed to be passed by the Assembly unless a majority of both the two major communities vote in its favour.
('90', 433, 7, 8, 835545) 9. The Viceroy shall forthwith call together the above constitution making machinery which shall be governed by the provisions stated in paragraph 8 above.
('90', 433, 8, 9, 835701) The Transfer of Power 1942 47, Vol. VII, pp.

('90', 435, 4, 6, 839461) 159 60 APPENDIX XVII (B) PRESS NOTE
('90', 435, 5, 7, 839497) Complaints have been received by Government that rumours to the effect that the salt duty may be reduced or abolished have sown doubt and uncertainty in the minds of traders and manufacturers to such an extent as to discourage the purchase of salt, thereby hampering trade and slowing down manufacture and, in view of the present chronic transport difficulties and of the further difficulty of transporting this commodity during the wet months, entailing serious risk of a salt famine in upcountry areas.
('90', 435, 5, 8, 840002) To obiate these risks, Government desires to make clear that any change would only be made after a full and comprehensive investigation which would necessarily take considerable time, and that ample notice would be given in order to permit the disposal of duty paid stocks.

('90', 435, 9, 13, 840588) For some reason the Delegation wished him to be asked merely to see the Viceroy, and they would drop in later, which is all rather in a line with their methods of indirect approach.

('90', 435, 9, 15, 840839) He came at 7.30 p.
('90', 435, 9, 16, 840858) and I spoke a monologue for 15 minutes or so, telling him generally how things were going.
('90', 435, 9, 17, 840949) Then the Delegation came in, just as his silence was up, and the Secretary of State and Cripps started their explanations and blandishments.
('90', 435, 9, 18, 841090) The result was a shock to them.
('90', 435, 9, 19, 841122) Gandhi, who had been living with Ghaffar Khan and Patel, the two malcontents, had adopted entirely their point of view, said the proposed solution was “worse than Pakistan”, and he could not recommend it to Congress we must either adopt entirely the

('90', 437, 1, 2, 842724) APPENDIX XX
('90', 437, 2, 3, 842736) STATEMENT OF CABINET DELEGATION AND VICEROY 1
('90', 437, 3, 4, 842782) May 16, 1946
('90', 437, 4, 5, 842795) 1. On march 15th last just before the despatch of the Cabinet Delegation to India, Mr. Attlee, the British Prime Minister, used these words :
('90', 437, 5, 6, 842937) “My colleagues are going to India with the intention of using their utmost endeavours to help her to attain her freedom as speedily and fully as possible.
('90', 437, 5, 7, 843092) What form of Government is to replace the present regime is for India to decide; but our desire is to help her to set up forthwith the machinery for making that decision.
('90', 437, 5, 8, 843263) I hope that India and her people may elect to remain within the British Commonwealth.
('90', 437, 5, 9, 843349) I am certain that they will find great advantages in doing so.
('90', 437, 5, 10, 843412) But if she does so elect, it must be by her own free will.
('90', 437, 5, 11, 843471) The British Commonwealth and Empire is not bound together by chains of external compulsion.
('90', 437, 5, 12, 843563) It is a free association of free peoples.
('90', 437, 5, 13, 843605) If, on the other hand, she elects for independence, in our view she has a right to do so.
('90', 437, 5, 14, 843695) It will be for us to make the transition as smooth and easy as possible.”
('90', 437, 6, 15, 843769) 2. Charged in these historic words we—the Cabinet Ministers and the Viceroy—have done our utmost to assist the two main political parties to reach agreement upon the fundamental issue of the unity or division of India.
('90', 437, 6, 16, 843988) After prolonged discussions in New Delhi we succeeded in bringing the Congress and the Muslim League together in Conference at Simla.
('90', 437, 6, 17, 844122) There was a full exchange of views and both parties were prepared to make considerable concessions in order to try and reach a settlement but it ultimately proved impossible to close the remainder of the gap between the parties and so no agreement could be concluded.
('90', 437, 6, 18, 844390) Since no agreement has been reached we feel that it is our duty to put forward what we consider are the best arrangements possible to ensure a speedy setting up of the new Constitution.
('90', 437, 6, 19, 844576) This statement is made with the full approval of His Majesty’s Government in the United Kingdom.
('90', 437, 7, 20, 844673) 3. We have accordingly decided that immediate arrangements should be made whereby Indians may decide the future Constitution of India and an Interim Government may be set up at once to carry on the administra tion of British India until such time as a new Constitution can be brought into being.
('90', 437, 7, 21, 844969) We have endeavoured to be just to the smaller as well as to the larger sections of the people; and to recommend a solution which will lead to a practicable way of governing the India of the future, and will give a sound basis for defence and a good opportunity for progress in the social, political and economic field.
('90', 437, 7, 22, 845288) 4. It is not intended in this Statement to review the voluminous evidence
('90', 437, 8, 23, 845362) 1 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 16 5 1946
('90', 438, 0, 1, 845407) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 439
('90', 438, 1, 2, 845451) that has been submitted to the Mission; but it is right that we should state that it has shown an almost universal desire, outside the supporters of the Muslim League, for the unity of India.
('90', 438, 1, 3, 845643) 5. This consideration did not, however, deter us from examining closely and impartially the possibility of a partition of India; since we were greatly impressed by the very genuine and acute anxiety of the Muslims lest they should find themselves subjected to a perpetual Hindu majority rule.
('90', 438, 1, 4, 845936) This feeling has become so strong and widespread amongst the Muslims that it cannot be allayed by mere paper safeguards.
('90', 438, 1, 5, 846057) If there is to be internal peace in India it must be secured by measures which will assure to the Muslims a control in all matters vital to their culture, religion, and economic or other interests.
('90', 438, 1, 6, 846255) 6. We therefore examined in the first instance the question of a separate and fully independent sovereign State of Pakistan as claimed by the Muslim League.
('90', 438, 1, 7, 846412) Such a Pakistan would comprise two areas; one in the north west consisting of the Provinces of the Punjab, Sind, North West Frontier, and British Baluchistan; the other in the north east consisting of the Provinces of Bengal and Assam.
('90', 438, 1, 8, 846648) The League were prepared to consider adjustment of boundaries at a later stage, but insisted that the principle of Pakistan should first be acknowledged.
('90', 438, 1, 9, 846802) The argument for a separate State of Pakistan was based first, upon the right of the Muslim majority to decide their method of Government according to their wishes, and secondly, upon the necessity to include substantial areas in which Muslims are in a minority, in order to make Pakistan administratively and economically workable.
('90', 438, 1, 10, 847135) The size of the non Muslim minorities in a Pakistan comprising the whole of the six Provinces enumerated above would be very considerable as the following figures 1 show : NORTH WESTERN AREA Non Muslims Muslims Punjab 16,217,242 12,201,577 North West Frontier Proince 2,788,797 249,270 Sind 3,208,325 1,326,683 Br.
('90', 438, 1, 11, 847450) Baluchistan 438,930 62,701
('90', 438, 2, 12, 847477) –––––––––––––––––––––– –––––––––––––––––––––
('90', 438, 3, 13, 847522) 22,653,294 13,840,231
('90', 438, 4, 14, 847544) –––––––––––––––––––––– ––––––––––––––––––––– 62.07% 37.93%
('90', 438, 5, 15, 847603) 1The source carries the note : “All population figures in this Statement are from the most recent census taken in 1941.”
('90', 439, 0, 1, 847724) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 439, 1, 2, 847766) NORTH EASTERN AREA
('90', 439, 2, 3, 847785) Bengal 33,005,434 27,301,091
('90', 439, 3, 4, 847814) Assam 3,442,479 6,762,254
('90', 439, 4, 5, 847840) –––––––––––––––––––––– ––––––––––––––––––––––
('90', 439, 5, 6, 847886) 36,447,913 34,063,345
('90', 439, 6, 7, 847908) –––––––––––––––––––––– –––––––––––––––––––––
('90', 439, 7, 8, 847953) 51.69% 48.31%
('90', 439, 8, 9, 847967) The Muslim minorities in the remainder of British India number some 20 million dispersed amongst a total population of 188 million.
('90', 439, 9, 10, 848099) These figures show that the setting up of a separate sovereign State of Pakistan on the lines claimed by the Muslim League, would not solve the communal minority problem; nor can we see any justification for including within a sovereign Pakistan those districts of the Punjab and of Bengal and Assam in which the population is predominantly non Muslim.
('90', 439, 9, 11, 848452) Every argument that can be used in favour of Pakistan, can equally in our view be used in favour of the exclusion of the non Muslim areas from Pakistan.
('90', 439, 9, 12, 848605) This point would particularly affect the position of the Sikhs.
('90', 439, 9, 13, 848669) 7. We therefore considered whether a smaller sovereign Pakistan confined to the Muslim majority areas alone might be a possible basis of compromise.
('90', 439, 9, 14, 848818) Such a Pakistan is regarded by the Muslim League as quite impracticable because it would entail the exclusion from Pakistan of (a) the whole of the Ambala and Jullundur Division in the Punjab; (b) the whole of Assam except the District of Sylhet; and (c) a large part of Western Bengal, including Calcutta, in which city the Muslims form 23.6 per cent of the population.
('90', 439, 9, 15, 849189) We ourselves are also convinced that any solution which involves a radical partition of the Punjab and Bengal, as this would do, would be contrary to the wishes interests of a very large proportion of the inhabitants of these Provinces.
('90', 439, 9, 16, 849426) Bengal and the Punjab each has its own common language and a long history and tradition.
('90', 439, 9, 17, 849515) Moreover, any division of the Punjab would of necessity divide the Sikhs leaving substantial bodies of Sikhs on both sides of the boundary.
('90', 439, 9, 18, 849655) We have therefore been forced to the conclusion that neither a larger nor a smaller sovereign State of Pakistan would provide an acceptable solution for the communal problem.
('90', 439, 9, 19, 849830) 8. Apart from the great force of the foregoing arguments there are weighty administrative, economic and military considerations.
('90', 439, 9, 20, 849959) The whole of the transportation and postal and telegraph systems of India have been established on the basis of a united India.
('90', 439, 9, 21, 850087) To disintegrate them would gravely injure both parts of India.
('90', 439, 9, 22, 850150) The case for a united defence is even stronger.
('90', 439, 9, 23, 850198) The Indian armed forces have been built up as a whole for the defence of India as a whole, and to break them in two would inflict a deadly blow on the long traditions and high degree of efficiency of the Indian
('90', 440, 0, 1, 850409) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 441
('90', 440, 1, 2, 850453) Army and would entail the gravest dangers.
('90', 440, 1, 3, 850496) The Indian Navy and Indian Air Force would become much less effective.
('90', 440, 1, 4, 850567) The two sections of the suggested Pakistan contain the two most vulnerable frontiers in India and for a successful defence in depth the area of Pakistan would be insufficient.
('90', 440, 1, 5, 850743) 9. A further consideration of importance is the greater difficulty which the Indian States would find in associating themselves with divided British India.
('90', 440, 1, 6, 850899) 10. Finally there is the geographical fact that the two halves of the proposed Pakistan State are separated by some seven hundred miles and the communications between them both in war and peace would be dependent on the goodwill of Hindustan.
('90', 440, 1, 7, 851142) 11. We are therefore unable to advise the British Government that the power which at present resides in British hands should be handed over to two entirely separate sovereign States.
('90', 440, 1, 8, 851325) 12. This decision does not however blind us to the very real Muslim apprehensions that their culture and political and social life might become submerged in a purely unitary India, in which the Hindus with their greatly superior numbers must be a dominating element.
('90', 440, 1, 9, 851592) To meet this the Congress have put forward a scheme under which Provinces would have full autonomy subject only to a minimum of Central subjects, such as Foreign Affairs, Defence and Communications.
('90', 440, 1, 10, 851791) Under this scheme Provinces, if they wished to take part in economic and administrative planning on a large scale, could cede to the Centre optional subjects in addition to the compulsory ones mentioned above.
('90', 440, 1, 11, 852001) 13. Such a scheme would, in our view, present considerable constitutional disadvantages and anomalies.
('90', 440, 1, 12, 852104) It would be very difficult to work a Central Executive and Legislature in which some Ministers, who dealt with Compulsory subjects, were responsible to the whole of India while other Ministers, who dealt with optional subjects, would be responsible only to those Provinces which had elected to act together in respect of such subjects.
('90', 440, 1, 13, 852440) This difficulty would be accentuated in the Central Legislature, where it would be necessary to exclude certain members from speaking and voting when subjects with which their Provinces were not concerned were under discussion.
('90', 440, 1, 14, 852668) Apart from the difficulty of working such a scheme, we do not consider that it would be fair to deny to other Provinces, which did not desire to take the optional subject at the Centre, the right to form themselves into a group for a similar purpose.
('90', 440, 1, 15, 852919) This would indeed be no more than the exercise of their autonomous powers in a particular way.
('90', 440, 1, 16, 853014) 14. Before putting forward our recommendations we turn to deal with the relationship of the Indian States to British India.
('90', 440, 1, 17, 853138) It is quite clear that with the attainment of independence by British India, whether inside or out side the British Commonwealth, the relationship which has hitherto existed
('90', 441, 0, 1, 853312) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 441, 1, 2, 853354) between the Rulers of the States and the British Crown will no longer be possible.
('90', 441, 1, 3, 853437) Paramountcy can neither be retained by the British Crown nor transferred to the new Government.
('90', 441, 1, 4, 853533) This fact has been fully recognised by those whom we interviewed from the States.
('90', 441, 1, 5, 853615) They have at the same time assured us that the States are ready and willing to co operate in the new development of India.
('90', 441, 1, 6, 853738) The precise form which their co operation will take must be a matter for negotiation during the building up of the new constitutional structure, and it by no means follows that it will be indentical for all the States.
('90', 441, 1, 7, 853957) We have not therefore dealt with the States in the same detail as the Provinces of the British India in the paragraphs which follow.
('90', 441, 1, 8, 854090) 15. We now indicate the nature of a solution which in our view would be just to the essential claims of all parties, and would at the same time be most likely to bring about a stable and practicable form of constitution for all India.
('90', 441, 1, 9, 854325) We recommend that the constitution should take the following basic form : (1) There should be a Union of India, embracing both British India and the States, which should deal with the following subjects : Foreign Affairs, Defence, and Communications; and which should have the powers necessary to raise the finances required for the above subjects.
('90', 441, 1, 10, 854674) (2) The Union should have an Executive and a Legislature constituted from British Indian and States’ representatives.
('90', 441, 1, 11, 854792) Any question raising a major communal issue in the Legislature should require for its decision a majority of the representatives present and voting of each of the two major communities as well as a majority of all the members present and voting.
('90', 441, 1, 12, 855038) (3) All subjects other than the Union subjects and all residuary powers should vest in the Provinces.
('90', 441, 1, 13, 855140) (4) The States will retain all subjects and powers other than those ceded to the Union.
('90', 441, 1, 14, 855228) (5) Provinces should be free to form Groups with executives and legislatures, and each Group could determine the Provincial subjects to be taken in common.
('90', 441, 1, 15, 855384) (6) The Constitution of the Union and of the Groups should contain a provision whereby any Province could, by a majority vote of its Legislative Assembly, call for a reconsideration of the terms of the constitution after an initial period of 10 years and at 10 yearly intervals thereafter.
('90', 441, 1, 16, 855674) 16. It is not our object to lay out the details of a constitution on the above lines, but to set in motion the machinery whereby a constitution can be settled by Indians for Indians.
('90', 441, 1, 17, 855857) It has been necessary however for us to make this recommendation as to the
('90', 442, 0, 1, 855932) VOL. 90: 25 FEBRUARY, 1946 19 MAY, 1946 443
('90', 442, 1, 2, 855976) broad basis of the future constitution because it becomes clear to us in the course of our negotiations that not until that has been done was there any hope of getting the two major communities to join in the setting up of the constitution making machinery.
('90', 442, 2, 3, 856234) 17. We now indicate the constitution making machinery which we propose should be brought into being forthwith in order to enable a new Constitution to be worked out.
('90', 442, 2, 4, 856400) 18. In forming any Assembly to decide a new Constitutional structure the first problem is to obtain as broad based and accurate a representation of the whole population as is possible.
('90', 442, 2, 5, 856585) The most satisfactory method obviously would be by election based on adult franchise; but any attempt to introduce such a step now would lead to a wholly unacceptable delay in the formulation of the new Constitution.
('90', 442, 2, 6, 856802) The only practicable alternative is to utilize the recently elected Provincial Legislative Assemblies as the electing bodies.
('90', 442, 2, 7, 856928) There are, however, two factors in their composition which make this difficult.
('90', 442, 2, 8, 857008) First, the numerical strength of the Provincial Legislative Assemblies do not bear the same proportion to the total population in each Province.
('90', 442, 2, 9, 857153) Thus, Assam with a population of 10 millions has a Legislative Assembly of 108 members, while Bengal, with a population six times as large has an Assembly of only 250. Secondly, owing to the weightage given to minorities by the Communal Award, the strengths of the several communities in each Provincial Legislative Assembly are not in proportion to their numbers in the Province.
('90', 442, 2, 10, 857534) Thus the number of the seats reserved for Muslims in the Bengal Legislative Assembly is only 48 per cent of the total, although they form 55 per cent of the Provincial population.
('90', 442, 2, 11, 857714) After a most careful consideration of the various methods by which these inequalities might be corrected, we have come to the conclusion that the fairest and the most practicable plan would be— (a) to allot to each Province a total number of seats proportional to its population, roughly in the ratio of one to a million, as the nearest substitute for representation by adult suffrage.
('90', 442, 2, 12, 858100) (b) to divide this provincial allocation of seats between the main communities in each Province in proportion to their population.
('90', 442, 2, 13, 858231) (c) to provide that the representatives allotted to each community in a Province shall be elected by the members of that community in its Legislative Assembly.
('90', 442, 2, 14, 858391) We think that for these purposes it is sufficient to recognize only three main communities in India; General, Muslim, and Sikh, the “General” community including all persons who are not Muslims or Sikhs.
('90', 442, 2, 15, 858595) As the smaller minorities would, upon the population basis, have little or no representation, since they would lose the weightage which assures them seats in the Provincial Legislatures, we have made the arrangements set out in paragraph 20 below to give them a full
('90', 443, 0, 1, 858862) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('90', 443, 1, 2, 858904) representation upon all matters of special interest to the minorities.
('90', 443, 1, 3, 858975) (19) (i) We therefore propose that there shall be elected by each Pro vincial Legislative Assembly the following numbers of representatives, each part of the Legislative (General, Muslim or Sikh) electing its own representatives by the method of proportional representation with the single transferable vote :— TABLE OF REPRESENTATION SECTION A
